PUB-DATE: September 22, 1998

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 4336 words

HEADLINE: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT;
Suspicion and Resentment in Letters From Lawyers

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from documents released today by the House that show a thinly veiled animosity between the lawyers for the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, and President Clinton over testimony by Mr. Clinton and his aides. They clashed over executive privilege, leaks to reporters, the White House willingness to provide information, the President's schedule and the independent counsel's tactics and the request by his office for a blood sample from the President for DNA testing. 

FEB. 2, 1998
Seeking President's Testimony
 
From Robert J. Bittman, deputy counsel to Mr. Starr, to David E. Kendall, President Clinton's lawyer:
 
David:
As you know, President Clinton has publicly pledged to cooperate fully with the investigation involving Monica Lewinsky. Last Wednesday, January 28, I invited President Clinton, on behalf or the grand jury, to testify before the grand jury this Thursday, February 5, concerning matters relating to Ms. Lewinsky. You indicated in our conversation that you would get back to me as to whether the President will so testify. The grand jury awaits the President's decision; please advise me as soon as possible what the President decides.
Sincerely,
ROBERT J. BITTMAN
 
FEB. 4
Still Waiting for Testimony
 
From Mr. Bittman to Mr. Kendall:
 
David:
Although the President has declined the invitation to testify before the grand jury tomorrow, the grand jury's investigation continues apace. On behalf of the grand jury and in an effort to accommodate the President's schedule, we respectfully invite the President to testify before the grand jury next Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday, February 10 to 12.
Sincerely,
ROBERT J. BITTMAN
 
FEB. 5
On Press Leaks
 
From Charles F. C. Ruff, lawyer to the President, to Mr. Starr:
 
Mr. Starr,
This is in response to your letter of February 4, 1998.
First, I want to inform you that within 45 minutes of its delivery, James Bennet of The New York Times called the White House Press Office to ask whether I had received a letter from you concerning executive privilege. Since there could have been only a few persons on your staff who were aware of the letter's delivery, I ask that you immediately request that the F.B.I., using agents not affiliated with your office, investigate to determine who disclosed the existence of the letter and its substance (as well as, presumably, the fact and substance of our meeting) to the press. I and the three members of my staff who were aware of the letter before Bennet's call will be happy to be interviewed (under oath) in connection with any such investigation.
Let me move now to the substance of your letter. As you will not be surprised to learn, I disagree with your position on the applicability of executive privilege to discussions among senior White House staff and between senior staff and the President concerning the Lewinsky matter. . . .
Let me also clarify three points I made in our meeting. First, discussions among and between the President's senior staff involve the very capacity of the President and his staff to govern -- to pursue his legislative agenda, to ensure the continued leadership of the United States in the world community, and to maintain the confidence and support of the people who elected him -- all of which lie at the heart of his role under Article II of the Constitution. Second, as to what position the President himself might take on the assertion of executive privilege as to his communications if he were to be questioned, I did not purport to take any position -- "firm" or otherwise. And third, I indicated that, in deciding whether to assert privilege, we have historically sought to distinguish the substance of advisory and deliberative discussions from segregable facts, not available elsewhere, that may be contained in otherwise privileged communications.
Finally, I remain willing to explore all avenues for resolving our disagreement, although I admit to being more than a little uncertain as to how to conduct discussions without reading about them simultaneously in the press.
Sincerely,
CHARLES F. C. RUFF
 
FEB. 9
The Waiting Continues
 
From Mr. Bittman to Mr. Kendall:
 
David:
Last Wednesday, we, on behalf of the grand jury, extended a second invitation to the President to testify before the grand jury about his relationship with Monica Lewinsky. You did not respond to the invitation by last Friday, as requested in my letter. The grand jury's work continues. Notwithstanding your failure to respond, the grand jury would be pleased to accommodate the President's testimony any day or time this week.
Let me make our request specific and clear: the grand jury deserves to know whether the President will respond, favorably, to the invitation. Such an invitation is, of course, fully consistent with our profound respect for the Presidency in our system of separated powers. . . .
Sincerely
ROBERT J. BITTMAN
 
FEB. 13
Invitation Declined
 
From Mr. Kendall to Mr. Bittman:
 
Dear Bob:
This will respond to your letters dated February 4 and 9, 1998. I was unable to respond to your February 4 invitation by the Friday deadline you had indicated in your letter because I was in the process of dealing with prejudicial and false leaks of information about your investigation. . . . These leaks are highly unfair and prejudicial to the President and others, and, as you may know, on Monday I filed a sealed motion with the Chief Judge seeking judicial remedies in an effort to enforce the secrecy and confidentiality of the investigative process.
I acknowledge your invitation for the President to appear before the grand jury next week. The President has the greatest respect for the grand jury. However, under the circumstances, it is impossible to accept this invitation. The situation in Iraq continues to be dangerously volatile, and this has demanded much of the President's time and attention. The President also has a heavy travel schedule at present. Our access to him has necessarily been limited. Moreover, as I informed you during our February 3 telephone conversation concerning this matter, we have simply had inadequate opportunity to prepare so that we may give our client the informed advice of counsel which he, like every other citizen, deserves. Your recent letter references your office's "profound respect for the Presidency in our system of separated powers." However, I am certain that you understand why, in light of the well-publicized and questionable investigative techniques of your office, we feel we would be derelict in our professional duty to a client unless we assured ourselves that we had adequate opportunity to advise that client appropriately.
In the event you decide to "inform the grand jury of this turn of events", as stated in your letter, I would respectfully request that you also read my letter to the grand jury and make my letter part of the grand jury record.
I thank you for your courtesy.
Sincerely,
DAVID E. KENDALL
 
FEB. 17
On Possible Jones Contacts
 
From Mr. Kendall to Mr. Starr, complaining of improper contacts with lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones:
 
Dear Judge Starr:
I write with an inquiry in the wake of a Chicago Tribune article which appeared on February 11 (copy enclosed), and I am making this request in an effort to obtain accurate information so that I may decide how to proceed. The article reports that one of your partners in Kirkland & Ellis, Mr. Richard Porter, may have provided legal advice and services to plaintiff Paula Corbin Jones in her civil suit against President Clinton. The article also reports that someone at the law firm faxed a copy of a draft affidavit in the Jones case to the Tribune prior to the affidavit's filing in court, an action which would, if true suggest that the firm has indeed been involved in the legal prosecution of the Jones case. Finally, the article reports that one of the Jones lawyers Joseph Cammarata received advice from Mr. Porter on several occasions about legal issues in the Jones case. . . .
Additionally, there have been reports of your own participation in legal discussions with Ms. Jones' lawyers, prior to the time you were appointed Independent Counsel.
I hope you can therefore perceive why I am requesting accurate and specific information (i) concerning your own, Mr. Porter's and any other Kirkland & Ellis lawyer's, employees or agent's contacts with and assistance to Ms. Paula Corbin Jones and/or her attorneys or agents or supporting groups, and (ii) concerning what was conveyed to the Attorney General and the Special Division in January, 1998, about any such contacts and assistance, when you sought an expansion of your jurisdiction to encompass the Jones v. Clinton case.
I thank you for your courtesy.
Sincerely,
DAVID T. KENDALL
 
MARCH 4
Too Busy To Testify
 
From Mr. Kendall to Mr. Bittman, responding to a further request that the President appear before the grand jury:
 
Dear Bob:
This will respond to your letters dated February 21 and March 2, 1998. I apologize for my delay in responding. The fault is mine: as you know, we filed a lengthy reply on Friday in the sealed "leaks" matter, responding to your opposition to our original motion for contempt sanctions. That matter simply absorbed my time, but I am now able to give your correspondence the attention it deserves.
As I hope you are aware, the President has the greatest respect for the grand jury. I appreciate your own acknowledgment in your March 2 letter of the "grave duties of state" which are uniquely the President's and the "immense and weighty responsibilities" he must discharge. The buck really does stop with the President for decision-making on a vast range of issues that are critical to this country's safety and economic security.
While it is true that not every moment of the day is absorbed by the duties of office, the President is extraordinarily busy on a range of important public issues, some of which are visible and some of which are not. In our judgment, our ability to have access to the President is simply insufficient at the present time for purposes of representing him adequately in the matters with which you are concerned.
Accordingly, he will, on our advice, not be able to accept your invitation for him to testify at this time. I am certain you would agree that the President deserves the same right to the informed assistance of private counsel as does every other citizen.
Your most recent letter remarks that the situation in Iraq has "thankfully, eased." While there are some respects in which this may be true, the situation remains highly volatile, as a glance at today's newspapers will reveal. The continuing Southeast Asian economic crisis and the Bosnian situation also demand a great deal of the President's time, as do other national security issues, many of which are highly confidential.
On the domestic front, the President's schedule is equally congested. . . . Moreover, as I indicated in my earlier letter, we remain concerned about some of the well-publicized and questionable investigative techniques used by your office. Events of recent days have done nothing to alleviate this concern, and this necessarily affects our judgment as to the degree of preparation necessary to assure the President has adequate and informed legal assistance at the present time. . . .
Sincerely,
DAVID E. KENDALL
 
MARCH 13
Grand Jury Invitations
 
From Mr. Bittman to Mr. Kendall:
 
Dear David:
By your letter last Wednesday, March 4, 1998, the President has now declined five
invitations to testify and tell his story to the grand jury.
As time goes on, now eight weeks into the investigation, your claim that the President continues not to have time to prepare his testimony about Ms. Lewinsky is increasingly difficult for us to understand. We mean no disrespect whatever, mindful as we are of the President's constitutional obligations, but as stated in my letter of March 2, 1998, since the Monica Lewinsky matter began the President has found time to play golf, attend basketball games and political fund-raisers, and enjoy a ski vacation. On Jan. 12, 1998, the President was deposed for nearly a full day in the Jones v. Clinton lawsuit. Your co-counsel, Bob Bennett, has even moved to expedite the trial date in that case. In addition, as you remember, despite the President's weighty responsibilities we had no trouble scheduling the President's depositions for other Whitewater-related matters, and we were able to schedule his testimony the two trials in Little Rock with relative ease. In those trials, of course, he was summoned as a defense witness, not by the United States. . . .
In particular, a deposition format -- should the President refuse his right to present his testimony to the grand jury and face his fellow citizens eye to eye -- is an arrangement we stand ready to discuss. We are ready and able to accommodate any issues of Presidential dignity, as well as security, which of course can be readily accomplished at the United States Courthouse.
Nothing, in short, should stand in the way of the truth's coming out. As should be apparent, we continue to seek -- on behalf of the grand jury -- the President's truthful testimony before that body, which stands ready to sustain any inconvenience in order to respect the President's schedule, while at the same time carrying out its solemn function under our system of law.
Sincerely,
ROBERT J. BITTMAN
 
MARCH 18
The Issue of Cooperation
 
From Mr. Kendall to Mr. Bittman:
 
Dear Bob:
Thank you for your letter dated March 13, 1998. I will be equally frank in response.
For over four years now, the President has cooperated in every possible way with the investigation of the Independent Counsel. He has voluntarily given testimony under oath on three separate occasions to the independent counsel and twice to defendants (on each occasion, he was cross-examined by the independent counsel), he has submitted written interrogatory answers, he has produced more than 90,000 pages of documents, and he has provided information informally in a variety of ways.
I, took have dealt in good faith with your investigation for more than four years. Until the recent expansion of jurisdiction to cover the Lewinsky matter, I have not had occasion to raise, nor have I raised, the kind of concerns I have adverted to in the recent correspondence. I will be more specific: the actions of the Office of Independent Counsel in the past several weeks (as distinct from the actions of the grand jury) led me to believe that your investigation may not, in fact, be an even-handed search for justice but rather may be, for whatever reason, a campaign to embarrass and harass the President. I believe he is now plainly the object of your investigation. . . .
Of more serious concern to us is evidence that your office contrived to obtain the President's deposition testimony through improper and illegal means. Based upon what we have been able to learn thus far (see, e.g., the Page One Washington Post article on February 14, 1998, headlined "Linda Tripp Briefed Jones Team on Tapes"), your office, your agent Linda Tripp, and the Paula Jones lawyers apparently colluded to use the fruits of Tripp's felonious audiotaping (see Md. Code Ann. 10-402 (1997) of Lewinsky against the President at his deposition on Saturday, January 17, 1998. Curiously, Tripp appears to have been given immunity by your office immediately after the contacted you. She then secretly recorded at least one conversation with Lewinsky, an act that (unlike her previous audiotapings) does not appear to have been in violation of wiretap law. According to the Washington Post's February 14 article, Tripp arranged to have Lewinsky apprehended by your agents about noon on Friday, January 16, then put off a meeting with the Jones lawyers until (we believe) it became clear that Ms. Lewinsky would not herself agree to wear a recording device to gather evidence against others. At some point late in the afternoon, Tripp "sent word" to the Jones lawyers that she would talk to them, and she was transported to her home in Maryland (perhaps by one of your agents) where she proceeded to share both the existence of the illegal tapes 1 and their contents with the Jones lawyers, who were able to use this information the next day to question the President.
It appears to us that you did not seek, the Attorney General did not approve, and the Special Division did not authorize the extension of your jurisdiction based on any specific and credible evidence of criminal activity by a covered person.
Again, I would respectfully ask you to read this letter to the grand jury and to make it part of the grand jury record, if your letter to me is shared with the grand jury.
Sincerely,
 DAVID E. KENDALL
 
APRIL 3
About Testifying
 
From Mr. Bittman to Mr. Kendall:
 
Dear David:
I write in response to your letter of March 18, 1998, in which you declined our sixth invitation for the President's testimony, and in response to our meeting of March 20, 1998, during which you declined to answer my question whether the President will ever voluntarily testify about the matters involving Monica Lewinsky.
As you know, upon receipt of your letter I immediately called you to take you up on your offer to meet and discuss our mutual concerns regarding our six invitations to the President. Notwithstanding the numerous misstatements in your letter -- which are addressed herein -- I was hopeful that in light of the President's public pledges of cooperation we could finally arrange terms under which the President would voluntarily testify about the matters involving Ms. Lewinsky. My hopes were dashed at our meeting when you simply refused to discuss any of the "issues." Not only did you merely repeat some of the inflammatory allegations in your letter, you avoided even addressing -- much less answering -- the question I began our meeting with: Will the President ever voluntarily testify about the matters involving Monica Lewinsky? You refused several times to answer this question. . . .
Having tried and tried, I will now try once again. Please give me a straightforward yes or no answer to the following question: Will the President ever agree to testify voluntarily about the matters involving Ms. Lewinsky? If the President chooses again not to give his testimony, so that the grand jury may at least receive some of his evidence, please provide this office with any and all exculpatory evidence you may have.
Sincerely,
ROBERT J. BITTMAN
 
APRIL 17
Objections to Investigation
 
From Mr. Kendall to Mr. Bittman:
 
Dear Bob:
In my several letters and in our meeting, our position could not have been more clearly stated: we have serious objections to the origin and conduct of your Lewinsky investigation until those are satisfactorily addressed, we cannot, as a matter of professional duty to our client, allow the President to give further testimony at the present time. The issue remains open, however, and depends on your Office. . . .
Since your letter states it will address my concerns only "briefly", I will not restate here the issues I have raised at some length in my previous correspondence. I would note only that, once again, your letter stonewalls my request for information concerning contacts between members of the Independent Counsel's law firm (Kirkland & Ellis) and the Paula Jones lawyers as of the Jan. 16, 1998, expansion of your Office's jurisdiction to encompass the Lewinsky matter in the Paula Jones civil suit. My need for this information is obvious: if in fact personnel at Kirkland & Ellis have provided legal assistance in some way to the Jones side of the civil suit, Judge Starr would not have been qualified under the Ethics in Government Act to serve as independent counsel on the Lewinsky matter -- some other individual, with no connection to the Jones litigation, would have had to have been selected.. . .
For over four years, the President has cooperated fully with the investigation of the independent counsel, which has now gone on longer than a Presidential term. He has voluntarily given testimony under oath on three different occasions to the Independent Counsel and twice to defendants (on each occasion, he was cross-examined by the independent counsel), he has submitted written interrogatory answers, he has produced more than 90,000 pages of documents, and he has provided information informally in a variety of ways. This amounts to unprecedented cooperation with an investigation of unprecedented duration. . . .
Sincerely,
DAVID E. KENDALL
 
JULY 17
Invitations Declined
 
From Mr. Bittman to Mr. Kendall:
 
Dear David:
As you know, beginning January 28, 1998, we, on behalf of the grand jury, have invited the President six times to testify voluntarily about the matters involving Monica Lewinsky. Despite his previous cooperation with other aspects of our investigations and his public pledges to cooperate fully with this investigation and provide "more rather than less, sooner rather than later," the President has unfortunately chosen to decline each and every invitation to give his information to the grand jury. The grand jury simply can wait no longer for the President's voluntary cooperation.
Pursuant to 9-11.150 of the United States Attorneys' Manual and with all the requisite approvals thereunder, enclosed please find a subpoena for President Clinton to appear and give testimony before the grand jury on Tuesday, July 28, 1998, at 9:15 a.m. If the president agrees to comply with the subpoena and testify, we and the grand jury -- as we have previously stated -- will accommodate his schedule if he cannot appear on the 28th.
Sincerely,
ROBERT J. BITTMAN
Deputy Independent Counsel
 
JULY 24
Testimony to Grand Jury
From Mr. Kendall to Mr. Bittman:
 
Dear Bob:
I write in response to your letter of yesterday, which I believe to be now moot.
The President is willing to provide testimony for the grand jury, although there are a number of questions relating to the precise terms and timing which must be worked out. If you are willing to work within the framework of the last three times the President provided such testimony and if you are sincere in your statement that you will work to accommodate his schedule, we should quickly be able to finalize the arrangements. . . .
Sincerely,
DAVID E. KENDALL
 
JULY 24
Pleased by Response
 
From Mr. Bittman to Mr. Kendall:
 
Dear David:
We are gratified by your response to my letter of yesterday, and we are pleased by the President's decision to provide testimony for the grand jury.
You indicate in your letter that the President "is willing to provide testimony for the grand jury" and you suggest that such testimony take place in a forum outside the grand jury, on an uncertain future date. We are happy to discuss arrangements for the President's testimony that will be consistent with concerns of security an dignity of the Office of President. . . .
Sincerely,
ROBERT J. BITTMAN
 
JULY 31
A Blood Sample
 
From Mr. Bittman to Mr. Kendall:
 
Dear David:
I telephoned you twice this morning but was unable to reach you. Investigative demands require that President Clinton provide this office as soon as possible with a blood sample to be taken under our supervision. . . . I assure you this information will be kept strictly confidential and will be restricted to a handful of persons on a need-to-know basis only.
Your response to these requests will be greatly appreciated.
Sincerely
ROBERT J. BITTMAN
 
AUG. 3
Yes, With Conditions
 
From Mr. Kendall to Mr. Bittman:
 
Dear Bob:
This letter is written after receiving your second letter dated July 31, 1998, and after our telephone conversation this morning. We agree to provide the blood specimen you have requested (today, if possible), pursuant to the following conditions:
(1) This test, any analysis, our written correspondence, and our oral communications on this issue are all to be treated as highly confidential, subject to the full protections of Rule 6(e), Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure. Both the OIC and we will take the utmost precautions to preserve the confidentiality of this matter.
(2) The sample will be drawn by the White House physician ... , Dr. Connie Mariano, at the White House, in the presence of two representatives of the OIC, under medical procedures acceptable to the OIC. The sample will be immediately furnished to the OIC.
(3) You will execute an affidavit today setting forth your predication evidence for requesting this test, and you will preserve this affidavit in a secure place. You will set forth in the affidavit the evidence you would have presented to Chief Judge Johnson, as represented in your second letter of July 31, 1998.
(4) You will instruct the laboratory that does any analysis related to the specimen we furnish to preserve enough of the item being treated (e.g., any dress of Ms. Lewinsky's) to make possible a later, outside, comparative test of the same type, if appropriate.
I will look forward to receiving a written response to this letter, and we will speak later in the day concerning logistics.
Sincerely,
DAVID E. KENDALL
 
AUG. 17
The Lab Report
 
From the subsequent F.B.I. DNA analysis.
 
Results of Examination:
Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) profiles for the genetic loci D2S44, D17S79, D1S7, D4S139, D10S28, D5S110 and D7S467 were developed from HaeIII-digested high molecular weight DNA extracted from specimens K39 and Q3243-1 (a semen stain removed from specimen Q3243). Based on the results of these seven genetic loci, specimen K39 (CLINTON) is the source of the DNA obtained from specimen Q3243-1, to a reasonable degree of scientific certainty. . . .

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: September 22, 1998

SECTION: Section A; Page 17; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1018 words

HEADLINE: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE PRESIDENT;
With Nation Glued to Television, Clinton Sticks With His Peers

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

 BODY:
On a day of high-minded indifference to the disclosure of his grand-jury testimony, President Clinton passed his time yesterday in the consoling company of admiring fellow world leaders, contemplating terrorism, Social Security, the degradation of the oceans and the social safety net in the Netherlands.
He did not mention his grim-faced testimony, and he did not watch any of it either, his aides said. 
 After a speech to the United Nations and lunch with assorted heads of state, President Clinton went to the New York University School of Law to discuss how to strengthen democracy as global markets blur national boundaries. In a room full of aspiring lawyers and accomplished professors, he was not asked about his grand jury experience.
Instead, the President chewed over connections among domestic politics, social issues, economic development, environmental change and other matters with his friend Tony Blair, the Prime Minister of Great Britain; Romano Prodi, the Prime Minister of Italy, and Petar Stoyanov, the President of Bulgaria.
It was the kind of kitchen-table, peripatetic, highbrow gab that Mr. Clinton pioneered in Arkansas and has tried to translate to the world stage as President. In particular, he and Mr. Blair have conducted these sorts of earnest conversations before, but privately, with advisers in Washington and just outside London. This was the first time they treated the public -- for two hours -- to their earnest search to identify the world's looming problems and to define what they call a "third way" in politics.
"We believe in activist government, but highly disciplined," the President said, in trying to explain the concept to the audience in front of him and to that slice of the television audience that was not preoccupied with replays of his grand jury testimony.
Mr. Blair said, "We are witnessing, in effect, the rebirth of progressive politics," which he described as an eagerness for progress combined with a commitment to justice. Mr. Blair credited President Clinton, whom he called Bill, with giving the world "hope and confidence" that powerful nations will intervene to prevent humanitarian disasters.
The four leaders sat in red leather armchairs, with a round wooden table in front of them and an antique, here-there-be-monsters globe at their left. Mr. Clinton led the discussion, sinking back casually in his seat and pointing a finger as he posed questions to his fellow leaders. Hillary Rodham Clinton, who sat in the front row, did not participate, as she has in the private sessions.
The President quickly warmed to the discussion, describing the social safety net in the Netherlands, the needs of the Social Security system in the United States, and one Ugandan village's attempts to use "microcredit," or tiny loans, to build the "infrastructure of civil society." At one point, Mr. Clinton recalled former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's maxim that people may campaign in poetry but must govern in prose, as he turned to Mr. Prodi.
"Romano, what's your biggest domestic challenge?" he asked.
Mr. Prodi replied in his gravelly baritone, "My prose, my prose."
Grinning, the President returned, "Italians never have to speak in prose."
Things got so casual by the late in the session that Mr. Clinton was waving his hands as he offering breezy examples of his efforts to address the degradation of the oceans or to increase financing for research and development into the environment. Sucking on a candy, he said that in response Republicans in Congress "say that it's a Communist plot and they hold hearings on it."
As the audience laughed, Mr. Clinton said that he was trying to make a serious point, that too many policymakers "see an iron law between how much junk you put in the atmosphere and how much your economy grows." Until politicians are convinced that the economy can grow with environmental protection, he said, "we are playing Russian roulette with our children's future."
It was supposed to be a one-day trip to New York to address the United Nations. But the White House stretched it into two and half days of meetings with heads of government. The response Mr. Clinton has got -- including a standing ovation at the United Nations to the affectionate way Mr. Prodi called him Bill -- seemed sure to bolster his mood.
Whenever he has been confronted by scandal, Mr. Clinton has tried to direct attention instead toward his devotion to confronting the problems facing the country. That technique did not work today, at least in the view of White House aides, who were seething over the wall-to-wall broadcast coverage of the President's testimony, which took place on Aug. 17.
Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said he was not surprised that Mr. Clinton's speech at the United Nations, a call for a global crusade against terrorism, got less news media attention than his testimony. The testimony, he said, "has had that impact of fewer electrons dispersed in the air on that very vital and important subject," he said.
Decrying the release by the Republican Congress of Mr. Clinton's videotaped grand jury appearance, he called yesterday "arguably an unnecessary day in the life of our country, an awful day."
For her part, Mrs. Clinton presided over a two-hour panel discussion at New York University on the topic, Civil Society and the Future of Democracy."
In a room packed with professors, visiting policymakers, law students (and more reporters than usually sit through academic discussions), Mrs. Clinton was greeted with especially loud and long applause. And the other members of her panel took pains to show their regard for her.
In her own short and sober remarks, Mrs. Clinton emphasized the need to nurture citizenship, and to find a new ways to govern at a time when the old ways of governing are no longer effective.
Warning that neither government nor globalization should be blamed as the root of all evil, Mrs. Clinton said, in what sounded very much like a personal creed, that "we have to take the world as we find it and do what we can to improve upon it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: NEW YORK MEETING -- President Clinton yesterday with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, left, and Prime Minister Romano Prodi of Italy. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
HARNISCHFEGER ABANDONS SALE OF ITS BELOIT SUBSIDIARY

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Harnischfeger Industries Inc., the world's No. 2 manufacturer of paper-making equipment, said yesterday that slowing economic growth worldwide had forced it to suspend efforts to sell its Beloit pulp- and paper-making machinery subsidiary. Harnischfeger, based in Milwaukee, also said it had strengthened its anti-takeover plan by lowering the threshold at which shareholders could buy additional shares, making a takeover prohibitively expensive. Shares of Harnischfeger fell 68.75 cents, to $11.875, their lowest level this decade.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Building Workers Needed

 BODY:
Connecticut economists and industry experts say the exodus of construction workers during the state's recession, combined with a crackdown on unlicensed laborers and a lack of young people entering the field, is increasing construction prices and delaying home repairs.
In July, 63,400 people worked in construction in Connecticut, up 4 percent from the 60,900 people employed in the industry a year earlier. Construction employees earned an average of $833 a week, an increase of 4 percent from the average weekly wage of $801 in July 1997. 
 Through July, Connecticut communities had issued 20 percent more permits for new houses than in the first seven months of 1997. The state will tally about 12,000 housing starts this year, but would have had about 1,000 more if the home-building industry had all the workers it needed, according to Donald Klepper-Smith, an economist with Datacore Partners in Middletown, Conn. (AP)

HEADLINE: When a Big Company Hatches a Lot of Little Ideas

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
CHRYSTAL SOFTWARE'S document-processing products were born at the Xerox Corporation, but they sure did not fit there. Xerox can take years to develop a line of copiers; software goes stale in months. And Xerox thinks in terms of billion-dollar businesses. Even R. Steven Kiser, Chrystal's president, concedes that if Chrystal is wildly successful this year, its sales will not top $15 million. "We're not even a blip on Xerox's radar screen," Mr. Kiser said. "If we were still part of Xerox, we'd be killed off."
So why does Chrystal exist? Because two years ago, Xerox started a New Enterprises division whose sole purpose is to keep promising products from falling through corporate cracks. The group spun out Chrystal as a separate company, which Xerox expects to take public next year. 
 Chrystal and eight other companies that New Enterprises is nurturing still turn to Xerox for cash and services like legal advice. But each has its own board and sets its own strategy.
"I have full freedom, yet I don't have to waste time raising capital or building a support staff," Mr. Kiser said.
Xerox's take on it: "There are too many compromises when a new product is buried inside a big company, but that doesn't mean that we should let good products go," said Colin J. O'Brien, the new group's head.
Finally, corporate chiefs are acknowledging that entrepreneurs can breathe life into quirky ideas that, left within bureaucratic companies, would die of neglect or choke on red tape. The result is that corporate America, once considered anathema to all things entrepreneurial, is becoming a birthing ground for start-up businesses.
Often the big companies let fledgling firms buy into their benefits programs, use their lawyers and other support staff and drop their name with customers. But the small companies manage their own budgets, design their own compensation plans, usually heavily weighted toward equity rather than salary, and live or die by their own decisions.
The arms-length relationship seems to work for both sides. "Entrepreneurs have a passion to succeed under any circumstances, and they'll do even better without a corporate safety net," said Robert S. Sullivan, the dean of the Kenan-Flagler Business School at the University of North Carolina.
For the Xeroxes of the world, meanwhile, spinning out ventures is a relatively risk-free way to participate in new technologies without weakening their concentration on main product lines. "It's always better to throw out a lot of seeds and see what comes up," said AnnaLee Saxenian, a professor in the College of Environmental Design at the University of California, Berkeley.
Indeed, Professor Saxenian's research shows that one reason California's Silicon Valley has thrived more than that of Route 128, its high-tech counterpart near Boston, is that Silicon Valley firms have been generating a stream of start-ups. No one, not even the Small Business Administration, has quantified the spinoff trend yet. But anecdotal evidence is piling up. A few examples:
* Last year Lucent Technologies, a telecommunications company that took Bell Laboratories with it when it spun out from AT&T in 1996, started a new ventures group to nurture an assortment of products like high-definition television signals, electronic fingerprint identification and a technology that speeds responses to 911 calls. "Bell Labs still does a lot of research that isn't focused on our core businesses but has a lot of commercial potential," said Thomas M. Uhlman, the new group's president.
* In 1996 Hewlett-Packard Company, which shut its database-software business a year earlier, let some employees form a spin-out company, Timesten, around one particularly promising data-searching technology. Hewlett let an outside entrepreneur license a product in which computers read and transmit handwritten notes. Hewlett owns a stake in Timesten and receives royalties from the outsider. "We were tired of sending technologies to a watery grave just because none of our divisions wanted to commercialize them," said Joel S. Birnbaum, the director of HP Laboratories.
* The Thermo Electron Corporation, which started in 1956 as an energy company, has evolved into an incubator for companies in fields as disparate as health care, environment and analytical instruments. As soon as a product or a technology looks like it can go alone, Thermo Electron sells up to half of it on the public markets and uses the money it raises to develop other promising technologies. "Our core business has become generating new businesses," said John N. Hatsopoulos, the president of Thermo Electron, which has nudged two dozen fledgling companies out of the corporate nest.
EVEN the Federal Government has got into the act. As part of their move away from weapons research, many of the Department of Energy's laboratories have let employees start companies that commercialized technologies developed at those same labs.
For example, Rocky Flats, the former plutonium production plant outside Denver, has spawned companies that are working on products as diverse as optical communications and a vaccine to combat AIDS. Oak Ridge National Laboratories in Tennessee has turned a former uranium-enrichment plant into what is now called the East Tennessee Technology Park, which is currently home to start-up companies, many using Oak Ridge technologies. Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque has given rise to 60 companies.
"As long as a technology isn't classified, it's best to license it to an employee who will run with it," said Dan L. Hartley, Sandia's vice president for laboratory development.
Why is this happening now? Every decade has its managerial catch phrases, and the favorites in the 1990's have been "core competency" and "leadership position." The going theory is that companies should play only in their strongest products and technologies, that is, stick to their core competencies, and where they can dominate their market. What that means is that no product, no matter how intriguing, has a shot at development dollars unless it is a strategic fit.
Companies have also spent the decade wringing every last drop out of costs, and are now looking for other ways to rev up income. One easy way is to let employees, or even outsiders, take over unused patents or finish half-done research projects in exchange for royalties or shares in the new firm. "They just lose a small stake if the spin-out fails, but they have a potentially huge upside if it works," observed Rita McGrath, a management professor at the Columbia Business School.
And in trying to hurry their own products to market, companies have been forming numerous joint ventures and so-called strategic partnerships with suppliers, customers, even competitors. Psychologically, that makes it easier for once-insular companies to let new technologies out the door.
Polaroid is a case in point. The photography giant has traditionally played all its technological cards close to the vest. So when David V. Cronin, a Polaroid engineer, invented a way to control electrostatic discharge on computer hard drives, Polaroid tried to take it to the market itself. "They didn't have a clue how to commercialize it," Mr. Cronin recalled, so the company shelved the product.
As recently as two years ago, it would have stayed shelved. But Mr. Cronin, sensing a more open atmosphere, persuaded Polaroid to let him contact venture capitalists. The result is Cro-Bar (for Cronin barrier), a stand-alone company built around the new product that pays royalties to Polaroid. Mr. Cronin stayed with Polaroid ("I'm 65, I don't want to work an entrepreneur's hours anymore," he explained), but invested in the start-up.
THE ways in which corporations spin off small companies vary as widely as the companies themselves. Some, like Thermo Electron, take them public but hold onto a majority of the shares. Some, like Xerox, keep them private and hold onto 80 percent of the equity, reserving the choice to take them public later. Some, like Polaroid, take no equity position at all.
They also differ in the amount of help they offer. Thermo Electron asks its spin-out companies to carry 0.8 percent of its general administration costs on their books in exchange for investor relations, health insurance and other services. Xerox charges each spin-out 1 percent of its sales in exchange for access to support functions. "It's a real boon to get critical pieces of infrastructure at such favorable rates," said Ramana Rao, the chief technology officer of Inxight Software, which broke away from Xerox early last year.
Hewlett, in contrast, provides little cushioning or staff support to its spin-outs. "We don't want them to feel they can have a soft landing," Mr. Birnbaum said.
The entrepreneurs say the umbilical cords are a mixed blessing. Some note that it is harder to attract good talent when would-be employees know that their company is majority-owned by a ponderous corporation. Others say they sometimes feel locked into occupying suboptimal space in the parent's headquarters, or are using corporate services not really attuned to their needs. And many miss the expertise they may get from a more narrowly focused venture capitalist.
But most say the pros outweigh the cons. "Almost everything we've done would have been possible without Lucent's support," said Andreas C. Papanicolaou, the president of Lucent Digital Video, Lucent's high-definition television venture. "But it would all have been harder. Add a lot of hard things together and it gets almost impossibly difficult."

HEADLINE: When the Suits Can Save Your Shirt

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

 BODY:
DEBORAH L. JACOBS, lawyer-turned-writer, gave a heartfelt compliment to the young man who arrived with his helper to clean her house in Brooklyn recently: the name of his service was awfully clever. But she wasn't going to leave it at that. "Have you trademarked it?" she asked.
He had not, he told Ms. Jacobs, who happened to be the author of "Legal Smarts for Small Business." And that answer worried her, enough that she will not disclose the name of the young entrepreneur's business until he has finished scurrying around to obtain trademark protection. After all, a name that isn't trademarked can be used by someone else unless the first person brings out expensive legal artillery to stop the competition. 
 It was just one example, Ms. Jacobs said, of how small-business owners forge ahead optimistically, figuring that nothing can go wrong, when they should part with a few hundred dollars, or a few thousand depending on the legal task, for a lawyer who, by training and temperament, can anticipate everything going wrong. "How far can an entrepreneur get without a lawyer?" she said. "Pretty far. But it can cost you a lot, a whole lot, later."
Lawyers are usually not a happy part of the plan for a new business. Neither are accountants, investment advisers or other professionals whose job it is to protect a business from the things entrepreneurs would rather not think about.
"That's the typical entrepreneurial attitude," said Fred S. Steingold, a lawyer in Ann Arbor, Mich., and the author of "The Legal Guide for Starting and Running a Small Business."
"They want to get along with their business, and they're not detail-oriented," he said. "They're impatient. That's what makes them good entrepreneurs."
Some tiny service businesses, of course, start and run fine without professional advice; a dog walker or a window washer can obtain a business license (and probably should in many cities, for tax reasons), file a Schedule C and never pay for a consultation.
Even in a retail or a professional business, Ms. Jacobs said, "as a sole proprietor you can absolutely hang out your shingle without consulting a lawyer, although if you're operating out of your house you might want to check the zoning rules."
But any other form of ownership -- partnership and any type of corporation -- requires legal and probably accounting guidance.
On the complexity scale, the simplest is a partnership, which most experts say should begin with a written agreement spelling out, for example, what happens if one owner dies or quits the business. This is well-charted territory, especially since the Uniform Partnership Act governs in almost all states, and by following legal guides for the general public and form books that contain standard agreements, most people can do the paperwork and whatever modifications they want.
But even Mr. Steingold, whose publisher, Nolo Press, produces self-help books and software, suggests that a lawyer review an agreement. He gives the same advice for forming a simple corporation -- with the preliminary note that owners might want to first ask a lawyer whether they need to incorporate. (The main advantage, ordinarily, is protection of the individual owners from legal liabilities. There are tax advantages and disadvantages, too, best sorted out by an accountant.)
The paperwork -- state filing papers, articles of incorporation and shareholder provisions -- is manageable for most people; Nolo Press, among others, publishes general guides and versions specific to several states, including New York and California.
Having a lawyer review the documents is fairly painless: in Mr. Steingold's case, about an hour of his time, or $175. For handling the whole process, his flat fee in most cases is $600. (In big cities, where costs are generally higher, charges can run as high as $2,000.)
As for buying a business, whatever you plan to do, Mr. Steingold said, self-education and self-representation won't work. "You need advice on whether to buy the assets or just the corporate shell," he said. "The typical purchase agreement is pretty complicated. There are all kinds of decisions about how it's going to be financed. Then there are 10 to 20 documents that show up at a closing."
Some people, he said, will come into a lawyer's office with a proposed sales contract that originated with the seller or came from a form book, "but it would be difficult for somebody who doesn't have any legal experience to go through a closing."
Do-it-yourself accounting is not recommended either, but entrepreneurs can keep bills down by doing the prep work. Software programs offer simplified bookkeeping tasks and enable people to monitor cash-flow statements and projections.
Anyone starting a business should be thoroughly immersed in those numbers anyway, said Ginny Beauchamp, the vice president of the National Association for the Self-Employed in Washington. Still, Ms. Beauchamp added, however small the business, "having an accountant do audits a couple times a year is a very good idea, and if your business is growing by leaps and bounds, obviously you need help."
ONLY the simplest sole proprietorships can do without accountants for tax planning and preparation. Businesses can get in trouble for failing to keep up with changes in tax law, as many did several years ago when they failed to amend their Keough plans. Perhaps a quarter of small-business owners were delinquent in filing new plans with the Internal Revenue Service, many because they were unaware of the new requirement.
Ms. Jacobs said small-business owners, whether through cost-consciousness or hopeful ignorance, make two mistakes in circumventing lawyers.
First, she said, they wave off legal advice until they are in trouble. She mentioned the entrepreneur who spent hundreds of thousands of dollars making a CD-ROM called "The First Electronic Jewish Bookshelf." His product brought a warning letter from Microsoft, which was using the term "bookshelf." At that point, the entrepreneur had to get a lawyer and enter extremely expensive settlement negotiations.
Second, she said, "many attempt to play amateur lawyer." Ms. Jacobs recommends self-help books to pare legal costs and identify business concerns. Nolo's, she advised, "are very well researched and well written and provide great background." Even after practicing law for six years, she does not hesitate to hire others.
"When I need a specialized kind of legal help, I hire the best expert I can," she said. "I would no sooner be an amateur in the legal field than I would be an amateur electrician and rewire my house."
One problem with drafting legal documents is simply finding a helpful standard form. States vary in their use of common terms as well as in their substantive laws, and as a result the forms "get very generalized and watered down," Mr. Steingold said.
He should know. He wrote a form book himself, as a companion volume to the legal guide for small businesses. It includes, among others, employment contracts, commercial lease forms, purchase agreements and tax forms. But somebody taking a form from a book, he said, "would need to get local counsel to look at it."

HEADLINE: HOT SPOTS/SILICON ALLEY;
Putting a Funky Face on Wall Street

BYLINE: By EDWARD LEWINE 

 BODY:
TWO men in ponytails and a woman with a bleached-blond crew cut were hanging out in their sparsely decorated Internet consulting firm at 11 Broadway in lower Manhattan. Their upstairs neighbor, the president of an Internet company had just stopped by. He had sideburns to his chin.
"We were comparing notes about people in the building," explained Mary Olson of Transition Networks, as Paul Guzyk, the president of Infohouse, which provides access to the Internet as well as networking services, headed back to the ninth floor. "We do that sometimes." 
 Just two years ago, Transition Networks didn't exist, Infohouse was operated from an East Village bedroom and 11 Broadway was almost empty. But these days they are all thriving, thanks, in part, to Plug 'n' Go, a program that has put 151 new-media entrepreneurs into 400,000 square feet of cheap, well-wired offices in six buildings south of City Hall.
Industry experts credit the program with giving a funky, creative edge to Wall Street, where nose rings and chunky shoes are now seen among the Brooks Brothers suits, and with helping the growth of Silicon Alley, a loosely defined area downtown that has been popular with new-media companies for the last few years.
The New York Media Association, a trade group, estimated that there were 2,600 new-media companies in 1997. "I think Plug 'n' Go is one reason the industry is doing so well here," said Brian Horey, the association's director. "I would like to see it expanded."
But Plug 'n' Go has not been the only impetus to luring new-media contenders to the end of Manhattan, others say. "Silicon Alley happened despite government, not because of it," said Tom Watson of @NY, an on-line news service catering to local new-media businesses. "Plug 'n' Go was a reaction to what was already happening."
The program was started in February 1997 by the Alliance for Downtown New York, a nonprofit business improvement group, with help from the city and landlords. It was designed to help that part of New York recover from the loss of about 100,000 jobs in the early 90's, which left commercial buildings in the Wall Street area only a quarter full.
Sharon Greenberger, who manages the program, said the only business that had been growing downtown was information technology. So the Alliance tried to encourage young new-media companies, the Internet and other computer-related services to move in.
"These companies needed three things," Ms. Greenberger said, "cheap rent, easy connection to the Internet and short-term, flexible leases."
So Ms. Greenberger persuaded the owners of six semivacant buildings to offer small spaces at $15 a square foot (20 percent below market rate then) and to wire the offices for computers and T-1 lines and contract with an Internet provider.
Mr. Guzyk said the program has helped Infohouse, which began with two employees in 1995, to grow to 10 employees and a yearly gross of $1 million. "We can do things in this building much easier than if we were in a typical midtown building," he said.

HEADLINE: Making a Good Idea Her Own

BYLINE: By MIRTA OJITO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
HONEYMOONING on the beaches of Ibiza, an island off the southeastern coast of Spain, Dalia Almanza-Smith had what she calls an epiphany: the germ of an idea for a business that changed her life and helped to introduce postcards as a new form of advertising in America.
To be fair, she says, it was not her idea. She copied it from the bars and restaurants she visited during her European honeymoon four years ago and quickly adapted it to the American way -- bigger, bolder and better. 
 This is how it happened, she says, leaning closer across the table at a trendy bar here and clearly enjoying retelling the story of how she became an entrepreneur:
One day as she was leaving a French restaurant, she noticed a small rack of colorful postcards and picked one up. "What are these?" she asked a bartender.
"Take them, they're free," he told her.
"Why are they free?" she insisted.
The man shrugged. She turned the card around and realized what it was. "My God, this is advertising!" she said, showing it to her husband, Ron Smith, an executive with a management-consulting firm in Virginia. At the time, she was the advertising director for a Hispanic magazine.
"I was taken with the idea then," said Ms. Almanza-Smith, now a 38-year-old on her way to becoming a millionaire. "Advertising is what I know, and I knew that I had never seen anything like that."
After the episode in the bar, she says, she and her husband would lie on the beach and instead of planning their new life together, planned a new business.
By the time they came home two months later, they decided to use their savings and credit cards, about $40,000 altogether, to start a business they thought was new on this side of the Atlantic: using catchy postcards to push everything from milk to pantyhose in restaurants and bookstores. They even had a name, Frankie Freecards.
Ms. Almanza-Smith quit her job and, armed with years of reading Entrepreneur magazine, began working on the business plan. She soon discovered that at least two other people had been to Europe that summer, stumbled on the same idea and had started their own postcard businesses.
Undaunted, Ms. Almanza-Smith approached them with the notion of joining forces to minimize costs and offer wider distribution to clients. They formed a company and called it Go Card.
THE beginning was difficult, she admits. She called on restaurants and bookstores and, showing them a few faded cards from her trip, asked them to let her to put a rack with similar postcards on their walls.
"I kept telling them, 'It will be really pretty, I promise,' Ms. Almanza-Smith explained. "It was a total conceptual sale. I also told them I would have the cards in 30 days when, in reality, I had nothing."
Armed with contracts from the businesses, she then visited advertisers and, offering free cards or low rates, filled the racks.
By 1995, the business had taken off with clients in Chicago, Los Angeles, New York, San Francisco and Washington. Last year, with 400 clients and displays in more than 2,000 locations in 11 cities, the company had nearly $5 million in total revenue.
Just a few months ago, Ms. Almanza-Smith took her part of the business from Go Card, renamed it Hot Stamps and forged a partnership with Network Event Theater, a company in New York. She remains in charge of her company in Virginia but, through the New York partner, distributes her postcards to most of the major American cities.
She says her goal is to have a rack with her cards everywhere in the country.
"When I started with Go Card, I did not believe it would work," she said. "But once it did, it motivated me to do more. There is no way to stop me now."
Ms. Almanza-Smith attributes some of her pluckiness to her genes and her heritage. She was born in Mercedes, a small town in the southernmost tip of Texas, to Mexican-American parents. Her father owned an auto-parts business and her mother returned to college in her 40's to study business administration. "If she had the courage to sit next to 17- and 18-year-olds in the classroom, I had to have the courage to start a business," Ms. Almanza-Smith said.
As a Hispanic woman, she says, she also learned to rely on her own talents to succeed. She and her mother were the first women in the family to go to college.
"I learned early on that I had to persevere in whatever I got into because I had no other options," she said. "I was not going to inherit any money. I was not going to naturally follow any kind of family tradition or business. I had to invent myself."
That philosophy appears to be shared by many Hispanic women in the United States. Debra Silimeo, a deputy associate administrator of the Small Business Administration in Washington, who said that the rate of growth for businesses started by Hispanic women is 114 percent, compared with and average growth rate for all businesses of 26 percent.
Outwardly, success has not changed Ms. Almanza-Smith much. She still lives in the same house in suburban Falls Church, Va., and wears jewelry that only looks expensive. She said that she and her husband prefer to spend their newly acquired wealth by helping their extended families and taking them on their vacations abroad.
Just a few months ago, Ms. Almanza-Smith splurged on what she had always considered a luxury: she hired a gardener to plant flowers all over her yard.

LENGTH: 1565 words

HEADLINE: Where the Future May Be a Table Away

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: WOODSIDE, Calif.

 BODY:
JOHN SHOCH, a Silicon Valley venture capitalist, scans the room at Bucks, a folksy cafe in this affluent bedroom community, and notes that he recognizes about half the financiers, hardware engineers and software hackers who are seated, eating breakfast.
Mr. Shoch is doing what he does best. He calls it "surfing": looking for the next big thing in the nation's technology heartland. He is a key player in a remarkably efficient system that brings together vast pools of capital and good ideas. 
 There are signs everywhere in Silicon Valley that the region is no longer an unconnected bunch of competitors located near the Stanford University campus, which gave birth to the valley's first company, Hewlett-Packard Company.
Instead, changing jobs in Silicon Valley Inc. is now as simple as turning into a new driveway on the way to work, or as simple an idea as the newly created garage.com, which matches entrepreneurs with venture-capital firms.
A walk down University Avenue in Palo Alto, increasingly the valley's brain center, will take you past the brand-new offices of Accel Partners, one of the valley's premier venture-capital firms. The partners are upstairs; downstairs, "entrepreneurs-in-residence" are busy incubating start-ups.
This financing mechanism has created the semiconductor chip, the digital watch, video games, the personal computer and most recently the commercial Internet. Indeed, Silicon Valley is now a result of Moore's Law, the industrial process first described by the Intel Corporation co-founder Gordon Moore, which dictates that every 18 months chipmakers will be able to double the number of transistors on a given sliver of silicon.
Although it wasn't obvious until recently, Moore's Law is dictating that change here is exponential. The reason is easy to explain: exponential change is described by the graph of an arc that begins slowly on a horizontal plane and then almost instantly skyrockets vertically.
That is why time in the valley seems so compressed. This is evident from the exploding megahertz ratings of microprocessor chips to the ballooning megabyte storage capacities of memory chips and disk drives, making everything move faster at an ever-increasing rate. Around the valley it is best described as living on Internet time.
For Mr. Shoch, whose firm, Asset Management, has just completed a $100 million-plus fund, these are both heady and nervous times.
Surfing, in Mr. Shoch's parlance, means catching the next big wave of technology innovation. And despite the fact that there are more and more billions of venture-capital dollars flowing into the valley each year, it is complicated. (The recent stock-market jitters have left venture capitalists here nervous but still enthusiastic; in short, holding their breath.)
While the pace of change has become predictable, charting the direction of change is still an art form.
"Sometimes you'll paddle furiously to catch a wave that fails to materialize," Mr. Shoch said. "While at other times the wave will appear suddenly and you'll find yourself paddling just as furiously to try to catch it before it leaves you behind."
Some Silicon Valley venture capitalists have made their reputation by finding and riding a certain wave. For example, in 1989 John Hummer and Ann Winblad established the first venture-capital firm to focus exclusively on software companies, just when the software industry was blossoming.
And there are legendary figures, like John Doerr, a partner at Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers. Mr. Doerr has had the knack of making the best investments spanning three eras: personal computers, workstations and the Internet.
Sometimes venture capitalists will try to force the next wave by jump-starting financing for whole groups of companies. A classic model is the $100 million fund created several years ago by Kleiner, Perkins to finance companies that were starting businesses based on the Java programming language.
This tactic can also lead to blind alleys, catastrophic bad timing and unexpected twists and turns. As an example, everyone in Silicon Valley has believed for years that the next big thing would be an ultralight portable computer.
In fact, almost all of the valley's best thinkers have been inspired by the work of a small group of computer researchers led by the industry pioneer Alan Kay at Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center 25 years ago. The researchers proposed "Dynabook," a powerful two-pound, wireless computer connected to a global network of computer databases.
Sound obvious?
It did; it also appeared to be simple. Yet more than a dozen of Silicon Valley's most fabled catastrophes -- with company names like Grid, Gavilan, Momenta, Go, Io and Slate -- have foundered because neither the timing nor the technology was right. In today's economy, you need to have both elements working simultaneously.
MORE recently, in the early 1990's, everyone -- Silicon Valley venture capitalists to cable-industry tycoons and Redmond, Wash.-based software moguls -- was convinced that the next big thing would be interactive digital television. The vision was that the TV would become the portal for the information revolution. Happy families would sit in their living rooms in front of their TV's and bank, shop, communicate with other people and be entertained. The living room has so far not proven to be the right place for interacting with the Internet.
Missteps like these have led to absurdities like a Florida market trial in which a Silicon Valley company tried to hook up TV sets to computer workstations that had been fine-tuned to pump movies and digital information into homes. The concept failed because the computer workstations cost more than many families want to spend: $25,000 each.
The lesson, of course, is that in Silicon Valley the term "visionary" usually describes a job title and not an ability. If you pressure venture capitalists over a meal at Il Fornaio in Palo Alto, they will confess that they expect a shakeout and acknowledge that they are concerned about the huge capital flows coming into the valley.
One consequence can be seen in the remarkable appreciation of the value of new deals -- there is just too much money chasing too few great ideas.
But for the moment the risks seem to be outweighed by the incredible opportunities inspired by the emergence of cyberspace. While everyone was looking the other way, the Internet sneaked up on Silicon Valley and sent the venture-capital community racing to finance start-ups like Netscape Communications, Yahoo, Excite, Infoseek and Amazon.
The rise of the Internet has cranked up the valley's economy to a feverish pitch. Companies like Apple Computer and Sun Microsystems have been reinvigorated by the boom in Internet commerce. There are so many new companies being formed that initial public offerings are no longer the typical outcome for a start-up.
There are more than five times as many companies created each year as there are available I.P.O. dollars. Consequently, acquisition has become an endgame for most start-ups, according to Technologic Partners, a firm that monitors venture capital in Silicon Valley.
That in turn has made the valley even more of a technology hothouse, attracting a new kind of venture backer -- large technology companies like AT&T, Lucent, Intel and Microsoft.
Indeed, although Intel executives once referred to the valley's venture community as "vulture capitalists" because they would entice employees away to start to new chip ventures, the company is now running the valley's largest venture fund, valued at more than $300 million annually.
Yet despite the boom-time atmosphere, there are signs that the Internet wave is cresting and that Silicon Valley is entering one of those periods between new technologies and new industries.
Today there is no certainty about the next big thing after the Internet, but everyone is looking. Is it wireless data or is the time finally right for interactive digital television? There are some who believe they see signs the next wave is on the horizon.
Richard Shaffer, the president of Technologic Partners, which conducts market research and conferences, recently changed the title of one of his annual conferences from "PC Outlook" to "Technology Outlook."
The reason, he said, is that he has detected a renewed interest in the venture community in basic sciences and new technologies. If so, it would be a significant departure from the last five years. "I haven't heard talk about basic physics and optical electronics in a long time," Mr. Shaffer said.
Which might suggest that the valley is on the brink of one of those epochal shifts, perhaps from the world of electronic to optical computing. Such a shift has been predicted for many years by some of the valley's best thinkers. The world of optical computing is much more in tune with the communications-rich future that now seems all around.
The common wisdom here, however, is that any new invention is subject to the "15-year" rule: it usually takes at least 15 years for a new technology to make it from the laboratory to the market.
In a world where timing is everything -- the right investment at the wrong moment can be just as disastrous as making the wrong bet -- a venture capitalist can be left with a lot of sleepless nights, even in the best of times.

SECTION: Section G; Page 1; Column 1; Entrepreneurs 

LENGTH: 1779 words

HEADLINE: Heeding the Siren Call to Do Your Own Thing

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
MY father told the story over and over. He was a young and energetic broker employed by a big textile company, an immigrant's son prospering for the first time, when his boss summoned him one day and said that because of corporate setbacks, my father would have to accept a wage cut.
He refused. Impetuously, he and another young broker resigned, rented an office on Worth Street, then the center of the textile industry in Manhattan, and within a year they were earning more than they ever had. They not only brokered trades in cotton cloth, but purchased cloth themselves, gambling on resale at quick profits. "Taking a position," my father called it. He loved the risk. 
 My father was an entrepreneur or, more precisely, he exhibited some of the characteristics of an entrepreneur. The concept -- to break with routine, to innovate, to seize an opportunity, to develop something new -- is as old as capitalism. But the word itself and the characteristics it suggests have become popular among Americans only in the last 15 years as everyone, not just immigrants and their children, struggles for a place in a rapidly changing, increasingly competitive economy.
Responding to the demand, graduate business schools are initiating courses on how to be an entrepreneur, although the lectures are not nearly as specific as those in a statistics class or a management theory course. And corporate America is spending billions of dollars on the restless, entrepreneurial endeavor to develop popular new products or to rejigger old ones to boost sales.
Only a volatile stock market threatens to curtail this energy by depriving entrepreneurs, particularly small entrepreneurs, of some of the financing they need to carry out their ideas. Big companies have more cash savings to draw on and easier access to credit.
"Entrepreneurial activity became a concern to the general public in the 1980's, when we all thought that the United States was falling behind, and that the rest of the world, particularly Japan, would sink us," said William J. Baumol, an economist and historian at New York University. "As soon as people started worrying about this, they said that Japan was entrepreneurial and America had lost the spirit of entrepreneurship. And we began self-consciously to reacquire that spirit."
My father, getting started in the 1920's, never thought of himself as an entrepreneur and did not use that word. For him, opportunity and prosperity meant self-employment. The bold, risky act of going out on his own became, in hindsight, his heroic moment; each time he told the story, his children listened respectfully. He was proud of a journalist son who worked for a big wire service and then a big newspaper. But he wondered all his life why that son did not itch to start his own newspaper or buy one. For him, the entrepreneurial spirit, a term coming into vogue in his final years, resided exclusively in energetic small-business owners.
Small business has a role, of course. Starting a business, being your own boss, risking your savings, operating with high energy -- all these characteristics appear in the evolving definition of the entrepreneurial spirit, first described in the early 1800's by Jean-Baptiste Say, a French economist. But innovation and invention are its essence. And while a Sam Walton (Wal-Mart) or a Steven Jobs (Apple) or a James Clark and Marc Andreessen (Netscape) still emerge from the ranks of the lone-wolf entrepreneurs, innovation and invention occur as often today in big companies as in small ones. More often, probably.
"What has happened is that entrepreneurial innovation has become the prime competitive weapon, and industry can no longer wait for the occasional geniuses to come along with something new," Mr. Baumol said. "Companies have had to routinize invention and innovation. And the big companies have the money to do this."
Merck & Company, the giant pharmaceutical corporation, certainly does. Its scientists, who develop drugs at Merck's laboratories, are encouraged to take on the additional task of scouting outside the company -- through journals, newspapers, universities and friends -- for promising new research or new technologies that might lead to the development of a future drug. When they find this promising outside research -- to fight prostate disease, for example -- they make their case to a Merck board for money to finance or to buy the outside research or to form a partnership.
"An entrepreneur to me," said Bennett M. Shapiro, the executive vice president of Merck's worldwide basic research, "is someone who picks up something not going on at Merck, but is important to the future development of a drug, and then makes the case for why we should fund a relationship, as if he were an independent entrepreneur appealing to venture capitalists for money."
Not all of Merck's 5,000 scientists are so entrepreneurial, but those who are, and succeed in bringing valuable research to Merck, get handsome payoffs in stock options. Through two centuries of capitalism, the hope of a big payoff has driven entrepreneurs.
Similarly, Sealed Air Corporation, with 14,000 employees and $2.5 billion in annual sales, encourages its people to bring entrepreneurial proposals directly to T. J. Durmot Dunphy, the chairman, and other top executives -- going around the hierarchy to reach them when necessary. The goal is rapid corporate growth, another key characteristic of the modern entrepreneurial spirit, and Mr. Dunphy achieves it partly through his unorthodox reporting system.
Sealed Air's principal product is plastic air-bubble packaging, which cushions fragile products during shipment. Fast growth (Mr. Dunphy's company had only $5 million in annual sales when he took over in 1971) has come through the new forms of packaging developed at Sealed Air and through acquisitions.
"We are trying to expand quickly in Latin America," Mr. Dunphy said. "A conventional company would send its corporate development people, who would go about the task in some routine way. But the general manager of our Spanish subsidiary called me and said his operation was running well and he had time. He flies to Latin America once a month, and in six months he has purchased one company and is negotiating for another. I call that entrepreneurial."
But for all the entrepreneurial flexibility now evident in big companies, millions of Americans appear to believe that the entrepreneurial spirit resides mainly in small companies; that is, owner-operated companies with fewer than 100 employees. The great attention focused on Silicon Valley start-ups feeds this view. So do venture capitalists, who buy into the start-ups, hoping that their innovative products will run up big sales, quickly raising the value of the venture capitalist's investment.
The Small Business Administration and the National Federation of Independent Business, a powerful Washington lobbying group representing small companies, also foster the perspective that small companies are the chief source of entrepreneurial activity. For this reason, among several others, small companies should get Government support in the form of special tax breaks and special exemptions from some regulations. Or so the argument goes.
"In the rawest sense of entrepreneurial," said William Dennis, the federation's director of research, "if I establish a new firm, I have taken an entrepreneurial act. I have acted in the belief that I know something others don't, and I am exploiting an advantage others do not have."
That is an appealing thought at a time when self-employment is a big phenomenon, particularly among immigrants and among workers who have been laid off by corporations. By this definition, a Korean immigrant, for example, is entrepreneurial if he sets up a flower kiosk on a street corner, acting on an insight that, in his view, a competitor on the opposite corner has failed to grasp. He is acting on the belief that he will draw more customers because his new kiosk is closer than his competitor's to a bus stop.
"Entrepreneurship is a state of mind, a can-do attitude, a capacity to focus on a vision and work toward it," said Barry Rogstad, the president of the American Business Conference, whose membership consists of quickly growing corporations still operated by their founders.
Most economists agree that starting a business -- gambling your savings and going into debt to follow your "vision" -- is entrepreneurial. But if the Korean immigrant's kiosk survives and he then presides over a routine daily operation, as most small business owners do, is he still entrepreneurial?
The answer is no, unless he regains that status by giving his operation another entrepreneurial kick. David Allen, who founded Allen Associates in the Boston suburb of Ayer, fits this pattern.
Soon after earning an engineering degree 35 years ago, Mr. Allen began a company to manufacture and sell a wire-and-sponge device that he had invented and patented to keep corsages moist. The device sold, and for 20 years, he earned a steady five-figure income. His entrepreneurial start-up faded into a nonentrepreneurial, day-to-day operation. "I did not have a problem with that," Mr. Allen said recently. "Just running a business was enjoyment enough."
But not for his wife. When their two sons became teen-agers in the early 80's, Marie Allen joined her husband, bringing to the enterprise a background in, and a yen for, marketing. She soon hit on a way to increase sales revenues from the 600 wholesale florists who were her husband's customers.
Traveling to regional trade shows, Mr. Allen said: "We look for promising new products that people are trying to introduce into the floral industry, but cannot manage to sell. Marie takes them to market with our products; we currently are selling 25 different items to our customers."
Annual revenue for the Allens has nearly quadrupled to $1.1 million from $300,000, when Mrs. Allen came aboard 15 years ago, and it has reawakened the family business.
From Adam Smith's day, the entrepreneurial spirit, in one guise or another, has been a huge source of change and expansion for the capitalist market system. The great early-20th century economist, Joseph A. Schumpeter, gave the concept its modern, expansive twist, defining an entrepreneur as someone who breaks with routine.
The entrepreneurial function, he wrote, "does not essentially consist in either inventing anything or otherwise creating the conditions which the enterprise exploits. It consists in getting things done" right down to "making a success of a particular kind of sausage or toothbrush."
