PUB-DATE: September 23, 1998

SECTION: Section G; Page 8; Column 1; Entrepreneurs 

LENGTH: 1375 words

HEADLINE: Their Businesses May Be Small, But Their Ambitions Rarely Are

BYLINE: By BRENT BOWERS 

 BODY:
EVEN as children, many of them spotted a business angle nobody else did, and milked it for all it was worth.
At age 10, Harold S. Blue, now the chairman of Proxymed Inc., a health-care information-services company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., figured he could make more money if he hired playmates to shovel driveways instead of doing the work himself. He paid them $3 of the $5 he collected and even had the presence of mind to ply his trade outside his neighborhood so that the mothers wouldn't catch on to his scheme. 
 Before he was out of high school, Mr. Blue owned and operated two drug stores.
As a boy growing up in a village in India 100 miles north of New Delhi, Vinod Gupta, the founder of infoUSA Inc., a seller of business information in Omaha with projected sales this year of $250 million, caught frogs at a swamp and sold them to a research laboratory for lunch money. In college, he rented entire passenger-train cars to make a 36-hour trip to New Delhi, and then sold seat tickets individually for a quick 25 percent profit.
Donald J. Dalton, the founder of the Micro Overflow Corporation in Naperville, Ill., a company that adapts computer equipment for disabled people and expects revenues of $1 million this year, recalls how he would knock on people's doors when he was in middle school, asking if they had any household appliances to repair. At 12, he started Donny's Appliance Service in his basement. "Until about 10 years ago, I still got mail regularly delivered to Donny's Appliance," said Mr. Dalton, who is now 55.
Not every successful business owner can boast of such an early flair for salesmanship. But even those who drifted or were pushed into entrepreneurial careers seem to have a natural bent for seizing opportunities that make competitors wonder why on earth they didn't think of that themselves.
Is that what defines them? They are an eclectic lot who operate ventures that vary from grocery stores to Internet start-ups. Donald J. Jonovic, a consultant in Cleveland who has advised family businesses, says he never fails to be astonished by the "raw diversity" of American entrepreneurs.
"You look at some of them and you ask, 'My God, how'd that happen?' " he said.
In a country that prides itself on individualism and counts literally millions of entrepreneurs, it is a question worth asking. Small businesses, roughly defined as ventures controlled by their founders and having fewer than 100,000 employees, are an enormous force in the American economy.
But what drives their owners to strike out on their own rather than take refuge in the predictability and perks of salaried jobs?
The experts, of course, have their views. Mr. Jonovic says true entrepreneurs are marked by "tunnel-vision dedication" and supreme self-confidence. David G. Winter, a professor of psychology at the University of Michigan, said they are propelled by a zeal to excel at whatever they do, a trait he calls "achievement motivation."
"They have this optimism, this exuberance, this boldness," Mr. Winter said, which can take the form of restlessness, especially if their business grows into a larger, bureaucratic organization they can't control. If that happens, he said, "they may be so unable to deal with it that they get dismissed by their board. Or they may quit and start all over again."
He also said entrepreneurs often display a streak of authoritarianism because they believe their method is the only way to do things. "Doing their best is what matters most to them, as opposed to a concern with friendship or power," Mr. Winter said.
Entrepreneurs, he added, tend to come from middle-class backgrounds, not blue-collar homes or wealthy families, "which still view small business as a step downward into vulgar trade."
Mr. Jonovic said that many entrepreneurs are tightfisted, not out of greed but because each dollar they earn represents a small fraction of success. "I knew a successful entrepreneur who ended up in a nursing home and wouldn't pay for a private room because he wanted to keep his estate above $1 million," Mr. Jonovic said.
Entrepreneurs themselves cite a long list of self-defining characteristics and attributes: decisiveness, resilience, focus, a love of battle, a penchant for risk-taking, workaholism, good social skills.
But as they recount their histories, two core themes leap out, flip sides of the same coin: they want to be their own boss and, like the preadolescent Messrs. Blue, Gupta and Dalton, they show an uncanny knack for detecting opportunities that others missed.
Mr. Blue, the Proxymed chairman who is now 37, recalls how as a 16-year-old he talked the owner of a new doctors' building who was having trouble renting space into letting him set up a drugstore in the lobby. Before long, the complex was full, and his business boomed.
In his 20's, he started a chain of discount drug stores, then figured he could save 30 percent on the cost of generic drugs if he had his own generic-drug distribution company. "All it took was a wholesale license and a warehouse," Mr. Blue said.
Soon he sold the drugstores and expanded the distribution company. Then he sold the distribution company and got involved in another health-care business, which he sold. In the early 1990's, he invested in Proxymed, which operates an information network connecting doctors' offices with pharmacies, insurance companies and other industry sectors.
For most entrepreneurs, it all begins with the realization that working for somebody else just isn't a choice.
"I could have had a career at Six Flags, but I saw the light," said Keith M. Alper, a 36-year-old co-founder and the president of the Creative Producers Group, a St. Louis company that produces videos and special events for corporations.
Mr. Alper was named entertainment director for the Six Flags amusement park in St. Louis right out of college. He and a colleague soon put together a sideline by doing jobs for small organizations on tight budgets, including a fund-raising film for the St. Louis Zoo and an employee-motivation show for a hospital.
When Six Flags laid him off briefly, it struck Mr. Alper that as an employee "ultimately, you can't control the situation, no matter how hard you work.
"A magic light went off," he said. "I would go off on my own and succeed or fail on my own merits."
Today, Creative Producers Group, born in 1985, has revenues of about $10 million a year. Last fall, Mr. Alper opened an ad agency that writes brochures, designs corporate logos and Web sites and markets products for small businesses.
The decision to go it alone can be liberating, but it can also be scary because it means cutting off the corporate safety net. Eric B. Segal, the president of the Kenzer Corporation, an executive-recruiting firm in New York, recalls the near-panic he and his partner, Robert D. Kenzer, felt in the early days of running their company in the 70's.
Mr. Segal had been a corporate executive in the retail industry, but quit a high-paying job after he got what he viewed as an insufficient raise. As he and Mr. Kenzer scrambled to find clients, he said, he kept thinking: Where's the check? Where's Mommy?
"There are rules you learn from working in big business, but nobody's prepared for flying without the net until you do it," said Mr. Segal, who is 55. "It's frightening. I see a lot of corporate guys who can't make the conversion."
But many entrepreneurs insist that the absence of security is a small price to pay for the freedom to operate at their own pace and on their own scale. Sue Yellin, a small-business consultant who works out of her Manhattan apartment, says she is determined to remain a one-person show earning just enough money to live comfortably and "feed my cat Fancy Feasts."
Even so, Ms. Yellin is quick to see business possibilities in humdrum circumstances. A telemarketing specialist who has made an instructional tape titled "Warming Up to Cold Calling," Ms. Yellin, 46, has even figured out how to turn phone pitches she receives at home to her financial advantage.
"So many of the callers are terrible at selling," she said. "That gives me an opportunity to call their bosses and say, 'You should book me for some training.' "

HEADLINE: Fed by the Hand That Bites

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER 

 BODY:
FIFTY years ago, Lou Witzeman watched as a neighbor's house in an unincorporated area of Phoenix burned to the ground. A reporter at the time, Mr. Witzeman wrote the story for The Arizona Times, but he found a personal angle. He discovered that he, too, had no fire protection.
After unsuccessful attempts to find a municipal fire company that could provide service, "I realized I had to do it myself or forget it," he said. While continuing to work as a reporter, he formed a one-engine, four-person fire department that sold subscriptions for service to his neighbors. 
 In 1969, his company, Rural-Metro Corporation, began operating an ambulance service separate from the fire company. The service has grown into a company with annual revenues of $476 million and has shifted its focus to developing public-private partnerships.
In recent years, many more entrepreneurs are finding that the government is not simply the enemy and has more to offer than red tape. Multimillion dollar companies now do everything from operate prisons to deliver mail to American troops overseas. And small-business owners like Ben Farmer, a respiratory therapist, have taken over less weighty assignments. Mr. Farmer, for example, has been operating the paddle-boat rides for the last five years on the Downtown Canal in Indianapolis, where municipal services have been privatized extensively through competitive bidding.
"There is a whole market now of firms whose primary business is contract services for the government," said Adrian Moore, a director at the Reason Public Policy Institute, a nonprofit center in Los Angeles that focuses on privatization. "It's been around for a long time in the simplified form of janitorial services or purchasing contracts, but in the last 5 to 10 years it's gotten a lot more complex."
In many cases, what started as small entrepreneurial efforts have grown into huge corporations. The Corrections Corporation of America, started by a business executive, a lawyer and a corrections official in Tennessee, is a good model.
C.C.A., as it is known, was founded in 1983 in Nashville and got off the ground by operating a juvenile center in Memphis. It is now a business responsible for 78 prison-related ventures that encompass 63,308 beds, about 3.5 percent of the more than 1.8 million jail and prison beds in the United States.
"The private sector looks at the Federal Government as a new market," said Robert L. Raasch, the chairman of the Coalition for Taxpayer Value. "If the Federal Government looks at ways to save money, it's going to look to private sector bidders or entrepreneurs."
The coalition is spearheading the push for legislation that would result in privatization of what are considered commercial jobs in the Federal Government. The measure would push Federal agencies to decide whether to turn these commercial activities over to private companies.
Mr. Raasch said that his goal goes beyond privatization. He wants the Federal Government to stop taking business away from the private sector. As examples he used the Veterans Administration's hospitals competing for laundry contracts.
"Our official position is that anything that is not inherently governmental, like providing advice to the President or national security, should be done privately," Mr. Raasch said.
Organizations representing Federal workers, however, have opposed the measure, saying that it is based on a faulty assumption -- that making a government function private always saves money.
Opponents note that there are plenty of cases where privatization or extensive outside contracting has led to shoddy work and higher costs. In the private prison industry, cases of brutality, neglect and insufficient services have raised questions about prisons being a bottom-line business.
Companies handling government business is not new, but in recent years the relationships have become more entwined. For example, when United States troops went into Bosnia in 1995, a private Houston company did the troops' laundry, provided their meals and helped establish base camps.
The company, Brown & Root Services, won a five-year contract in 1992 to provide logistical services to forces deployed overseas because the military, after downsizing, began farming out support services. The contract has also taken the company to Somalia, Zaire and Haiti.
"They've done mail delivery, run shuttle services, provided potable water and taken care of solid waste," said Joan Kibler, the public-affairs officer for the Trans-Atlantic Program Center of the Army Corps of Engineers, which ran the service.
Representatives of small businesses complain that the the opportunities for them are more limited. "Larger businesses are more likely to do government contracting," said Dan Danner, a vice president of Federal Government relations with the National Federation of Independent Business. For what he called the "smallest of the small," local and Federal governments are still more of a problem -- think regulations and taxes -- than a benefit.
But Mr. Witzeman, who has retired but remains on the board of Rural-Metro, says that he still sees plenty of room for entrepreneurs to explore business relationships with all government levels.
"I didn't expect it to be this at the beginning," he said, considering how his company has grown into a major corporation by working with local governments. "But as I saw the trend developing I got less and less surprised. I wish I could be here 50 years from now to see where it's going. I think we'll have a very happy and cost-effective existence."

HEADLINE: Ingredients for Success: Ground Pigments and Linseed Oil

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SOLOMON; Deborah Solomon's most recent book, "Utopia Parkway: The Life and Work of Joseph Cornell," has just been issued in paperback.

 BODY:
CARL PLANSKY holds the strange distinction of being a prospering entrepreneur who has yet to acquire a tie or a jacket. He owns Williamsburg Art Supplies, a tiny shop on the Lower East Side of Manhattan that specializes in homemade oil paints. In an age when most paint is mass-produced, and when even much of the art in the galleries has a manufactured sheen (think video monitors), Mr. Plansky has earned a loyal following for his Old Worldish ways. "I don't want to boast," he said on a recent afternoon, "but all the schmeary painters buy from me."
At 47, Mr. Plansky is a short, rotund man with flyaway gray hair. Dressed in a plaid shirt, the tails hanging out over rumpled work pants, he looks like an artist, and in fact is one. Unable to live off the sale of his art, he went into the paint business in 1986. The idea of an artist grinding his own pigments may evoke quaint visions of Ye Olde Paint Shoppe, yet in New York, where the number of artists (roughly 100,000) well exceeds the entire population of Florence during the Renaissance, the competition among art-supply companies is fierce. 
 Last year, Mr. Plansky sold 21,000 tubes of oil paint, not quite as many as, say, Winsor & Newton, a London-based company that sold 2 million tubes in North America alone. Nonetheless, Mr. Plansky is thrilled to claim an income in the mid-five figures. "It's like having a perpetual, never-ending grant," he exclaimed.
His storefront on East Fourth Street is picturesque, a tiny, sun-flooded space stocked with a bright array of supplies -- jars of powdered pigment, quart-size bottles of linseed oil, tubes of oil paint in colors that span the rainbow. On a typical day, his customers might range from art students with spiked hair and pierced noses to leading painters like Milton Resnick, Bill Jensen, Terry Winters and Brice Marden. "I have a special relationship with Carl's colors," Mr. Marden noted with affection, referring to the company's wide selection of one-of-a-kind hues, which include Spanish Earth, Intense Black and Courbet Green.
Mr. Plansky describes his entry into the paint business as a kind of happy accident. In 1985, working from his studio in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, he began making oil paint for himself. Although he had no plans to sell it, within a year his artist-friends had mooched, bartered and bought enough paint from him to turn him into the master supplier of the Williamsburg art crowd. Mr. Plansky wasn't sure whether that meant he was a bona fide success or just a potential tax evader, and he promptly contacted the Internal Revenue Service.
"I was making too much money to pretend that my activities were like Grandma's cookies at the flea market," he recalled. "There were too many checks, so I had to go legit and get a tax number for resale."
To be sure, the stereotypical artist is thought to be hopeless at numbers, and Mr. Plansky says it's true. His company is now a bustling operation with five employees and a hilltop factory outside Oneonta, N.Y., yet he tries to stay removed from the nuts and bolts. He relies on an accountant to take care of what he calls "all that payroll stuff." An office manager keeps track of sales. The company has never advertised or taken out a loan. While other executives plot expansionist dramas, Mr. Plansky routinely declines offers from retail outlets eager to sell his products. "If I made the paint any faster," he explained, "the quality wouldn't be the same."
Most oil paint is made from a mixture of ground pigments and linseed oil, but that basic recipe, like any recipe, is only as good as the person using it. While big paint companies generally grind every last ounce of pigment and oil to a uniform consistency, Mr. Plansky, using a three-roll mill designed in the 19th century, grinds each of his 120 colors to a consistency of its own. Artists who are Minimal, Conceptual or just overly literal are not likely to love Mr. Plansky's paint. Rather, it appeals to those who revel in the muckiness of oil paint.
"Carl makes the best paint around," said Bill Jensen, a 53-year-old painter of darkly churning abstractions. "With commercial paints, everything comes out feeling like molasses. But with Carl's paint, every color has a different texture. His raw umber is unbelievable. It feels like sand."
Naturally, Mr. Plansky's corporate competitors are less impressed with his home-brewed paint. "It's just about elitism," said Lynn Pearl, a spokeswoman for Winsor & Newton, the long-established seller of artists' oil paints. "Artists like having a secret source. They like to think they're using a paint that there are only five tubes of. But we believe that commercial paints are superior because of the fineness of the pigment particles."
Debates about oil paint are as old as oil paint itself, which was invented at the dawn of the Renaissance. All the Old Masters ground their own pigments, while famously refusing to share their recipes. The exact ingredients of any artist's paint was considered a matter of utmost secrecy, giving rise to suspicion, furious gossip and scholarly treatises. "If you go to the British Museum," Mr. Plansky noted, "you could no doubt find beneath a pile of 20,000 books a treatise titled, 'How I Think Rubens Probably Made His Famous Glazes to Get That Enamel-Like Quality in His Nudes.' "
A turning point came in the mid-19th century, with the invention of the squeeze tube. Artists had previously stored their paints in pig bladders, which were prized for being airtight; tubed paints offered a new convenience. They brought on the phenomenon of the Sunday painter, and the biggest shake-up in art history since the Renaissance. As Mr. Plansky explained, offering a view of French Impressionism not likely to be heard in an art-history class: "Suddenly artists had portable materials. They could go outdoors and paint plein-air and not have to worry about puncturing some bladder."
The son of a hairdresser ("My father specialized in big hair for weddings and bar mitzvahs," he said), Mr. Plansky grew up in Baltimore. At 18, he moved to New York, eager to prove himself in the art capital, or rather to suffer the grand indignities of the creative life. After a stint at the New York Studio School, he worked at odd jobs, spending about a decade behind the counters of delicatessens in Greenwich Village. "I was the best lox slicer in New York," he said.
OVER the years, Mr. Plansky has received intermittent encouragement for his own artwork -- big, voluptuous landscapes that focus mostly on trees. When he had his first solo show, at the 55 Mercer gallery in SoHo in 1992, the critic Jed Perl noted in The New Criterion: "I can't think of another artist of Plansky's generation who has such a splendiferous feeling for paint. . . . Plansky is a natural."
These days, however, Mr. Plansky can't find a gallery willing to exhibit his work. He regularly wanders SoHo and Chelsea with slides of his more recent paintings, humbly asking dealers to take a look. "The cult of youth makes it hard to get a show," he said with resignation. "Everyone wants the latest thing, but the latest thing is retro or neo-retro. I don't get it."
In the meantime, Mr. Plansky is glad to be earning a living in the paint business, even if surveys indicate that the demand for oil paint is no longer growing. Since the 50's, when Jackson Pollock and Willem de Kooning splashed out their Abstract Expressionist masterpieces and invested oil paint with a new grandeur, rival paints have come along. The 60's saw a boom in acrylic paints, which are made from a liquid form of plastic and allow artists to wash their brushes in water, as opposed to smelly turpentine. Acrylics were the perfect complement to the no-muss, no-fuss look of Warhol's soup cans and the Pop productions of their era.
Nowadays, the latest vogue is for "water-based oil paint," a contradiction of terms that is proving to be a commercial success. "It's really insane," Mr. Plansky observed. "How can someone choose a paint just because it's easy to clean up?"
It's true that oil-on-canvas loyalists can sometimes seem like an embattled minority. Yet Mr. Plansky has played no small part in keeping them alive, or at least well stocked with supplies. His paints are competitively priced, from $7 for a standard studio-size tube of burnt umber to $30 for cobalt yellow. Special customers receive a 30 percent discount but, as Mr. Plansky said, "Everyone is a special customer."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carl Plansky with the paints that pay for his fine-art painting. His one-of-a-kind hues include Spanish Earth and Courbet Green. (Jeff Weiner for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 355 words

HEADLINE: SCHOOL OF HARD KNOCKS: LESSON 1;
Safer in the Rapids Than by the Shore

BYLINE: By BRIAN ALEXANDER 

 BODY:
AS a teen-ager, Bill Kimpton was fired from the Clift Hotel in San Francisco. Later, he was rejected for admission to Cornell University's School of Hotel Administration. But in 1981 Mr. Kimpton finally became a hotelier when he left investment banking and took over the Hotel Bedford, a rundown tourist flop on Union Square in San Francisco.
He renovated the building, but then the recession in the early 80's left the beds empty. On the verge of bankruptcy, Mr. Kimpton began to push the Bedford's relatively low rates to some potential corporate accounts that normally used chain hotels. The tactic worked, and the Hotel Bedford was saved. 
 Seventeen years later, Mr. Kimpton, now 63, has built a string of 22 European-style hotels in the United States owned or managed by the Kimpton Group. Most of the hotels are anchored by well-regarded restaurants.
The formula is successful. In 1988, the Kimpton Group had revenues of $34 million. This year, it expects $300 million, its occupancy rates consistently ranking at or near the top of the industry.
"Life is a big river, and if you can relax and sit in the middle of it with some energy, you will enjoy the adventure and make it through any rapids," Mr. Kimpton said. "If you sit still and hold onto the side of the bank, you will get beaten up by the river."
He continued: "This concept for the hotels came together when I was in London, staying at a little hotel called the Wilbraham. I think a room was $35, but it was so friendly, the fabrics so warm, I said, Wow, I like this and I am paying 10 percent of what I just paid at the Intercontinental.
"It was a tiny room, a small bed, but the people were so friendly, the bartender called me by name, the room clerk said hello. I said to myself, This feels like home.
"The key is to maintain integrity and honesty because if you are honest with yourself and honest with everybody around you, they will give you second, third, fourth chances. If you fake it, you'll wonder why it didn't work."
The moral of the story? "Trust your intuition and let go of the fear," Mr. Kimpton said.
 BRIAN ALEXANDER

SECTION: Section G; Page 6; Column 1; Entrepreneurs 

LENGTH: 1770 words

HEADLINE: Students at B-Schools Flock to the E-Courses

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill.

 BODY:
AS the sun begins its pink descent behind the neo-Gothic spire of Deering Library, two barefoot students lazily toss a Frisbee across a great expanse of lawn. Backpack-toting undergraduates saunter by. Four flights up, in Northwestern University's Leverone Hall, 18 students and a professor are gathered around a classroom table dotted with water bottles and cups of iced coffee. Pens are filling notebooks.
It is a classic academic scene, but the talk this July evening is not of Dante or of the pre-Socratics. It is of angel investors, price-earnings ratios and what it means to work for a company so young that its founders still have no desks or no telephone lines. The students, led by Steven Rogers, a clinical professor of management, are spending their summer working for start-up companies in the area in what may turn into full-time jobs. All the students are in the master's program of Northwestern's Kellogg School of Management, one of scores of business schools that over the last five years have built programs and majors in entrepreneurship studies, an arresting mix of the plainly pragmatic and the utterly ephemeral. 
 Driven by student and alumni demand, no field is hotter today in business studies than that of entrepreneurship. Whereas a generation ago the goal of top M.B.A. graduates was to join a Fortune 500 company and climb the corporate ladder, students' most fervent desire nowadays seems to be to come up with a marketable idea, start a company and work for themselves.
"This is like the end of the 19th century when Rockefeller and Carnegie were the icons," said Steven N. Kaplan, a professor at the University of Chicago who teaches entrepreneurial finance. "Today it is Bill Gates and Warren Buffett. So much of what will dominate the landscape in 50 years is starting now."
According to Murray Low, who directs entrepreneurship studies at Columbia University, scholarship in the field is exploding. In the mid-1980's there were only a few scholarly journals devoted to new businesses; today there are 26, most of them started in the last five years. In 1980, there were 18 entrepreneurship chairs at business schools; today there are more than 200.
Jerome Katz of St. Louis University, who has been tracking this growth, says that in a 1991 study of the approximately 300 accredited business schools in the country, a couple of dozen were found to offer some course work in entrepreneurship. Today, about 120 of them offer it as a major.
While defining entrepreneurship studies remains problematic, scholars in the field agree that its sudden popularity has several roots. First, the corporate downsizing of the 80's changed the view that a good corporate job meant long-term security. Second, technology and globalization have changed the way the world does business. A product's shelf life has been greatly reduced, and challenges from remote places mean that companies need flexibility, which is a challenge for large, formal hierarchies of traditional corporations.
Finally, scholars say, young people have grown up in an environment that emphasizes independence and self-reliance.
Jon A. Levey, a student in the Northwestern group, epitomizes the new spirit. Having secured a good job at a regional bank straight out of college seven years ago, Mr. Levey left last year to get a master's in management and recently joined Firefly Greetings, which sells custom business and personal cards and gifts over the Internet. With its six employees, the entire company could fit into this classroom. Mr. Levey said he couldn't be happier about the switch.
"I spent several years in corporate America and it wasn't for me," he said. "I couldn't stand getting a paycheck signed by someone else."
His fellow students around the table expressed similar sentiments -- the thrill of taking a risk, building something from scratch, sharing in the next industrial revolution that computers seem to be generating. The question for business schools is: How do you teach all that?
"Entrepreneurship is really about the three P's: pride, passion and perseverance," said A. Barry Merkin, a clinical professor of entrepreneurship at Kellogg. "It's about risk-taking, boldness and confidence."
The best analogy, Mr. Merkin noted, is to sports. "Intuitive qualities are essential, but few can reach real heights without coaching," he said. "There are basic things to learn, like accounting and finance, but also narrower areas like writing a business plan, raising capital. I also try to give my students a feeling of what it is like to go through something like this, the tensions and frustrations, because folks who go into this without realizing what they are doing will face nervous breakdowns, heart attacks and divorce."
These are not matters, either the business plans or the heart attacks, most academics with Ph.D.'s want to teach or to study. There is a lack of reliable data on start-up companies, and without data it is hard to produce rigorous scholarship, the grist of academic careers. This has created a split, because alumni are donating truckloads of dollars to set up centers and chairs in entrepreneurship, yet there are no scholars to fill them. Professor Katz of St. Louis University said that dozens of the entrepreneurship chairs remained empty.
New York University is a good example. Its Stern School of Business has four endowed chairs of entrepreneurship, two unfilled.
"I see entrepreneurship as a word in search of a meaning in the academic sense," said George Daly, Stern's dean. "Academics sort themselves into these little silos, and entrepreneurship is not easily matched for them. But the role being played by small, innovative enterprises in our society is phenomenal and should be studied. The challenge is to persuade academics to look beyond their own boundaries."
Mr. Daly added: "By nature, of course, academics are not very entrepreneurial. Like a number of business-school deans, I find myself fighting the prevailing winds."
Business schools are increasingly turning to practitioners rather than scholars to teach entrepreneurship, either alone or paired with a more traditional professor. That is why Mr. Merkin of Kellogg is called a "clinical professor," on the model of medical school professors who are M.D.'s rather than Ph.D.'s. This, too, has caused tension.
"Generally speaking, tenured professors consider businessmen without Ph.D's to be lower-life forms," said Kenneth P. Morse, the founder of high-tech ventures and managing director of the Entrepreneurship Center at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Sloan School of Management. "But there were 1 million start-ups in the world last year, and anyone who wants to be involved in such a start-up has a lot to learn -- how to pick the funding, how to give a raise, how not to run out of money. This is different from what used to be taught. General Motors is never going to run out of money."
Y OUNG scholars are beginning to take the plunge. One is Professor Kaplan, who is interested in the evolution of corporate governance since the wave of mergers and acquisitions of the 80's reshaped many companies. His course on entrepreneurial finance is one of the most sought after at the University of Chicago.
Another scholar bringing respectability to the field is Paul A. Gompers, an associate professor of business administration at Harvard Business School. Professor Gompers acknowledges the difficulty in gathering data but says the field is too exciting to allow that to be a barrier.
"I get data from private consulting firms or through large pension funds or endowments that provide access to their files," Professor Gompers said. "A lot of it is hand-collected. I'm putting together data on 1,300 firms, collecting a complete financial history, their boards of directors, scales of compensation to study how they operate and grow. I have hired 10 to 15 research assistants during the course of this project over the last two and a half years."
Meanwhile, much of what goes on at entrepreneurship centers today consists of students going through the motions of setting up new ventures, and sometimes actually doing the ventures. Business school has turned into a kind of laboratory. Business-plan competitions, both local and national, have grown rapidly in scale with students presenting their plans to venture capitalists and competing for donated prize money to help them set up companies.
One such winner was Evan Schumacher, a 29-year-old native of Boston who finished at Northwestern this spring. His plan called for setting up a software company that tracks global shipping, freight and customs management for international firms. Mr. Schumacher won the Kellogg competition and took his plan to Austin, Tex., in May for national finals. He was a finalist, and as he walked off the stage after his presentation, his wireless microphone still clipped to his lapel, a man in the audience approached him and asked how much he needed.
The man became the company's first angel investor, in for $250,000. The company, Celarix, was born at the end of June in Chicago. So far, it has raised $500,000 from investors and is planning to raise another $1 million to $2 million from venture- capital firms. A third employee will join the company this month.
 
For Teen-Agers, Too, There Are Programs to Get Started
 COLLEGE isn't the only place where students can study entrepreneurship. In a 1994 Gallup poll, 7 out of 10 American high-school students said they wanted to start their own business. Some are young dreamers who have always believed they would chart their own course. Others have seen parents or relatives lose jobs through downsizing and want to avoid the same fate.
There are programs that teach the fundamentals of starting a business, often through practical experience, to young people and their teachers.

HEADLINE: His Dream Is That We'll All Hear Little Voices

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

DATELINE: WAYNE, N.J.

 BODY:
DRIVE west from Manhattan, through the Lincoln Tunnel and into the thick of one of the many commercial bloodstreams that feeds the suburban beast engulfing New York City. Go about 20 miles from the Hudson River, past the Tick Tock Diner and the all-night A&P, to a nondescript office building that overlooks a 14-theater multiplex and a warehouse-size Costco.
That is where you'll find, on the third floor, a modest little company called Audible Inc., which just happens to have outsize ambitions. 
 It's an unlikely location, certainly, for a three-year-old Internet start-up, one that hopes to create a big audience for something completely different: custom audio information delivered on demand over the Web to portable devices you can listen to any time and anywhere while jogging, say, or driving to work.
Then again, the guy who founded the company, Donald Katz, is a rather unlikely entrepreneur.
"You're a journalist!" a partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers exclaimed when Mr. Katz went to its Silicon Valley offices more than two years ago to ask for venture capital. "What makes you think you can start a business?"
Good question. And in the answer lies not just the reason some of the smartest investors in the United States, including Kleiner Perkins and Patricof & Company, have anted up about $18 million on the entrepreneurial dream of Mr. Katz, who is 46 and the author of three highly acclaimed nonfiction books. It also offers a clue as to why so many of the best and the brightest of a generation that once disdained business, particularly the idea of starting a small business, now embrace it.
"When we were growing up, business was grubby, something our fathers did," said Fred Smoler, a professor of literature at Sarah Lawrence College who has known Mr. Katz for more than 25 years. "The ideal was to become an artist, a writer, involved in politics, something like that."
That is no longer true. Today, starting a business strikes many people, particularly younger people, as a worthy goal -- something valuable beyond simply the money it might bring.
A recent study by the Wells Fargo Bank and the National Federation of Independent Businesses' Education Foundation found that of the record 5.6 million Americans who started their own businesses in 1996, about half were under the age of 36. Most of their businesses were tiny, home-based operations, of course, but "instead of marching to the beat of corporate drums," said William J. Dennis, the author of the study, many more young people "prefer to build or buy their own drum, allowing them to pound out their own beat."
Mr. Katz never marched to anyone's beat but his own. In starting Audible, he drew on his own experiences as a writer combined with the thirst to create something new from the seemingly limitless potential of the Internet. "Audible seeks to wed the oldest of human technologies, the spoken word, with the newest of technologies," he said with characteristic ardor. "We want to be a leader in teaching the Internet to talk."
Translating that vision into a successful business will not be easy. Like just about every other Internet venture these days, including several that have gone public and quickly been bid into billion-dollar market valuations, Audible, still private, is losing plenty of money.
The company has about 35 employees, its own portable player and a Web site (www.audible.com) where users can immediately download from a selection of 16,000 hours of copyrighted audio files containing everything from traditional read-aloud books like Frank McCourt's "Angela's Ashes" ($9) to bundles of advice from the Harvard Business Review ($3 to $13) and such. For all its success in building a new infrastructure, however, the company is just beginning to attract paying customers.
Mr. Katz is accustomed to taking risks. For two decades, from the time he left the London School of Economics in 1975 to write, on spec, an article for Rolling Stone magazine on the Basque separatist movement, Mr. Katz was a freelance journalist. Early on, he penetrated the bomb-throwing Red Brigade in Italy and survived a dangerous visit to Ethiopia during a civil war. But he never romanticized the revolutionaries and terrorists he covered.
In the early 80's, Mr. Katz turned his attention to a world that seemed even more of a mystery: money and business. Originally from Chicago, he decided to write a book about Sears, Roebuck & Company, his hometown giant. Sears, the once-great store of the American middle class and one of the most secretive corporations in the country, was in the midst of an immense crisis. Mr. Katz persuaded Edward Telling, its chief executive, to give him carte blanche access to the company.
"You must be a hell of a salesman," Sears' top public-relations executive, who had opposed the move, told Mr. Katz. The book, "The Big Store," took six years to research and write.
Mr. Katz followed with two other books that also required him to open closed doors, one a look at the post-World War middle-class experience told through a single extended family that revealed its most intimate secrets, and the other an inside look at Nike and its reclusive chairman, Phil Knight. In business, surprisingly, Mr. Katz did find a subject worthy of epic treatment. And he discovered he had a taste for it.
WITH Ed Lau, his college roommate who moved into the computer industry, Mr. Katz began to develop an idea for a business that would deliver radio programs and audio books through the Internet. His next book project, on the convergence of digital technologies, was dropped.
"It was something I couldn't write into reality," Mr. Katz said. "I had to do it."
Not all of Mr. Katz's old habits were perfectly adaptable to his new entrepreneurial world.
"His first business plan was 160 pages long, and there were no numbers in it," Andrew J. Huffman, an experienced computer-industry executive who recently became Audible's president and chief executive officer, said with a laugh and only a touch of exaggeration. "Everybody else does maybe 10 to 20 pages."
But many of his skills did prove useful. He found a fresh outlet for the powers of persuasion that had opened so many doors in his writing career. The first big convert was Tim Mott, now a wealthy private investor in Ketchum, Idaho, who is renowned in Silicon Valley as a co-founder of Electronic Arts, the computer-game maker, and Macromedia, a software company specializing in multimedia graphic-design applications.
"I get calls all the time about start-up ideas, and I probably look at at least one business plan a week," Mr. Mott said. "Over the course of five years, I've seen, maybe, four that I wanted to commit money and time. This was one of them."
With Mr. Mott as chairman, they made the round of venture-capital firms. "Tim's business experience and Don's visionary ideas were a powerful combination," said Kevin Compton, a partner at Kleiner Perkins who became their chief backer there. "Three minutes into conversation you could just feel Don's passion."
Audible stands out in the crowded Internet bazaar in a few important ways. For one, it is not simply an on-line store like amazon.com, which relies on traditional package services to deliver books and CD's at a discount. Nor is it one of the myriad media Web sites that are counting on advertising to pay the freight.
Rather, Audible is built around the premise that lots of people are willing to pay regularly to fill their time -- on the go -- with constantly changing audio packages of entertainment, news and practical advice. Audio books are already a $1.6 billion business, and Audible can offer essentially the same thing at a lower price. Even more promising is the potential for pumping millions of mobile workers full of management information, corporate training and "time-shifted" business news while traveling.
To make all that possible, Audible had to design its own portable player. It is roughly the size and shape of an electric razor, holds two hours of audio and plugs into a personal computer through a cradle similar to one used in hand-held computers. People can carry the battery-powered gadget anywhere, listen to it through headphones or play clips in a car stereo system. Programs are stored on a computer, ready to refill the player as soon as it is returned to its cradle, which remains attached to the computer.
FOR the moment, though, the player is also an Achilles heel. It is relatively expensive, costing $200 as a stand-alone purchase. Two hours is not enough storage time, particularly since lots of audio books run three to four hours. And it is not easy for the technologically challenged to use.
To overcome these drawbacks, Audible is developing a second-generation player with greater abilities and is exploring new pricing plans similar to those used to sell mobile-phone services, in which buyers would receive the player at a steep reduction if they sign up for a subscription.
Relying mostly on word of mouth, Audible says it has attracted more than 5,000 customers and shipped about 3,000 players. Those using the player spend an average of about $20 a month on fresh content.
But Audible's real ace in the hole is not the player but the rights it has painstakingly sewn up with dozens of content providers. It is planning to introduce new programs -- from an audio digest of The Wall Street Journal to National Public Radio's "Fresh Air" program -- that will be sent automatically to a subscriber's computer. And it will adapt all Audible products so that they can be played on a variety of portable devices, beginning with the hand-held organizers powered by Microsoft's Windows CE software.
Even before the recent stock-market turmoil, Audible's outside investors, who own about 56 percent of the company (the founders and employees own the rest) remained cautious about going public, insisting they do not intend to sell stock until the company is generating a growing and predictable revenue stream.
Which is a good thing, given the uncertainty about even the most promising Internet ventures.
"There's no in-between," said Paul Hawken, the author of "Growing a Business" and an entrepreneur who co-founded Smith & Hawken, the mail-order garden-supply and clothing company. "Either Audible will be wallpaper, or it will be a billion-dollar-pus company."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Donald Katz, center, and the staff of Audible Inc., gather in its Wayne, N.J., headquarters for darts and drinks on Friday afternoons. (Normon Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Big in Small Business, Straining to Grow

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH 

 BODY:
THERE is an old joke told by statistics professors about a fellow who has his feet in the oven and his head in the freezer: on average, he feels fine.
The lesson is that statistics can be wildly misleading if they are not put into perspective. It's a point that is often lost in the popular notion that female entrepreneurship is a robust and increasingly significant segment of the American economy. 
 It is true that more and more women are starting, or running, their own businesses. Women now own nearly 40 percent of the 23 million businesses in the United States. Female-owned businesses employ more than 18 million people, generate more than $2 trillion in sales annually and have obtained more bank loans than ever before. And the growth of employment by female-owned businesses is greater than the national average in nearly every region of the country and in nearly every major industry.
So these should be heady times for women. But another, gloomier statistic may be more significant than the rest: women get less than 2 percent of the venture capital invested each year in American businesses. And it is venture capital, more than anything, that moves an entrepreneurial endeavor from the spare bedroom and into the big, or even medium, leagues.
"There's just no equity funding available for women-owned businesses," said Jere W. Glover, the chief counsel for advocacy at the Small Business Administration.
The reason is simple, he said: "Most venture-capital funds are run by white men. And most venture capitalists will tell you that the majority of their deals come from people they've known in the past."
Investing venture capital can be risky. It is essentially betting on someone else's expertise and ability, so knowing the entrepreneur is a definite advantage. It is also a world centered on country clubs and sky boxes, to which comparatively few women have access.
"It's an old-boys network," said Sherrye Henry, an assistant administrator of the office of women's business ownership at the S.B.A. "They get on their planes and go to golf games. We're really trying to find ways to get around that cultural pattern of lending in this country."
It is still possible to borrow money from banks, and women have made significant progress there. Over the last seven years, bank loans to women and insured by the S.B.A. have tripled in number and increased in dollar value by 164 percent. That's about 48,000 loans worth about $7 billion. Some banks, like Wells Fargo, even have special lending programs for businesswomen.
The problem with bank loans, however, is that an informal but nearly impenetrable limit of about $100,000 exists. It is what some people call "the other glass ceiling."
Most small-business owners with solid credit ratings can borrow $100,000 with little difficulty, Mr. Glover said. "You can probably borrow that much money just with credit cards," he added.
"But over $100,000, the debt-to-equity ratio that banks insist on hits you very quickly," he said. "In a very fast-changing economy, like information and technology, you either grow or perish."
By contrast, the median amount of the typical venture-capital deal is $6 million to $7 million. And though some eight million female-owned businesses exist, most are small. In fact, only 15 percent have employees.
Even those who succeed in landing venture capital have lots to say about the obstacles women face. Susan Williams DeFife of McLean, Va., has made the leap from one-woman home office to a thriving enterprise with 16 employees in an office building nearby.
Now 37 years old, Ms. DeFife was working for an organization called Women Executives in State Government in the early 1990's when she decided to become an entrepreneur. After several years looking for the right enterprise, she settled with on-line services in 1994. They were used very little by businesswomen then, she said, because there was little relevant information. The women also felt that on-line discussion groups, often dominated by men, were condescending.
Ms. DeFife and three male friends who had taken buyouts from I.B.M. then started Women's Connection Online (womenconnect.com), a job-and-information service for women. The men moved on, leaving Ms. DeFife to manage the struggling company on her own. "I was making a decent part-time living working 60 hours a week out of my home," she recalled.
Then came one of the most important ingredients in producing a successful business: luck. At an annual dinner of the Northern Virginia Technology Council, Ms. DeFife sat next to a venture capitalist. Later, she and a man she had brought into the business for his computer expertise, met with the investor, whom she declined to identify.
It was a meeting full of tough questions and heavy analysis, summed up with a statement she knew was true. "He said, 'Your biggest problem is going to be being taken seriously.' And he told me I was smart to have a man involved. I didn't get angry; I'm not sure why."
EVENTUALLY, the investor became her mentor, guiding her through dozens of unsuccessful attempts to raise money. With each pitch she found herself more self-confident and aware of what impressed investors and what didn't.
"I talked a lot about the mission of the company, but they wanted to hear about how they would make money," she said. "I can hold my own now.You can't be afraid to hear 'No.' "
Ultimately, she raised $500,000 from a venture-capital fund and another $130,000 from individual investors, including her mentor. Earlier this year, she got another $1.5 million from venture-capital funds, based on the business's good health.
As an alternative to the old venture-capital system, the S.B.A. has organized the Angel Capital Electronic Network on the Internet, at www.sba.gov/advo, and has won approval from 28 states to allow companies to register and seek investors. Using the network lets companies avoid the cumbersome and expensive process of registering state by state. The project, which is just getting off the ground, has produced few results so far.
So the portrait of female entrepreneurs may show encouraging signs of growth, but high hurdles remain. More than 80 percent of the businesses are in traditionally female areas: 52 percent are service businesses; 19 percent are retail, and 10 percent are finance, insurance or real estate. And nearly three-fourths of the female-owned firms operating in 1991 were still in business three years later, compared with two-thirds of all American firms, according to an S.B.A. survey.
As Ms. Henry sees it, there has been important progress since the time when, not so long ago, "some of the best ideas for women died in bank parking lots."
The Clinton Administration, Ms. Henry said, has made a priority of increasing the number of female-owned businesses. And after Congressional hearings in 1994, when many women complained about getting short shrift from banks, a program to help women prepare loan applications began.
"Many had service businesses that don't have widgets on the shelves that banks like to take over," Ms. Henry said. To compensate for the lack of traditional collateral, she added, "we take women to intermediaries who shine those bank packages up to a fare-thee-well."
And there is tremendous growth, at least by percentage, for women in nontraditional businesses, like construction companies and computer services, she said. "Women are into everything," Ms. Henry said. "And women have done this in the face of big cultural barriers."

LENGTH: 964 words

HEADLINE: It's Her Label and She'll Sign Who She Wants To

BYLINE: By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
WHEN Bettina Richards was an artist-and-repertory executive for big recording companies, she didn't like the way they treated musicians. Her favorite bands were ignored if they weren't best sellers; one lead singer, who went on to make a gold album, was told he shouldn't be singing at all.
"I wasn't happy," Ms. Richards said. "I was making money, but I couldn't talk to anyone about the great show I saw last night or the great record I found. It was a job." 
 So in 1992, she started her own company: Thrill Jockey Records, named after a gang of delinquents in a B movie. It would release music she cared about and let the musicians decide what to release, how to package it and how to run their careers. "I wanted a company where the artists' expectations and the labels' abilities were in line," she said. "I don't think major labels are inherently evil or out to destroy the world. I just don't happen to use music that fits their system."
That music, Ms. Richards said, is simply "what I like." Thrill Jockey is a leading outlet for what some critics have named "post-rock": instrumentals that elude categorization as jazz, pop tunes or dance music. The label's best-selling band is Tortoise, whose most recent album has sold nearly 100,000 copies worldwide.
But Thrill Jockey has also released albums by the neo-Appalachian duo Freakwater, two women who sing about hard times; the electronic group Oval, which has built compositions on the sounds of skipping CD's, and the Nerve, a peppy alternative-rock band.
"It's kind of freaky, left-of-center stuff that she puts out, but at the same time there's a big enough audience so that she can make a living," said Nic Harcourt, the creative music director of KCRW-FM in Santa Monica, Calif., and the host of the station's "Morning Becomes Eclectic," a program that the music business on the West Coast follows closely.
In six years, Thrill Jockey has released 60 albums (both as CD's and old-fashioned vinyl LP's), singles and EP's. All but three releases have broken even or turned a profit. By contrast, 80 percent to 90 percent of albums from major labels post losses. But Thrill Jockey works on a grass-roots scale, seeking sales in thousands rather than millions; its typical release breaks even with sales of 1,500 CD's and 500 LP's. Last year, Thrill Jockey's profit was $183,000, and while that is probably less than what Columbia Records spends on catering, it is a success story in independent rock.
Until last year, Ms. Richards, who is 33 years old, did everything herself, from signing talent to lining up band interviews. Now Thrill Jockey has three other full-time employees and one part timer and is about to buy its own small building.
Ms. Richards started Thrill Jockey while working four days a week at Pier Platters, an alternative-rock record store in Hoboken, N.J. She ran the label from her third-floor walk-up apartment on Avenue C in Manhattan, carrying mail-order CD's to U.P.S. because she didn't ship enough to qualify for a pickup. Her capital was $20,000 from her grandmother, $10,000 from her father and the $5,000 from her savings account; she has never needed another infusion. Her business advisers were people who had started their own labels.
"I was constantly asking advice from people: cheaper places to press things, ways to cut corners," she said. "One thing about independently distributed record labels is that you don't get this competitive feeling. As long as you are willing to reciprocate with information, people are happy to give it."
In 1995, Ms. Richards moved from New York to Chicago, where her main manufacturer and distributor, Touch and Go, is based. Rent and taxes are considerably lower than they are in New York, she noted.
Many independent companies are stepping stones for bands that hope to be discovered by major labels. By contract, the smaller labels then share in the profits from the major-label releases. "I don't want to spend my time as a farm label," Ms. Richards said. "From a business standpoint, it would be better to have bands bound to contracts so I'd get a piece of their future. But I don't want to make money from a system I don't support."
Thrill Jockey makes unusually generous deals with musicians. Once an album breaks even, the label and the musicians each get 50 percent of the gross receipts. "When the net comes down, they actually get more than me," Ms. Richards said. Contracts are often literally a handshake.
Ms. Richards chooses bands that, she thinks, can benefit from the scale of her company and will stay. "If becoming famous is their primary focus, then we're not the right label for them," she said. "But if they want to continue to make music and live off that, then that's a goal we can achieve."
Thrill Jockey records most albums for under $3,000, one three-hundredth of what a band like U2 spends, and advertises sparingly. Video clips tend to be made by friends of the bands or as projects by art students, though they have been shown occasionally on MTV. Thrill Jockey depends largely on the unpaid promotion of college radio stations and reviews in the press, but it also uses club disk jockeys and skateboarding magazines to reach consumers.
"Each record is totally different," Ms. Richards said. "It's not as if I sold a really great new garbage can or a nice clock. Your most popular band this year could be completely unpopular next year. My company has to be flexible and adapt.
"I want my company to stay in business and do well," she said. "But the creative stuff was always the motivation that sparked it. It wasn't, I see a way to make money better. It was, I can make this artist's experience better.
"This is a lot of work," Ms. Richards added. "But it never feels like a job."

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 2; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 2400 words

HEADLINE: Vive la Pizza: Simple, Rustic and, Yes, French

BYLINE: By MARK BITTMAN 

 BODY:
EVEN though the French influence is everywhere in New York's culinary world, a few foods that are common in France have managed to escape the city's dragnet and remain almost unknown here. The French pizza is one stunning example. Yes, pizza. Although it is most often known as a pissaladiere, it is what it is: a round, flat bread, crisp on the bottom, simply garnished on top, rustic and yet urbane.
At first, I couldn't remember seeing even one here, but recently I went searching for these French pizzas, with some success. At the restaurant Provence in SoHo, there is in fact a pissaladiere that gets it just right: a serving of leavened bread with a thin, brittle crust on the bottom and, on the top, a blanket of golden sauteed onions and a bit of anchovy. At Picholine on the Upper West Side, a similar but smaller pissaladiere is sometimes offered as an appetizer. Another kind of French pizza, the tarte flambee of Alsace, usually served with bacon, chopped onion and a touch of the creamy cheese called fromage blanc, is a study in achieving complex flavors and textures with the minimum number of ingredients. Mercer Kitchen in SoHo serves one version. 
 Beyond these, the offerings are sparse, indeed. But travel through the regions of France with your eyes open for anything that looks like pizza, and you'll come back impressed not only by how plentiful these pizzas are but also by their variety. Some, like the galette de Perouges, are sweet rather than savory. And many of them are served at room temperature.
In fact the pizzas of France and Italy, despite having different tendencies in herbs and cheese, have more in common with each other than they do with most of those produced here. Most American pizzas appeal to the national tendency toward excess, and they have been corrupted into serving as a complete meal -- a weighty concoction consisting of a ton of chewy mozzarella and a host of strong-flavored ingredients loaded onto a crust that, whether thick or thin, can barely support its toppings.
In Italy, most pizzas are exactly in the spirit of the pissaladiere and the tarte flambee, often with toppings that are no more than a sprinkling of rosemary, salt and olive oil. Or more elaborately, there is the addition of a few slices of tomato and a little fresh mozzarella, with the cheese lighter and less stringy than what we're used to.
That simplicity is more in keeping with the origin of pizza, which probably occurred spontaneously in different places. The likeliest explanation is this:
In areas where bread was a staple, communal ovens were traditionally fired up only once or twice a week. Since large loaves keep better than smaller ones, the standard loaf was four to nine pounds. It was only natural for the frugal bakers to throw the remaining scraps of dough into the oven while it was heating. Some dough was undoubtedly formed into small loaves -- rolls, essentially -- and some was patted into flat, pielike breads that cooked almost instantly. The temptation to top these flat breads with whatever was around was obviously irresistible. The result was pizza, or whatever you want to call it. The variations from one region to another might be merely matters of nuance or effort.
The Provencal version of the pissaladiere, for instance, is often garnished with two of the region's signature ingredients: black olives and sliced tomatoes, both in minuscule amounts by our standard. It is usually served at room temperature as often as not because in Provence, and throughout France, pizza is snack bread. Since it lacks gobs of cheese congealing on top, it retains its appeal even when cool.
Perhaps the best pissaladiere I ever had was served at Cours Saleya, the wonderful open-air market in the heart of old Nice. It was baked in a wood-burning oven a few blocks away, sent to the market by bicycle and eaten standing up or at picnic tables shaded by huge awnings. The wedges were gently sweet and intensely salty; the crust, just a half-inch thick, was perfumed with the local olive oil and was perfectly browned and crisp. It was so simple -- mostly just sweet onions on a wonderful crust. And yet it was so much more.
If pissaladiere is the most familiar of the French pizzas, galette de Perouges is the most surprising. This is the best-known product of Perouges, a well-preserved and perfectly restored medieval village not far from Lyons. Although galette is a word used for many free-form tarts in France, this particular galette seems more familiar than most: a large, round pie, slid into an oven on a paddle and cut into crisp wedges.
On closer inspection, however, and especially on tasting, this is no common variation on pizza. The crust is rich and sweet -- a yeasted dough made with butter and sugar, and rolled nearly flat. And the topping is butter and sugar; no more. Since this is remarkably fertile farmland, one of the most productive areas of France, it is perhaps not surprising that its pizza is supremely rich.
The galette is baked in a hot oven until the sugar caramelizes and the crust becomes brittle; unlike most pizzas, this dough is not chewy but crunchy. You can buy slices of the galette on the street, but it is best eaten as served at the Ostellerie du Vieux Perouges, the 500-year-old hotel-restaurant in the center of town. There, it is presented as a more formal dessert, with fresh fruit and a toupin, or tub, of creme fraiche.
The tarte flambee of Alsace may be the world's northernmost indigenous and legitimate pizza. You see it everywhere, although it is most common in the north, around Strasbourg. Alsace is French, of course, but the food, language and appearance are quite German in character. In this regional crossroads, there are many variations, based largely on the background of the baker.
Tarte flambee is a bit puffier and less flat than most pizza. Although it is usually spread with fromage blanc, bacon and onion before baking, there are many variations.
"The differences are usually based on religion," said Norbert Mueller, the owner of Chez Norbert, a restaurant in Bergheim, a village in Alsace. "Protestants, who are economical, often use much less cheese; Jews, who don't eat pork, omit the bacon, and Catholics make them as rich as possible." This last generalization may be based on the fact that Friday -- traditionally a meatless day for Catholics -- was also the day on which many ovens were fired up, so a rich tarte flambee might have been the day's main meal.
Whatever the variation, there is a peculiar convention in tarte flambee: Each wedge is rolled from the wide crust end to its point, and the rolls are eaten end to end.
Since French pizzas are so difficult to find outside France -- and are among the easiest of all pizzas to make -- it makes sense to try them at home. Drawing inspiration from what I tasted in France, and from Charles Van Over's book, "The Best Bread Ever" (Broadway, 1997), I recreated three French pizza recipes.
I took a couple of liberties, for simplicity's sake. First, I used the same dough for both pissaladiere and tarte flambee; a classic tarte flambee's dough would be made without the olive oil I use here, but I think it only enhances it.
Second, the best tarte flambee uses onions that have been salted for a day or so; salting draws out their water, which makes them milder and helps them to brown. It's a nice refinement, but not essential. And assuming that few people have access to fromage blanc, I substituted a combination of sour cream and milk, which I believe works equally well; it also makes a good stand-in for creme fraiche, if you want to serve it with a galette de Perouges.
Finally, my pizza dough recipe makes enough for two pizzas; if you're baking only one, wrap the remaining dough in plastic and freeze it for as long as a month. Then, just bring it to room temperature and pick up right where you left off.
 
DOUGH FOR PISSALADIERE OR TARTE FLAMBEE
 
Time: at least 1 hour
 1 teaspoon instant or rapid-rise yeast
 3 cups (about 14 ounces) all-purpose or bread flour, plus more as needed
 2 teaspoons salt
 2 tablespoons plus 1 teaspoon olive oil.
 
 1. Combine yeast, flour and salt in food processor. Turn machine on, and add 1 cup water and 2 tablespoons oil through feed tube.
 2. Process for about 30 seconds, adding more water through feed tube, a little at a time, until mixture forms a ball and is slightly sticky to the touch. If it is dry, add another tablespoon or two of water, and process for another 10 seconds. (In unlikely event that mixture is too sticky, add flour, a tablespoon at a time.)
 3. Turn dough onto floured work surface, and knead by hand for a few seconds to form a smooth, round ball. Grease bowl with remaining olive oil, and place dough in it. Cover with plastic wrap or damp cloth, and let rise in warm, draft-free area until dough just about doubles in size, or at least 1 hour. (You can also let dough rise more slowly, in refrigerator, for as long as 6 or 8 hours.)
 4. Follow recipe for pissaladiere or tarte flambee.
 Yield: Enough dough for 2 pizzas, each approximately 12 inches.
 
TARTE FLAMBEE
 
Time: 45 to 60 minutes
 
Dough for 1 tart (see recipe)
Flour for sprinkling over dough
Oil for baking sheet
1 cup fromage blanc or creme fraiche, or 3/4 cup sour cream thinned with 1/3 cup milk
 1/3 to 1/2 cup minced onions
 1/3 to 1/2 cup minced bacon
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
 
1. Preheat oven to at least 500 degrees (600 is better, if your oven goes that high). Knead dough lightly, and place it on a lightly floured surface; sprinkle it with a little more flour, and cover with plastic wrap or towel. Let it rest while oven heats.
 2. Pat or roll out dough as thinly as possible to diameter of 12 inches, using more flour or oil as necessary. The process will be easier if you allow dough to rest occasionally between rollings. If you have a pizza stone in your oven, place dough on a floured peel, or long-handled board; if you do not, lay dough on baking sheet brushed lightly with olive oil. Let dough rest for 15 to 30 minutes, or until it begins to puff ever so slightly.
 3. Spread fromage blanc or alternatives on dough. Sprinkle with onions, bacon, a little salt and plenty of pepper. Bake until nicely crisp, about 10 minutes; if tart is browning unevenly, rotate it back to front about halfway through cooking time. Serve hot.
 Yield: about 4 servings.
 
PISSALADIERE
 
Time: about 60 minutes
 
 Dough for 1 pizza (see recipe)
 Flour for sprinkling dough
 3 tablespoons olive oil
 1 1/2 pounds onions, peeled and thinly sliced
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
 1 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves, or 1/2 teaspoon ground thyme
 6 to 10 anchovies (optional)
 About 12 good pitted black olives, cut in half (optional)
 6 to 8 thin slices of tomato (optional).
 
 1. Preheat oven to 450 degrees. Knead dough lightly, and place it on lightly floured surface; sprinkle it with a little more flour, and cover with plastic wrap or towel. Let rest while oven heats and you cook the onions.
 2. Place olive oil in large skillet, and turn heat to medium-high. Add onions, along with some salt and pepper, and cook, stirring frequently, until onions give up their liquid and become quite soft, at least 15 minutes; do not allow onions to brown. When they are cooked, turn off heat and stir in thyme.
 3. Pat or roll out dough as thinly as possible to diameter of 12 inches, using more flour or oil as necessary. The process will be easier if you allow dough to rest occasionally between rollings. If you have a pizza stone in your oven, place dough on a floured peel, or long-handled board; if you do not, lay dough on baking sheet brushed lightly with olive oil. Let dough rest for 15 to 30 minutes, or until it begins to puff ever so slightly.
 4. Spread dough with onions, and then decorate, if you like, with anchovies, olives, and tomato. Bake until nicely crisp, 15 minutes or more; if tart is browning unevenly, rotate it back to front about halfway through cooking time. Serve hot or at room temperature.
 Yield: about 4 servings.
 
GALETTE DE PEROUGES
 
Time: about 2 hours
 
 1 teaspoon instant or rapid-rise yeast
 2 cups flour, plus more for sprinkling
 Pinch salt
 1/4 cup plus 1 tablespoon sugar
 1stick cold unsalted butter, cut into chunks
 1 egg
 Zest of 1 lemon
 1 stick unsalted butter, softened.
 
 1. Combine yeast, flour, salt, tablespoon of sugar, cold butter, egg and lemon zest in food processor. Turn machine on, let it run for a second until mixture is blended, and then let machine run while you add 1/4 cup water through feed tube, a little at a time, until mixture forms a ball and is slightly sticky to the touch. If it is dry, add another tablespoon or 2 of water, and process for another 10 seconds. (In the unlikely event that mixture is too sticky, add flour, a tablespoon at a time.)
 2. Turn dough onto very lightly floured work surface, and knead by hand for a few seconds to form a smooth, round ball. Place in a bowl, covered with plastic wrap or damp cloth, and let rise in warm, draft-free area until dough just about doubles in size, or at least 1 hour. (You can also let dough rise more slowly, in refrigerator, for as long as 6 or 8 hours.)
 3. Preheat oven to at least 500 degrees (600 is better, if your oven goes that high). Knead dough lightly, and place it on a very lightly floured surface; sprinkle it with a little more flour, and cover with plastic wrap or towel. Let it rest while oven heats.
 4. Pat or roll out dough as thinly as possible to a diameter of 12 inches, using a little more flour if necessary. The process will be easier if you allow dough to rest occasionally between rollings. If you have a pizza stone in your oven, place dough on a floured peel, or long-handled board; if you do not, lay dough on lightly buttered baking sheet.
 5. Spread dough with softened butter, and sprinkle it with remaining sugar. Bake until crust is nicely crisp and sugar lightly caramelizes, about 10 minutes; if galette is browning unevenly, rotate it back to front about halfway through cooking time. Serve hot or at room temperature as a snack, or at room temperature with creme fraiche and cut-up ripe fruit.
 Yield: about 6 servings.

HEADLINE: HOT SPOTS/SILICORN VALLEY;
Meditating for Fun and Profit

BYLINE: By ANDREW BLUTH 

DATELINE: FAIRFIELD, Iowa

 BODY:
LOCALS call this town, tucked in the rolling hills of southeastern Iowa, Silicorn Valley. And while the landscape is covered with cornfields, the economy in this valley of 10,000 thrives largely on its abundance of start-up companies, many of them high-tech.
Indeed, Fairfield has attracted entrepreneurs from around the country, in addition to having a few who are native, and many of the start-ups have become multimillion-dollar international corporations. 
 What brings these creative business minds to this corner of Iowa? The majority are followers of Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, the leader of the Transcendental Meditation movement who purchased the campus of the bankrupt Parsons College here in 1974 and turned it into Maharishi University of Management.
With the Maharishi came hundreds of believers, many of whom already had business experience and diverse backgrounds. One of these is 47-year-old Cliff Rees, who came from the East Coast to Fairfield in 1985 as a co-owner of an oil company. He started Telegroup in 1989 with a friend and fellow meditator, Fred Gratzon, a 52-year-old who used to be an ice cream vendor in Fairfield.
At first the company hired a handful of other friends from the T.M. community, but now it employs more than 600 people and is the 13th largest long-distance telecommunications company in the United States. (In 1997, its total revenues were $337 million.) A Telegroup competitor, USA Global Link, is also headquartered in Fairfield and was founded by another T.M. adherent.
Sitting cross-legged in his office, Mr. Rees called meditation "a great business tool that clears my mind and allows me to focus on detail."
Maharishi University says it does not offer seed money to companies owned by T.M. people. Yet the T.M. community has played a major role in the birth of many start-ups by providing expertise.
The old guard's acceptance of new, diverse ideas has been equally instrumental. The business atmosphere is highly charged, encouraging enterprising behavior not normally found in such small settings.
But while Fairfield's leaders have welcomed the prosperity that the university has brought, they also point out that a lot of Fairfield's best entrepreneurs are in fact Iowans (but not necessarily T.M. followers).
In 1978, Dick Smith, who is not a student of T.M., founded Agri-Industrial Products. Now his company has nearly 100 employees and is the country's largest producer of orange roadside construction barrels and dozens of other plastic products.
Mr. Smith said that Fairfield has a history of entrepreneurship predating Maharishi University, and that once the groundwork is laid, it becomes even easier for new companies to develop. "There's a ripple effect," he said. "Some companies spin off new companies, and it just continues to grow."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fairfield, Iowa, is home to a mix of high-tech and agribusiness ventures. (Linda Kahlbaugh for The New York Times)
