HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Science and a Business, a Saver and a Killer

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

BLOOD
An Epic History of Medicine and Commerce
By Douglas Starr
Illustrated. 441 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50
Douglas Starr points out early in this "Epic History of Medicine and Commerce" that when human blood has been broken down into derivative products, its market value is 1,600 times that of refined petroleum: about $40 for a barrel of oil compared with $67,000 for an equivalent quantity of blood. Blood, in other words, is not just a compelling, mystical symbol of the spirit of life; it is a commodity and is medically indispensable. In "Blood," Mr. Starr, the co-director of the Graduate Program in Science Journalism at Boston University, has written a fascinating history of blood, both as a challenge for scientific understanding and as a product of global business. 
 Scientific understanding, of course, had to come first, and some of the most absorbing parts of Mr. Starr's story involve excursions into medical history, when the role of blood in the body was determined and the practice of transfusing it was invented. The tales of early experimenters, like Jean-Baptiste Denis of France and the members of the Experimental Philosophy Club at Oxford, are science history at a high and exciting level. Mr. Starr covers the early experiments by which sick humans were transfused with animal blood, explaining not only why such experiments were bound to fail but why the early experimenters actually believed they had achieved some success.
These early transfusers were terribly wrong in their methods, but Mr. Starr reminds us of the major contribution they made to science. Before them, the human condition was believed to be a matter of mysterious, semi-magical humors, one of which was blood. They determined that the body was a matter of "chemicals, vessels and pumps" with blood, previously deemed a kind of magical substance, a nutrient, a biological substance.
Mr. Starr moves on to an equally riveting chapter on the practice of bleeding, which endured for 2,500 years in the West despite the fact that in almost every case it did more harm than good. His portrait of Benjamin Rush, the American founding father whose fanatical, blind devotion to bleeding as a cure-all killed many of his patients, is a study in scientific obtuseness.
What Mr. Starr calls "the modern era of transfusion medicine" began in 1908 with the work of a French researcher named Alexis Carrel, who lived in New York. Carrell invented the technique of taking blood from one person and putting it into another, sometimes, when luck prevailed, saving lives. The principle that determined success or failure was, of course, blood type, unknown to Carrell. It was discovered around the turn of the century by a brilliant Viennese named Karl Landsteiner.
Mr. Starr traces each of the scientific steps by which blood could become a commodity, sketching in along the way some interesting side implications, such as the early use of blood type in criminal or paternity investigations and the historical significance of hemophilia in Russian history. (It brought the mystic healer Rasputin to the Romanov court.) But the bulk of the volume is devoted to the second element in the history of blood, its role as an increasingly important international product that had to be collected, broken down into its constituent parts, stored and sold.
"In every epoch, people had seen blood as more than it really was -- more than a liquid or component of their body, but as a reflection of their image and understanding of themselves," Mr. Starr writes. He is speaking of the way World War II accelerated research into the techniques of blood transfusion, so that a wounded soldier was given blood he had donated months before. "Blood, once held in religious regard, had been removed from a man's circulatory system, separated, processed, freeze-dried, packaged, shipped and reconstituted -- only to be injected into the same individual in a completely different form several months later and half a world away."
Mr. Starr tells all this in sprightly, vigorous fashion, smoothly explaining the technical side of things, adding colorful descriptions of a large international cast of characters here and there. Sometimes he piles on a bit too much detail, as, for example, when he describes the blood bank system as it evolved in a half-dozen countries. Still, the narrative generally moves briskly as Mr. Starr recounts the full and sometimes very dark story.
He tells, for example, of hideous experiments performed on prisoners by Josef Mengele-like Japanese researchers during the World War II, and, in the late 1960's and 70's, the morally troubling concentration of blood collection centers in poor countries like Nicaragua, which became a source of blood products for the rich, industrialized world. Vast profits were made by a new sort of entrepreneur, the international blood broker. In Nicaragua, this global economic system, in which the bodies of the poor were a kind of raw material for the rich, became a focus of revolutionary anger against the dictator Anastasio Somoza Debayle.
But Mr. Starr foreshadows his story, then ends it with the most troubling episode in the history of blood as a commodity: the spread of the AIDS virus in contaminated blood. His foreshadowing has to do with the sensational 1992 trial of four French bureaucrats, three of whom were convicted of failing to stop the use of H.I.V.-contaminated blood products in thousands of transfusions. Mr. Starr's history of this incident is a gripping piece of reporting.
He stresses the French illusion that, because their blood collection system was based entirely on voluntary, unpaid donations, the supply was safe. And even when that illusion died, the failure to adopt sterilization techniques and the unwillingness to destroy valuable stocks of available blood "condemned thousands of French citizens to AIDS."
For a time, in other words, blood became a dubious commodity, one that killed as well as saved, until effective steps were taken to insure the safety of the product. The efforts to do that mark a final chapter in a rich story admirably told in this book.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Douglas Starr (Stephen B. Soumerai/Alfred A. Knopf)

LENGTH: 693 words

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
A Rape and Beating, Later 3 Murders And Then the Twist

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
The young women whom Brandon Teena dated all agree about one thing. Brandon, a fresh-faced 21-year-old Nebraskan who was raped and beaten by two acquaintances on Christmas Eve in 1993, then shot to death with two others by the same pair a week later, knew how to treat a woman. He was courtly and sent flowers and was an excellent kisser. Growing up, the star he most idolized was Cher.
Even after Brandon's girlfriend, Lana Tisdel, discovered he was really a woman (he was born Teena Brandon) undergoing hormone therapy in anticipation of a possible sex change operation, she did not recoil in horror. But in the eyes of Brandon's male friends, Thomas Nissen and John Lotter, two shiftless young men from the rural Nebraska town of Falls City, to which he had just moved from Lincoln, once they discovered his sex, he became a freak. They felt at once betrayed and sickened. 
 "The Brandon Teena Story," Susan Muska and Greta Olafsdottir's riveting, understated documentary, bends over backward not to sensationalize a murder case that encapsulates the deep-seated fears about gender and alternative sexuality harbored by millions of Americans, especially those living in the heartland. Falls City, an economically depressed small town with an all-white population of just under 5,000, epitomizes that sprawling rural and semi-rural section of the United States that might be described as the Land of the Pickup Truck.
Those who live and work here may have heard of gay liberation, but they've never met an uncloseted gay or transgendered person and have no desire to do so. Although Falls City prides itself on being a close-knit, God-fearing community, we learn that it has a high rate of domestic violence. You can sense these ominous undercurrents during a scene at a local demolition derby where all the men are toting guns.
The film methodically interviews the surviving principals, including the killers, both of whom were convicted of first-degree murder and are now in prison, one of them (Mr. Lotter) on death row. We meet Brandon's parents, who talk sympathetically about their dead child's troubled life. Brandon had suicidal tendencies, and having no other means of support, eked out a living by forging checks.
When we first meet the killers, who are interviewed separately, they seem nice enough, although we later learn that each had already served time in prison. As they recall their early friendship with Brandon, it's obvious that they liked him and were fooled by his sexual charade. What's so unnerving about the movie, which opens today at the Film Forum, is how unemotional most of their recollections are. Their voices are as flat and uninflected as the austere Nebraskan landscape.
The film's most casually horrifying note is sounded by the sheriff in charge of the rape case, who offhandedly refers to the victim as "it." Because of his failure to prosecute the rape case vigorously, Mr. Nissen and Mr. Lotter were free to track Brandon down at a farmhouse on New Year's Eve and kill Brandon and his companions, 24-year-old Lisa Lambert and her friend Philip Devine, a visitor who happened to be at the wrong place at the wrong time.
The grisly details of the murders are reconstructed through audio recordings made during Mr. Nissen's 1995 murder trial. Mr. Nissen, in exchange for testifying against Mr. Lotter, was spared the death penalty but sentenced to three consecutive life terms. Mr. Lotter's appeals are awaiting review by the United States Supreme Court.
"The Brandon Teena Story" shows us that in the Land of the Pickup Truck, the hatred and fear of unorthodox sexuality run deep. Instead of being shouted, it festers until it explodes in acts of violence whose cause even the killers themselves don't seem to comprehend fully.
 
THE BRANDON TEENA STORY
 
Produced, edited and directed by Susan Muska and Greta Olafsdottir; directors of photography, Ms. Muska and Ms. Olafsdottir; music by Lorrie Morgan, Dinah Washington, April Stevens and the Brown Brothers; released by Zeitgeist Films. At the Film Forum, 209 Houston Street, South Village. Running time: 90 minutes. This film is not rated.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lana Tisdel, left, the last girlfriend of Brandon Teena, right. (Zeitgeist Films)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: That's a Wrap: A Fad's Fade-Out

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
JUST last summer, Wrap-a-Rama was a bustling, happy little food shop on lower Second Avenue in Manhattan, serving up yummy meals with names like "Tikka Break" and drinks like strawberry-banana smoothies. Regulars crowded in for the wraps -- burrito style sandwiches filled with foods from around the world, like Indian chicken or Greek salad -- and to sit at painted tables and watch the East Village go by.
Then one day, Wrap-a-Rama was gone. So was the Wrap Shack, its competitor around the corner. The story was the same in major cities from Chicago to Los Angeles. 
 Just two years ago, tiny stores selling wraps sprang up like weeds, enticing curious eaters with their eclectic ingredients and low-caloric, healthful claims.
But like so many food trends whose allure is their hipness factor, many wrap shops were mowed down by fast-moving competitors or by mainstream food purveyors like Wendy's and Au Bon Pain, which both offered cheaper knockoffs.
Indeed wraps, like so many start-up concepts, were in many ways victims of their own success, signaling a cautionary tale for other future restaurateurs and food purveyors. Not unlike crepes in the 70's, frozen yogurt in the 80's and juice bars in this decade, wraps have been co-opted, and in many cases, defeated.
"When we opened the store in 1996, it was very good," said Ranjit Singh, the owner of the defunct Wrap-a-Rama, which he got going with $120,000 in personal savings combined with money from two partners. "But then a lot of other food operators started offering wrap variations, and suddenly you didn't have to go to wrap stores anymore. We were just breaking even."
At its height, the shop brought in sales of about $1,300 a week, but profits were scant.
It could be that the concept is not special enough, said Mr. Singh, who returned to his native London to work in a conveyor-belt sushi restaurant, in which you sit and the food travels by.
"Food is like clothing," he said. "If there is a hot item at Macy's, it will be all over the New York streets. Then it's only in fashion a short while. I now call that my M.B.A. year."
Although there are no numbers on wrap-store start-ups and failures, most food-industry experts agree it has been a volatile business. No one knew the volatility would come so quickly.
"In all my years in the food business," said David Barrows, the chief executive of World Wrapps, an early wrap chain, "I have never seen anything copied so fast or in so many numbers. Even the story of how this business was started was copied."
The great wrap struggle also underscores how risky food businesses are in comparison with other start-up retail ventures.
"More Americans want to start restaurants than anything else, and yet restaurants have the highest failure rate," said Rieva Lesonsky, the editorial director of Entrepreneur magazine.
Unlike accessories stores, for example, food shops are expensive to open. You need a stove, a giant refrigerator and other storage places, as well as packaging for the finished product and plenty of labor. There are health regulations that are costly to meet, and copycats spring up almost instantaneously, since it's difficult to keep the ingredients of a gussied-up sandwich a secret.
The genesis of the wrap has become part of entreprenurial lore. Four supereducated pals, Matthew Blair, Keith Cox, Eduardo Rallo Verdugo and Will Weisman, were vacationing in Mexico in 1994, trying to think of a joint business venture. Recalling their love of burritos, they came up with the wrap. The first store, World Wrapps, in San Francisco, was capitalized with a small investment from friends.
First-year sales were about $1 million. Two of the founders returned to business school, but two remained on the management team. Today, World Wrapps has 26 stores altogether in California and in Seattle. Refusing to give sales or earnings figures, Mr. Barrows, the chief executive, said there are plans for more stores.
When they came on the market, wraps seemed to fit perfectly with eating and life-style trends of the 90's: billed as more healthful than sandwiches -- which in many cases was a function of marketing, not reality -- and often sold in combination with fresh-fruit smoothie drinks, they played on Americans' obsession with eating better on the run.
The wrap also invoked fusion foods, which mix ingredients from two or more cultures, a fad that persists in other restaurants as well. Wraps may have a south-of-the-border look, but can be stuffed with Thai chicken, Caribbean shrimp or goat cheese.
With so much going for it, why did the fad fizzle, leaving so many entrepreneurs belly up?
"A wrap is a menu category," said Dennis Lombardi, who runs the restaurant group at Technomic, a food-service consulting firm in Chicago. "But it is not necessarily the basis for a whole line of concepts."
AS a menu category, many fast-food chains have been quick to steal it. TGI Friday's, Wendy's, Long John Silver and Au Bon Pain are just a few of the large chains that added wraps to their menus after World Wrapps took off. Although their versions were less exotic and not as fresh, they were less expensive and, compared with the hamburgers and fried fish being sold alongside them, seemed less sinful in terms of fat and calories.
The mainstream's acceptance raised the wrap's profile but also diluted its coolness, which for many wrap entrepreneurs was disastrous.
"I think there has been overexposure," said James Pappas, who owns Original Wrap City, a Manhattan store.
Moreover, wraps are essentially a lunchtime meal; a wrap shop cannot cater easily to a breakfast or a dinner crowd, when McDonald's and the like are buzzing. "And there is lots of competition for lunch," Mr. Lombardi said. "If you have a group going to lunch, and one person vetos the wrap place, they all go to Wendy's, and the person who wants a wrap can get one there."
Consumers hold wrap stores to tougher standards than other fast-food establishments when it comes to quality. "I think consumers care more about what is in the wrap than the wrap themselves," said John McMillen, a food analyst at Prudential Securities. "And maybe some of those stores didn't cut it in the middle."
Such was the case of Todo Wraps, a Seattle-based chain that World Wrapps acquired a year and a half ago. Mr. Barrows said that when they picked up the chain, the company's locations were strong, but it was selling a limited menu with dull vegetable wraps and cheaper meats and fish than World Wrapps used. Fresh salmon and exotic spices were added, and those stores have much higher sales now, he says, though he declined to give financial information about the company.
Suffice it to say that variety counts. World Wrapps offers 18 different types (most stores offer about 10), and the teriyaki chicken and other fillings can be purchased over rice, not wrapped.
Julie Malveaux, a spokeswoman for the National Restaurant Association in Washington, was more direct. "I can't say why certain wrap restaurants are closing," she said. "But what I notice about the ones that are viable is that they have changing menus, pairing wraps with smoothies or other health-conscious drinks. They remind me of coffee shops when they first took off."
Mr. Barrows suggested a slightly different recipe for surviving and thriving. "Taking the high-quality road makes for a success," he said. "But it is not easy to do that."

HEADLINE: A Museum In Mexico Suddenly Shuts Down

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 22

 BODY:
With no fanfare and surprisingly little mourning, a museum that critics had extolled as Mexico's finest forum for modern art was closed on Sunday, a victim of cost slashing at the leading television network, Televisa.
The museum, the Cultural Center for Contemporary Art, shut its doors at the Spartan but spacious rust-colored building where it had offered 172 exhibitions over 12 years, including authoritative retrospectives of Mexican artists like the painter Maria Izquierdo and the photographers Manuel Alvarez Bravo and his first wife, Lola. 
 The museum was created from scratch out of a collaboration between Emilio Azcarraga Milmo, the billionaire owner of Televisa, who died last year; his friend Robert R. Littman, a New Yorker who directed the museum from its founding, and Paula Cussi, a Mexican actress whose love affair and eventual marriage to Mr. Azcarraga lasted two and a half decades.
The Cultural Center became a respectable stop on the international circuit, after shows like an affectionate 1987 homage to Leo Castelli, the New York art impresario, and a 1990 display of Salvador Dali works from the Reina Sofia National Art Museum in Madrid. Thriving on ample budgets from Televisa, the museum accumulated a distinctive collection of works by young artists from Mexico, the United States and Europe.
Although Televisa officials said the center would continue to operate as a museum-without-walls by lending its collection for shows in other spaces, considerable confusion seems to surround its future.
"Things are completely unclarified to me," Mr. Littman said. He said he would pack up the center's collection to store it in a warehouse at a Televisa complex in a suburb above the capital city.
Televisa officials have indicated that the building that housed the museum, originally a press center for the 1984 World Cup soccer championships, would be sold or let for commercial purposes yet to be determined.
For now, only 15 works from the permanent collection, by American artists including Edward Ruscha and Brice Marden, will be hung in the residence of the United States Ambassador, Jeffrey Davidow, which is not regularly open to the public.
Although there were few protests from Mexican artists, leaders of Mexico's art world were appalled by Televisa's decision to close the Cultural Center and dismiss its 120-member staff to save the $12 million devoted to its annual budget.
"This is like a divorce where only one party makes the decision," said Raquel Tibol, the longtime art critic for the weekly magazine Proceso. "It is an action by a private company that fails to respect the tacit cultural agreement between a museum and its public."
But Televisa officials said they could no longer afford the Cultural Center under the austerity regimen the company adopted after the death of Mr. Azcarraga, a strong-willed magnate known as the Tiger, who built his family's business into one of the largest media empires in the world. A son, Emilio Azcarraga Jean, who is 30, took over the conglomerate after his father's death.
Ms. Cussi had caught the elder Azcarraga's eye in the early days of her career at Televisa when she was reading horoscopes on the air. Although she had no expertise in modern art or experience as a museum curator, he made her chairwoman of the center and appointed Mr. Littman to direct it.
"Paula is a very smart lady and a very quick study," Mr. Littman said. "To stay with Emilio for 25 years, you have to know about politics, art, entertainment, economics. She was very conversant, and she spent a lot of time researching."
As the museum's reputation grew, Azcarraga's support became more enthusiastic. For most of his lifetime Televisa had a monopoly hammerlock on television in Mexico, and he was frequently criticized for producing crass programming to appeal to the lowest common denominator among Mexican viewers. The Cultural Center allowed him to show that he could make a sophisticated contribution to Mexican culture.
"He really enjoyed coming to the openings," Mr. Littman recalled. "It was an important part of his life. Emilio had many opportunities to kiss us goodbye, but he never did."
The museum's popularity in Mexico was established in 1988 with a show that brought together images of the Virgin of Guadalupe, Mexico's patroness saint. In 1990 Mr. Littman organized an exhibition by Robert Motherwell and other artists from around the world to illustrate essays of art criticism by Octavio Paz, the Mexican poet.
But relations between Ms. Cussi and the Azcarraga family cooled after the death of the elder Azcarraga, from whom she was separated in 1994. In August 1997 she severed her all her ties to Televisa when she sold the company shares that he had left her in his will, for a figure estimated in Mexican press reports at $40 million.
Initially the younger Mr. Azcarraga made a public pledge in front of all of Televisa's employees to keep the museum open. But financial pragmatism, in the wake of a punishing recession in 1995, prevailed.
Gaston Melo, a Televisa vice president, said the company was not planning to sell off the permanent collection.
"Selling has never been the point," Mr. Melo said. He said Televisa was negotiating with public universities and Government museums for shows of the collection.
The museum's demise provoked little outcry among Mexican artists, most of whom remain suspicious of Televisa. But its closing leaves the cultivation of modern art in Mexico almost entirely with Government museums.
"We provided an independent focus on the visual arts," Mr. Littman said. "We didn't have to do a show because the President of Mexico signed a peace treaty with Lower Slobovia."
Mrs. Tibol, the art critic, said: "There is absolutely no one left who can fill the void. No one even aspires to doing it. There is a spiritual reluctance to barge into the abandoned house that someone else built."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A gallery at the Cultural Center for Contemporary Art, now closed. (Keith Dannemiller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For Indie Films, 1979's Lark Turns Into This Year's Institution

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
When Sandra Schulberg rented a screening room in Manhattan in 1979 to show 20 new films to producers and distributors, she felt as if she was doing something radical. "The intention was to try to create an alternate film economy," said Ms. Schulberg, a filmmaker herself. "I did not see it becoming an institution."
Nearly 20 years later, independent films have become a regular part of the cultural vocabulary, and the Independent Feature Film Market started by Ms. Schulberg has become an important early showcase for films like "My Dinner With Andre," "Welcome to the Dollhouse," "Roger and Me" and "The Brothers McMullen." 
 This year's market, which began on Friday and runs through this Friday, includes some 700 filmmakers and about 1,300 other people in the industry who come to make connections and find new talent. Films are shown at the Angelika Film Center, at 18 West Houston Street in Greenwich Village, and surrounding locations.
Filmmakers who want to show their work submit videotapes with a registration fee of $275 to $450, depending on the length of the film and the timing of the submission. This year, the number of projects on the market, including unproduced scripts, is roughly 400, said Michelle Byrd, the executive director of the Independent Feature Project, the country's largest membership organization for independent filmmakers, which administers the market.
Among the more talked-about projects this year, Ms. Byrd said, are "LaMastas," described at the market's on-line site (www.ifp.org) as a " 'Forrest Gump' meets 'Goodfellas,' " and "The Accident," a memoir filmed over 25 years. Ken Liotti said his film "The Waiting Game" is also one of the "hot" ones. "The buzz we've gotten is incredible," Mr. Liotti said. "All the festivals have approached us. Now we're on the map, which is the purpose of doing it."
Mr. Liotti, 40, said he wrote, directed and produced his 88-minute film -- about the misadventures of struggling actors who wait on tables -- after writing for Hollywood and never seeing his films produced. "I've been in development hell for 10 years," he said. "I wanted to see one of my movies up on the screen."
In addition to screenings, the market features several seminars every day, including "Who's Who in the Documentary World," "Coaching Screenwriters: Accessing Resources and Developing Strategies" and "How to Pitch to HBO Documentary Programming."
This year's market will reunite several alumni and a screening series at the Anthology Film Archives, on Second Street at Second Avenue in the East Village, to highlight 10 of the market's major previous films, including "Down by Law," "Daughters of the Dust" and "Stand and Deliver."
In addition, the market will present its second annual Gordon Parks Awards, which gives $10,000 to an African-American director and $10,000 to an African-American screenwriter. The Independent Feature Project says these awards helped increase the participation of black filmmakers in the market over the last two years from 16 in 1996 to 55 this year.

HEADLINE: Needed: A Fed for the World

BYLINE: By Jeffrey E. Garten; Jeffrey E. Garten is dean of the Yale School of Management and the author of "The Big Ten: The Big Emerging Markets and How They Will Change Our Lives."

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
Even as emerging markets sink into depression and stocks plunge from Montreal to Melbourne, a global economy is slowly emerging, albeit in a tortuous and painful way. But governments seem paralyzed, unable to deal with both the crisis and the opportunity.
Today's chaotic international market mirrors how the American economy evolved between the Civil War and the 1930's. For well over half a century we, too, had booms and busts, countless bank failures, rampant bankruptcies. Capitalism was an uncontrollable Darwinian process, with big winners and big losers. 
 But over time the United States set up crucial central institutions -- the Securities and Exchange Commission (1933), the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (1934) and, most important, the Federal Reserve (1913). In so doing, America became a managed national economy. These organizations were created to make capitalism work, to prevent destructive business cycles and to moderate the harsh, invisible hand of Adam Smith.
This is what now must occur on a global scale. The world needs an institution that has a hand on the economic rudder when the seas become stormy. It needs a global central bank.
The sad fact is that we cannot rely on existing institutions or on national leaders for global economic stability.
The International Monetary Fund knows how to deal with one or a few countries at a time, but not an international phenomenon in which all countries' problems occur at once and are linked. The World Bank's mission has included financing big projects and alleviating poverty, but it is not designed for financial crises.
Simply trying to coordinate the world's powerful central banks -- the Fed and the new European Central Bank, for instance -- wouldn't work, either. If there is no inflation in the United States, the Fed won't lower interest rates simply because that would help, say, Southeast Asia. Such global responsibility is not in the Fed's charter. The European Central Bank, meanwhile, seems proud of its narrow focus on Europe. The result is inadequate attention to the three-quarters of the world consisting of emerging markets.
Effective collaboration among finance ministries and treasuries is also unlikely to materialize. These agencies are responsible to elected legislatures, and politics in the industrial countries is more preoccupied with internal events than with international stability.
An independent central bank with responsibility for maintaining global financial stability is the only way out. No one else can do what is needed: inject more money into the system to spur growth, reduce the sky-high debts of emerging markets, and oversee the operations of shaky financial institutions.
A global central bank could provide more money to the world economy when it is rapidly losing steam. For example, it could buy the bonds of the Central Bank of Brazil, thereby injecting hard currency into that country when it most needs the help (like right now). It would have the ability to buy a country's debt at steep discounts, a crucial need now because in countries like Thailand and Venezuela debts are piling up and preventing new lending and new investment. Ultimately a lot of this debt could be resold at a profit.
Such a bank would play an oversight role for banks and other financial institutions everywhere, providing some uniform standards for prudent lending in places like China and Mexico. The regulation need not be heavy-handed; providing clear and reasonably verified information to the market on the real state of banks around the world would be a leap forward. Investors could then make the informed judgments that they couldn't have made in, say, Russia or Indonesia.
None of these functions are being performed effectively now, and it will be impossible to have a world economy that doesn't resemble a reckless roller coaster unless they are.
There are two ways a global central bank could be financed. It could have lines of credit from all central banks, drawing on them in bad times and repaying when the markets turn up. Alternately -- and admittedly more difficult to carry out -- it could be financed by a very modest tariff on all trade, collected at the point of importation, or by a tax on certain global financial transactions.
One thing that would not be acceptable would be for the bank to be at the mercy of short-term-oriented legislatures. Witness how the United States Congress has consistently failed to provide new money for the I.M.F. even as the world economy slides toward deep recession.
A crucial political question is, To whom would a global central bank be accountable? It would have too much power to be governed only by technocrats, although it must be led by the best of them. One possibility would be to link the new bank to an enlarged Group of Seven -- perhaps a "G-15" that would include the G-7 plus rotating members like Mexico, Brazil, South Africa, Poland, India, China and South Korea.
Another issue is the relationship between a global bank and the Fed. There would have to be very close collaboration. The global bank would not operate within the United States, and it would not be able to override the decisions of our central bank. But it could supply the missing international ingredient -- emergency financing for cash-starved emerging markets. It wouldn't affect American mortgage rates, but it could help the profitability of American multinational companies by creating a healthier global environment for their businesses.
It is never easy to create a new institution; too many people have vested interests in the status quo. Moreover, when these new structures are most needed, officials are preoccupied with managing the current crisis. When calm is restored, attention turns to something else. But the current global financial slide, with no one at the center to limit the damage, is evidence enough that there is a huge gap in the structures necessary to make globalization work.
As the eminent economic historian Charles Kindleberger said in examining the causes of the Depression, "For the world economy to be stabilized, there has to be a stabilizer, one stabilizer." He was commenting on the lack of leadership by America in the 1930's. Today, with the United States still showing no appetite for such a role, a global central bank could be an enormous help.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Dip, in Unusual Tandem With Wall Street

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of United States Treasury securities fell for the first time in five days yesterday despite weakness in stocks.
Analysts said investors might have been a little reluctant to buy at current prices with yield levels, which move inversely to prices, already at historic lows. 
 The 30-year bond's price fell 19/32, to 105 8/32. Its yield rose to 5.15 percent, from 5.12 percent Monday.
For most of the last two months the bond market has derived strength from the selloff in stocks, reflecting moves by investors around the world to the relative safety of Treasury securities. So it was considered unusual that both bonds and stocks fell yesterday.
Some analysts attributed the bond weakness to uncertainty over what the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee will do at its meeting next Tuesday. While speculation has increased that the Federal Open Market Committee may move to lower rates, which could help soothe anxiety in global markets, there is no obvious reason for reduced rates in the United States, where the economy is showing resilience.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said, "At the very least, the F.O.M.C. will adopt a bias toward easing at this meeting, but the probability of an actual easing at this juncture has increased markedly and may well be more likely."
Others were more emphatic in their prediction that the Fed would move to ease rates. Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist at the DKB Securities (USA) Corporation, said in his latest market report that the Fed would take such a step because of deepening distress in emerging markets, the threat of global deflation and some signs of slowing economic growth in the United States.
Additional insight into the economy's performance will emerge later this week when the Commerce Department releases a revision to the second-quarter gross domestic product number, along with August data for durable goods orders, personal income and consumer spending.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, whose ambiguous remarks about interest rates last week contributed to a large selloff in stocks, will be testifying today before the Senate Budget Committee.
Also today, the Treasury will sell $15 billion of new two-year notes, which by late yesterday were being offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 4.62 percent.

HEADLINE: Keeping Asia Liquid

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Preventing World Recession" (editorial, Sept. 17): With roughly 40 percent of the world in recession, it is imperative that the International Monetary Fund be provided with the $18 billion requested by the Clinton Administration. But I.M.F. financing is only a first step. 
 The Federal Reserve should also cut interest rates and loosen monetary policy. This would provide the liquidity without which Asia, Eastern Europe and South America would fail to stabilize. The flight of dollars from the developing world and depreciating local currencies have prevented affected economies from recovering their economic footing.
Making capital more available to them through lower interest rates and greater cash flow would help countries like those along the Pacific Rim grow their way out of recession. The economic deterioration that continues in much of the world must be stopped, and it is up to the United States to lead.
 
JERRY J. JASINOWSKI
President, National
Association of Manufacturers
Washington, Sept. 17, 1998

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Trade Official Says China Market Is Closed Tighter

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 22

 BODY:
A senior American trade official today criticized what he called China's unwillingness to open its markets to foreign companies, and accused the Chinese of tightening some restrictions on foreign businesses.
The remarks by the official, David L. Aaron, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, reflected what has become an increasingly tense trade relationship between Beijing and Washington. 
 Mr. Aaron said China's policies had helped produce a $1 billion-a-week trade deficit for Americans. He said the United States would look for new ways to press China into allowing improved access for American businesses to the nation's 1.2 billion people if the situation did not improve. "They have taken this relationship for granted," Mr. Aaron said, adding later, "The list of barriers is just getting bigger and we're not crossing anything off the list -- that's the problem."
Mr. Aaron, who was in Beijing to attend a conference and meet with Chinese officials, offered hope that the huge trading partners could ultimately cooperate. But the polite discussions on trade that surrounded President Clinton's visit here this spring have evidently given way to exasperation and blunt talk. Mr. Aaron characterized his meetings with the Chinese as "somewhat somber."
"We recognize that the Chinese have lots of difficult problems to face," Mr. Aaron told a small group of reporters, listing the broad Asian economic crisis, troubled state-owned enterprises and this summer's disastrous floods. "But my job is to make sure that on that list of problems is this trade deficit and the treatment of businesses here."
United States figures show the trade deficit with China exceeding $50 billion annually, and growing.
Mr. Aaron's admonitions came after a tense few weeks in which new American regulations banned imported goods from China packed in untreated wood crates or pallets, a ban that may well affect more than half of Chinese exports to the United States.
American officials say the new requirements are necessary to prevent further invasions by the Asian long-horned beetle, which in the last two years has emerged from Chinese raw-wood packing material to kill thousands of trees in New York and Chicago. But Chinese trade officials say the regulations were motivated not by bugs but by protectionism.
"The unilateral action taken by the United States could impact the normal development of Sino-American trade," China's Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation said in a statement last week.
Although the United States has for years wanted Beijing to further open its markets, it had hoped China's stated desire to join the World Trade Organization would take care of the problem, since free markets are a condition of membership. But the Chinese Government has apparently accepted that it will not gain admission to the trade organization now, and the United States has been left to apply pressure on its own.
Today, Mr. Aaron said that barriers to American business in China seemed to be multiplying rather than shrinking.
He said, for example, that the authorities here had generally not let foreign companies develop a distribution network for their goods, and he complained of China's unwillingness to grant licenses to foreign companies in such service businesses as insurance. In the last few years, a number of American companies have established offices in Beijing, anticipating that such licenses would be approved.
Mr. Aaron also complained that the huge Chinese telecommunications market was mostly off limits to foreign companies and noted that the Government was contemplating banning the few foreign companies that had indirect investment in that industry.
China has created many more subtle barriers as well, Mr. Aaron said, such as increasingly cumbersome regulations on foreign currency transactions. He cited a resurgence in counterfeiting that was now so professional that copycat goods even carried fake Underwriters Laboratories seals.
"If W.T.O. isn't moving us toward market access and opening, we're going to have to find other methods," he said, adding that the Clinton Administration was now "looking at other options."
Officially, Mr. Aaron was in Beijing to attend a conference on Chinese energy needs and to talk to officials in preparation for the annual meeting of the Joint Committee on Commerce and Trade, a Chinese-American panel, in Washington next month. He said he was still optimistic that such joint forums could help resolve trade disputes, at least in some cases.
Chinese officials say the American trade deficit is not nearly as large as United States officials contend, maintaining that it is closer to $20 billion than $50 billion.

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 390 words

HEADLINE: Rising Costs in Health Care

 BODY:
A report by economists at the Department of Health and Human Services predicts that growth in health-care spending will increase substantially over the next 10 years. Total health expenditures are expected to rise from $1 trillion in 1996 to $2.1 trillion by 2007, jumping from 13.6 percent of gross domestic product to 16.6 percent. That is likely to translate into much higher health insurance premium increases than has been the case in recent years. These numbers are discouraging, particularly since the projections do not even reach the years when baby boomers will begin utilizing health care intensively in their late 60's and 70's.
The relatively low growth in spending of the past four years is actually an aberration from long-term trends, made possible by a rapid shift of American workers into managed-care plans from costly fee-for-service plans where there were few constraints on what doctors and hospitals could charge or patients could request. Many economists have said for some time, however, that this tamping down of costs is a one-time effect achieved mostly by getting price discounts out of hospital systems and squeezing down doctors' fees. 
 The long-term ability of managed care to control escalating costs is likely to be more modest. Although it can help by subjecting doctors' decisions to review and emphasizing preventive care, managed care has not been able to resist consumer demands for expensive technological procedures, a big driver of health spending. Changing practice standards and new and more expensive drugs will continue to push up spending even after managed care squeezes the easy-to-attack inefficiencies out of the health delivery system. The growth of point-of-service plans where enrollees have greater choice of doctors may further weaken managed care's ability to control costs.
This country already spends more on health care as a share of gross domestic product than any other nation, yet 41 million Americans have no health coverage at all. The shift toward managed care has produced a few good years of relatively stable costs. But it has not reduced the problem of the uninsured. With costs starting to accelerate again, the hope that managed care could extract enough savings out of the system to cover millions of uninsured Americans seems less and less likely.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Clinton and Obuchi Break Ice but Solve No Economic Problems

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
President Clinton and Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan met for the first time yesterday and struggled to reassure the markets that they agree on a common strategy to pull the world's second-largest economy out of a recession that is fueling economic turmoil on three continents.
But after nearly three hours of meetings in New York, the two leaders emerged with no agreement about what Japan will do about the trillion dollars in bad debts that have acted like an anchor on the world economy. 
 Their chief areas of agreement, aides said, were a shared concern about North Korea, a decision to meet again early next year and the politically mandatory promise to call each other by their first names.
While trying to sound upbeat, American officials acknowledge that they emerged from the meeting with no better sense of how Mr. Obuchi planned to resolve a politically paralyzing debate over the bank debt that is already threatening the Prime Minister's loose grasp on power.
The bad bank debts now overshadow trade disputes and growing security concerns in the Pacific as the No. 1 issue between the two countries. The tower of debt has frozen economic activity, forced Japan to keep insolvent banks afloat and set off waves of turmoil far beyond Japan's own shores.
In a brief and carefully stage-managed appearance with Mr. Obuchi, President Clinton acknowledged that an "immensely complicated political situation" in Japan limited the Prime Minister's options.
Indeed, the divisions among the political parties in Japan are so complex that Mr. Obuchi was unable to address Mr. Clinton's main concern: Tokyo's vow to use tens of billions of dollars in public funds to prop up some of the world's largest banks.
As the two men met, a political deal to merge or nationalize the virtually insolvent Long Term Credit Bank of Japan, a huge financial institution, appeared to be unraveling in Tokyo.
"The Prime Minister made it clear that they were working very hard on this legislation, that there are a lot of moving pieces, and he did not make a commitment," Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said yesterday afternoon.
Meetings with American presidents are always important for Japanese prime ministers. No matter what the subject of the session, it is critical for a new Japanese leader to demonstrate that he can hold his own with an American president and fend off, when necessary, the incessantly demanding Americans.
To bolster the Prime Minster, the White House planned to fly the two leaders to the Rockefeller estate in Tarrytown, where they could hold their meeting in a bucolic setting. But fog kept their helicopters grounded, and the meeting was held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Park Avenue.
What made this meeting unusual was that it was also important for Mr. Clinton, at several levels. Without resolving Japan's problems, Mr. Clinton's hopes of calming the world financial turmoil -- a task he committed himself to in a speech last week at the Council on Foreign Relations -- would be greatly impaired, if not doomed.
More immediately, the session was the latest opportunity for Mr. Clinton to demonstrate that he is focusing on substantive issues despite the continuing jockeying in Washington over impeachment proceedings or a possible censure.
Mr. Clinton insisted to reporters at one point yesterday that he had ignored the televised deluge of testimony and commentary. "Believe it or not, I haven't read the report," he said, referring to Kenneth Starr's referral to Congress.
But as a political diversion, the meeting with Mr. Obuchi did not amount to much.
The lack of progress came as little surprise to the Administration. This was the fourth time in 18 months that Mr. Clinton has urged a Japanese prime minister to act quickly on resolving the banking crisis that has frozen lending and investment throughout Asia.
But despite the series of running meetings between the two countries in Tokyo, San Francisco and Washington, there is little to show in the way of progress -- beyond resentment of American pressure in Japan and frustration at Japanese intransigence in Washington.
The American strategy for dealing with Japan has been to coordinate a series of increasingly urgent-sounding warnings -- first from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Mr. Summers, then from Germany and other European countries, and most recently from the International Monetary Fund. The problem is how to direct those critiques.
In an interview on Monday and at a news conference yesterday, Mr. Obuchi appeared to agree with the broad outlines of the American strategy: to pump money into viable banks and force the sale of real estate that has been sitting on the banks' books -- mostly unsold, because the banks do not want to have to confront how far prices have fallen.
But striking that deal involves finding common ground among the strongest political forces in Japan. Among them are banks and companies that finance the country's political parties, particularly Mr. Obuchi's Liberal Democratic Party. And then there are the opposition leaders, in control of the upper house of Parliament, who reflect the popular distaste for bailing out badly run banks and real estate moguls.
Mr. Obuchi seemed to reflect the difficulty of weaving through that minefield yesterday when he said he was "neither optimistic nor pessimistic" about the chances of getting financial reforms through Parliament. Taking a line from Mr. Clinton, he said that "this is not only an issue for Japan, but something that has major implications on economies of Asia as well as the whole world."
In his interview on Monday, Mr. Obuchi acknowledged that he had yet to convince the Japanese public or Parliament that the issue went beyond Japan's domestic interests. But he argued that he had been underestimated, a point he made obliquely to Mr. Clinton today when he noted that he had been compared in the American press to "cold pizza," a slight that clearly annoyed Japanese bureaucrats.
Mr. Clinton, his aides said, reassured Mr. Obuchi that he had eaten cold pizza the night before in his hotel.

HEADLINE: One Patch of Russia's Economic Crazy Quilt

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: KRASNOYARSK, Russia, Sept. 18

 BODY:
With the rugged stoicism that typifies this vast Siberian territory, Nina V. Popova thought she could ride out Russia's economic storm.
But last week tax inspectors barged into her small food shop. After poring through her ledgers, they warned her she had violated Gov. Aleksandr Lebed's new "anti-crisis" decree. 
 "They said we can only charge 10 percent more than we pay for the food," she said. "But we have to pay for electricity and heat. We have to pay for security, and we have to pay salaries. If they force this decree on us we simply won't survive."
Russia's financial crisis has not only rocked Moscow's political establishment. It has also stirred many of Russia's far-flung regions to set their own economic course and establish price controls.
A former general, presidential hopeful and the new governor of this Siberian region, Mr. Lebed has led the charge. Angry at the soaring prices that have stunned Russians, Mr. Lebed has not just declared war on inflation. He has tried to make it illegal.
He is hardly alone. From the northwestern city of Novgorod to the western territory of Yakutia, authorities are taking a page out of the socialist playbook and intervening to set prices.
Russia is fast becoming a crazy quilt of zones with Draconian price controls, territories with milder price restrictions and regions with no controls at all.
The populist decrees have brought a measure of comfort to consumers shocked by sharp jumps in prices for food and medicine.
"We may infringe on the rights of people but it is in their interest," Mr. Lebed said in interview. "The strict measures have played their role and soon will be abolished."
But the stop-gap controls also contain the seeds of new problems. Stores and factories complain they are being denied the profit they need to weather Russia's raging economic storm. Shortages have emerged, as producers ship their goods to regions where prices run free.
Virtually nobody thinks the controls are a substitute for a national strategy to rescue Russia from its economic malaise.
But with Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov still struggling to form a national Cabinet, there is no overarching plan.
Mr. Lebed owes his job to Krasnoyarsk's economic distress. Tapping the deep well of discontent, Mr. Lebed scored an upset victory over the region's incumbent Governor in a bitterly contested race last spring.
An immense region one-fourth the size of the United States, Krasnoyarsk has some of the nation's largest factories along with Siberia-size economic problems. But Mr. Lebed assured the voters that the region need an experienced crisis manager, not an economist.
Certainly, Mr. Lebed has been sorely tested. With the collapse of the ruble, tax revenues plummeted. Panic buying cleared the shelves of baby food and cold medicine, leaving the region with dangerously small reserves.
Last week, residents in the city of Krasnoyarsk, the administrative capital of the region, found themselves without hot water when the authorities ran short of coal.
The only bright spot came when Mr. Lebed hosted a glitzy popular music festival, which was sponsored by one of Russia's leading television networks -- a brief distraction in what promises to be one of the toughest winters in years.
Chastened by his region's economic woes, Mr. Lebed no longer talks confidently about single-handedly turning the situation around. Krasnoyarsk, he says, needs a greater share of the nation's tax receipts and lower rail and electricity tariffs to thrive over the long term.
It is Mr. Lebed's short-term plan, however, that has led Krasnoyarsk's citizens to draw the political battle lines. Anxious to quell the economic turmoil sweeping the nation, Mr. Lebed has decreed controls on the price of meat, fish, bread, flour, cereal, pasta, beverages and coal.
The measures officially took effect a week ago when the order was published on the front page of the regional newspaper Krasnoyarsk Worker.
Under Mr. Lebed's system, producers who want to raise the wholesale price of goods need to appeal to a panel of government officials at least five days in advance. Officially, no ceiling on wholesale prices was set. But a Lebed aide has proclaimed that producers should be satisfied with a profit of 2 percent.
Retail prices are regulated according to a formula. Shop owners are not be allowed to sell their food and beverages for more than 10 percent more than what they paid for them. And Krasnoyarsk's tax inspectors are conducting spot checks to make sure.
Mr. Lebed has emerged in recent weeks as the most popular alternative to the Communists in the public opinion polls. But his brand of capitalism is both populist and exceedingly vague. "I am certainly on the verge of breaking the law, but I think my measures are justified," Mr. Lebed said earlier this month. "The emergency situation is compelling me to take emergency measures."
Defending his price controls, Mr. Lebed said they were needed to head off a wave of frenzied buying by consumers desperate to stock up before prices soared even further.
Another goal, he said, was to stop profiteering by local producers, who were taking advantage of the crisis to ratchet up their prices even though they have been somewhat insulated from the effects of Russia's falling currency. The aim, he insisted, was not to set the price of imported goods.
"Why should milk become more expensive? Has the price of cows gone up?" he said in an interview.
Mr. Lebed is not the only one to turn to price controls. Kaliningrad has declared a state of emergency. The tax police in Novgorod have prowled through the city, fining shops for exorbitant prices.
In the southern Russian city of Stavropol, fights broke out when consumers and merchants banded together against government inspectors, who they complained were interfering with local trade.
Even pricey Moscow has imposed a 20 percent limit on the markup for basic staples, though city officials insist it is more of a guideline than a law.
Still, Mr. Lebed's decree has been assailed by his critics, who say it shows his penchant for simplistic and authoritarian solutions to complex economic problems.
"This shows that no member of the Lebed team thinks in economic terms," said Aleksei M. Kleshko, a member of the Krasnoyarsk City Council."They only know how to deal with the crisis through administrative means."
To be sure, many local factory directors and shop owners are unhappy.
"The Government acts just like it did in the days of Soviet power, when business people were considered bourgeois speculators," said Yevgeniya Kuznetsova, the president of Pikra, a local beverage company and the first factory to be privatized in the Krasnoyarsk region.
After the ruble collapsed, the upgrading of the factory's beer production unit was stopped in mid-stream after a German factory refused to provide any more equipment on credit.
That has increased the factory's need for cash. Meanwhile, sales have fallen, as consumers have cut back on their purchase or beer and soft drinks so that they can stock up on flour, grain and cooking oil.
Ms. Kuznetsova said her company will be skating too close to the edge if it is restricted to a profit rate of 2 percent. Already, she has gone to a four-day work week to reduce costs.
"The government does not seem to worry about the collapse of small and medium business," she said bitterly.
At her small shop down the street from Pikra, Ms. Popova is more distressed than angry. A sturdy woman with an engaging manner, she voted for Mr. Lebed because of his promises to bring order to Krasnoyarsk.
Ms. Popova is already something of a survivor. She set up her food store in a working class district earlier this year after the investment company she was working for went bankrupt. Her store sells sausages, bread, alcohol and cooking oil. Saleswomen receive just 360 rubles a month (about $24 at current exchange rates) for their 12-hour-a-day jobs. Because the volume of sales is low and because her store also has to pay for utilities and an alarm system, Ms. Popova needs to mark up her goods by 20 percent just to break even, she said.
The Krasnoyarsk tax police, however, were not impressed by her arguments. After shuffling through the shop's balance sheets, they told her the store was exceeding the 10 percent mark-up allowed for salt, sugar and cereal. No fines were levied yet, but Ms. Popova was summoned to the local tax office to do some explaining.
"All summer long I told our saleswomen they should be patient and that I would increase their salaries a little bit in the fall," she said. "Now, I may have to fire some of them."
Still, Ms. Popova is reluctant to assign the blame to the gruff-talking Governor.
"I pinned hopes on him because I thought he would be tough," she recalled. "But he turned out to be too tough. He's not an economist, though, and this was probably done by his team. I still hope to prove to him that this is not right, and I might even vote for him again."

HEADLINE: About New York;
An 'Invisible' Life Remains So in Death

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
JOSE SORIANO loved walking around the city. It was a welcome stress-buster from his routine of working long shifts at a Brooklyn clothing factory. Some days he sauntered through Central Park to his railroad flat in El Barrio, taking in the sights of the city he adopted eight years ago when he moved here from Mexico. His wife, Fausta, worried about him, but he shrugged off her concerns. There's always light, he reassured her. And people look out, too.
"He always said: 'I would never leave New York. I love this city,' " his wife recalled. "He said he would only leave as a dead man." 
 In the next few days, Mr. Soriano will return to Mexico just that way. In a box. On Saturday night, as he was walking home through Central Park, he was stabbed to death near Belvedere Castle. He was 47 years old and leaves behind the family that had joined him in this country only four years ago.
As is the custom among the tightly knit extended families that cushion the hard life of Mexican immigrants in New York, friends and relatives bearing food and comfort have been trooping up the dark, narrow staircase of the Sorianos' tenement home on East 106th Street.
The rooms are nearly barren, mostly just beds, dressers and pictures of Our Lady of Guadalupe. The place is quiet, save for the sound of murmured adult conversation or the squeals of babies being carried by young women.
The silence extends to the rest of the city, too. Unlike other times when people have been beaten or killed in Central Park, there has been little outrage over Mr. Soriano's death. Contrast that with past attacks on the Jogger or the Piano Teacher, to name two vicious crimes in the city's great green backyard that infuriated the public and kept journalists busy for weeks.
Nor have there been visits from the Mayor or condolence calls from the Police Commissioner. Maybe the response would have been better had early reports not inaccurately called Mr. Soriano homeless, or if the Sorianos had been tourists or more upwardly mobile. But they are the kind of people whose countrymen do the kind of drudge work that keeps the local economy growing and humming for the benefit of the leisure class.
Basically, the reaction is as dead as Mr. Soriano. And the people around him know it.
"I think there is an obvious difference in how people are treated and how crimes are treated for people who live below 96th Street and people who live above 96th Street," said the Rev. Bruce Lewandowski, the associate pastor of St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church, the Sorianos' parish. "You have somebody here who is a so-called 'invisible person,' an immigrant who is most likely undocumented. They're invisible. They don't count."
So much so, that it took the authorities a day to realize that Mr. Soriano was not homeless. That description might have been true a few years ago, and only in the emotional sense, as he made the transition from Mexico to New York. He had come to the city to save some money and bring his wife and two sons up north, a goal he accomplished four years ago. His wife can still remember the exact date, July 29, 1994. A Friday.
"He had gone to Mexico and I told him I did not want to stay alone anymore," she said in Spanish. "For good or bad, I came with him. I didn't want to be separated anymore. I wanted to be by his side."
TRUE enough, they even worked together in a factory that made maternity clothing. It helped ease her transition to a new country, although she stopped working nearly three years ago when their daughter Grizelle was born. Mrs. Soriano's health was not good, so he told her to stay home while he put in six days a week at the Brooklyn factory for a few hundred dollars.
"He was paid by the piece," she said. "So when he could, he would want to continue working. He was one of those people who did not want to be at home. He would leave at 6 in the morning and come home at 10."
As difficult as such a meager existence was, the Sorianos found pride in being able to provide for their three children. They knew no other way.
"He always said it was hard here, but it was harder in Mexico," Mrs. Soriano said. "I never asked the government for help. We live to work."
Last Saturday he left work and went to a store to buy a pair of baseball cleats for a friend who played with him on a team in Red Hook. For the first time in their life together in New York, he never came home. Mrs. Soriano kept an all-night vigil.
"I sat," she said. "I stood. I looked out the window for him. But no."
The next day, she said detectives spoke to her husband's teammates in Brooklyn, and that's when word of his fate finally reached her.
"I think he wanted to come home walking through the park," Mrs. Soriano said. "And he found death along the way."
The police took her to the precinct station house, she said, then let her go after a while, promising to let her know when they had something to report. She said she has not heard anything since the police arrested a suspect in the case, only to drop the charges later.
"I heard the Mayor talking about the crime on the news," she said. "But nobody called from his office. Is it because we are Hispanic? Do they think we come here to take something from them? We only come to work. Or is it because we're poor?"
Mrs. Soriano does not have enough money to send his body back to Mexico. Friends and relatives are taking up a collection, but they are just as strapped as she. Yet they offer lessons in compassion.
"When something like this happens, we talk to each other and try to help with what we can," she said. "Maybe they cannot help with money, but they can help with moral support."
She will help, too, by returning to work in the coming weeks. Her husband's bosses said she was welcome to her old job.
"I want to push my children ahead," she said. "My husband is gone. He has to rest. The dead go to rest. The living are here to struggle to keep living."
She walked over to the window where she stood on Saturday night. In her hand was a picture of her husband, natty in a baseball uniform that had "Braves" emblazoned on the jersey.
"Mira," their daughter, Grizelle said, as she tugged at the picture. "Papi. Papi."
Outside, the streets were gray and damp. A few doors away from the Sorianos' building, a wall was decorated with a mural of St. Sebastian tied to a pillar, his nearly naked body pierced by arrows.
"We walk among each other in a deep dream," read an inscription, "committing small acts of violence among one another. The heart that awakens first will take us to the heavens from this earth."

HEADLINE: D'Amato Ad Seeks to Exploit Upstate Resentment of New York City

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Playing directly to upstate voters' longstanding antagonism toward New York City, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato began broadcasting a television advertisement yesterday asserting that his Democratic challenger, Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, had written off upstate New York with statements and votes throughout his career.
"Liberal Brooklyn Congressman Chuck Schumer doesn't think upstate New York matters," the announcer says over the bouncy sounds of lounge music, while the screen depicts a jagged saw cutting off the rest of New York State and leaving only downstate behind. The advertisement will air only north of New York City, Mr. D'Amato's aides said. 
 The advertisement reinforces the principal message spread by Mr. D'Amato, a Republican seeking a fourth term in Washington, during a two-day trip upstate on Sunday and Monday: that Mr. Schumer was hostile to the concerns of people who live north of New York City. To make the point, the advertisement pointed to statements and votes cast by Mr. Schumer, going back to 1977, on bills ranging from cutting dairy price supports to raising gas taxes.
"On Election Day, send Chuck Schumer a message: There's more to New York State than just Brooklyn," the announcer says.
Mr. Schumer's advisers attacked the advertisement as polarizing and politically out of bounds. "It is a desperate and misleading attempt at division from a candidate who is behind in the polls," said Howard L. Wolfson, Mr. Schumer's spokesman. "Chuck Schumer is a tax-cutting, crime-fighting Democrat and Al D'Amato just doesn't know how to react to that."
Mr. D'Amato's decision to air the stark advertisement -- and risk both alienating supporters in New York City and courting criticism that he is seeking to divide voters -- clearly signals the political weight he is attaching to upstate in this difficult re-election campaign. Mr. D'Amato's advisers, explaining the reasons behind the pointed attack, said that based on past elections, they expected 45 percent of the vote to come from upstate, compared with 30 percent in New York City and 25 percent from the suburbs.
In 1994, Gov. George E. Pataki also banked on upstate support to defeat Mario M. Cuomo, but avoided direct appeals to rivalries between the two parts of the state. In this campaign, Mr. Pataki, who is by all accounts in a strong position as he seeks a second term this year, has made a particularly vigorous appeal for support from downstate voters -- an appeal that Democrats said yesterday might be complicated by the emerging tactic of his fellow Republican.
In effect, Mr. Pataki and Mr. D'Amato are offering different political responses to what they each perceive as the same problem: that Republicans will be hurt this year by the struggling upstate economy. Mr. D'Amato is trying to push up his vote upstate, where he has historically been strong, while Mr. Pataki, who is looking for a large re-election victory to enhance his credentials as a national candidate, is looking to New York City for support.
In making the advertisement, Mr. D'Amato's advisers combed through Mr. Schumer's record in Congress and the State Assembly, seeking votes that served the interests of Mr. Schumer's constituents in Brooklyn but might not sit well with voters elsewhere in the state. For example, Mr. Schumer voted for two bills designed to curb payments to dairy farmers, to the benefit of milk drinkers. He also voted three times to increase the gas tax, another position that was not likely to offend the sentiment in his urban district.
Mr. D'Amato's advisers called the attack a fair case based on Mr. Schumer's record. "These are his quotes and his votes," said Kieran Mahoney, a senior political adviser to Mr. D'Amato. "And I think if anybody had some concerns about this, it would be the 40 percent of New Yorkers who live west of the Hudson River and north of the Tappan Zee Bridge."
However, Mr. Schumer's aides disputed one central element of Mr. D'Amato's advertisement -- its quotation of Mr. Schumer as saying, "To me, the West begins across the Hudson River."
Mr. Wolfson said the comment was taken out of context. And a transcript of the April 1997 press conference where Mr. Schumer made it suggests he was making a joke. Mr. Schumer mistakenly identified Senator Richard J. Durbin as being from Idaho. He is from Illinois.
"To you, I am from a Western state," Mr. Durbin said, according to Federal News Service, which transcribes news conferences in Washington.
The transcript describes Mr. Schumer as laughing, and then saying: "That's right. To me, the West begins across the Hudson River. In any case, we are glad to be here."
Mr. Mahoney defended the use of the quotation. "He said it," Mr. Mahoney said.
Mr. D'Amato's supporters did not offer any apologies for the tactics. Asked if they were playing to prejudice among upstaters against city residents, Edward I. Koch, the former Mayor who lost his 1982 bid for governor largely because of a poor showing upstate, let out a howl: "Absolutely!"
He called Mr. Schumer a typical New York City politician -- and he did not mean that as a compliment. The Congressman, Mr. Koch said, "takes credit for everything. He's a stereotype."
"Not all is fair in love and war," Mr. Koch said. "This is fair. It's not unfair to say that a candidate that comes from one section of the state might discriminate in favor of the section he comes from."
New York's voting history offers an explanation for Mr. D'Amato's tactics. In 1992, he defeated Robert Abrams, his Democratic opponent, by about 81,000 votes out of 7 million cast. Mr. Abrams won New York City by just over 460,000 votes, and Mr. D'Amato made up the difference by his showing in the suburbs and upstate.
And Mr. D'Amato, who was born in Brooklyn and made his name on Long Island, would appear to have little to lose in the county that he once called home. At last count, there were 133,913 registered Republicans in Kings County, compared with 846,512 Democrats.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

United Airlines' Parent Picks Insider as President
James E. Goodwin, a longtime senior executive, was named president and chief operating officer of UAL, the parent of United Airlines, succeeding John A. Edwardson, who was forced out by the carrier's powerful unions.
The appointment immediately vaulted Mr. Goodwin, 54, into the race to succeed Gerald Greenwald, UAL's chairman and chief executive, whose five-year employment contract expires next summer. C4. 

Murdoch in German Media Deal
Rupert Murdoch, chairman of the News Corporation, Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia and Mediaset S.p.A., Italy's largest private broadcasting company, plan to buy as much as 25 percent of the Kirch Group, Germany's second-largest media company, for about $2 billion. C3.
 
Dow Drops, but Small Stocks Rise
The Dow industrials fell 36.05 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 7,897.20, with Coca-Cola accounting for a third of the drop. The market as a whole advanced, buoyed by smaller companies and technology shares. C8.
 
Treasury bond prices fell for the first time in five days, and the yield on the long bond rose to 5.15 percent, from 5.12 percent Monday. C8.
 
3Com Earnings Exceed Forecasts
Rebounding from a loss a year ago, 3Com reported earnings of $93.7 million, or 26 cents a share, surpassing analysts' estimates of 20 cents a share, thanks largely to its Palm Pilot portable computing device. 3Com had disappointed investors in the past as it worked through a glutted inventory of modems. The company announced the results after the close of regular stock trading. C21.
 
Clinton and Obuchi Seek Agreement
President Clinton and Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan, meeting for the first time, struggled to reassure financial markets but failed on reach agreement on a common strategy to pull the world's second-largest economy out of a recession. A14.
 
U.S. Official Criticizes China
David L. Aaron, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, on a visit to Beijing, criticized what he called China's unwillingness to open its markets. C2.
 
Fed Official Warms to Rate Cut
The president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, William J. McDonough, suggested that he had become more open to the idea of a cut in interest rates. C7.
 
Former MCI Chief Resigns
Gerald H. Taylor, MCI's chief executive who was to run the international operations of the new MCI Worldcom Inc., has resigned. C4.
 
Nomura to Buoy American Unit
Nomura Securities said that it would inject $380 million in capital into its American unit, Nomura Holding America Inc. C3.
 
Philippine Airlines May Shut Down
Barring a last-minute rescue, Philippine Airlines, Asia's oldest scheduled carrier, will shut down at midnight tonight. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. C6.
 
Advertising Women's Take on Ads
Advertising Women of New York will present honors and dishonors today at the group's second annual appraisal of how women are portrayed in sales pitches. Among those considered laudable are two AT&T ads by Young & Rubicam. Advertising. C5.
 
Portraying the Internet in 3-D
Two prominent Internet pioneers have founded a company called Invisible Worlds to create a three-dimensional portrayal for those navigating the Internet. C7.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
SALES IN ASIA WILL BELOWER THAN EXPECTED, COMPAQ SAYS

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that sales of its personal computers in Asia would be lower than expected this year because of the region's economic crisis. The Houston-based company said that the number of computers it sells in Asia would be little changed from a year earlier and that overall sales for the region would fall short of earlier targets. It declined to disclose the targets or last year's sales. Compaq is cutting prices to shed its leftover models and is reining in costs at Digital Equipment, which it acquired in June for more than $9 billion. The shares rose 25 cents, to $31.875.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
COOPER CAMERON WARNS ON EARNINGS AND PLANS LAYOFFS

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Cooper Cameron Corporation, a maker of oil and natural gas equipment, warned yesterday that earnings would fall below estimates in the third and fourth quarters and that the company would cut about 500 jobs as Asian economic troubles reduce sales. The Houston-based company said lower-than-expected sales would cut third-quarter earnings to about 70 cents a share, below the 84-cent average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call Corporation. Cooper said fourth-quarter earnings would be about 75 cents a share, below the 93-cent estimate. To cut costs, Cooper will lay off 5 percent of its work force in the next 60 days and will close a production plant in Missouri City, Tex. The shares fell $5, to $29.25.
