HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Uplifting Lessons in a Sweet, Tumbledown World

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
More than half a century after the full employment during World War II put an end to the Great Depression, that agonizing era is serving a new generation as a fount of wisdom: Hard times teach hard but useful lessons.
In films like "The Grass Harp" and today's arrival, "Shadrach," a generation raised in prosperity turns to a difficult past, suffuses it with a romantic glow and gazes with something like envy on its simple ways while tapping its people for insights into life's eternal verities, like death. 
 On more than one level, the slight, sweet, sentimental "Shadrach" is a labor of love by Susanna Styron, the film's director and co-writer, from an autobiographical tale by her father, William Styron, published in Esquire in 1978.
The events of "Shadrach," which unfold in the Tidewater country of Virginia in 1935, are seen through the eyes of 10-year-old Paul Whitehurst (Scott Terra), a clean-cut, well-brought-up only child of respectable parents whose best friend is Little Mole (Daniel Treat).
Little Mole is one of the Dabney clan, descendants of pre-Civil War tobacco plantation owners who have now plummeted to the category popularly known as white trash. The boys are unwashed, and the girls are slatternly, except for young Edmonia (Monica Bugajski), the apple of Paul's eye. Presiding over this brood are Trixie Dabney (Andie MacDowell), the beer-swilling, warmhearted mother (Deborah Hedwall) and Vernon Dabney (Harvey Keitel), the embittered, foulmouthed, unemployed sire who ekes out a living as a moonshiner.
For young Paul, life is about to become complicated. His mother is in the early stages of illness. His parents are called away to a distant family funeral, and the boy wins permission to spend a few days with the Dabneys. At the same time, a footsore old black man is making his weary way north from Alabama.
His name is Shadrach (John Franklin Sawyer), and when he reaches the Dabneys' littered yard after a 600-mile journey, he reveals that he is a 99-year-old former Dabney slave who has come back to die and asks to be buried on the grounds of the old plantation, where the Dabneys still maintain a tumbledown shack.
So Paul and the Dabneys and the incontinent Shadrach set out in Vernon's rickety car to fulfill the old man's wish, only to be told by the not unfriendly local sheriff that laws have changed, and it is now illegal to bury someone on private property.
Not only does the sheriff imply that he will shut down Vernon's still if he is disobeyed; he also puts Vernon in the position of having to come up with the near-impossible sum of $35 to pay for a funeral and burial in a cemetery.
As Shadrach sinks toward death and the Dabneys and Paul take turns tending the old man, the question hangs in the air: Will the Dabneys (Vernon, that is) honor their promise?
And for Paul, these few days foreshadow his mother's impending death.
While confronting life and death and growing up, Ms. Styron does not shy from dealing with segregation, with black and white children separated in a theater while watching a Stepin Fetchit comedy, and white men like Vernon using uninhibited language to designate blacks and President Franklin D. Roosevelt as the source of their woes.
At the same time, she evokes the simple decency of people who manage to retain their fundamental humanity in the face of hardship.
"Shadrach" is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). It contains foul language, racial epithets and profanity, the nude buttocks of happy children swinging over a swimming hole, a used condom and a dead body.
 
SHADRACH
 
Directed by Susanna Styron; written by Ms. Styron and Bridget Terry, based on the short story by William Styron; director of photography, Hiro Narita; edited by Colleen Sharp; music by Van Dyke Parks; production designer, Burton Rencher; produced by John Thompson, Boaz Davidson and Ms. Terry; released by Columbia Pictures. Running time: 133 minutes. This film is rated PG-13.
 
WITH: Harvey Keitel (Vernon), Andie MacDowell (Trixie), Monica Bugajski (Edmonia), Deborah Hedwall (Mother), Darrell Larson (Father), Scott Terra (Paul), Daniel Treat (Little Mole), Jonathan Parks Jordan (Middle Mole), Erin Underwood (Lucinda), John Franklin Sawyer (Shadrach) and Martin Sheen (Narrator).

HEADLINE: What Will Mom and Dad Dream Up Next

BYLINE: By JACK KADDEN 

 BODY:
With cup holders sprouting in every corner and nook of American cars (there are seven in a Dodge Caravan), it was only a matter of time before someone came up with the Stroll'r Hold'r, an ingeniously simple cup holder that snaps on to the handle of a baby stroller.
 But that someone wasn't a marketing whiz at Sears or an engineer at Fisher-Price. It was Gail Frankel, a young Dallas mother who was a speech pathologist. 
 "I had two kids, one in a stroller and one walking by my side," she said. "I had lots of stuff and no place to put it."
 Most of the entrepreneurs who develop gear for the parents of babies are like Mrs. Frankel, clever amateurs trying to fill a need they have discovered while raising their own children.
 "Truly, this was not what I thought I would be doing with my life," Mrs. Frankel says now, 10 years after starting her company, Kel-Gar, which makes the Stroll'r Hold'r and dozens of other products meant to make parenting easier. Among them are the Snap 'n' Stroll, a fanny pack with pockets for a water bottle and a cellular phone, and the Clip 'n' Cool, a fan that attaches to a crib, a stroller or a playpen.
 Perhaps more than any other industry, the field of baby gear is very open to new products and companies. At the annual trade show sponsored by the Juvenile Products Manufacturers Association, as many as 100 of the 350 companies are first-time exhibitors, some beginner companies with only one or two products, said Bridget K. Reuter, an association spokeswoman.
 "Many of these companies," Ms. Reuter added, "are started by new parents home with new babies, finding a need and using their creativity to meet that need."
 Often, such companies offer their products by mail order, through catalogues or in specialy stores. But even the largest retailers are receptive and sell many of these items.
 Within a year after Mrs. Frankel began producing the Stroll'r Hold'r, Toys R Us agreed to sell it (it retails for $6), and her company was making a profit.
 JACK KADDEN

CORRECTION-DATE: September 25, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article and a picture grouping on Wednesday in the special Entrepreneurs section, about baby products devised by parents, included an incorrect phone number for Well-Fed Baby, the maker of one such product, frozen kosher baby food. The number, toll free, is (888) 935-5333.

GRAPHIC: Photo (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)
 
Chart:
The Boppy
In 1989, Susan Matthews was working in advertising in Denver when she saw a sign in her daughter's day-care center asking parents to make pillows to prop up babies so they could see around them. That inspired the Boppy, a U-shaped pillow that sells for $20 to $30 and can also be used by mothers while nursing. In 1990, it won a best-new product award from the Juvenile Products Manufacturers Association, and it helped plant the seeds for Ms. Matthews's company, Camp Kazoo Limited, which now has 75 products.
 
Kikibarn
Kristine Kanefick is a 28-year-old artist who lives on a farm in River Falls, Wis., and has been concerned for a long time about farm animals in danger of extinction. She has translated that worry into a company, Kikibarn Arts for Biodiversity, which makes stuffed reproductions of endangered farm animals, like the American curly horse shown here. The animals sell for around $35, are sewn by women who live nearby and are made of organic cotton and wool from the endangered Navajo Churro sheep.
 
Smartsleep
Even with a Ph.D. in piano, Heide Brende was surprised by how quickly her newborn son, Carter, would calm down while listening to Bach. So she decided to make a recording of classical music called Smartsleep. Ms. Brende, who is 32 and lives in Pasadena, Calif., hired a concert hall in Texas and recorded herself playing classical selections on a Steinway to create "a concert-hall sound," she said. So far, she has sold about 1,500 CD's at $16 each, and 1,000 cassettes at $11, via mail order.
 
ABC
For years, Amy Shumway's Florida-based company, ABC Development, made novelty items like the foam reindeer antlers that are sold at parades, and housewares like scrub brushes. But when her first child was born six years ago, she entered a new field, juvenile products. "It's almost like products come out of necessity when you have a child," she said. Her first item for parents was the Bottle Scrubber, a wooden brush with a foam head that collapses to enter the bottle. It sells for about $2.50. The juvenile products industry, she says, is "very receptive to new ideas, and there are a lot of ways to get into it, through catalogues and mail order."

The Well-Fed Baby
For Robin Sweet, a former pediatric nurse, inspiration came in the form of a starving infant. She and her husband adopted a baby, Nicolai, in Russia, who at six months weighed a mere six pounds. "He was very malnourished," she said, "and when we brought him home, we knew we'd have to be careful what we fed him." Nicolai grew rapidly on a soy-based formula and progressed to homemade organic baby food, which brought about a cookbook called "The Well-Fed Baby." At readers' urging, she started a company by the same name to produce frozen Kosher organic baby food. The four different meals sell for just under $2 each.
 
Nurture Parenting Products
Christine Prefontaine, a 29-year-old mother, says she went into business last year making baby slings for one reason: "I couldn't find any funky baby stuff. Everything was pastels. I wanted to make stuff for my generation." Ms. Prefontaine soon added nursing dresses to her line to compete with the more conventional products on the market. "I wanted to provide an alternative that was fun and a little bit sexy. We kind of forget how we got pregnant in the first place." Her company, Nurture Parenting Products, now farms out the sewing to a contractor in Ms. Prefontaine's hometown of Arlington, Va.
 
Under the Canopy
Marci Zaroff didn't wait until she had children to become an entrepreneur. "I did my first business card when I was 11," she said. "I did calligraphy for weddings and invitations for special events. I was born a businesswoman." Now she runs a catalogue company called Under the Canopy, in Randolph, N.J., which sells more than 150 natural products, including children's clothing. Ms. Zaroff, who has two children and a degree in marketing, says that clothes made from natural fibers like hemp and organic cotton are "the wave of the future," adding: "This business is like natural foods was 10 years ago. What happened with natural foods, that's what's going to happen to ecofashion."
 
Hands-Free Baby Bottle
"You'd think that a mother would have come up with this idea," said Prudente Cueto, a former insurance agent who invented the Hands-Free Baby Bottle when his daughter was about six months old. Basically a baby bottle with a long plastic straw -- his invention -- that sells for $8, eliminates the need to retrieve bottles tossed out of car seats or high chairs. Mr. Cueto's company, Podee, based in San Diego, sells 100,000 bottles a year. He says it is particularly popular with mothers of twins and triplets.
 
Stroll'r Hold'r
With sales of more than 100,000 a year, the Stroll'r Hold'r continues to be one of the top items in the Kel-Gar company line. It sells for about $6. Gail Frankel, the company's founder, said the corporate name is a combination of her married name and her maiden name, Garfield. "The Gail Company sounded too cutesy," she said.

HEADLINE: For Indie Films, 1979's Lark Turns Into This Year's Institution

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN

 BODY:
When Sandra Schulberg rented a screening room in Manhattan in 1979 to show 20 new films to producers and distributors, she felt as if she was doing something radical. "The intention was to try to create an alternate film economy," said Ms. Schulberg, a filmmaker herself. "I did not see it becoming an institution."
Nearly 20 years later, independent films have become a regular part of the cultural vocabulary, and the Independent Feature Film Market started by Ms. Schulberg has become an important early showcase for films like "My Dinner With Andre," "Welcome to the Dollhouse," "Roger and Me" and "The Brothers McMullen." 
 This year's market, which began on Friday and runs through this Friday, includes some 700 filmmakers and about 1,300 other people in the industry who come to make connections and find new talent. Films are shown at the Angelika Film Center, at 18 West Houston Street in Greenwich Village, and surrounding locations.
Filmmakers who want to show their work submit videotapes with a registration fee of $275 to $450, depending on the length of the film and the timing of the submission. This year, the number of projects on the market, including unproduced scripts, is roughly 400, said Michelle Byrd, the executive director of the Independent Feature Project, the country's largest membership organization for independent filmmakers, which administers the market.
Among the more talked-about projects this year, Ms. Byrd said, are "LaMastas," described at the market's on-line site (www.ifp.org) as a " 'Forrest Gump' meets 'Goodfellas,' " and "The Accident," a memoir filmed over 25 years. Ken Liotti said his film "The Waiting Game" is also one of the "hot" ones. "The buzz we've gotten is incredible," Mr. Liotti said. "All the festivals have approached us. Now we're on the map, which is the purpose of doing it."
Mr. Liotti, 40, said he wrote, directed and produced his 88-minute film -- about the misadventures of struggling actors who wait on tables -- after writing for Hollywood and never seeing his films produced. "I've been in development hell for 10 years," he said. "I wanted to see one of my movies up on the screen."
In addition to screenings, the market features several seminars every day, including "Who's Who in the Documentary World," "Coaching Screenwriters: Accessing Resources and Developing Strategies" and "How to Pitch to HBO Documentary Programming."
This year's market will reunite several alumni and a screening series at the Anthology Film Archives, on Second Street at Second Avenue in the East Village, to highlight 10 of the market's major previous films, including "Down by Law," "Daughters of the Dust" and "Stand and Deliver."
In addition, the market will present its second annual Gordon Parks Awards, which gives $10,000 to an African-American director and $10,000 to an African-American screenwriter. The Independent Feature Project says these awards helped increase the participation of black filmmakers in the market over the last two years from 16 in 1996 to 55 this year.

HEADLINE: Needed: A Fed for the World

BYLINE: By Jeffrey E. Garten; Jeffrey E. Garten is dean of the Yale School of Management and the author of "The Big Ten: The Big Emerging Markets and How They Will Change Our Lives."

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
Even as emerging markets sink into depression and stocks plunge from Montreal to Melbourne, a global economy is slowly emerging, albeit in a tortuous and painful way. But governments seem paralyzed, unable to deal with both the crisis and the opportunity.
Today's chaotic international market mirrors how the American economy evolved between the Civil War and the 1930's. For well over half a century we, too, had booms and busts, countless bank failures, rampant bankruptcies. Capitalism was an uncontrollable Darwinian process, with big winners and big losers. 
 But over time the United States set up crucial central institutions -- the Securities and Exchange Commission (1933), the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (1934) and, most important, the Federal Reserve (1913). In so doing, America became a managed national economy. These organizations were created to make capitalism work, to prevent destructive business cycles and to moderate the harsh, invisible hand of Adam Smith.
This is what now must occur on a global scale. The world needs an institution that has a hand on the economic rudder when the seas become stormy. It needs a global central bank.
The sad fact is that we cannot rely on existing institutions or on national leaders for global economic stability.
The International Monetary Fund knows how to deal with one or a few countries at a time, but not an international phenomenon in which all countries' problems occur at once and are linked. The World Bank's mission has included financing big projects and alleviating poverty, but it is not designed for financial crises.
Simply trying to coordinate the world's powerful central banks -- the Fed and the new European Central Bank, for instance -- wouldn't work, either. If there is no inflation in the United States, the Fed won't lower interest rates simply because that would help, say, Southeast Asia. Such global responsibility is not in the Fed's charter. The European Central Bank, meanwhile, seems proud of its narrow focus on Europe. The result is inadequate attention to the three-quarters of the world consisting of emerging markets.
Effective collaboration among finance ministries and treasuries is also unlikely to materialize. These agencies are responsible to elected legislatures, and politics in the industrial countries is more preoccupied with internal events than with international stability.
An independent central bank with responsibility for maintaining global financial stability is the only way out. No one else can do what is needed: inject more money into the system to spur growth, reduce the sky-high debts of emerging markets, and oversee the operations of shaky financial institutions.
A global central bank could provide more money to the world economy when it is rapidly losing steam. For example, it could buy the bonds of the Central Bank of Brazil, thereby injecting hard currency into that country when it most needs the help (like right now). It would have the ability to buy a country's debt at steep discounts, a crucial need now because in countries like Thailand and Venezuela debts are piling up and preventing new lending and new investment. Ultimately a lot of this debt could be resold at a profit.
Such a bank would play an oversight role for banks and other financial institutions everywhere, providing some uniform standards for prudent lending in places like China and Mexico. The regulation need not be heavy-handed; providing clear and reasonably verified information to the market on the real state of banks around the world would be a leap forward. Investors could then make the informed judgments that they couldn't have made in, say, Russia or Indonesia.
None of these functions are being performed effectively now, and it will be impossible to have a world economy that doesn't resemble a reckless roller coaster unless they are.
There are two ways a global central bank could be financed. It could have lines of credit from all central banks, drawing on them in bad times and repaying when the markets turn up. Alternately -- and admittedly more difficult to carry out -- it could be financed by a very modest tariff on all trade, collected at the point of importation, or by a tax on certain global financial transactions.
One thing that would not be acceptable would be for the bank to be at the mercy of short-term-oriented legislatures. Witness how the United States Congress has consistently failed to provide new money for the I.M.F. even as the world economy slides toward deep recession.
A crucial political question is, To whom would a global central bank be accountable? It would have too much power to be governed only by technocrats, although it must be led by the best of them. One possibility would be to link the new bank to an enlarged Group of Seven -- perhaps a "G-15" that would include the G-7 plus rotating members like Mexico, Brazil, South Africa, Poland, India, China and South Korea.
Another issue is the relationship between a global bank and the Fed. There would have to be very close collaboration. The global bank would not operate within the United States, and it would not be able to override the decisions of our central bank. But it could supply the missing international ingredient -- emergency financing for cash-starved emerging markets. It wouldn't affect American mortgage rates, but it could help the profitability of American multinational companies by creating a healthier global environment for their businesses.
It is never easy to create a new institution; too many people have vested interests in the status quo. Moreover, when these new structures are most needed, officials are preoccupied with managing the current crisis. When calm is restored, attention turns to something else. But the current global financial slide, with no one at the center to limit the damage, is evidence enough that there is a huge gap in the structures necessary to make globalization work.
As the eminent economic historian Charles Kindleberger said in examining the causes of the Depression, "For the world economy to be stabilized, there has to be a stabilizer, one stabilizer." He was commenting on the lack of leadership by America in the 1930's. Today, with the United States still showing no appetite for such a role, a global central bank could be an enormous help.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Dip, in Unusual Tandem With Wall Street

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of United States Treasury securities fell for the first time in five days yesterday despite weakness in stocks.
Analysts said investors might have been a little reluctant to buy at current prices with yield levels, which move inversely to prices, already at historic lows. 
 The 30-year bond's price fell 19/32, to 105 8/32. Its yield rose to 5.15 percent, from 5.12 percent Monday.
For most of the last two months the bond market has derived strength from the selloff in stocks, reflecting moves by investors around the world to the relative safety of Treasury securities. So it was considered unusual that both bonds and stocks fell yesterday.
Some analysts attributed the bond weakness to uncertainty over what the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee will do at its meeting next Tuesday. While speculation has increased that the Federal Open Market Committee may move to lower rates, which could help soothe anxiety in global markets, there is no obvious reason for reduced rates in the United States, where the economy is showing resilience.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said, "At the very least, the F.O.M.C. will adopt a bias toward easing at this meeting, but the probability of an actual easing at this juncture has increased markedly and may well be more likely."
Others were more emphatic in their prediction that the Fed would move to ease rates. Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist at the DKB Securities (USA) Corporation, said in his latest market report that the Fed would take such a step because of deepening distress in emerging markets, the threat of global deflation and some signs of slowing economic growth in the United States.
Additional insight into the economy's performance will emerge later this week when the Commerce Department releases a revision to the second-quarter gross domestic product number, along with August data for durable goods orders, personal income and consumer spending.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, whose ambiguous remarks about interest rates last week contributed to a large selloff in stocks, will be testifying today before the Senate Budget Committee.
Also today, the Treasury will sell $15 billion of new two-year notes, which by late yesterday were being offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 4.62 percent.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Three Media Investors Seek A Stake in Germany's Kirch

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Rupert Murdoch; Prince Walid bin Talal, from Saudi Arabia, and Mediaset S.p.A. plan to buy as much as 25 percent of the Kirch Group, Germany's second-largest media company, for about $2 billion, the prince's adviser and Mediaset executives said.
As part of the plan, Kirch would be reorganized and would sell stock to the public early next year, the adviser, Tarak Ben Ammar, said in an interview today. Mr. Ben Ammar sits on the board of Mediaset, which is Italy's largest private broadcasting company and is controlled by the former Italian Prime Minister, Silvio Berlusconi. 
 A spokesman for Kirch declined to comment.
A link with debt-laden Kirch would create Europe's biggest television alliance, straddling Italy, Germany, Spain and Britain.
The allied investors would be better able to compete against the major American networks in creating television series, films and shows. Mr. Murdoch, who controls extensive media holdings, and Mediaset would obtain a foothold in Germany's potentially lucrative market, which is Europe's largest, with more than 33 million households owning televisions.
"It's at the point where one can't think of doing anything in pay-TV in Germany without Kirch," Laurent Carozzi, a media analyst at Paribas in London, said. "They now have an opportunity to get in the market because of Kirch's financial weakness."
Analysts estimate the privately held German company has debts of 3 billion marks, or $1.8 billion. Kirch controls a digital television venture, DF1; 25 percent of a pay-television service, Premiere; a commercial channel, SAT1, and a sports channel.
Mediaset's chairman, Fedele Confalonieri, said the planned alliance would focus on commercial television financed by advertising, rather than on pay television.
Price Walid's role would be that of an investor, but the Murdoch-Kirch-Mediaset alliance could cooperate with ART, the Arab satellite television venture in which the prince's Kingdom Holdings company owns 30 percent, Mr. Ben Ammar said.
"How often do you find an important group like Kirch that wants to open up to friendly shareholders?" Mr. Ben Ammar said. "This is a great investment opportunity."
It is not clear how the Kirch stake would be distributed among the three partners and through which of his companies Mr. Murdoch would make the investment, Mr. Ben Ammar said.
Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation owns the Fox television network in the United States and controls British Sky Broadcasting P.L.C., Britain's biggest pay-television company. It also has television ventures in Asia.
The Asian economic crisis is prompting Mr. Murdoch to turn his attention to "fortress Europe," Mr. Ben Ammar said.
Mr. Murdoch's British Sky Broadcasting is buying Manchester United P.L.C., Britain's richest soccer club, for about $1 billion. The Kirch alliance could allow him to tap Kirch's worldwide broadcasting rights for World Cup soccer and could strengthen his hand in negotiations to form a European "super league" of top soccer clubs like A. C. Milan, which is owned by Mr. Berlusconi.
Mediaset itself was listed on the Italian stock market in a similar transaction two years ago, with Mr. Berlusconi's Fininvest S.p.A. holding company selling part of its stake to Kirch, Prince Walid and others.

HEADLINE: Keeping Asia Liquid

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Preventing World Recession" (editorial, Sept. 17): With roughly 40 percent of the world in recession, it is imperative that the International Monetary Fund be provided with the $18 billion requested by the Clinton Administration. But I.M.F. financing is only a first step. 
 The Federal Reserve should also cut interest rates and loosen monetary policy. This would provide the liquidity without which Asia, Eastern Europe and South America would fail to stabilize. The flight of dollars from the developing world and depreciating local currencies have prevented affected economies from recovering their economic footing.
Making capital more available to them through lower interest rates and greater cash flow would help countries like those along the Pacific Rim grow their way out of recession. The economic deterioration that continues in much of the world must be stopped, and it is up to the United States to lead.
 
JERRY J. JASINOWSKI
President, National
Association of Manufacturers
Washington, Sept. 17, 1998

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
The Dow Declines by 36.05 as Other Gauges Post Gains

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks were generally higher yesterday, but the market's most closely watched indicator, the Dow Jones industrial average, ended with a small loss.
The Dow fell 36.05 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 7,897.20. Shares of companies whose profits are seen as vulnerable to slowing economies abroad were hit the hardest. Shares of Coca-Cola, which gets 66 percent of its net revenue from outside North America, accounted for nearly a third of the Dow's drop. 
 But shares of smaller companies and technology companies sent other market gauges sharply higher. The Nasdaq composite index, laden with many technology issues, closed up 17.37 points, or 1.03 percent, at 1,697.80. The Russell index of 2,000 smaller companies rose 5.60 points, or 1.54 percent, at 368.24.
Other market indexes rose. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 5.74, or 0.6 percent, to 1,029.63. Advancing stocks outnumbered decliners by a 19-to-11 ratio on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Dow average's failure to keep up with the gains in the broad market "raises the question of a change in leadership" away from big companies, said Robert Streed, a money manager with the Northern Trust Company, which oversees $200 billion. Big stocks trounced smaller ones for the last three years, and if the rest of the market is catching up now it may signal that stocks reached bottom on Sept. 1, when the Dow fell to 7,400.30, he said.
In one sign of rising optimism, investors put cash in stock mutual funds this month after pulling out an estimated $5.4 billion in August. August was the first month since September 1990 that investors withdrew more cash from stock funds than they added, according to Trimtabs.com, which tracks fund flows. The redemptions occurred as the S.&.P 500 fell 15 percent and some international equity markets had even bigger losses.
Shares of airlines were higher, pushing the Dow Jones transportation average up 62.65, or 2.24 percent, at 2,865.29. AMR rose 1 5/16, to 65 9/16;Delta Air Lines climbed 2 15/16, to 103 15/16; Southwest Airlines gained 1 5/16, to 21 9/16.
A number of technology stocks were strong. America Online rose 3 3/4, to 106 1/8, while Yahoo Inc. gained 6 5/8, to 102 15/16. Microsoft was up 1 5/16, to 109 3/16; Compaq Computer rose 1/4, to 31 7/8, and Micron Electronics, ended up 9/16 at 14 9/16.
Drug makers led the gains in the S.& P. 500.
"Drug stocks are a safe place to hide, as they have a source of growth not dependent on the domestic economy or overseas" sales, said Michelle Clayman, chief investment officer of New York-based New Amsterdam the Partners L.L.C, which oversees $652 million.
Schering-Plough rose 4 1/2, to 101 5/8; Pfizer gained 3 5/8, to 101 7/16, and Eli Lilly rose 3 9/16, to 79 7/8.
Gains were tempered by Coke and other companies that rely on overseas markets for a significant percentage of sales.
Jennifer F. Solomon, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, cut her 1998 and 1999 earnings estimate on Coke, and lowered her target price to $59 from $83 a share. Shares of Coca-Cola fell 2 15/16, to 56 1/4, and are down 36 percent from their July 14 high.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Trade Official Says China Market Is Closed Tighter

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 22

 BODY:
A senior American trade official today criticized what he called China's unwillingness to open its markets to foreign companies, and accused the Chinese of tightening some restrictions on foreign businesses.
The remarks by the official, David L. Aaron, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, reflected what has become an increasingly tense trade relationship between Beijing and Washington. 
 Mr. Aaron said China's policies had helped produce a $1 billion-a-week trade deficit for Americans. He said the United States would look for new ways to press China into allowing improved access for American businesses to the nation's 1.2 billion people if the situation did not improve. "They have taken this relationship for granted," Mr. Aaron said, adding later, "The list of barriers is just getting bigger and we're not crossing anything off the list -- that's the problem."
Mr. Aaron, who was in Beijing to attend a conference and meet with Chinese officials, offered hope that the huge trading partners could ultimately cooperate. But the polite discussions on trade that surrounded President Clinton's visit here this spring have evidently given way to exasperation and blunt talk. Mr. Aaron characterized his meetings with the Chinese as "somewhat somber."
"We recognize that the Chinese have lots of difficult problems to face," Mr. Aaron told a small group of reporters, listing the broad Asian economic crisis, troubled state-owned enterprises and this summer's disastrous floods. "But my job is to make sure that on that list of problems is this trade deficit and the treatment of businesses here."
United States figures show the trade deficit with China exceeding $50 billion annually, and growing.
Mr. Aaron's admonitions came after a tense few weeks in which new American regulations banned imported goods from China packed in untreated wood crates or pallets, a ban that may well affect more than half of Chinese exports to the United States.
American officials say the new requirements are necessary to prevent further invasions by the Asian long-horned beetle, which in the last two years has emerged from Chinese raw-wood packing material to kill thousands of trees in New York and Chicago. But Chinese trade officials say the regulations were motivated not by bugs but by protectionism.
"The unilateral action taken by the United States could impact the normal development of Sino-American trade," China's Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation said in a statement last week.
Although the United States has for years wanted Beijing to further open its markets, it had hoped China's stated desire to join the World Trade Organization would take care of the problem, since free markets are a condition of membership. But the Chinese Government has apparently accepted that it will not gain admission to the trade organization now, and the United States has been left to apply pressure on its own.
Today, Mr. Aaron said that barriers to American business in China seemed to be multiplying rather than shrinking.
He said, for example, that the authorities here had generally not let foreign companies develop a distribution network for their goods, and he complained of China's unwillingness to grant licenses to foreign companies in such service businesses as insurance. In the last few years, a number of American companies have established offices in Beijing, anticipating that such licenses would be approved.
Mr. Aaron also complained that the huge Chinese telecommunications market was mostly off limits to foreign companies and noted that the Government was contemplating banning the few foreign companies that had indirect investment in that industry.
China has created many more subtle barriers as well, Mr. Aaron said, such as increasingly cumbersome regulations on foreign currency transactions. He cited a resurgence in counterfeiting that was now so professional that copycat goods even carried fake Underwriters Laboratories seals.
"If W.T.O. isn't moving us toward market access and opening, we're going to have to find other methods," he said, adding that the Clinton Administration was now "looking at other options."
Officially, Mr. Aaron was in Beijing to attend a conference on Chinese energy needs and to talk to officials in preparation for the annual meeting of the Joint Committee on Commerce and Trade, a Chinese-American panel, in Washington next month. He said he was still optimistic that such joint forums could help resolve trade disputes, at least in some cases.
Chinese officials say the American trade deficit is not nearly as large as United States officials contend, maintaining that it is closer to $20 billion than $50 billion.

SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1964 words

HEADLINE: 'New' Germans Find Escape From Tainted Past

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: HANOVER, Germany

 BODY:
They have grappled with their nation's history and understand its shame. They see their future with a self-confidence their parents lacked.
Germany's baby boomers have come of age, a new elite that has moved into the country's boardrooms and its barracks, worldly, drawn largely from the former West Germany, and above all striving for a sense of normality in a land whose elders felt anything but easy with themselves. 
 Opinion polls give no clear indication of this generation's likely voting patterns in national elections on Sept. 27, in which Chancellor Helmut Kohl, 68, is in the fight of his political life against Gerhard Schroder, 54.
But it is clear that no politician can afford to ignore this generation, a broad swath of the 60 million voters. For it will define the agenda in business, style, the arts and, increasingly, in politics as a dominant Germany faces a new era.
"There is an entire generation stretching from 35 to 50 that is running the country," Lieut. Col. Carsten Jacobson, 43, a general staff officer and former tank commander, said at his home near a lake south of Hanover. "It is the managers, the political leading class, the top civil servants."
It is a generation forged by two key dates: 1968, when a student revolt in Europe produced a broader sense of its power, and 1989, when the fall of the Berlin wall led to German reunification. It is also a generation that has molded American thinking about how Germany will brace for a new century -- aware of its own interests and ready to pursue them, and to assume greater responsibility within the European and Atlantic alliances.
"The question is whether they have overcome their fear of being German, and the answer is: Yes," said J. D. Bindenagel, a senior United States State Department official with long experience in Germany.
German companies are major players in the economies of the victorious wartime Allies. German soldiers, once barred from service outside their country, now patrol the Balkans. When Europeans seek a lead in dealing with the Russian crisis, they turn reflexively to Bonn. And much of Europe's ability to make its single currency work will demand German leadership.
 
The Divide
Nazis Shaped the West, Communists the East
As with much of Germany's modern visage, it is a generation with two profiles: west and east.
Many westerners were born of parents who experienced Nazi Germany first hand, yet frequently lived in denial of complicity as they rebuilt their country into Europe's richest. Yet all were nurtured by the peace, prosperity and self-confidence of the German economic miracle.
In the former East Germany, the dynamic was different: a Communist leadership denied not just responsibility for the Nazi era, but also the individual initiative encouraged in the west -- creating divisions that linger today. But what differentiates Germany's baby boomers from their American counterparts is the legacy of the past.
German success, like American success, is measured in snappy suits and slick cars, exclusive vacations and rich homes. But where the American collective memory unfolded from victory in World War II, many Germans of an earlier generation emerged with the crushing, guilt-laden burden of the Holocaust and defeat.
By contrast, the new Germans are bolstered by a consensus that while Germans of their age must prevent history from repeating itself, time has distanced them from their forebears' guilt. They are far readier to assert their interests, sometimes as Germans, sometimes more as Europeans, in a contradictory world where globalization has heightened national competition, just as the conflicts of the post-cold-war era in places like Bosnia and Albania demand cooperation.
 
The Soldier
From Years of Isolation To a Global Role
Throughout the cold war, the soldiers of the former West Germany were forbidden -- by the Constitution and often by inclination -- from venturing outside the huge land mass patrolled by NATO. When the cold war ended, many Germans, including those in the military, still resisted American insistence that reunification brought new responsibilities in policing an unruly world.
Colonel Jacobson was not one of them. "We are a country at the crossroads of European history," he said. "We border nine countries. We are 80 million people. We are a wealthy country and a magnet to neighbors who are not as wealthy. It's generally felt that we have a moral burden. But I don't think we have any alternative but to take an active role."
Inevitably, though, the emergence of that role took Germany back to its past and, specifically, to its history in the Balkans, where Hitler's armies sustained a fascist regime in Croatia. From 1945 to the mid-1990's, when a German medical unit cautiously deployed to Croatia, followed by the dispatch of combat troops to Bosnia, the Balkans represented a taboo.
"It would be stupid as a German soldier to go to the Balkans without knowing what happened there," Colonel Jacobson said. "And since everything in the Balkans is history, there is no nice gesture to get around that."
So in late 1997, Colonel Jacobson set off for Sarajevo for what became a seven-month stint as military assistant to a German two-star general serving under American command of the international peace force in Bosnia.
It went "remarkably well," he said. Despite historical mistrust, there were no personal affronts. Indeed, he said, he discovered that working 24 hours a day with other soldiers in the multinational force, some from countries that had been invaded by Nazi Germany, "Germans were not looked at differently."
"We have found our way back to the choir of nations as soldiers," Colonel Jacobson said.
 
The Banker
U.S. Business Ties Blur Distinctions
Along that route, of course, the United States was a mentor. But here too, for a newer generation, attitudes toward America have become more textured as Germans have moved away from being perceived as Teutonic stereotypes.
"I don't feel very German in Britain or the United States," said Gabriele Eick, 46, the head of communications at Dresdner Bank. "I feel very much at home. I would be embarrassed if people thought: the typical German."
Ms. Eick's resume could almost be that of an American high flier, reflecting a career that for many years unfolded within German subsidiaries of big American corporations like IBM, A. C. Nielsen and Burson-Marsteller.
Now, though, Ms. Eick's career has brought her into a different and potentially more combative relationship with an important part of American society: part of her job is to mold the corporate response to a class-action suit by Holocaust survivors who say Dresdner and other banks profited from their suffering.
Ms. Eick was born in the former East Germany in 1952 and her family fled to the west just a few months before the Berlin wall was built in 1961.
"My generation grew up on American folk songs," she said. "I know more American folk songs than German ones. And this is how I learned a large part of my English. I grew up with a very strong, positive American orientation."
Sentiments like these are much different from those of people like Chancellor Kohl, whose teen-age years unfolded under the occupation of French and American forces.
Indeed, as Hermann Grohe, a 37-year-old member of Parliament in Bonn put it: "I meet American legislators with the feeling that these are representatives of the people in the most important democracy in the world. But I don't see them as 'the victor.' "
Nowhere has that been more evident than in the world of business. German publishing houses have taken huge stakes in American publishing. Volkswagen owns auto plants from the Czech Republic to Spain. Daimler-Benz bought Chrysler. SAP, a German software company, is the fourth largest in the American-dominated hi-tech world. BMW owns the Rover car company in Britain and has agreed with Volkswagen to parcel out ownership of Rolls Royce and Bentley.
 
The State Official
New Economic Gains Don't Yet Close Divide
The acquisitive drive was forced on German business by a changing world. The European single market and the prospect of a European single currency obliged companies to think in terms of far wider networks, while the broader dynamics of the auto industry led the drive for economies of scale as a means of survival in the global competition. And that, in turn, revolutionized German big business, creating the readiness not just to advance into global markets, but also to challenge Germany's stultified labor practices.
One of the key players in this transformation was Helmut Panke, 52, BMW's industrial relations director, who set up the company's operation in Spartanburg, S.C., between 1993 and 1995.
"Foreigners change because they see a different Germany," he said. "But Germany and the Germans changed because they have experienced more of the global network."
Of course that view came from the west, and Matthias Platzeck, 44, the environment minister of Brandenburg, in the east, sees things differently.
Mr. Platzeck was 7 when the Berlin wall was built, sealing him into a cocoon of social protection, outright repression and Soviet domination.
"If you learned a second language, it was Russian or Polish," Mr. Platzeck said. And even now, the sophistication of western Germans does not extend so easily to the easterners. "The ability to jump across the pond is a western thing," he said.
It was a world, he said, that treated the Holocaust as "a side issue" and tried to teach its children to glorify the Soviet Union. And it has left a different legacy.
In eastern Germany, unemployment is twice as high as in the west, at 20 percent, and it afflicts mainly the 50-plus generation, the group that in the west gained most from the economic miracle. The causes for the easterners' joblessness are well known: reunification brought a wave of Deutschmark capitalism, utterly destroying industries that had offered artificial full employment.
But, Mr. Platzeck said, that same shock wave may have galvanized a younger generation, forcing members into service industries, the media and other sectors. "Unlike in the west, 80 percent of professional people in eastern Germany who do have jobs have changed their jobs in the past seven years," he said. "Big changes are on the way with the European single currency. And easterners are better armed for that."
 
The Election
A Real-World Measure Of the Generation Gap
The generational shifts evoke the real subtext driving Germany's election: How will this new generation propel Europe's economic powerhouse toward the challenges of the European unity?
Mr. Kohl's Social Democratic opponent, Mr. Schroder, is 14 years younger than the Christian Democratic Chancellor and likes to call himself a Spatgeborene, a word that means "born late" and denotes those whose birth came late enough to avoid all taint of the Third Reich.
While Mr. Schroder is narrowly ahead in opinion surveys, though, his personal popularity is equaled by a Christian Democrat of his generation, Wolfgang Schauble, Chancellor Kohl's heir apparent. And many believe that if he won, Mr. Kohl would soon hand over to Mr. Schauble. In other words, whatever the outcome on Sept. 27, this is likely to be Mr. Kohl's last election before he bows out.
Mr. Schroder's choice as economics minister is Jost Stollmann, 43, an iconoclastic computer millionaire who has angered the Social Democratic party traditionalists by rejecting their left-wing economic platform.
"Germany's future," Mr. Stollmann declared recently, "is neither left nor right, not ideological but pragmatic. It will be a different way, our own German way."

HEADLINE: Midwest Farmers Running Out of Options in Protest on Imports

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BISMARCK, N.D., Sept. 22

 BODY:
Farmers and ranchers who blockaded Canadian border crossings on Monday to keep farm products out of the country may have few options besides seeking a grain-dumping action by the Federal Government with the International Trade Commission.
Hundreds of farmers and ranchers blockaded Canadian border crossings and stopped a Canadian Pacific train for about 20 minutes near Portal, N.D., by putting a tractor on the tracks. 
 One Montana farmer, Hank Zell of Shelby, said: "These little towns are drying up. Farmers don't have any money."
Frustration with trade policies has intensified so much that North and South Dakota officials began pulling over Canadian trucks last week under tougher inspection programs for wheat and livestock.
"Our market just keeps slipping away from us," said the blockade organizer, Ron Jensen of Sweetgrass. "We just can't afford to produce a bushel of grain for $2. The Federal Government says it costs us $5.54 to produce it."
The farmers have had this argument before.
From June 1993 to May 1994, Canada shipped nearly 91 million bushels of wheat south. Under pressure from farmers and farm-state lawmakers, the United States adopted limits that year on the amount of wheat Canada could export to the United States without paying tariffs.
But those quotas -- which allowed Canada to ship only 55 million bushels of wheat annually before tariffs were imposed -- were lifted a year later, and grain shipments from Canada have increased to 73.2 million bushels in the last year.
The law used to impose the tariffs was abolished during negotiations in 1995 under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, said Neal Fisher, administrator of the North Dakota Wheat Commission.
Now, the most talked-about and perhaps only option for the farmers is to get the Federal Government to bring a case against Canada before the International Trade Commission accusing the country of dumping grain at below-cost prices.
To do this, the Government would need to know the prices set by the Canadian Wheat Board, which exports all wheat grown in western Canada. But efforts by Congress's General Accounting Office to audit the board have failed.
Not everyone blames the Canadians. Ford Runge, an economics and law professor at the University of Minnesota, said Canadian grain imports might have some modest regional impact on prices, but in the main, farm prices are set by larger forces of supply and demand.
"This is just a reflection of farmers' frustration with low prices and a series of bad years," he said.
Canadian officials contend that they are simply meeting customer demand and are not dumping wheat on the American market.
"It's customer satisfaction we're capitalizing on now in the U.S.," said Jim Pietryk, a spokesman for the wheat board. "Our durum, the last couple of years, has been disease-free."
A North Dakota State University study last year found that durum and barley producers in the upper Midwest had lost nearly $270 million in income in three years because of Canadian grain dumping. Processors said they were forced to buy Canadian grain because of disease-plagued domestic crops.
American farmers dispute this, saying there is plenty of good grain south of the border.
Another problem for farmers is that United States trade officials tabulate wheat import figures on a nationwide basis. Mr. Fisher said that meant the impact of Canadian imports on farmers in the upper Midwest was not adequately measured.
A spokesman in the office of the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, who spoke on the condition he not be identified, pointed out that the United States exported 28 times as much wheat each year as it imported from Canada -- making it hard for farmers to make a case that the market has been disrupted.
The Asian currency crisis has made the situation worse by depressing demand from abroad. That and high-yield harvests at home have resulted in overflowing storage elevators, particularly in the Northwest.
Some farmers have little hope in Government intervention.
Larry Neubauer of Sweetgrass, Mont., said he had had it with trade officials.
"The peaceful ways, the talking ways, the diplomatic ways, have basically been exhausted," Mr. Neubauer said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Is Seeking More Money for Military Readiness

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
A week after the nation's military commanders warned him about growing fiscal strains on the armed services, President Clinton today proposed giving the Pentagon an immediate new infusion of cash and opened the door to a much larger increase in military spending in 2000.
In a letter to Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen, Mr. Clinton said he would take "additional steps" to plug a series of shortfalls already envisioned in the Pentagon's $270 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins on Oct. 1. 
 Those shortfalls, which commanders told the President were eroding their readiness to fight and win the next war, have led to shortages of spare parts for warplanes, cuts in training and difficulties in recruiting and keeping qualified troops.
Mr. Clinton specifically pledged to address each of those readiness problems and promised to avoid similar problems in the 2000 budget that the Office of Management and Budget will propose early next year.
"I commit to you that then men and women of our armed forces will have the resources that they need to do their jobs," Mr. Clinton said in the letter, which Pentagon officials made available on the condition that they not be identified.
The letter did not mention specific figures, but officials at the Pentagon said the Clinton Administration would immediately propose adding $1 billion to the $4 billion emergency supplement already proposed for the coming budget.
For the next budget, the President's commitment is less clear. A spokesman at the White House said Mr. Clinton had yet to commit himself to increasing the overall military budget for 2000, which is set to grow slightly to $276 billion
But an Administration official said Mr. Clinton -- implicitly in the letter and explicitly in conversations with senior officials at the Pentagon -- had indicated his support for the first significant increase in military spending since he took office.
How significant remains to be worked out. The Pentagon's budget makers have yet to come up with a figure, but analysts have estimated that an increase could fall between $10 billion and $20 billion, for an increase of 3.5 percent to 7 percent.
The President's pledges came only a week before the Joint Chiefs of Staff, led by Gen. Henry H. Shelton, is to appear before the Senate Armed Services Committee at a special hearing on problems with the military's readiness. The pledges will give the chiefs something to use to respond to Republicans who have become increasingly critical of the Administration's military spending, accusing Mr. Clinton of letting the armed forces weaken.
At their meeting with Mr. Clinton at the National Defense University last week, the Joint Chiefs and the unified combat commanders warned that the increasing duties at home and aboard placed heavy strains on the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps at a time when budgets have more or less stayed level with inflation.
The readiness strains have led to a series of problems, Pentagon officials say, from shortages of spare parts to a growing gap between civilian and military pay that many in the Pentagon believe is forcing the most qualified troops to leave.
In today's letter, Mr. Clinton wrote, "Readiness is a perishable commodity and requires our serious attention."
Mr. Cohen and General Shelton have tried to highlight the shortfalls in recent months, laying the groundwork for a plea for additional money. The issue has become more urgent, they have said, because Congress has refused for two years to agree to close more unneeded military bases, a step that could save $20 billion over the next decade.
Republican aides in the House and the Senate said today that they were unaware of the President's letter, though they indicated that any increase in defense spending was likely to receive broad support. Already there have been bipartisan calls to increase the Pentagon's budget for everything from new weapons programs to improvements in the quality of life.
It was unclear how the Administration would pay for any increase in military spending. Another Administration official said the $1 billion increase in the immediate future would most likely be obtained through cuts elsewhere in the Federal budget.
As for future budgets, Mr. Clinton has pledged not to spend any surpluses until the White House and Congress agree on how to preserve the Social Security system.
Without the surplus, the balanced-budget agreement would force the Administration to cut spending elsewhere to pay for any significant increase for the Pentagon, a move that could lead to fights within the Administration and the Democrat Party over priorities.
The agreement, which has been overtaken by the booming economy, capped Pentagon spending at about $270 billion this year, but the caps come off next year.
The Council for a Livable World Education Fund, an advocacy group in Washington, said in a statement today that Congress was using "anecdotal evidence" of readiness problems to justify pork-barrel increases in weapons systems in their home states. The council added, "Congress is more interested in preserving local jobs than helping to solve any readiness problems."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Nomura to Double Capital of U.S. Unit

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 22

 BODY:
The Nomura Securities Company said today that it would inject $380 million of capital into its American unit, Nomura Holding America Inc., this month to increase its financial strength.
Nomura, Japan's biggest brokerage firm, said the decision to almost double the unit's capital came in response to a deteriorating market environment, partly a result of economic turmoil in Asia and Russia. 
 Earlier this month, Nomura said its American and British units had combined losses of $350 million on their holdings of Russian Government bonds at the end of August, after Russia's slide into financial crisis.
In addition, there have been unconfirmed reports that Capital America, a San Francisco-based unit of Nomura Holdings that specializes in repackaging commercial real estate loans for sale to investors, lost about $200 million on loans. The business's founder and vice chairman, Ethan Penner, resigned last week to start his own company. Mr. Penner, 37, had unusually strong control of its venturesome lending policies.
Widespread concern that a worsening in emerging markets was hurting Nomura's profitability helped briefly drag down the brokerage firm's stock price today below 1,000 yen for the first time since November 1985. Its shares finished 16 yen lower at 1,030 yen, or $7.60.
After the news of Nomura's Russian losses, leading credit-rating agencies placed Nomura under review for possible downgrading.

HEADLINE: Rising Costs in Health Care

 BODY:
A report by economists at the Department of Health and Human Services predicts that growth in health-care spending will increase substantially over the next 10 years. Total health expenditures are expected to rise from $1 trillion in 1996 to $2.1 trillion by 2007, jumping from 13.6 percent of gross domestic product to 16.6 percent. That is likely to translate into much higher health insurance premium increases than has been the case in recent years. These numbers are discouraging, particularly since the projections do not even reach the years when baby boomers will begin utilizing health care intensively in their late 60's and 70's.
The relatively low growth in spending of the past four years is actually an aberration from long-term trends, made possible by a rapid shift of American workers into managed-care plans from costly fee-for-service plans where there were few constraints on what doctors and hospitals could charge or patients could request. Many economists have said for some time, however, that this tamping down of costs is a one-time effect achieved mostly by getting price discounts out of hospital systems and squeezing down doctors' fees. 
 The long-term ability of managed care to control escalating costs is likely to be more modest. Although it can help by subjecting doctors' decisions to review and emphasizing preventive care, managed care has not been able to resist consumer demands for expensive technological procedures, a big driver of health spending. Changing practice standards and new and more expensive drugs will continue to push up spending even after managed care squeezes the easy-to-attack inefficiencies out of the health delivery system. The growth of point-of-service plans where enrollees have greater choice of doctors may further weaken managed care's ability to control costs.
This country already spends more on health care as a share of gross domestic product than any other nation, yet 41 million Americans have no health coverage at all. The shift toward managed care has produced a few good years of relatively stable costs. But it has not reduced the problem of the uninsured. With costs starting to accelerate again, the hope that managed care could extract enough savings out of the system to cover millions of uninsured Americans seems less and less likely.

HEADLINE: Quarter Profit At Goldman Declines 25%

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN

 BODY:
Goldman, Sachs & Company said yesterday that it earned $754 million before taxes in its fiscal third quarter, a drop of about one-fourth from the second quarter, as global market turmoil took a toll on profit and cast doubts on Goldman's own planned public offering of stock.
Executives acknowledged yesterday that they were debating whether to delay the private partnership's much-anticipated initial public offering, a decision some market analysts look to as a statement on the stock market's health. If the firm were to delay the offering, it would suggest that some of America's most successful investment bankers considered it unlikely that financial markets would significantly recover before year's end. 
 The firm's six-man executive committee does not have to decide whether to proceed with the offering until early next month, said the executives, who spoke on the condition that they not be identified. It is still scheduled for November. But top company officials are at least considering the prospect of delaying until 1999, especially since the firm expects its earnings slide to continue through the fourth quarter.
"You can't go public if you can't deliver the quarter," a Goldman executive said. "And you can't fight the tape," he said, alluding to the falling stock prices of financial company rivals.
Conditions in financial markets and the stock prices of Goldman competitors have deteriorated sharply since June, when the 189 partners voted to take the firm public. Goldman's two main peers, Merrill Lynch & Company and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, have both seen their stock prices plunge by about half from their peaks in July. They had been trading at high levels in relation to earnings on hopes that profit would continue to grow quickly, but the reverse is turning out to be the case.
The Goldman, Sachs earnings decline is indicative of a broader Wall Street trend, as Goldman is the first of the big securities firms to report results. Many financial companies have suffered losses in emerging markets since August. But the bigger worry now is the health of bond markets in advanced economies, a far more important source of profit. Russia's decisions to devalue its currency and to default on some domestic debt have wreaked havoc with prices of debt securities, and the turmoil shows little sign of easing.
John A. Thain, Goldman's chief financial officer, said in a statement that the firm's earnings in some areas, including mergers and acquisitions advising and asset management, remained robust through the third quarter, which for Goldman means the months of June, July and August. But trading and underwriting of new equity and debt issues took a hit, he said, and the slowdown has continued in September.
"Increased volatility in the financial markets, the widening of credit spreads, a decline in liquidity in certain markets and a reduction in global equity values have adversely affected many participants in the financial services sector," Mr. Thain said. "We expect these conditions to negatively impact our fourth-quarter results."
Though Goldman's third-quarter earnings were 25 percent less than in the second quarter and about 20 percent less than the quarter a year earlier, results for the year to date remain strong.
For the first nine months of the 1998 fiscal year, the firm reported pretax earnings of $2.814 billion, compared with $2.447 billion for the corresponding period of 1997. Net revenue for the first nine months was $7.605 billion and expenses were $4.791 billion. Goldman reports only pretax earnings as the individual partners settle their own taxes.
The earnings drop is roughly in line with expectations, said Raphael Soifer, securities industry analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman. But because June and July were relatively strong months, the 25 percent slump in earnings for the quarter implies a bad August, he said. And with the slump continuing into September, the stars are not well aligned for a big Goldman initial public offering.
"One wonders how one can bring a big I.P.O. into a market this volatile," Mr. Soifer said.
Two other securities companies, Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers, will also report results this week. Analysts are expecting Morgan Stanley to show a similar 25 percent drop in earnings compared with the second quarter. Lehman Brothers, whose profit depends more on trading and the bond market than do Morgan's or Goldman's, is expected to sustain even sharper damage, with operating earnings falling by about half from the second-quarter level.
Virtually all other brokerage firms and big international banks are expected to report falling quarterly profit, and in some cases, losses.
Wall Street is usually quick to react to changes in market conditions, and many expect companies to begin laying off workers in coming weeks. Merrill Lynch and Bankers Trust have already warned that layoffs are possible.
Guy Moszkowski, who analyzes the securities industry for Salomon Smith Barney, said that with no quick turnaround for financial markets in sight, banks and brokerage firms would look for ways to save money.
"They will look to cut as much fat as they can as soon as they can," he said. But Mr. Moszkowski added that some Wall Street houses overreacted to the 1994 market downturn and dismissed too many people, making them ill prepared to profit when markets recovered. "The lesson from 1994, I think, is that they shouldn't be too quick to cut muscle."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Philippine Airlines may shut down operations tonight, a victim of the Asian economic crisis.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:
BARRING a last-minute rescue, Philippine Airlines, Asia's oldest scheduled carrier, will shut down at midnight tonight. This means passengers who until now have flown the airline's daily nonstop flight between Los Angeles and Manila, or the thrice-weekly nonstop flights between San Francisco and Manila, will have to make other arrangements. But no other arrangements from the United States will include nonstops.
Northwest Airlines, for example, has daily flights to Manila from nine United States cities, including New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco. But all of them connect through Tokyo, which after a layover of about two hours requires a change of plane and an additional four and a half hours of flying. Northwest's daily flight from Memphis to Manila via Tokyo also requires a stop and a change of plane in Seattle. 
 UAL's United Airlines flew nonstop between San Francisco and Manila until Feb. 20, when it finally pulled the plug on that unprofitable route. Now United's Manila-bound passengers have to fly to Tokyo and connect with another airline -- as do those of AMR's American Airlines and Delta Air Lines. Continental Airlines' passengers can fly nonstop to Honolulu from Newark, Houston and Los Angeles, then connect on Continental Micronesia to Manila after a stop in Guam.
Philippine Airlines has been hurt by a series of strikes, by the Asian financial crisis and by overly ambitious expansion plans that have saddled the carrier with $2 billion in debt. "Demand in Asia has just dried up, and several airlines there are verging on bankruptcy," said Michael Boult, director of supplier relations for Rosenbluth International, the large business travel management company.
Rosenbluth and other travel management companies almost never book clients on struggling airlines, lest they fail and leave passengers stranded. But they have no problem booking with Singapore Airlines, Qantas Airways, Air New Zealand, ANA, Cathay Pacific or Japan Airlines. Moreover, Mr. Boult said that the fire-sale fares offered by many Asian carriers, in an effort to keep afloat, had led to "aggressive corporate discounting" of as much as 25 percent -- even by United States and European carriers -- for fares to Asia.
"I think 1999 will still be rough going for the weaker Asian carriers," Mr. Boult said. "But there's no doubt in my mind that the Asian market will rebound in the year 2000," although not necessarily with all the current airlines intact.
 
Prices on the Rise
Business travelers should prepare themselves for another year of heavy passenger loads on airlines and high occupancies in business hotels. And, of course, higher prices for both. A preliminary study by American Express, released yesterday, projects an overall increase of 5 to 6 percent for the cost of business travel next year.
The price increases will again be led by air fares, which will rise an expected 4 to 5 percent, and for hotel rooms, which will go up 7 to 10 percent in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and the 22 other top business destinations,
The forecast numbers, based on data from American Express and other industry sources, could change if current economic turmoil overseas and stock market instability in the United States translate into lower demand for business travel. As of now, though, the company said, it is advising companies "to brace for another tough year with few travel bargains."
 
A Really Tall Ship
That behemoth looming over the New York skyline from Pier 88 beginning tomorrow will be neither an apparition nor something out of a Japanese science fiction film. Instead, it will be the 109,000-ton, 18-deck, $450 million Grand Princess, the world's most expensive and biggest passenger ship -- taller than either Niagara Falls or the Statue of Liberty.
Launched last May, the ship -- owned by the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company -- cruised the Mediterranean until Sept. 11, before heading to Manhattan. The actress Olivia de Havilland will formally christen the ship next Tuesday at 10:30 A.M.; the first marriage in the ship's wedding chapel will be performed this Friday at 10 A.M. Beginning Oct. 4, the ship -- 53 feet too wide to get through the Panama Canal -- will begin almost eight months of seven-day Caribbean cruises from Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Obuchi Break Ice but Solve No Economic Problems

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

 BODY:
President Clinton and Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan met for the first time yesterday and struggled to reassure the markets that they agree on a common strategy to pull the world's second-largest economy out of a recession that is fueling economic turmoil on three continents.
But after nearly three hours of meetings in New York, the two leaders emerged with no agreement about what Japan will do about the trillion dollars in bad debts that have acted like an anchor on the world economy. 
 Their chief areas of agreement, aides said, were a shared concern about North Korea, a decision to meet again early next year and the politically mandatory promise to call each other by their first names.
While trying to sound upbeat, American officials acknowledge that they emerged from the meeting with no better sense of how Mr. Obuchi planned to resolve a politically paralyzing debate over the bank debt that is already threatening the Prime Minister's loose grasp on power.
The bad bank debts now overshadow trade disputes and growing security concerns in the Pacific as the No. 1 issue between the two countries. The tower of debt has frozen economic activity, forced Japan to keep insolvent banks afloat and set off waves of turmoil far beyond Japan's own shores.
In a brief and carefully stage-managed appearance with Mr. Obuchi, President Clinton acknowledged that an "immensely complicated political situation" in Japan limited the Prime Minister's options.
Indeed, the divisions among the political parties in Japan are so complex that Mr. Obuchi was unable to address Mr. Clinton's main concern: Tokyo's vow to use tens of billions of dollars in public funds to prop up some of the world's largest banks.
As the two men met, a political deal to merge or nationalize the virtually insolvent Long Term Credit Bank of Japan, a huge financial institution, appeared to be unraveling in Tokyo.
"The Prime Minister made it clear that they were working very hard on this legislation, that there are a lot of moving pieces, and he did not make a commitment," Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said yesterday afternoon.
Meetings with American presidents are always important for Japanese prime ministers. No matter what the subject of the session, it is critical for a new Japanese leader to demonstrate that he can hold his own with an American president and fend off, when necessary, the incessantly demanding Americans.
To bolster the Prime Minster, the White House planned to fly the two leaders to the Rockefeller estate in Tarrytown, where they could hold their meeting in a bucolic setting. But fog kept their helicopters grounded, and the meeting was held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Park Avenue.
What made this meeting unusual was that it was also important for Mr. Clinton, at several levels. Without resolving Japan's problems, Mr. Clinton's hopes of calming the world financial turmoil -- a task he committed himself to in a speech last week at the Council on Foreign Relations -- would be greatly impaired, if not doomed.
More immediately, the session was the latest opportunity for Mr. Clinton to demonstrate that he is focusing on substantive issues despite the continuing jockeying in Washington over impeachment proceedings or a possible censure.
Mr. Clinton insisted to reporters at one point yesterday that he had ignored the televised deluge of testimony and commentary. "Believe it or not, I haven't read the report," he said, referring to Kenneth Starr's referral to Congress.
But as a political diversion, the meeting with Mr. Obuchi did not amount to much.
The lack of progress came as little surprise to the Administration. This was the fourth time in 18 months that Mr. Clinton has urged a Japanese prime minister to act quickly on resolving the banking crisis that has frozen lending and investment throughout Asia.
But despite the series of running meetings between the two countries in Tokyo, San Francisco and Washington, there is little to show in the way of progress -- beyond resentment of American pressure in Japan and frustration at Japanese intransigence in Washington.
The American strategy for dealing with Japan has been to coordinate a series of increasingly urgent-sounding warnings -- first from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Mr. Summers, then from Germany and other European countries, and most recently from the International Monetary Fund. The problem is how to direct those critiques.
In an interview on Monday and at a news conference yesterday, Mr. Obuchi appeared to agree with the broad outlines of the American strategy: to pump money into viable banks and force the sale of real estate that has been sitting on the banks' books -- mostly unsold, because the banks do not want to have to confront how far prices have fallen.
But striking that deal involves finding common ground among the strongest political forces in Japan. Among them are banks and companies that finance the country's political parties, particularly Mr. Obuchi's Liberal Democratic Party. And then there are the opposition leaders, in control of the upper house of Parliament, who reflect the popular distaste for bailing out badly run banks and real estate moguls.
Mr. Obuchi seemed to reflect the difficulty of weaving through that minefield yesterday when he said he was "neither optimistic nor pessimistic" about the chances of getting financial reforms through Parliament. Taking a line from Mr. Clinton, he said that "this is not only an issue for Japan, but something that has major implications on economies of Asia as well as the whole world."
In his interview on Monday, Mr. Obuchi acknowledged that he had yet to convince the Japanese public or Parliament that the issue went beyond Japan's domestic interests. But he argued that he had been underestimated, a point he made obliquely to Mr. Clinton today when he noted that he had been compared in the American press to "cold pizza," a slight that clearly annoyed Japanese bureaucrats.
Mr. Clinton, his aides said, reassured Mr. Obuchi that he had eaten cold pizza the night before in his hotel.
