HEADLINE: One Patch of Russia's Economic Crazy Quilt

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

DATELINE: KRASNOYARSK, Russia, Sept. 18

 BODY:
With the rugged stoicism that typifies this vast Siberian territory, Nina V. Popova thought she could ride out Russia's economic storm.
But last week tax inspectors barged into her small food shop. After poring through her ledgers, they warned her she had violated Gov. Aleksandr Lebed's new "anti-crisis" decree. 
 "They said we can only charge 10 percent more than we pay for the food," she said. "But we have to pay for electricity and heat. We have to pay for security, and we have to pay salaries. If they force this decree on us we simply won't survive."
Russia's financial crisis has not only rocked Moscow's political establishment. It has also stirred many of Russia's far-flung regions to set their own economic course and establish price controls.
A former general, presidential hopeful and the new governor of this Siberian region, Mr. Lebed has led the charge. Angry at the soaring prices that have stunned Russians, Mr. Lebed has not just declared war on inflation. He has tried to make it illegal.
He is hardly alone. From the northwestern city of Novgorod to the western territory of Yakutia, authorities are taking a page out of the socialist playbook and intervening to set prices.
Russia is fast becoming a crazy quilt of zones with Draconian price controls, territories with milder price restrictions and regions with no controls at all.
The populist decrees have brought a measure of comfort to consumers shocked by sharp jumps in prices for food and medicine.
"We may infringe on the rights of people but it is in their interest," Mr. Lebed said in interview. "The strict measures have played their role and soon will be abolished."
But the stop-gap controls also contain the seeds of new problems. Stores and factories complain they are being denied the profit they need to weather Russia's raging economic storm. Shortages have emerged, as producers ship their goods to regions where prices run free.
Virtually nobody thinks the controls are a substitute for a national strategy to rescue Russia from its economic malaise.
But with Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov still struggling to form a national Cabinet, there is no overarching plan.
Mr. Lebed owes his job to Krasnoyarsk's economic distress. Tapping the deep well of discontent, Mr. Lebed scored an upset victory over the region's incumbent Governor in a bitterly contested race last spring.
An immense region one-fourth the size of the United States, Krasnoyarsk has some of the nation's largest factories along with Siberia-size economic problems. But Mr. Lebed assured the voters that the region need an experienced crisis manager, not an economist.
Certainly, Mr. Lebed has been sorely tested. With the collapse of the ruble, tax revenues plummeted. Panic buying cleared the shelves of baby food and cold medicine, leaving the region with dangerously small reserves.
Last week, residents in the city of Krasnoyarsk, the administrative capital of the region, found themselves without hot water when the authorities ran short of coal.
The only bright spot came when Mr. Lebed hosted a glitzy popular music festival, which was sponsored by one of Russia's leading television networks -- a brief distraction in what promises to be one of the toughest winters in years.
Chastened by his region's economic woes, Mr. Lebed no longer talks confidently about single-handedly turning the situation around. Krasnoyarsk, he says, needs a greater share of the nation's tax receipts and lower rail and electricity tariffs to thrive over the long term.
It is Mr. Lebed's short-term plan, however, that has led Krasnoyarsk's citizens to draw the political battle lines. Anxious to quell the economic turmoil sweeping the nation, Mr. Lebed has decreed controls on the price of meat, fish, bread, flour, cereal, pasta, beverages and coal.
The measures officially took effect a week ago when the order was published on the front page of the regional newspaper Krasnoyarsk Worker.
Under Mr. Lebed's system, producers who want to raise the wholesale price of goods need to appeal to a panel of government officials at least five days in advance. Officially, no ceiling on wholesale prices was set. But a Lebed aide has proclaimed that producers should be satisfied with a profit of 2 percent.
Retail prices are regulated according to a formula. Shop owners are not be allowed to sell their food and beverages for more than 10 percent more than what they paid for them. And Krasnoyarsk's tax inspectors are conducting spot checks to make sure.
Mr. Lebed has emerged in recent weeks as the most popular alternative to the Communists in the public opinion polls. But his brand of capitalism is both populist and exceedingly vague. "I am certainly on the verge of breaking the law, but I think my measures are justified," Mr. Lebed said earlier this month. "The emergency situation is compelling me to take emergency measures."
Defending his price controls, Mr. Lebed said they were needed to head off a wave of frenzied buying by consumers desperate to stock up before prices soared even further.
Another goal, he said, was to stop profiteering by local producers, who were taking advantage of the crisis to ratchet up their prices even though they have been somewhat insulated from the effects of Russia's falling currency. The aim, he insisted, was not to set the price of imported goods.
"Why should milk become more expensive? Has the price of cows gone up?" he said in an interview.
Mr. Lebed is not the only one to turn to price controls. Kaliningrad has declared a state of emergency. The tax police in Novgorod have prowled through the city, fining shops for exorbitant prices.
In the southern Russian city of Stavropol, fights broke out when consumers and merchants banded together against government inspectors, who they complained were interfering with local trade.
Even pricey Moscow has imposed a 20 percent limit on the markup for basic staples, though city officials insist it is more of a guideline than a law.
Still, Mr. Lebed's decree has been assailed by his critics, who say it shows his penchant for simplistic and authoritarian solutions to complex economic problems.
"This shows that no member of the Lebed team thinks in economic terms," said Aleksei M. Kleshko, a member of the Krasnoyarsk City Council."They only know how to deal with the crisis through administrative means."
To be sure, many local factory directors and shop owners are unhappy.
"The Government acts just like it did in the days of Soviet power, when business people were considered bourgeois speculators," said Yevgeniya Kuznetsova, the president of Pikra, a local beverage company and the first factory to be privatized in the Krasnoyarsk region.
After the ruble collapsed, the upgrading of the factory's beer production unit was stopped in mid-stream after a German factory refused to provide any more equipment on credit.
That has increased the factory's need for cash. Meanwhile, sales have fallen, as consumers have cut back on their purchase or beer and soft drinks so that they can stock up on flour, grain and cooking oil.
Ms. Kuznetsova said her company will be skating too close to the edge if it is restricted to a profit rate of 2 percent. Already, she has gone to a four-day work week to reduce costs.
"The government does not seem to worry about the collapse of small and medium business," she said bitterly.
At her small shop down the street from Pikra, Ms. Popova is more distressed than angry. A sturdy woman with an engaging manner, she voted for Mr. Lebed because of his promises to bring order to Krasnoyarsk.
Ms. Popova is already something of a survivor. She set up her food store in a working class district earlier this year after the investment company she was working for went bankrupt. Her store sells sausages, bread, alcohol and cooking oil. Saleswomen receive just 360 rubles a month (about $24 at current exchange rates) for their 12-hour-a-day jobs. Because the volume of sales is low and because her store also has to pay for utilities and an alarm system, Ms. Popova needs to mark up her goods by 20 percent just to break even, she said.
The Krasnoyarsk tax police, however, were not impressed by her arguments. After shuffling through the shop's balance sheets, they told her the store was exceeding the 10 percent mark-up allowed for salt, sugar and cereal. No fines were levied yet, but Ms. Popova was summoned to the local tax office to do some explaining.
"All summer long I told our saleswomen they should be patient and that I would increase their salaries a little bit in the fall," she said. "Now, I may have to fire some of them."
Still, Ms. Popova is reluctant to assign the blame to the gruff-talking Governor.
"I pinned hopes on him because I thought he would be tough," she recalled. "But he turned out to be too tough. He's not an economist, though, and this was probably done by his team. I still hope to prove to him that this is not right, and I might even vote for him again."

HEADLINE: About New York;
An 'Invisible' Life Remains So in Death

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
JOSE SORIANO loved walking around the city. It was a welcome stress-buster from his routine of working long shifts at a Brooklyn clothing factory. Some days he sauntered through Central Park to his railroad flat in El Barrio, taking in the sights of the city he adopted eight years ago when he moved here from Mexico. His wife, Fausta, worried about him, but he shrugged off her concerns. There's always light, he reassured her. And people look out, too.
"He always said: 'I would never leave New York. I love this city,' " his wife recalled. "He said he would only leave as a dead man." 
 In the next few days, Mr. Soriano will return to Mexico just that way. In a box. On Saturday night, as he was walking home through Central Park, he was stabbed to death near Belvedere Castle. He was 47 years old and leaves behind the family that had joined him in this country only four years ago.
As is the custom among the tightly knit extended families that cushion the hard life of Mexican immigrants in New York, friends and relatives bearing food and comfort have been trooping up the dark, narrow staircase of the Sorianos' tenement home on East 106th Street.
The rooms are nearly barren, mostly just beds, dressers and pictures of Our Lady of Guadalupe. The place is quiet, save for the sound of murmured adult conversation or the squeals of babies being carried by young women.
The silence extends to the rest of the city, too. Unlike other times when people have been beaten or killed in Central Park, there has been little outrage over Mr. Soriano's death. Contrast that with past attacks on the Jogger or the Piano Teacher, to name two vicious crimes in the city's great green backyard that infuriated the public and kept journalists busy for weeks.
Nor have there been visits from the Mayor or condolence calls from the Police Commissioner. Maybe the response would have been better had early reports not inaccurately called Mr. Soriano homeless, or if the Sorianos had been tourists or more upwardly mobile. But they are the kind of people whose countrymen do the kind of drudge work that keeps the local economy growing and humming for the benefit of the leisure class.
Basically, the reaction is as dead as Mr. Soriano. And the people around him know it.
"I think there is an obvious difference in how people are treated and how crimes are treated for people who live below 96th Street and people who live above 96th Street," said the Rev. Bruce Lewandowski, the associate pastor of St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church, the Sorianos' parish. "You have somebody here who is a so-called 'invisible person,' an immigrant who is most likely undocumented. They're invisible. They don't count."
So much so, that it took the authorities a day to realize that Mr. Soriano was not homeless. That description might have been true a few years ago, and only in the emotional sense, as he made the transition from Mexico to New York. He had come to the city to save some money and bring his wife and two sons up north, a goal he accomplished four years ago. His wife can still remember the exact date, July 29, 1994. A Friday.
"He had gone to Mexico and I told him I did not want to stay alone anymore," she said in Spanish. "For good or bad, I came with him. I didn't want to be separated anymore. I wanted to be by his side."
TRUE enough, they even worked together in a factory that made maternity clothing. It helped ease her transition to a new country, although she stopped working nearly three years ago when their daughter Grizelle was born. Mrs. Soriano's health was not good, so he told her to stay home while he put in six days a week at the Brooklyn factory for a few hundred dollars.
"He was paid by the piece," she said. "So when he could, he would want to continue working. He was one of those people who did not want to be at home. He would leave at 6 in the morning and come home at 10."
As difficult as such a meager existence was, the Sorianos found pride in being able to provide for their three children. They knew no other way.
"He always said it was hard here, but it was harder in Mexico," Mrs. Soriano said. "I never asked the government for help. We live to work."
Last Saturday he left work and went to a store to buy a pair of baseball cleats for a friend who played with him on a team in Red Hook. For the first time in their life together in New York, he never came home. Mrs. Soriano kept an all-night vigil.
"I sat," she said. "I stood. I looked out the window for him. But no."
The next day, she said detectives spoke to her husband's teammates in Brooklyn, and that's when word of his fate finally reached her.
"I think he wanted to come home walking through the park," Mrs. Soriano said. "And he found death along the way."
The police took her to the precinct station house, she said, then let her go after a while, promising to let her know when they had something to report. She said she has not heard anything since the police arrested a suspect in the case, only to drop the charges later.
"I heard the Mayor talking about the crime on the news," she said. "But nobody called from his office. Is it because we are Hispanic? Do they think we come here to take something from them? We only come to work. Or is it because we're poor?"
Mrs. Soriano does not have enough money to send his body back to Mexico. Friends and relatives are taking up a collection, but they are just as strapped as she. Yet they offer lessons in compassion.
"When something like this happens, we talk to each other and try to help with what we can," she said. "Maybe they cannot help with money, but they can help with moral support."
She will help, too, by returning to work in the coming weeks. Her husband's bosses said she was welcome to her old job.
"I want to push my children ahead," she said. "My husband is gone. He has to rest. The dead go to rest. The living are here to struggle to keep living."
She walked over to the window where she stood on Saturday night. In her hand was a picture of her husband, natty in a baseball uniform that had "Braves" emblazoned on the jersey.
"Mira," their daughter, Grizelle said, as she tugged at the picture. "Papi. Papi."
Outside, the streets were gray and damp. A few doors away from the Sorianos' building, a wall was decorated with a mural of St. Sebastian tied to a pillar, his nearly naked body pierced by arrows.
"We walk among each other in a deep dream," read an inscription, "committing small acts of violence among one another. The heart that awakens first will take us to the heavens from this earth."

HEADLINE: Russia and U.S. Plan to Guard Atom Secrets

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Russian and American officials agreed today on a program to discourage Russia's nuclear scientists from leaving for Iraq, Iran or other aspiring nuclear powers.
The aim is to create commercial projects in Russia's closed nuclear cities, which are off-limits to foreigners and Russians without special permission. 
 Throughout the cold war, the cities produced nuclear material and weapons for the Soviet nuclear arsenal, but since the breakup they have fallen on hard times.
Nuclear workers have found themselves without jobs, and wages have been delayed for those who are employed. This month nuclear workers demanding back pay demonstrated in front of the Atomic Energy Ministry here.
Under the accord the United States will help the cities start commercial, non-military ventures. Up to $30 million is to be provided through the 1999 budget year.
The agreement covers all 10 of the closed cities. The initial assistance, however, will concentrate on three: Arzamas-16, near the Volga River city of Nizhny-Novgorod, Chelyabinsk-70, in the Urals, and Krasnoyarsk-26, in Siberia.
The accord was signed today in Vienna by Bill Richardson, the American Energy Secretary, and Yevgeny Adamov, the Russian Atomic Energy Minister.
"I cannot emphasize enough how important it is to us all that economic hardship not drive Russian nuclear weapon scientists into employment in places like Iran and North Korea," Mr. Richardson said.
Some specialists, however, said the program was far too limited given the scale of the problem, which has been aggravated by the collapse of the ruble and soaring inflation.
Kenneth Luongo, a former Energy Department official who heads a non-profit group focusing on Russian security issues, said it would take months before the first money can be dispersed because of Congressional reporting requirements in the United States.
He said the assistance should be expanded to include not just the development of new businesses but joint efforts to develop environmental technology and other forms of cooperation.
Under the accord a joint American and Russian panel will pick the commercial projects that will receive money. American officials said it was too soon to provide specifics but that the type of project they had in mind was under way at Arzamas-16, where the Russians plan to convert a warhead production plant to produce automotive parts.
In addition to investing in commercial ventures, the fund will be used to train Russian nuclear specialists in business planning. The two sides also signed a parallel agreement intended to smooth the way for the United States to buy uranium removed from Russian nuclear weapons, another potentially important source of income for the cash-strapped Russian nuclear complex.
Russia is converting highly-enriched uranium from nuclear warheads into low-enrichment uranium under a 1993 agreement with the United States. The low-enriched uranium is to delivered to the United States for use as reactor fuel.
But the deal has snagged over disputes about the terms of the sale. Today's agreement does not resolve all the outstanding differences, but the Energy Department hopes it will lead to a commercially-viable arrangement.

HEADLINE: D'Amato Ad Seeks to Exploit Upstate Resentment of New York City

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY

 BODY:
Playing directly to upstate voters' longstanding antagonism toward New York City, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato began broadcasting a television advertisement yesterday asserting that his Democratic challenger, Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, had written off upstate New York with statements and votes throughout his career.
"Liberal Brooklyn Congressman Chuck Schumer doesn't think upstate New York matters," the announcer says over the bouncy sounds of lounge music, while the screen depicts a jagged saw cutting off the rest of New York State and leaving only downstate behind. The advertisement will air only north of New York City, Mr. D'Amato's aides said. 
 The advertisement reinforces the principal message spread by Mr. D'Amato, a Republican seeking a fourth term in Washington, during a two-day trip upstate on Sunday and Monday: that Mr. Schumer was hostile to the concerns of people who live north of New York City. To make the point, the advertisement pointed to statements and votes cast by Mr. Schumer, going back to 1977, on bills ranging from cutting dairy price supports to raising gas taxes.
"On Election Day, send Chuck Schumer a message: There's more to New York State than just Brooklyn," the announcer says.
Mr. Schumer's advisers attacked the advertisement as polarizing and politically out of bounds. "It is a desperate and misleading attempt at division from a candidate who is behind in the polls," said Howard L. Wolfson, Mr. Schumer's spokesman. "Chuck Schumer is a tax-cutting, crime-fighting Democrat and Al D'Amato just doesn't know how to react to that."
Mr. D'Amato's decision to air the stark advertisement -- and risk both alienating supporters in New York City and courting criticism that he is seeking to divide voters -- clearly signals the political weight he is attaching to upstate in this difficult re-election campaign. Mr. D'Amato's advisers, explaining the reasons behind the pointed attack, said that based on past elections, they expected 45 percent of the vote to come from upstate, compared with 30 percent in New York City and 25 percent from the suburbs.
In 1994, Gov. George E. Pataki also banked on upstate support to defeat Mario M. Cuomo, but avoided direct appeals to rivalries between the two parts of the state. In this campaign, Mr. Pataki, who is by all accounts in a strong position as he seeks a second term this year, has made a particularly vigorous appeal for support from downstate voters -- an appeal that Democrats said yesterday might be complicated by the emerging tactic of his fellow Republican.
In effect, Mr. Pataki and Mr. D'Amato are offering different political responses to what they each perceive as the same problem: that Republicans will be hurt this year by the struggling upstate economy. Mr. D'Amato is trying to push up his vote upstate, where he has historically been strong, while Mr. Pataki, who is looking for a large re-election victory to enhance his credentials as a national candidate, is looking to New York City for support.
In making the advertisement, Mr. D'Amato's advisers combed through Mr. Schumer's record in Congress and the State Assembly, seeking votes that served the interests of Mr. Schumer's constituents in Brooklyn but might not sit well with voters elsewhere in the state. For example, Mr. Schumer voted for two bills designed to curb payments to dairy farmers, to the benefit of milk drinkers. He also voted three times to increase the gas tax, another position that was not likely to offend the sentiment in his urban district.
Mr. D'Amato's advisers called the attack a fair case based on Mr. Schumer's record. "These are his quotes and his votes," said Kieran Mahoney, a senior political adviser to Mr. D'Amato. "And I think if anybody had some concerns about this, it would be the 40 percent of New Yorkers who live west of the Hudson River and north of the Tappan Zee Bridge."
However, Mr. Schumer's aides disputed one central element of Mr. D'Amato's advertisement -- its quotation of Mr. Schumer as saying, "To me, the West begins across the Hudson River."
Mr. Wolfson said the comment was taken out of context. And a transcript of the April 1997 press conference where Mr. Schumer made it suggests he was making a joke. Mr. Schumer mistakenly identified Senator Richard J. Durbin as being from Idaho. He is from Illinois.
"To you, I am from a Western state," Mr. Durbin said, according to Federal News Service, which transcribes news conferences in Washington.
The transcript describes Mr. Schumer as laughing, and then saying: "That's right. To me, the West begins across the Hudson River. In any case, we are glad to be here."
Mr. Mahoney defended the use of the quotation. "He said it," Mr. Mahoney said.
Mr. D'Amato's supporters did not offer any apologies for the tactics. Asked if they were playing to prejudice among upstaters against city residents, Edward I. Koch, the former Mayor who lost his 1982 bid for governor largely because of a poor showing upstate, let out a howl: "Absolutely!"
He called Mr. Schumer a typical New York City politician -- and he did not mean that as a compliment. The Congressman, Mr. Koch said, "takes credit for everything. He's a stereotype."
"Not all is fair in love and war," Mr. Koch said. "This is fair. It's not unfair to say that a candidate that comes from one section of the state might discriminate in favor of the section he comes from."
New York's voting history offers an explanation for Mr. D'Amato's tactics. In 1992, he defeated Robert Abrams, his Democratic opponent, by about 81,000 votes out of 7 million cast. Mr. Abrams won New York City by just over 460,000 votes, and Mr. D'Amato made up the difference by his showing in the suburbs and upstate.
And Mr. D'Amato, who was born in Brooklyn and made his name on Long Island, would appear to have little to lose in the county that he once called home. At last count, there were 133,913 registered Republicans in Kings County, compared with 846,512 Democrats.

HEADLINE: HOT SPOTS/SILICON HOLLOW;
Bomb's Birthplace Gets Down to Business

BYLINE: By CHRIS WOHLWEND 

DATELINE: OAK RIDGE, Tenn.

 BODY:
THIS city of 28,000 accepted long ago that its claim to fame was as a birthplace of the atomic bomb, which also brought a modicum of fortune.
It was here that uranium was enriched for the first nuclear weapons. And even though nuclear fuel is still manufactured by the Oak Ridge National Laboratories, the end of the cold war and ensuing layoffs and buyouts left a high concentration of brainpower in this area idle. That talent pool has since become a lure for entrepreneurs interested in capitalizing on the city's history of science and technology. 
 "The technical thinking has always been here," said Thomas C. Rogers, a business leader active in development projects in what locals call Silicon Hollow. What was missing was a mechanism to harness that thinking into profitable purposes.
That is why Technology 2020 was born, a nonprofit "incubator" geared to high-tech endeavors, the product of a collaboration among the Oak Ridge and Knoxville chambers of commerce, the University of Tennessee and the Energy Department. Financing is provided by the Energy Department, the university and private companies like BellSouth, Motorola and U.S. Internet, as well as Lockheed Martin and Bechtel Jacobs, the primary contractors for the Federal laboratories here.
As Mr. Rogers, the president of Technology 2020, described it, the organization provides space, up-to-the-minute communications networks and mentoring and guidance for technology start-ups. "First it's, 'Look, it works,' from the technical people, then it's, 'What's the market for it?' " Mr. Rogers explained. "That's where we come in."
The first graduate of Technology 2020 was Pro-2-Serve, which assembles teams of technicians and engineers to work on short-term projects, like screening prospective managers for a John Deere plant and developing a personal computer-based firefighter qualification system for the National Association of State Foresters and the Forest Service.
Pro-2-Serve's president, Barry Goss, and his wife, Karen Goss, the co-founder, said they knew that people in Oak Ridge had precision skills in narrowly defined fields that could be used in a variety of applications. In 1997, its first full year of operation, the company grossed $3 million in revenues.
The graybeard of rebirth here is Ipix, founded 12 years ago by Steve Zimmerman and Lee Martin, engineers at Oak Ridge National Laboratories. Their idea was to remove the distortion from photographs that are made with a 180-degree (fisheye) lens. In two years, they developed software that with a digital camera provides a 360-degree undistorted view of an image by using only two photographs, thereby creating an "immersive" experience for viewers.
The applications? Someone buying a house can "stand" in a room on the Internet and "tour" the entire space. Or an Elvis Presley aficionado can visit the Graceland Web site and take in the King's Jungle Room. Or a football fan can take the field with his favorite N.F.L. team. And it can all be done on the home computer.
Ipix, now headed by a former Motorola executive, Jim Phillips, is flush with victories in two patent-protection suits and has landed contracts with Kodak, Nikon, CNN, the Discovery Channel and other companies, including car makers and resort chains. "The top graduates from M.I.T. and Princeton come here to work," Mr. Phillips said. "When I say we're in Oak Ridge, people all over the world -- scientists, engineers -- know exactly what I'm talking about."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jim Phillips, left, and Steve Zimmerman of Ipix, which creates 360-degree images. (Rick Owens for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: McCall Says Pension Fund Is to Invest in Small Concerns

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
A month after he warned that New York City's economy is too dependent on the financial giants on Wall Street, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall announced that the state employees' pension fund would invest $100 million in a program that makes loans to small businesses in the city and around the state.
The loans should help create jobs for workers with few skills in communities where work is hard to find, Mr. McCall said. The 15-year loans are administered by the New York Business Development Corporation, a private organization created by the State Legislature in the 1950's and financed by 159 banks around the state. 
 Despite the job benefits, the pension fund is less interested in doing good than in making a profit, Mr. McCall said. "You may describe this as socially responsible," he said of the program, "but we see it as a sound investment."
A similar $100 million investment that the fund made 10 years ago has had an annual return of 7.75 percent, according to the Comptroller's office.
The earlier investment financed 290 loans worth $82 million, which the Comptroller's office said created almost 8,000 jobs.
"These are people you can really depend on," Mr. McCall said of the borrowers. "They are putting their heart and soul, and some of their own money, into it."
The new $100 million investment is actually small potatoes for the $105 billion pension fund, which covers 880,000 state and local government workers. The booming stock market has produced unusually high returns for the fund, which last year had a 30 percent gain on its investments; during the last two years, taxpayers have saved $530 million, because the big investment gains meant that governments were able to contribute less to the pension system, Mr. McCall said.
While the profits from a small-business investment program are far lower than those produced by the stock market during the last few years, they are far steadier, Mr. McCall said. The fund diversifies, he said, so that "it is not affected by the current ups and downs in the market."
Mr. McCall, who is running for re-election, made his announcement in front of Fine Fare Grocers, a supermarket on Frederick Douglass Boulevard just north of 132d Street in Harlem. Three years ago, the spot was a vacant lot, which Mariano Diaz bought from the city with the help of a $200,000 loan from the program, he said.
Mr. Diaz, whose family is in the grocery business and who already owned a food store on 110th Street, said he took the risk of opening the new supermarket, which is surrounded by several housing projects, because he could own the building himself.
"I control my own destiny," he said, instead of paying a landlord. Today, Mr. Diaz and his wife, Iris, employ 15 people at the store, and have opened another in Brooklyn.
Another beneficiary of the program is Centre Fence, a Bronx company that sells and installs chain-link fences. A $600,000 loan allowed the company to buy a warehouse in Throgs Neck. Because Centre Fence now owns its own building, it has been able to become bonded to do larger jobs, said Marty Friedman, the company's controller.
Business is now so good, Mr. Friedman said, that the company has hired and is training 8 unskilled workers to help out its 10 longtime employees.
Without the program, the company would have had a hard time expanding, he said. Unlike a bank, the program was willing to finance almost the whole purchase price of the warehouse.
Besides, he said, "banks always had the attitude that you had to prove you didn't need the money in order to get it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and Mariano Diaz, left, in front of Fine Fare Grocers, a new Harlem store that Mr. Diaz built with the help of a $200,000 loan financed by a program of the state pension fund. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Two Hospitals on the Same Block In Brooklyn Discuss Partnership

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
The state-run University Hospital of Brooklyn and the city-run Kings County Hospital Center, which face each other from opposite sides of Clarkson Avenue in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, have agreed to begin talks aimed at creating a partnership.
Officials for both hospitals said that while collaborations had periodically been discussed -- and abandoned -- for nearly a decade, the increasingly competitive health-care market in the city had made it virtually impossible to sustain two hospitals on the same block. 
 The board of the State University of New York, which runs University Hospital, voted unanimously yesterday to begin joint planning discussions with the Health and Hospitals Corporation, the agency responsible for New York City's 11 public hospitals and assorted clinics and nursing homes. The corporation's board is expected to vote on, and pass, a similar resolution when it meets today.
University Hospital, which is better known as Downstate, already provides all the doctors and medical services at Kings County through an affiliation contract with the city. For decades, the Health and Hospitals Corporation has paid academic medical centers hundreds of millions of dollars each year to run its public hospitals.
But despite the fact that doctors at both hospitals crossed the street to work, the institutions remained competitive, often vying for the same patients and operating independently with separate administrative, planning, medical, nursing and purchasing departments. The city has long complained that doctors from Downstate poached insured patients, leaving Kings County with the poorest and sickest patients.
"We need to work cooperatively rather than competitively," said Peter Pileggi, the associate provost for health education and hospitals in the state university system's office of campus liaison. "These discussions are designed to continue fostering our education mission within an integrated delivery system."
One factor driving the collaboration talks is the poor physical state of Kings County, a hulking, crumbling hospital and one of the few in the city that still houses patients in open wards. The city first talked about rebuilding it in the early 1960's, and in 1983 came up with a plan that was to be completed by 1986.
Fifteen years later, the city has spent about $110 million and has almost nothing to show for the money except a series of fraud investigations and lawsuits.
In many ways, health industry experts said, the two hospitals are well suited to join forces. Kings County, with 756 beds and 4,673 employees, has an active trauma center and a complex of primary-care clinics; Downstate, with 376 beds and 1,970 employees, has no emergency room and focuses on research and specialty care, like cardiac and orthopedic surgery.
Officials at both institutions acknowledged that any kind of joint agreement, even one that falls short of a full-scale merger, would have to include difficult labor negotiations. Employees at the two hospitals are not represented by the same unions. In addition, people in the community have mixed feelings about such a partnership, trying to understand complex economic forces but fearing a cutback in services to a population that is poorer and sicker than most others in the city.
"There are real challenges to completing this agreement," said Dr. Luis Marcos, president of the hospitals corporation. "But a unified hospital is the best choice for the future of health care in central Brooklyn."

HEADLINE: 150 Million Jobless, Global Study Says

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Sept. 23

 BODY:
At least 150 million people worldwide are jobless, and this number is expected to rise by millions before the end of the year, the International Labor Organization said today.
At least 10 million people have joined the unemployed this year because of the financial crisis in Asia, the I.L.O. said in issuing its World Employment Report, 1998-99. 
 By year-end, as many as 12 million more could be unemployed, mostly in Asia, said Rashid Amjad, the report's author. The newly released global jobless numbers are up substantially from the previous I.L.O. compilation in 1996-97, which listed 128 million jobless.
Among the unemployed are an estimated 60 million people between the ages of 15 and 24, who are searching for work but cannot find it, said the study by the I.L.O., a United Nations agency based in Geneva.
Only labor markets in the United States and, to a lesser extent, the European Union, benefited from economic growth in the first half of 1998, the 258-page report said.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Greenspan's Congressional Testimony

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from testimony yesterday by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, before the Senate Budget Committee and an exchange between Mr. Greenspan and Senator Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire and a committee member, in a question-and-answer session following the testimony: 
 When I testified before the Congress in July, I noted that some of the effects of the international crisis had actually been positive for the United States financial markets and economy, for example, by lowering long-term interest rates paid by our households and businesses. However, the most recent, more virulent phase of the crisis has infected our markets as well. Concerns about business profits and a general pulling back from risk-taking in the midst of great uncertainty around the globe have driven down stock prices and pushed up rates on the bonds of lower-rated borrowers. Flows of funds through financial markets have been disrupted, at least temporarily. . . .
There is little evidence to date, however, that foreign problems or the tightening in financial conditions in domestic markets have produced any significant underlying weakness in the American economy as a whole. Moreover, labor markets remain tight and hourly compensation has continued to grow more rapidly. Nonetheless, the increases in overall costs and the C.P.I. have been held to modest levels by reasonably good productivity advances, lower oil prices and foreign competition.
However, looking forward, the restraining effects of recent developments on the U.S. economy are likely to intensify. As I noted in Congressional testimony last week, we can already see signs of the erosion of production around the edges, especially in manufacturing. Disappointing profits in a number of industries and less rapid expansion of sales suggest some stretching out of capital investment plans in the months ahead. Lower equity prices and higher financing costs should damp household and business spending, and greater uncertainty and risk aversion may also lead to more cautious spending behavior.
When I testified on monetary policy in July, I explained that the Federal Open Market Committee was concerned that high -- indeed rising -- demand for labor could produce cost pressures on our economy that would disrupt the ongoing expansion. I also noted that a high real Federal funds rate was a necessary offset to expansionary conditions elsewhere in financial markets. By mid-August, the committee believed that disruptions abroad and more cautious behavior by investors at home meant that the risks to the expansion had become evenly balanced. Since then, deteriorating foreign economies and their spillover to domestic markets have increased the possibility that the slowdown in the growth of the American economy will be more than sufficient to hold inflation in check. . . .

MR. GREGG: Mr. Chairman, you talked about the need for an ad hoc remedy at this time because you can't put in place the long-term actions which would require -- which are required to get what you think is a sound financial process throughout the world. Would part of that ad hoc remedy or an element of that ad hoc remedy be constructively impacted by a rate cut in the United States?

MR. GREENSPAN: I thought that would be the second or third question.

MR. GREGG: Let's get it out early, you know.

MR. GREENSPAN: Obviously, I can't be directly responsive to that question. All I can say to you --

MR. GREGG: I'm talking about in theoretical terms, in the ad hoc -- in the ad hoc remedy concept.
MR. GREENSPAN: I got the point. I've been able to string more words into fewer ideas than anybody I know, and I'm continuing to do that.
Let me say this: that I and my colleagues at the F.O.M.C. and amongst the central bank governors are pretty much engaged on a day-by-day basis -- in many cases, hourly, hour-by-hour -- in watching the processes that are going on and trying to understand them better.
I do think we're getting and perhaps we'll reach some conclusions as to what is fundamentally wrong, meaning what are the shortfalls in the existing system, similar to the types of notions which I raised in my prepared remarks.
But I do think that we have to bring the existing instabilities to a level of stability reasonably shortly, to prevent the contagion from really spilling over and creating some very significant further difficulties for all of us.
I can't comment on this particular stage what particular actions will or will not be taken. But I really would suggest to you that I think we know where we have to go. I think we understand the process. I do not think we underestimate the severity of the problems with which we are dealing. But exactly what instruments we will employ and well -- and when they will be employed -- I'm not at liberty at this stage to offer it, because I'm not the only person involved in making those decisions.

HEADLINE: Brazil Makes Fast Recovery From Brink of Economic Collapse

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil Sept. 23

 BODY:
Only two weeks ago Brazil's stock market was crashing and its banking system was leaking currency reserves at a rate of more than $2 billion a day. Financial collapse or a crushing devaluation looked almost inevitable.
But the panic that throttled this business and finance center has subsided just as suddenly as it emerged as an outgrowth of the currency crisis in Russia. At least temporarily, Brazil's stock market and banking system appear to have stabilized, adding to the evidence that the financial contagion spreading around the world is linked to unpredictable flights of perception and mood that can shift from one week to the next. 
 No serious expert says Brazil is out of trouble yet. Indeed, a recession caused by high interest rates looks virtually inevitable in 1999, and the Government faces tough choices to reduce a fiscal deficit that represents better than 7 percent of gross domestic product. But the Brazilian stock market has recovered better than 50 percent since Sept. 10. Volatility has subsided, with far lower daily trading volumes until today, when the market shot up almost 11 percent, largely in response to remarks in Washington by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, suggesting that he might favor lower interest rates.
More importantly, local economists point out, the volume of capital flight has slowed to a manageable, though still troublesome, $500 million a day.
As the ninth largest economy in the world and the principal motor of Latin America's economic growth, Brazil's improving fortunes have helped strengthen the Mexican peso, eased fears that Argentina might have to remove its peso from a dollar peg, and led a modest rally in most of the region's stock markets.
"Ten days ago we were talking about the end of the world," said Mauro Schneider, vice president for economic research at ING Barings here. "Things could still change overnight, but you don't see investors selling at any price anymore." Paulo Mallman, finance director of BicBanco, a Brazilian bank, said: "The panic is over. Apparently the crisis has eased a little bit."
Such expressions of what can be described at best as cautious optimism reflect Brazil's continued vulnerability to events outside its control, such as a potential stock market plunge in the United States, a collapse of the new Government in Russia, or a reversal in the improving fortunes of the Japanese yen. But they also seem to suggest that President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, the Clinton Administration, and the International Monetary Fund and other world lending institutions may have weeks or months -- rather than days as some once feared -- to construct a coordinated rebuilding effort based on new loans and slashing the Brazilian Government deficit.
President Cardozo sent mixed signals in recent weeks about whether he would seek an I.M.F. lending package, but in a speech today he said it was "in the country's interests to carve out" a bailout package. Experts believe such a package could include contributions of up to $50 billion from the I.M.F., the World Bank and other institutions.
The Brazilian crisis peaked on Sept. 10 when the Brazilian stock market plummeted 16 percent in a single day. On that Thursday and Friday Brazilian and foreign businesses and individuals withdrew a total of $4 billion from Brazilian banks. While the stock market was down 50 percent for the year, the banking system's dollar reserves had fallen from $74 billion to $51 billion over the course of a single month.
Panic set in when not even the Government's doubling of interest rates to better than 40 percent stemmed the tide of capital flight. But the psychology began to change with a speech on Sept. 11 by Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin, which broke weeks of silence from the Clinton Administration that had left investors confused about United States policy.
"The financial stability and prosperity of Brazil is of vital importance to the U.S.," Mr. Rubin said in a statement that has become a mantra for local investors seeking reassurance. In the next few days President Clinton and officials of the I.M.F. and the Group of Seven leading industrial countries declared they would stand by Latin America, helping to reverse a growing impression among businesses and investors that capital controls and a steep devaluation of the Brazilian currency were imminent.
After the calming words from abroad, said Bolivar Lamounier, a political consultant to several banks here, "people sat down and thought through what they were doing." Several experts noted that recent polls showing that President Cardoso would win a landslide victory on Oct. 4, giving him far more political clout to deal with the crisis, also helped calm investors.
Then last week the Government bolstered its ailing accounts by successfully completing privatization sales of a state bank and two power companies worth better than $2 billion.
After the privatizations, ING Barings released a report last Friday suggesting that Brazil might be able to speed up divestitures, including its huge oil company Petrobras and the enormous commercial bank Banco do Brasil, to raise more needed capital. The report concluded on a hopeful note, saying, "Despite the financial turmoil, foreign corporations still express great interest in purchasing strategic concerns from the Brazilian government."
Carlos Kawall L. Ferreira, Citibank's chief economist in Brazil, said he was heartened by the deceleration of capital flight.
He said most of the money now leaving the country was related to stock sales or corporations paying off debts in anticipation of an economic slowdown.
"We're not seeing the same panic anymore," Mr. Ferreira said. Still, noting that reserves had fallen to $47 billion, he added: "My fear is the money will not come back in the next several weeks or months. International support will be needed for Brazil."

HEADLINE: James C. Dudley, 77, Investment Adviser

 BODY:
James Chittenden Dudley, an investor and geologist who was also active in education, died Sept. 16 in Danbury Hospital in Danbury, Conn. He was 77 and lived in Redding, Conn.
The cause was cancer, his family said. 
 Mr. Dudley had been a managing partner of Dudley & Company, a Manhattan-based investment management firm he helped found, for more than a decade.
He was born in Duluth, Minn., graduated in 1943 from Harvard College and was a navigator on American bombers in World War II.
After the war he worked in metals exploration. Then he was an analyst at Grace Bank and later was a general partner in the investment firm Cyrus J. Lawrence & Sons, both in Manhattan. In 1969, he became an independent investment adviser. He was also a longtime vice chairman of AEA Investors Inc. and served on the boards of several other companies.
Mr. Dudley headed the board of trustees of Dana Hall School in Wellesley, Mass. He was on several visiting committees at Harvard, where he endowed a chair in economic geology. He also endowed scholarships at Dana Hall and at Milton Academy in Milton, Mass., and, with his wife, established the 36-acre Highstead Arboretum in Redding, Conn.
He is survived by his wife, the former Elisabeth Claypool; his sons David C., of Denver, and Henry C., of Bedford, N.Y.; two daughters, Sarah Dudley Plimpton of Manhattan and Jane C. Dudley of Seattle, and 10 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: James Fletcher, 63, a Banker In Poor Chicago Areas, Dies

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
James Fletcher, chairman of the South Shore Bank, a pioneering lender to some of the poorer neighborhoods in Chicago, died of complications of lymphoma on Sept. 16 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Chicago. He was 63 and a lifelong resident of the city.
Mr. Fletcher was one of a group of idealistic young bankers in the early 1970's who transformed a struggling commercial bank into a model of how a for-profit company could help revitalize deteriorating communities. 
 South Shore has been one of few banks to operate in low-income neighborhoods and make money investing in the community. Many locally owned banks in low-income neighborhoods are criticized because they are run very conservatively, making few loans with the deposits they gather. Others, notably Freedom National Bank in Harlem, have failed because of lending policies that were too aggressive.
Mr. Fletcher "felt very strongly that we had a dual objective, to make a profit and to do development work," said Milton Davis, the vice chairman of the Shorebank Corporation, South Shore's holding company, and one of the bankers who took over the company in 1973.
"If there was an application for a loan that might not be profitable but would contribute enormously to the development of an area, he would always take the side of development," Mr. Davis said. "But he was successful in finding a way to put a credit on the books of the bank structured in a way that we were sure to be repaid."
Mr. Fletcher was born on Jan. 21, 1935, in Chicago. After graduating from Northern Illinois University in 1958, he served three years in the Marine Corps and then taught in the Chicago public schools for three years.
In 1963, he joined the Chicago Committee on Urban Opportunity as an urban planner for the city's anti-poverty program. He held several other government jobs before joining Hyde Park Bank and Trust, near the University of Chicago, in 1969 to work in its urban redevelopment lending division.
The South Shore Bank, then a traditional commercial bank, was struggling to survive as its neighborhood population changed from white to black. It wanted to move into the Standard Oil Building in downtown Chicago, but its application was rejected by the Federal Government after protests by the community.
In 1972, several executives from Hyde Park Bank, including Ronald A. Grzywinski, its president, raised $4 million from foundations, church groups and wealthy individuals to buy South Shore and devote it to community development.
Mr. Fletcher left Hyde Park for South Shore in 1978. At first, he ran a fund that made equity investments in small businesses and a nonprofit institute, linked to the bank, that operated some of the development projects.
In 1983 he was named president of South Shore Bank, and in 1996 he became chairman.
The success of South Shore drew the attention of Bill Clinton when he was Governor of Arkansas. Mr. Clinton encouraged the establishment of a similar bank in Little Rock, and in his 1992 Presidential campaign he promised to encourage other community development banks modeled on South Shore.
But South Shore's practices have at times been criticized.
Several community groups and black churches protested South Shore's acquisition of Indecorp, the largest black-owned bank in Chicago, in 1995. They complained that South Shore was mainly owned by white people and big companies, including the largest commercial banks in Chicago. Mr. Grzywinski, the chairman, and many of the managers are white. Mr. Davis is black, as was Mr. Fletcher.
Since the acquisition, however, South Shore has increased the loans that are made at the Indecorp branches from 30 percent of deposits to 70 percent.
Mr. Fletcher is survived by his wife, the former Norma Gant; his mother, Mildred Fletcher Holtz of Milwaukee; three daughters, Cheryl Mulholland of Costa Mesa, Calif., and Maria Barksdale and Kathleen Lisciotto, both of Chicago; a son, James P. Fletcher of Chicago; seven grandchildren, and two sisters, Kathleen Hall of Racine, Wis., and Sharon F. Schultz of Milwaukee.

HEADLINE: Senate Votes to Curb Bankruptcy Abuse by Consumers

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to overhaul the bankruptcy system and make it more difficult for consumers to walk away from debts.
The sweeping clampdown on consumers, especially those who are perceived as able to repay their debts, reflects a strong sense in Congress that widespread abuse of the bankruptcy system has spurred a record number of personal bankruptcies in each of the last three years, despite the booming economy. 
 In making it harder for debtors to walk away from their unpaid bills, the legislation would help banks and credit-card companies recoup billions of dollars a year.
"The free ride is over," said Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who shepherded the bill to passage.
The bill passed by a lopsided vote of 97 to 1. Only Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, voted against it. Mr. Wellstone said that he was offended by the relentless, multimillion-dollar lobbying effort by banks and credit-card companies on behalf of the bill and that consumers were "left out of the loop."
But today's vote does not guarantee that the bill will become law. The Senate version must now be reconciled with a House bill, which is vastly different, and time is running out for lawmakers to reach an accord.
Not only does Congress plan to adjourn in less than three weeks, but the members who must resolve the differences between the two bills have less time than others. The bills started in the judiciary committees in each house, which means those committees must send members to the joint House-Senate conference to reconcile the bills. But the House Judiciary Committee is so consumed with whether to impeach President Clinton that it seems to have little time for other matters.
"A lot of people are wondering if Judiciary has the time," Mr. Grassley said. "It's a major problem."
The Clinton Administration has left itself considerable leeway for final negotiations on the bill. In a statement of policy, officials said they generally supported the Senate version but wanted a final bill to curtail abuses by creditors, not just debtors. It was not clear whether the Senate bill, which does address creditor abuse to some degree, went far enough for the Administration.
Both the Senate and House, which passed its bill in June, spurned numerous attempts by Democrats to tighten the rules on banks and credit-card companies to make them more accountable for lending practices that lure consumers, even those already heavily in debt, with solicitations for additional credit.
The Senate version, however, would require banks and credit card companies to disclose to consumers in every monthly bill how much they will owe over the months -- or, more likely, years -- in accumulated debt and interest if they make only the minimum payment.
And the Senate bill would crack down on people who move to states like Florida and Texas, which protect them if they put all their money into expensive houses and then file for bankruptcy.
The Administration has called the House bill too stringent. That version, much preferred by the bank and credit-card industries, imposes an income test on those who seek protection from creditors under Chapter 7, which erases most debt.
But by contrast, the more lenient Senate version gives judges some discretion in determining whether someone files under Chapter 7 or goes through a more rigorous repayment schedule under Chapter 13.
Still, the bills in both houses are grounded in a similar philosophy that the White House seems to share: that filing for bankruptcy has become too easy and, with a record 1.35 million consumers filing in 1997, unfairly cost American business $40 billion in that year alone.
Credit-card lending is among the most profitable sectors of the banking industry, which otherwise has little room for growth. The industry estimates that the bills in both houses could help them recoup $4 billion a year.
Many Democratic Senators who spoke out earlier against the bill wound up voting for it. One, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, maintains that the Senate version is so preferable to the House version that he wants to strengthen the hand of Senate conferees in negotiating with the House.
But many longtime allies of those Democrats were disappointed with the vote. Gary Klein, director of the National Consumer Law Center, said the Senate's provisions were better than the House's, but he added, "It is unclear whether those provisions are strong enough to prevent abusive marketing practices prevalent in the extension of consumer credit."
Elizabeth Warren, a Harvard law professor who opposes the bill, applauded the Senate for acknowledging for the first time that credit-card companies were responsible for some consumer debt. But she still argues that it is a bad bill. "How can democratically elected representatives vote to transfer wealth from financially troubled families to corporate lenders who are making record profits?" she asked.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
As Placebo Or RealCure, Fed Rate Cut Seems Closer

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
Everybody seems to want the Federal Reserve policy makers to cut interest rates when they meet Tuesday. And why not? With financial chaos sweeping through Asia, Russia and now Latin America, a rate cut would seem a smart inoculation against recession for the domestic economy. That is certainly the view of the Business Roundtable, a group of corporate leaders, as it vigorously lobbies for the Fed to cut the cost of borrowing for American businesses. Lower rates would also help individual debtors and foreign countries saddled with loans that must be repaid in dollars.
Alan Greenspan, in Congressional testimony yesterday, encouraged investors to anticipate a small cut when he noted that "deteriorating foreign economies and their spillover to domestic markets" were slowing the economy and tilting the Fed's concern from worrying about inflation to worrying about recession. 
 Yet, true to their reputations as party poopers, many economists side with Allan Meltzer, a professor of economics at Carnegie Mellon University, who labels a rate cut premature. At most, a plausible case can be made for a middle ground -- a small, therefore symbolic, cut next week that would not, unless conditions drastically change, be followed by additional cuts.
There is no compelling economic case yet for prolonged easing by the Fed.
The talk of a rate cut starts with the fact that a quarter of the world's population is mired in recession or worse. Investors, with a self-fulfilling fear that countries are about to devalue or run out of reserves, are fleeing with dollars that these countries cannot afford to cough up. Even the Japanese economy, the world's second largest, has slipped into recession this year. Brazil, the ninth-largest economy, flirts with its own financial crisis.
The impact is already being felt in the United States. Exports are dropping, as are commercial property prices, housing starts and consumer confidence, a harbinger of consumer spending. Major American banks are announcing overseas losses, which might force them to retrench on domestic as well as foreign lending.
Rate cuts, proponents say, could mitigate these recessionary shocks by encouraging consumers and businesses to spend more. Rate cuts could also help nudge down interest rates abroad, easing the burden on debtor countries and giving foreign investors reason to believe that their investments are secure.
But Mr. Meltzer of Carnegie Mellon says the economic blows to the United States are "little more than rumor."
"The groups that are screaming the loudest for rate cuts are the ones that yelped for the Fed to keep its hands off the economy when its chairman cautioned against irrational exuberance," he said. "In fact, the economy is strong and needs no help from the Fed."
In fact, unemployment rates are at their lowest levels in three decades, retail sales are brisk, and housing starts, though they dropped last month, remain well above last year's levels. Business fixed investment is rising, and stock prices, though well off their summer peaks, remain high by many measures.
Mickey Levy, chief economist at Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities, says: "Falling oil prices, interest rates and ample growth of the money supply provide for healthy growth of the economy. If the Fed eases anyway, it could create inflationary pressures down the line."
What would persuade these economists to support rate cuts? Concrete evidence that prices are falling or that bank reserves are dipping to dangerous levels, threatening a credit crunch. Neither is true. Wages, the primary component of prices, are rising at a 4 percent annual clip. And bank capital, according to David Hilder of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, is substantial -- by his estimates about 30 percent above the levels recommended by regulators. Banks have enough reserves to absorb substantial losses from investments in Asia and other trouble spots without cutting off domestic borrowers.
Mr. Levy supplies another reason for the Fed to refrain from repeated rate cuts. "They solve no big problem and in places abroad threaten to do more harm than good," he concludes. Rate cuts cannot help Russia, whose problems are rooted in corrupt and incompetent government policies, or Japan, whose banks are buried in loans to bankrupt companies. Rate cuts could even drive down the dollar, thereby raising the price of Japanese and Brazilian exports, depressing sales and further shrinking those economies.
The major problem abroad is psychological, argues Alan Blinder, an economics professor at Princeton and a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who is an unapologetic liberal and a self-proclaimed "inflation dove." As an academic and Fed member, he has advocated looser monetary policies than most of his colleagues deem prudent. Yet even he rejects calls for steep rate cuts now. "The United States is one of the few countries that does not need a monetary boost now," Mr. Blinder said, "and the Fed should divert its focus to the needs of foreign economies only with the frequency of 50-year hurricanes."
Instead, Mr. Blinder makes a clever, if tentative, case for taking a half step. The problem abroad, he says, is a "crisis of confidence that has one investor's fear feed on another's. It is plausible to address a fear that is at its root psychological with symbolic measures."
Specifically, the Fed could -- ideally in cooperation with the reluctant Germans -- cut rates by a small amount, say, a quarter or perhaps even a half of a percentage point. Such amounts, he admits, are too small to do much good but also too small to pose a serious inflation threat if the economy remains strong. The act could, however, send a reassuring signal to investors that the Fed is prepared to step in as needed to keep financial markets on an even keel. Mr. Blinder ponders no more than this half step.
The question then is whether the Fed, too, is contemplating a rate cut to calm jittery investors or a prolonged strategy to ease monetary policy.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Questions on Coca-Cola in Market Turmoil Abroad

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Coca-Cola Company executives have summoned Wall Street analysts for a hastily scheduled meeting tomorrow morning in New York, suggesting that the leading soft-drink company is about to deliver ominous news about earnings.
Coke derives most of its fortunes from overseas, where economic crises have ravaged the earnings of many American multinational companies. 
 The Atlanta-based company declined to comment about the substance of the meeting, other than to call it "a volume and earnings update for the third quarter and the full year." But it is the first time Coke has organized an analysts' briefing on such short notice -- analysts were called on Tuesday -- and the first briefing since the economic crisis now afflicting Asia, Russia and Latin America began more than a year ago.
Things are already at a relative low point for Coke; many analysts have already reduced their forecasts for volumes and earnings over the last few weeks, and the share price has plummeted from a mid-July high of $88.938 to $58 at the market's close yesterday, on a day when the broad market rose more than 3 percent. In addition, the company was dealt a setback by the French Government last week, which rejected Coke's plans to buy the Orangina brand from Pernod-Ricard S.A.
Questions about Coke's profitability abroad have intensified as the economic problems overseas have worsened. Will key Latin American markets, like Mexico, be the next to fall? Is Eastern Europe, in the shadow of the stagnant Russian economy, about to unravel? How bad will sales be in Japan, where they were off 3 percent in the second quarter? How much of all this already is reflected in Coke's stock price?
Gillette and Procter & Gamble, two consumer-products giants often mentioned in the same breath as Coke, issued warnings about their earnings earlier this week, further raising speculation about what Coke executives might say tomorrow.
"The chances are good that we are going to see them guide near-term estimates lower," said Marc Cohen, a beverage analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company, adding that he thought the company would also offer encouragement that the fundamentals for a good long-term performance remain intact.
Mr. Cohen said he expected Coke executives to forecast sales growth of 5 percent to 6 percent for the third quarter, compared with 9 percent to 10 percent in the first half.
"We had anticipated some moderation, but it has moderated more than we thought it would," he said.
Jennifer Solomon, a beverage analyst for Salomon Smith Barney, who downgraded the stock from "buy" to "hold" 13 months ago, said, "They are certainly going to have to give some guidance on earnings, and they may just confirm what's out there." At the very least, the meeting, with Coke's chairman and chief executive, M. Douglas Ivester, and the company's chief financial officer, James E. Chestnut, is expected to focus on how Coke, which last year collected two-thirds of its profits outside the United States, plans to navigate this latest downturn. While Coke has shown skill at running its business in individual countries despite local economic problems -- the Mexican peso crisis in 1994-95, during which Coke proved itself better equipped than some local brands to withstand the pressure, and wound up with more market share, is often cited -- the current challenge is greater.
"These are macroeconomic factors that they have to manage through," said Doug Lane, a beverage analyst with Merrill Lynch, "and they've never had to do it on such a broad-based scale. That's what's different this time."
Mr. Lane said Latin America, where Coke made about 17.5 percent of its profits last year, was already starting to show signs of a slowdown in its consumption of Coke products. In Mexico, he added, sales were still strong but he expected them to slow; yesterday Merrill Lynch lowered its rating on the main Coke bottler in Mexico, Coke Femsa, from "buy" to "neutral."
Mr. Ivester and Mr. Chestnut are expected to reiterate Coke's longtime position, that economic downturns present investment opportunities for the company around the world, and that Coke is generally planning more for the long term. Bill Pecoriello, an analyst with Sanford Bernstein, said the picture may become bleaker once additional factors are included. Much of the downgrading so far, he said, has come from concerns about currency devaluations that hurt multinational company earnings abroad when converted into dollars.
"Now what you're talking about is revisions related not only to falling sales volume, but also increased sales expenses," he said. "They are not reducing the market spending in the short run, which means you are spending more than you would have per unit, had the volume not decelerated."
Another analyst, Emanuel Goldman of Paine Webber in San Francisco, said he remained bullish on Coke, and had met with his sales force yesterday to tell them that "the time to buy Coke is when it breaks."
"The irony of all this is that the long-term story is as strong as it's ever been," Mr. Goldman said. "This doesn't mean that they are having fun right now. But they are very good at managing within environments that for some companies would be very difficult."

HEADLINE: A Cornucopia of Native Foie Gras;
Partners' Efforts Produce Menu Delicacy in Abundance

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

DATELINE: FERNDALE, N.Y.

 BODY:
Not long ago, a sumptuous slice of fresh foie gras, cut from the fat-rich liver of a force-fed duck or goose, was a rarity on American menus. Even as French restaurants flourished in the 1980's, desperate chefs usually had to settle for canned pates. Those willing to defy Federal restrictions on imports of raw poultry even had the delicacy smuggled from France inside fish bellies.
Nowadays, though, top restaurants across the nation are awash in fresh foie gras. The delicacy is so abundant that chefs have indulged in American-style innovations that might make a Frenchman faint: barbecued foie gras, foie gras pizza, foie gras quesadillas. 
 The opening of this pipeline can be traced largely to a former bond trader from Great Neck, N.Y., and an Israeli-born duck-breeding expert, who have teamed up to become the largest producer of fresh foie gras in the United States.
The two men, Michael A. Ginor and Izzy Yanay, own and operate Hudson Valley Foie Gras and Duck Products, a 200-acre farm in Sullivan County, two hours northwest of Manhattan. They also operate two 100-acre farms in nearby White Lake, N.Y., and another 100-acre farm outside Montreal.
Their company, formed almost eight years ago, is one of only two in the country that produce fresh foie gras; the other, Sonoma Foie Gras, is in California. Hudson Valley Foie Gras estimates that it produces about 80 percent of the product made in the United States.
"We did it because I could never get it here, and when I did, it wasn't any good," said Mr. Ginor, 34, the company's president, who first tasted foie gras 15 years ago as a college student outside Tel Aviv, where cubes of low-grade foie gras were served grilled and skewered, on a plate with hummus and pita.
David Waltuck, chef and owner of Chanterelle in TriBeCa, said his restaurant would probably not be serving foie gras if Hudson Valley had not started up. "The stuff from Hudson Valley is the best," he said.
To become the kings of foie gras -- they sell 220 tons a year of livers as yellow as the cornmeal they feed their hybrid ducks -- Mr. Ginor and Mr. Yanay, the general manager, have had to surmount several problems that had long held back the industry.
For decades, disease has stymied large goose farms in the United States and in Europe, and to many Americans, foie gras still means goose. Today, however, goose foie gras (foie gras d'oie) is only made in very small quantities in Israel, Hungary and parts of the Perigord and Alsace regions of France. Everywhere else, foie gras comes from a duck (foie gras de canard), mostly the moulard duck.
Besides disease, geese have a number of other problems. They are, some experts say, more intelligent than ducks, which means they will not take food from a stranger, making force-feeding more difficult. They have more fragile necks, another obstacle to feeding. And the rest of the goose ages faster than the liver, rendering the breast and other parts inedible, and making the process uneconomical.
Goose liver also contains a high percentage of fat, so it can be cooked only at low temperatures. "If you are making a terrine, goose is fine, but if you sear it, saute, broil, grill, the goose disappears and you are left with fat melted in the pan and liver," Mr. Ginor said. "Americans are inherently more comfortable with those cooking methods. Like cooking hamburgers."
As for duck foie gras, efforts to use Muscovy ducks have not been economical, because they usually breed only six months of the year, require lots of care and, to a lesser degree, have the same melting problem as geese because of their high-fat livers.
In the late 1970's, though, Mr. Yanay, an expert in poultry production who was then working in Israel, made a breakthrough. He developed an artificial insemination method to cross large numbers of female Pekin ducks with male Muscovy ducks to produce disease-resistant, but sterile, moulards.
The result was that birds with some Muscovy duck characteristics could be bred year-round in large numbers. Better yet, the moulard foie gras is easier to cook than goose or Muscovy foie gras. It is also, many say, more flavorful than foie gras from a Muscovy duck.
"The moulard is so perfect for foie gras production," Mr. Ginor said, "that 70 percent of the livers harvested in the world now come from moulard, including most of those in France."
The only trouble with the moulard, and the main reason no one has yet duplicated Hudson Valley's efforts in the United States, is that artificial insemination on a large scale is not easy. But that is Mr. Yanay's expertise. "What we do here, nobody else here can do," he said.
On the way to meeting in the Catskills and changing the course of foie gras history, Mr. Ginor and Mr. Yanay, coincidentally, both spent time in Israel.
Mr. Yanay came to the United States from Israel in the early 1980's. With some financial backing, he worked for a while with Commonwealth Farms in Ferndale to get a domestic fresh foie gras industry started. But acrimony developed before the industry did, and Mr. Yanay, 48, soon left the company.
Mr. Ginor, meanwhile, spent the 80's getting an M.B.A. from New York University and then made a small fortune as a bond trader and salesman at David Lerner Associates. He was born in Seattle, the son of a Boeing engineer, and raised in Israel and on Long Island. After a few years on Wall Street, he began searching for more meaning (and, apparently, danger) in his life; he joined the Israeli Army. Upon returning to the United States with dual citizenship in the late 80's, he decided that instead of merely harvesting money each day, he wanted a passion.
"I'm a foodie," he said recently, a few days after his return from a food and wine tour of South Africa. "I made a lot of money in the 80's, and I decided I wanted to do something that I really love, which was work with food. Now, I am almost a celebrity. I have a foie gras cookbook coming out. I'm opening two restaurants. I love the business."
His decision to concentrate on foie gras came after he ate what he said was particularly awful foie gras in an appetizer at the Cafe Rakel in Manhattan in 1989. A complaint to the chef led him to the owners of D'Artagnan, a wholesaler of game and meat products in Newark. They referred him to Mr. Yanay, who was driving a truck after his departure from Commonwealth Farms.
Upon learning about Mr. Yanay's skill and after researching the state of the domestic market for fresh foie gras, Mr. Ginor formed a partnership with Mr. Yanay in 1990. Mr. Ginor and a relative anted up $1.3 million to buy an old chicken farm not far from Commonwealth Farms, which they later bought for $1.4 million in 1992. Mr. Ginor also hounded chefs across the country to try his product, and established links with D'Artagnan and eventually 73 other wholesalers.
In 1993 and 1994, he fended off letter-writing campaigns and demonstrations by animal-rights activists smeared with red paint, who cited foie gras as one of the most cruel animal food products because of what the French call gavage: forcing the birds to swallow up to a pound of feed through a tube three times a day so that their three-ounce livers grow to as much as 12 times their normal size.
Mr. Yanay says the treatment of the ducks is no crueler than many other things done to animals raised and killed for food. He also says that the birds naturally overeat before they migrate and that their esophaguses are calcified, so the funnel and tube used for feeding are not seriously abrasive.
The lambasting by animal-rights activists apparently has had little effect on aficionados of fine food. So popular has fresh foie gras become that earlier this year Hudson Valley was sold out of product, leaving chefs screaming for more foie gras.
"A shortage?" said Mr. Waltuck of Chanterelle. "It was a complete lack."
Since then, the farm has increased production, and Hudson Valley now sells 220 tons of foie gras a year, an average of 7,500 pounds of liver each week, up from 2,700 pounds in 1992 (the average liver weighs about 1.5 pounds). The company's annual sales of all its products total $9 million, and pretax profit margins are 18 percent.
Hudson Valley gets about $50 for all the parts of each bird it sells to its 75 wholesalers; the liver alone fetches about $28 to $36 a pound, depending on the grade. Byproducts include the breast, which is called a magret; the legs, which are used for confit; feathers for down; tubs of duck fat for cooking or, for French-food devotees, spreading like butter on a baguette; the skin for crackling, and what the French call lardon, a pork-rind-like snack.
"We sell everything but the quack," Mr. Ginor said.
