HEADLINE: Business Group Fails to Mollify Giuliani

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Determined to clamp down on the business group that oversees sanitation, security and other services in the Grand Central Terminal area, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the group must do more than change its leadership to stay in operation.
His comments came less than an hour after the group, the Grand Central Partnership, announced the resignation of its president, Daniel A. Biederman, and the replacement of its chairman with Bernard H. Mendik, an ally of Mr. Giuliani. 
 The departure of Mr. Biederman was a stunning turnabout for a man who was once hailed as an architect of public-private partnerships, and who has been given substantial credit for helping to clean up midtown Manhattan during a time of economic straits.
But those changes in leadership did not seem to appease the Mayor, who has sought to curb the powers of business improvement districts, which collect assessments in return for providing supplemental services, including street lighting, security and garbage pickup.
Mr. Giuliani has questioned the financial operations of the Grand Central Partnership, whose record of success during the last decade has inspired imitators in cities across the country. In July, he cut off funds to the district and refused to renew its contract, complaining that Mr. Biederman, a onetime ally and the group's president, had created a fief by heading two other midtown BID's at Bryant Park and 34th Street and receiving a combined salary of $350,000.
Yesterday, he suggested that the Grand Central Partnership had no future. "They're all finished," Mr. Giuliani said yesterday morning of the group and its leadership. "Somebody has to come in and look over their books, their records, their accounts, and find out how they spent money."
The Mayor has raised questions about the Grand Central Partnership's $30 million bond debt, and whether the city would be liable for repayment in case of a default by the district. He has also sought to determine whether the three districts headed by Mr. Biederman had wrongfully mingled funds raised by their assessments. Mr. Biederman and district officials have denied any wrongdoing.
Later in the day, City Hall issued a statement that seemed to temper the Mayor's remarks, but stopped short of saying the partnership was back in business. "Today's developments at the Grand Central Business Improvement District are a positive sign and the administration is encouraged by them," the statement said. "The important thing for the city to do now is determine whether the structure and the finances of the organization are sound."
A director of the group, however, was discouraged by the Mayor's comments. "They're going to starve us to death," said the director, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Business improvement districts have proliferated in the city since the mid-1980's. As quasi-governmental institutions run by private businesses, the groups have the power to impose taxes on property owners to provide additional public services.
But the success of the districts and their increase in number have also left them in control of huge sums of money and services in the central business districts, stripping credit and accountability from City Hall.
The Giuliani administration had cut the lifeblood of the Grand Central Partnership in July by freezing $6 million in assessments and refusing to renew the group's five-year contract with the city. The city was able to freeze the money because it collects the assessments on behalf of the districts.
In a signal of the partnership's capitulation two months after vowing to fight the Mayor in court, Norman Sturner, the group's chairman, "nominated and appointed" Mr. Mendik to replace him at a membership meeting of the partnership yesterday. Mr. Sturner said he made the nomination because "the Mayor would like to see Bernie Mendik as interim chair." He then called for a vote of the members, who unanimously approved Mr. Mendik.
Mr. Mendik, a co-chairman of Vornado Realty Trust, a publicly traded real estate company, did not attend the meeting. Mr. Biederman will be replaced as president by Lowell J. Tooley, vice president of operations for the BID's at Grand Central, Bryant Park and 34th Street.
The city has demanded that the three districts, which share staff, computers and some office space, begin to operate separately, a condition that district leaders have argued will cost them more than $2.5 million a year just in personnel costs.
At the meeting, Barbara Wolff, an assistant commissioner at the city's Department of Business Services who has been in talks with the partnership, told the group that the new appointments would allow the two sides to resume talks about renewing its contract. But Jack Deacy, a spokesman for the Giuliani administration, later said that Ms. Wolff was "premature in declaring that the city would reopen negotiations."
Although the Giuliani administration imposed new rules this year barring anyone from serving as president of more than one improvement district, Mr. Biederman has not resigned from either the 34th Street Business Improvement District or the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation, whose contracts with the city run until 2001. Both groups declined to comment last night.
Mr. Biederman, who declined to be interviewed, issued a statement saying that he was proud of his role as a founder of the partnership in 1988 and in helping to "greatly reduce crime by building $25 million of beautiful capital improvements on streets and sidewalks."
Many members of the Grand Central group say that the long-running dispute with the Giuliani administration has been dispiriting.
"It doesn't feel good, or taste good," said William G. Cohen, the executive vice president of Newmark & Company Real Estate and a board member. "Is Dan guilty of a crime? No. Has the neighborhood benefited from the BID? Yes. Dan Biederman was a great leader. It was his life's work."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Stocks Surge As Fed Offers Hint on Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks surged 3.26 percent yesterday, as Federal Reserve officials hinted strongly at an interest-rate cut, perhaps next Tuesday, to arrest a global economic skid that is threatening to turn into a worldwide recession.
More than half the market's gain came in the final hour of trading, after Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, who disappointed markets last week by saying no international plan for a coordinated rate cut was being developed, renewed investors' hopes. 
 "Deteriorating foreign economies and their spillover to domestic markets have increased the possibility that the slowdown in the growth of the American economy will be more than sufficient to hold inflation in check," Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Budget Committee this afternoon. "I think we know where we have to go."
He indicated a cut would be considered at a meeting Tuesday of the central bank's policy-making committee.
Earlier, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, William McDonough, made similar, though less pointed, comments about risks to economic growth to reporters in London.
The Dow Jones industrial average raced 257.21 points to close at 8,154.41. The advance was the average's fifth-biggest point gain on record, but it was not close to a record in percentage terms.
The Dow's advance above the 8,000 mark yesterday put it at its highest level since it plunged 512.61 points on Aug. 31. It had peaked nearly 1,200 points higher on July 17, but most other stocks had begun falling long before then.
Stocks also powered to strong gains across Europe, with main indexes up 3.82 percent in Germany and more than 2 percent in Britain and France. Brazil's market, highly volatile of late, soared nearly 11 percent on brightened prospects for aid, while Mexican stocks jumped more than 9 percent. Japan's stock market was closed for a holiday. At the midday recess today, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 379.31 points, or 2.75 percent, at 14,169.12. In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index was 3.28 percent higher in early trading.
Although the rally here was broadly based -- gainers swamped losers among the Standard & Poor's 500 by 420 to 14 -- financial, oil and Internet-related stocks were particular standouts. Analysts also pointed to what they said was a now clearly established preference among investors seeking bargains among smaller companies.
"They got washed out very hard," said Hank Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed in Kansas City. "People think they are getting value here."
The Nasdaq market, home to many small companies as well as some dominant computer and software issues, rose 3.68 percent, better than both the Dow and the S.& P. 500, which was up 3.54 percent.
Some of the most startling leaps were by the Internet stars Amazon.com, up 16 15/16, and Yahoo, up 14 15/16.
"The Internet stocks really got going," said Andy Brooks, head of stock trading at T. Rowe Price in Baltimore. "Buyers are going after stocks that can move."
Citicorp, with major foreign exposure that pushed its stock as low as 83 1/2 recently, rebounded 10 3/8, or 11 percent, to 105 1/2, after the Justice Department and the Federal Reserve approved its $46.4 billion merger with Travelers Group, removing the last obstacle to the combination of a giant bank with a leading Wall Street and insurance firm. Travelers rose 3 9/16, or 9.1 percent, to 42 15/16.
Anthony F. Dwyer, chief market strategist at Ladenburg Thalmann, is one of the biggest bulls on smaller stocks, citing their superior rebounds from market declines. Using the Russell 2000 index as his gauge, Mr. Dwyer calculated a 46.2 percent gain over the six and a half months following recent bear markets, while the Dow climbed 37.9 percent over about 11 months.
"The bottom line is that the smaller-cap stocks outperform their larger brethren by close to 10 percentage points in a significantly shorter period," he said.
The big oil stocks, though, posted handsome gains yesterday, as crude prices appeared to bounce solidly off their lows. Atlantic Richfield rose 4 3/8, to 71 3/8; Mobil 4 5/16, to 79 1/4; Chevron 3 5/8, to 84 11/16, and Exxon 3 1/4, to 70 5/16. Schlumberger, whose business is oilfield services, climbed 3 1/2, to 52 7/8.
Drugs were another strong blue-chip group, with Pfizer up 5 1/16, to 106 1/2, and Warner Lambert up 3 5/16, to 78 13/16.
Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered decliners by 2,377 to 800, with 62 making new highs and 117 new lows.

Treasury Bonds Fall
By Reuters
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 9/32, to 105 3/32, yesterday, to yield 5.16 percent, in late trading.
Analysts cited asset reallocations out of bonds and into a rallying stock market, as well as prospects for lower short-term interest rates.
In contrast, two-year notes were up 4/32 , to 1011/32 , yielding 4.56 percent. "To hold on to two-year notes at these levels, you have to believe that the world financial crisis is going to continue," said Chris Rupkey, vice president and financial economist at Bank of Tokyo/Mitsubishi.
He predicted the Federal Reserve would ease interest rates by a quarter percentage point, noting that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, had warned "that deflation from the Far East is heading our way and that it will slow the economy more than would have been expected."
The Treasury sold $15.0 billion in two-year notes at a high yield of 4.615 percent yesterday.
Five-year notes were up 11/32, to 103 13/32, to yield 4.47 percent. Ten-year notes advanced 10/32, to 107 13/32, to yield 4.66 percent.
At the short end of the maturity range, three-month bill rates were down 12 basis points, or hundredths of a point, to 4.55 percent, and six-month bill rates were off 14 basis points, to 4.51 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Seeing a Fund as Too Bigto Fail, New York Fed Assists Its Bailout

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has helped organize the rescue of a large and prominent speculative fund, indicating that regulators recognize that the failure of such a fund would damage already fragile world markets.
Under an agreement reached late yesterday, the fund, Long-Term Capital Management L.P. of Greenwich, Conn., received a cash infusion of more than $3.5 billion from a consortium of commercial banks and investment firms. The fund, whose founder is John Meriwether, a former vice chairman of Salomon Inc., and whose partners included two Nobel prize winners, is said to be have a portfolio worth $90 billion. 
 The deal came after representatives of 16 banks and brokerage houses met at the offices of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in downtown Manhattan. It is extremely unusual for the Federal Reserve to get involved in the bailout of such a fund, known as a hedge fund, a virtually unregulated type of investment firm, which despite its name, speculates in high-risk trades in markets around the world.
A spokesman for the New York Federal Reserve Bank, the biggest of the Fed's 12 regional banks, declined to comment.
But the Federal Reserve Bank's actions show that regulators are deeply concerned about the impact that a liquidation of Long-Term Capital's trades would have on brokerage firms and banks already struggling with huge losses from worldwide market turmoil.
Regulators in the past have encouraged creditors and borrowers to work together to avoid the kind of panic selling of a portfolio that could harm other investors in a particular market. For example, during the downturn in real estate in the early 1990's, the Fed asked banks to work with developers on the ropes. After the stock market crash in 1987, the Fed made capital available to securities firms that might have been on shaky ground.
For the Fed to get involved with a speculator like Mr. Meriwether is an indication that this time around, the asset of greatest concern is not commercial real estate or stocks. This time, it is bonds.
Long-Term Capital has been hurt by the same market developments that have led to losses at many investment firms. As turmoil in Russia grew, culminating with the country's de facto default on some debt and its devaluation of the ruble, investors fled risky securities. Many took refuge in the United States Treasury market, where prices surged, driving yields to record lows.
This confluence of events hurt Mr. Meriwether, who had been a big buyer of riskier bonds; adding insult to injury, the firm had also sold Treasury securities as a hedge for its non-Treasury bond holdings. When Treasury prices rose, Mr. Meriwether wound up on the losing end of both sides of his trades.
And like many hedge funds, Long-Term Capital made its bets on borrowed money. At times, the value of its positions exceeded its capital by 50 or 100 times. Recently, for example, Mr. Meriwether's firm was said to be holding positions worth $90 billion, while its capital stood at $2.3 billion.
The Fed may have been prompted to act quickly on Long-Term Capital's problems because it realizes that many of the world's hedge funds and most of the big brokerage houses have billions of dollars in trades on their books that are identical to those skewering Mr. Meriwether.
"The Fed is aware of the precarious position that exists among the largest dealers who have positions in virtually every fixed-income product versus Treasuries," said one trader, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "If Long-Term Capital had to take off its trades, all the hedge funds and dealers would be killed."
Why? Because having a seller liquidating billion-dollar positions in these markets would drive them even lower than they now are. This could cause other failures among hedge funds and make dealer firms' losses increase, causing another wave of selling.
Even without panic selling, things have been bad for Long-Term Capital since August. At the beginning of the year, the firm had around $4.8 billion in capital. By Sept. 2, that capital had dwindled to $2.3 billion.
His losses rising, Mr. Meriwether wrote a three-page letter to his investors. He explained that his fund was down 44 percent in the month of August alone and was off 52 percent for the year. Some 82 percent of the losses came in so-called relative value trades, a specialty of Mr. Meriwether's, which identify small price differences between, say, a futures contract on a particular bond and the security itself. The remaining 18 percent was lost in trades in which Long-Term bet on a certain issue, up or down. Included in this group were losses in emerging markets, including Russia.
In the letter, Mr. Meriwether affirmed his belief in the trades his firm had made. He asked investors to consider making additional investments to the firm. By all accounts, no one did. Indeed, at about this time, the firm went to Soros Fund Management asking for an infusion of $500 million. The request was denied.
In the weeks since Mr. Meriwether wrote his letter, the market has hammered Long-Term Capital relentlessly. Treasuries have kept rising and all other debt has continued to lag. Even if he did not try to liquidate some of his trades, having to assess the value of his portfolio each night, as all funds are required to, meant that he did need to put up more capital.
It was no surprise, then, that in recent days, bond traders have suspected Mr. Meriwether and his associates of trying to unload some of their holdings to meet margin requirements. Last Friday, for example, Long-Term Capital bought a number of Treasury futures to liquidate one side of a huge trade. The buying moved the spread between the futures and the so-called cash market in that particular issue by one-quarter of a point, an enormous move in the world's deepest, most liquid securities market.
Terms of yesterday's bailout were not given. But bankers say that the institutions -- including Goldman, Sachs, Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, J. P. Morgan, Chase Manhattan and UBS of Switzerland, among others -- agreed to put up roughly $250 million each in return for an equity stake in Long-Term Capital.
It is believed that existing equity holders, also known as limited partners, would end up with a greatly diminished ownership in the firm, between 10 and 20 percent of their original stakes. A spokesman for Long-Term Capital declined to comment on yesterday's developments.
Mr. Meriwether, of course, has faced adversity before. He left his position as vice chairman of Salomon Brothers in 1991 after Paul Mozer, one of the firm's Treasury traders, was caught trying to corner the market in two-year Treasury securities. Mr. Meriwether formed Long-Term Capital in 1994, along with the Salomon Brothers alumni Lawrence E. Hilibrand and Eric R. Rosenfeld, and Robert H. Merton and Myron S. Scholes, both Nobel laureates in economics.
With its stable of star traders, Long-Term Capital attracted money from banks, brokerage houses and wealthy individuals, all of whom agreed to lock up their investments until at the earliest, the end of this year.
Even if Long-Term Capital rides out this storm, the world of hedge funds will probably never be the same. Many investors will likely flee all such funds, and regulators will probably scrutinize their operations a lot more closely. Mr. Meriwether himself will be under the scrutiny of an oversight committee appointed by the banks that bailed him out.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
MCDONALD'S EXPECTS 13% TO 14% RISE IN SALES ABROAD

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that it expected third-quarter sales outside the United States to rise 13 percent to 14 percent before adjusting for the strong dollar. That kind of growth, even in the face of economic instability in some regions, would exceed most analysts' expectations. The international outlook follows promises last month by McDonald's new chief executive, Jack Greenberg, that per-share earnings would continue to rise 10 percent to 15 percent annually for the next five years. McDonald's, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., has more than 23,500 fast-food restaurants in 113 countries. Its shares closed unchanged at $56.50 in trading of 3 million.

LENGTH: 928 words

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Brewers Do Part in Sosa's Season

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE

 BODY:
THERE was a time when the familiar slogan in this bratwurst burg bragged about "the beer that made Milwaukee famous." But in baseball's year of the Great Home Run Race, Milwaukee is now known for the pitching staff that made Sammy Sosa famous.
With his two homers here yesterday for a total of 65, Sosa had hit 12 against the Brewers' staff this season. More importantly, he had tied Mark McGwire for the major league home run lead. McGwire went 1 for 3 with a single and two walks last night against the Houston Astros in St. Louis. 
 When Sosa was hitting four home runs in three days against the Milwaukee Brewers nearly two weeks ago, the Cubs slugger was asked what he thought of the Brewers' transfer to the National League this season after nearly three decades in the American League.
With his trademark smile, Sosa replied, "I think it was a very good move."
Very good for him, certainly.
Before yesterday's game, Sosa had been in an 0-for-21 slump since he had tied McGwire with his 63d homer, a grand slam in San Diego a week ago. McGwire had hit two more since then, and with only several days left in the season, the competition that had riveted fans throughout the summer appeared to be over.
But suddenly Sosa energized the race, slugging home runs in the fifth and sixth innings.
"I still think Mark will finish in front of me," Sosa said. "I have to give up and sacrifice myself to get on base. Mark don't have to go to the playoff. When you try to go to the playoff, you never think about home runs. I came back today and hit the ball; it's part of the game," he said. "It's a good sign. I feel great today. I feel patient. When I play like that, I have a better chance. Yesterday I use three bats, today I use one -- the good one."
"I have to say this is my lucky team," he said later, alluding to the Brewers.
But as a group, Sosa and the Cubs weren't feeling lucky. They lost, 8-7, in the ninth inning when three Brewer baserunners suddenly scored as left fielder Brant Brown dropped a fly ball that should have been a routine final out.
"What happened to Brownie can happen to everybody," Sosa said. "What happened today, just forget about it and keep going."
Sosa's first homer, off Rafael Roque in the fifth inning, floated into the right-field stands at County Stadium, 344 feet away. His second, off Rod Henderson in the sixth, soared over the center-field fence, 410 feet away.
Asked if he would trade the two homers for a victory, Sosa said: "Definitely. I care about winning. I care about the team."
But the loss, like Sosa's two homers, are in the book now. His 12 homers against the Brewers average one for each of the 12 games between the teams this season -- the highest per-game homer ratio against one team in major league history.
Lou Gehrig, the Iron Horse first baseman of the Yankees, hit 14 homers against the Cleveland Indians' staff in 1936 for the major league record. Joe Adcock of the Milwaukee Braves and Hank Sauer of the Chicago Cubs each hit 12 against one team in one season for the National League record -- Adock against the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1956, Sauer against the Pittsburgh Pirates in 1954.
But in those eras, teams played 22 games against each other team every season. Sosa hit his 12 against the Brewers in 12 games.
Sosa's homers also gave him 155 runs batted in. It's the fourth highest total in N.L. history, behind Hack Wilson's major league record 190 for the Cubs in 1930, Chuck Klein's 170 for the 1930 Philadelphia Phillies and Wilson's 159 in 1929.
But the number Sosa seemed more concerned with were the eventual number of dead and injured from Hurricane Georges in the Dominican Republic, where he grew up and where he returns each off season.
"I haven't heard anything," he said. "When we get to Houston tonight, I will make some phone calls and try to find out. It is bad.
"But maybe this," he said, speaking of his two homers, "helps them feel a little better."
As the Cubs departed for Houston and Friday night's opener of their season's concluding three-game series, Kerry Wood, their 21-year-old right-hander who struck out 20 Astros on May 6 to tie the major league record, was almost as much a part of their storyline as Sosa and Brown.
Wood hasn't pitched since Aug. 31, when he sprained a ligament in his right elbow. Now he may or may not return as a starter Saturday.
"Kerry threw the ball very well," said Jim Riggleman, the Cubs' manager, after Wood fired fastballs and a few curveballs for about 10 minutes yesterday. "We'll see how he feels tomorrow, but I'd say it's 50-50 at best that he'll pitch in Houston."
After his brief workout, Wood said, "I feel O.K., it's up to them." But even with the wild-card berth at stake, Riggleman and Ed Lynch, the Cubs' general manager, might decide not to risk reinjuring the golden arm that represents the future of the Cubs' pitching staff.
Kevin Tapani (19-8) will open for the Cubs against Mike Hampton (11-7). Terry Mulholland (6-5) is scheduled for Sunday against Shane Reynolds (19-8) unless he's needed in relief before that. The Astros won't use Randy Johnson until next Wednesday's division series opener.
If Wood doesn't return Saturday, Mark Clark will start against Jose Lima, who has surrendered two of Sosa's three homers against the Astros this season.
But no matter who pitches for the Cubs in Houston, their wild-card chances will depend on Sammy Sosa.
"If we make it to the playoff, yes, I will be happy with this season," he said. "But if we don't, I got to go home and sing the blues."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Environmentalists Vow To Fight Referendum

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
A coalition of environmental groups pledged yesterday to oppose passage of a referendum asking taxpayers to bail out counties for debts incurred in the building of incinerators because, the coalition said, location of the trash burners in low-income neighborhoods amounts to environmental racism.
Dana Natale, an anthropologist at Montclair State University who surveyed the locations for the coalition, Reclaim New Jersey, said the incinerators were being built in areas where residents "tend to have low levels of education, poor economic conditions and high levels of minority residents." 
 The November ballot question will ask voters to approve using money from a 1980 bond issue to pay off debt incurred by counties to build the incinerators, which cannot compete in a trash disposal market that was deregulated by court decisions last year, said Madelyn Hoffman, director of the Grassroots Environmental Organization, a coalition member.
If approved, the initiative would pay off $180 million of the $1.6 billion in debt incurred by counties under now-defunct regulations intended to control the flow of solid waste throughout the state.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Tax Break Helps Sales

BYLINE: By Nick Ravo 

 BODY:
New York's fourth sales-tax-exemption week, held earlier this month, resulted in increased sales of 71 percent compared with a typical week in September at stores surveyed in the city, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said on Tuesday.
From Sept. 1 through Sept. 8, The 8.25 percent sales tax was eliminated for items of clothing and shoes priced under $500. During a tax-free shopping week in September 1997, when only clothing that cost less than $100 was tax free, merchants reported average sales increases of 48 percent. In January 1997, when the sales tax was not levied on clothing and shoes under $500, retailers reported average increases of 77 percent. 
 The city's Economic Development Corporation surveyed 125 New York City retailers with locations in all five boroughs to determine the impact of the sales tax exemption.
Another tax-free week is scheduled for Jan. 17 through 24. As during the most recent tax-free week, clothing and footwear under $500 will be exempt from sales tax.
In December 1999, New York State will eliminate its 4 percent tax and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's 0.25 percent sales tax on clothing and shoes under $110. Municipalities will have the option of eliminating their sales taxes.
 NICK RAVO

HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
Honeycombs in Flight: Office of Tomorrow?

BYLINE: By Julie V. Iovine 

 BODY:
ANYONE who works in a cubicle knows that its shroudlike isolation bears no resemblance to real privacy. But it may come as a surprise that the people who design today's office systems agree that cubicles are long overdue for a makeover.
"When I think about having to go to a box every day and perform a job in one of those little spaces, it doesn't seem human," said Ross Lovegrove, a British designer who was asked by the Herman Miller company -- which introduced the precursor to the cubicle concept in the 60's -- to help give new life to the spaces where roughly 60 percent of America's white-collar work force toils. 
 The system that the design team developed, which looks in part like a marauding raptor, might have been conceived for Sigourney Weaver's console in "Aliens." It is intended as an antidote to the piles of cables snaking around workers' feet.
Inspired by the computer mantra "plug and play," it consists of components that build up from the floor, rather than cantilevering from shoulder-height panels. A slick shell of translucent honeycombed plastic, it stands on silvery birdlike legs that attach directly to floor tiles, integrating the floor into the structure and masking cables for the computer, telephone and lights.
The approach was to think inside out. "As we move further away from pencil and paper, the support technology needed to convey voice, power and data becomes massive," Mr. Lovegrove said. "The infrastructure of even 10 years ago can't handle it." The goal was to transform the cubicle into a thing of "lightness and grace," he said. The system is also a lot easier to break down and reconfigure, a priority for office managers reared on notions of "high churn" (turnover) and faced with good old downsizing.
The "privacy" this system will provide is open to interpretation: an assortment of ethereal cotton-spandex screens that flex like wings can be snapped in place to offer some semblance of visual and audio separation. (They look great, but will they do the trick when a colleague is ranting on the phone at a spouse?) And then there are the file boxes: stacks of perforated plastic that bear an uncanny resemblance to the milk crates that another generation used to store LP's.
Still a prototype, the product -- known informally as Emma, after a grandmother of someone on the design team's staff -- is a collaboration between Interface Architectural Resources, a carpet manufacturer, and Herman Miller, the second largest manufacturer of office furniture in the country and no stranger to office innovation since it introduced the Action Office in 1964. Mr. Lovegrove's partner on the team was Stephen Peart, a designer who lives near San Francisco.
The system was previewed in June at Neocon, the trade show for the commercial furniture industry. "Everyone was buzzing around saying, 'You've got to see it,' " said Shashi Caan, a senior designer at Gensler, an architectural interiors firm. "Functionally, it wasn't all that new. Conceptually, it was fascinating. By simplifying all the parts and pieces and letting them be the decorations themselves, it made a really strong statement."
Others were most impressed by the Legolike components, which can be built up to accommodate a single worker or a team. "It comes as close to real building blocks as I've ever seen," said Roger Yee, editor of Contract Design, a trade magazine. "All the parts are universal."
"It doesn't presume how you're going to use it," Mr. Yee said -- whether in a traditional office with freestanding furniture or in a cubicle arrangement. He said the system "is honest enough to say it doesn't know the shape of the office of the future."
But in a business bred on brown laminates, the translucent plastic -- inspired by "the economy of such natural structures as honeycombs," Mr. Lovegrove said -- raised the most eyebrows. Kent Gawart, a business development executive at Herman Miller, which hopes to introduce the system next year, said many people at Neocon thought the plastic "went way beyond being viable."
So it's back to the drawing board for a few more embellishments -- namely a nice mahogany desktop, the kind the boss always gets.

(Photographs by Herman Miller Inc.); OFFICE SUPPORT -- The linchpin of Herman Miller's new office system is a leg, left, that plugs directly into flooring, inset, which conceals the tangle of cables. (Herman Miller/Lovegrove)

HEADLINE: Covering the Territory;
On the Web, Titans Battle for Turf

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER 

 BODY:
WHILE there are thousands of real estate sites on the Internet, a battle appears to be shaping up between two titans: Home Advisor, run by Microsoft, the mogul of cyberspace, and Realtor.com, which is operated by Real Select for the National Association of Realtors and is the leader in home listings on the Web.
Microsoft opened Home Advisor in July. Prospective buyers can troll electronic neighborhoods for demographic data, calculate how much house they can afford using specific information about a house they like and even get pre-approved for a loan. A prospective buyer can specify the type of house sought and receive an E-mail message when one pops up. 
 The problem is getting the house to pop up. Microsoft has 300,000 to 400,000 listings, compared with 1.3 million at Realtor.com, according to information supplied by the companies.
In a recent random test, Microsoft had no listings for three-bedroom, two-bathroom houses between $100,000 and $300,000 in Olathe and Overland Park, Kan., two of the fastest-growing communities in the Kansas City area. At Realtor.com, however, there were 31 listings for the houses of that size at $100,000 in Olathe alone.
In Houston Heights, north of downtown Houston, where the two sites were on more level ground, running a comparison became more interesting. At the outset, both sites provide the national average for mortgage interest rates. Last Friday, Realtor.com was advertising 7.05 percent on a 30-year-fixed mortgage, 6.81 percent on 15-year fixed and 6.19 percent on a one-year variable. Microsoft's rates were 6.56 for the 30-year, 6.24 for the 15-year and 5.48 for the variable mortgage. Representatives at each site said the differences in rates cited could be due to the use of different sources: Microsoft's Home Advisor uses information from an outside company; Realtor.com uses figures from the National Association of Realtors.
Realtor.com breaks areas down by state, city and ZIP code. Customers then say how much they want to pay for what kind of house, specifying the number of bedrooms and total rooms, age of the house and square footage. Customers can also specify things like the number of stories, accessibility for the disabled, central air-conditioning, fireplaces and lot features.
Using only the very basic limitations of three bedrooms and two baths with a price of about $200,000, Realtor.com listed 22 properties in the Heights. The basic format provided a picture (when available) and brief description. The houses that appeared ranged in price from $160,000 to $239,000, with more details on request.
Using the same limitations, Home Advisor came up with 15 listings. The initial listing gives the size of the house and price, with no address; by clicking, the house hunter gets more information. Home Advisor also locates the property on a map and provides basic demographic information on the area. Houston Heights, for example, was described as having a population of 32,271, an annual median income of $31,306, an average household size of 2.45 people and a median age of 34.3 years.
Realtor.com, which has been on line since 1996, has more than 1.2 million listings, about 95 percent of all listings nationwide, said Michael Keller, vice president for marketing at Real Select. The data, which are supplied by Multiple Listing Services, include 148 of the largest 150 markets. The site has 3.25 million visitors per month doing more than 65 million searches.
Realtor.com does provide neighborhood information and school reports, but they are done through private companies, which charge a fee. For $19.95, consumers can get five reports over a seven-day period on schools, crime and the environment. A buyer can get a credit report through the site in only 30 seconds, but it will cost $8, or $29.95 for a report including results from three major credit bureaus.
Microsoft, on the other hand, is going for the superstore approach. Its Home Advisor site has five key areas: How Much Can I Afford, Finding a Neighborhood, Finding a Home, Finding a Loan, and Offer and Closing. "We're the first to have all five of these area in an integrated fashion," said Ian Morris, lead product manager for Home Advisor.
Although other sites may link services together, Mr. Morris said Home Advisor was different because it brought the services together in one navigational scheme. So, for example, a buyer who finds an interesting house can go on to calculate what the monthly payment would be, using interest rates posted on the site. Although addresses in many cities are not posted, the house can be pinpointed on a map and distances -- say, to Grandmother's house -- can be calculated.
While the company offering reports on neighborhood crime statistics through Home Advisor charged $20 for a report, it was possible for a shopper looking for a house in Houston to type in an address and find out at no charge whether any convicted child molesters lived in the surrounding area.
ALTHOUGH praised for its innovations, the site has been criticized as being a vehicle for Microsoft to make money by charging companies to sell mortgages. But Mr. Morris countered that by charging its "lender partners" a fee, Microsoft was able to provide free home listings.
As for the number of its listings, Mr. Morris noted that Home Advisor had been on line for only a couple of months, while Realtor.com had been on the Net for a couple of years. He said Microsoft had "deals in place" that would result in its listings numbering more than half a million, with more being added all the time.
Another problem with Home Advisor was that it repeatedly disconnected during attempts to use it. The problem was reported to the company and appeared to be solved in later tests.
While Realtor.com and Home Advisor are attracting lots of attention, competitors like Home Shark -- which can search more than a million listings in more than 350 Web sites -- are giving them a run for their money. Home Shark, a company that specializes in discount mortgages on line, has created a site with many of the same special features as Home Advisor. Although it does not have its own real estate database, it uses Home Scout, a search engine that draws from other real estate databases. A search of Houston through Home Shark, using the same criteria as before, landed more than 1,000 matches. The problem was narrowing the search to a particular area within the city.
Many of the major real estate sites have similar features. Consumers should spend some time exploring various sites to see which format best fits their needs.
In addition, keep in mind that these sites are there to make money. While basic neighborhood and school information is available for free, fees are generally charged for more details or more contact information.
Here are a few more of the many real estate sites on the Web with interesting and valuable information:
 
www.homes.com Has listings from Homes and Land magazine, which publishes listings for thousands of communities where the publication is distributed; the site also includes lots of other information for home buyers.
 
www.homescout.com: Compiles listings from other Web sites and directories.
 
www.luxury-realestate.com: A trove of high-end properties, with more than 1,000 listings in 35 countries.
 
www.rent.net: Advertises more than 2.5 million rental properties in the United States and Canada. Also includes relocation resources.
If you look around these and other sites and don't find what you want, try a site for the town you're interested in or for a real estate agency.

LENGTH: 1917 words

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH: JACK LENOR LARSEN;
A Life's Warp and Weft

BYLINE: By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
JACK LENOR LARSEN was ready for his close-up.
"It's nun's veiling," he said of the sheer, black, collarless suit he was wearing that summer day, "designed by my friend Massimo Vignelli. It's cooler than cotton."
Mr. Larsen is a man of the cloth, but it's not like that. He is possibly the most accomplished textile designer living, certainly one of the most innovative and influential in the second half of the 20th century. With the success of several thousand fabric patterns behind him -- many as original as modern architecture -- he has been prolific and powerful in the design community. And through the collections that his travels inspired, the middle-class home and office have become conversant with vibrant traditions everywhere -- from Thailand to Kenya. 
 The handsome Mr. Larsen's life has also been a fabric of sorts, of acquaintance with the rich and celebrated, of social prowess and business sense that has brought him fame and fortune, taken him to six continents and led the fashionable world to his door.
Now, this month, at 71, he has published an autobiography, "Jack Lenor Larsen: A Weaver's Memoir" (Harry Abrams). Friends -- he has known everyone, from Marilyn Monroe to Frank Lloyd Wright -- have undoubtedly heard these stories at the table at Longhouse Reserve, his 12,000-square-foot home in East Hampton, N.Y., which is also an arts foundation and a 16-acre garden open to the public. Mr. Larsen spins a good tale.
Mr. Larsen doffs a hat -- a black straw Amish number -- and points inside to the label. "They're called Park Avenue, but they come from Muncie," he said.
Jack Lenor Larsen lives in East Hampton and on Park Avenue, but as he would have you remember, he is a weaver from Seattle. Born in 1927 to Danish-Norwegian immigrants from Canada, he still presents the simplicity of his Northwest background -- the warp to the weft of his sophistication, rooted in the Douglas firs and Olympic Mountains and glacial, salmon bays of Puget Sound. His father was a building contractor. Intrigued with design, Mr. Larsen studied architecture at the University of Washington. In 1945, there was great interest in crafts in the Northwest. The young designer took a weaving course that put his future in his hands.
"After two years of architecture, drafting things that would never be built, weaving felt good indeed," he recalled. "It had horizontals and verticals, like architecture, and was dependent on materials and light and shadow, but I had real yarns and real color and real structure."
Mr. Larsen also made the first of a life's work of influential friends, Chan Khan, born in Lima, the son of the Chinese Ambassador and the last direct descendant of Kublai Khan. Mr. Khan was exporting pre-Columbian textiles. Amazed by the beauty of their systems, Mr. Larsen decided to become a weaver.
Liberated by his decision, he moved to Los Angeles as part of a company of unattached young friends involved in art, design, music and dance. They roved the coast; Mr. Larsen wove cloth from pine cones and seed pods scavenged on beaches.
He met Dorothea Hulse, who owned Handcraft House, a custom weave shop and school to the stars. Home crafts were voguish in Hollywood in the 1950's; she gave him work teaching weaving. One of Mr. Larsen's students was Joan Crawford, not the first person one associates with home economics.
"She was weaving plaid suits for her children," he said. "She had burned out on another marriage and she decided, well, she still had children," he recalled with a sharp grin. "We took her at her word," he said of Ms. Crawford's role as good mother. "It wasn't the first part she had studied. But it was such a mask. She wore tremendous amounts of makeup and her personality was as covered up."
Mr. Larsen had a brief stint back in Seattle. He hung out his sign, "Jack Larsen -- Weaver," on his studio door. A woman brought him pants to mend. A professor from the Cranbrook Academy of Art in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., offered him work as a teaching assistant. Mr. Larsen stayed on as a graduate student, on scholarship.
"For designers, Cranbrook was a kind of Hollywood," he said. "We were 65 students in the academy, and there were 65 gardeners. They had just stopped shining the students' shoes."
He made himself known to Eleanor Lloyd Richards, who had taught there. "She was from a Dutch family that owned the Upper East Side," Mr. Larsen said. In 1952, when Mr. Larsen arrived in New York, Mrs. Richards wrote him a check to help him bring his loom and 40 boxes of belongings with him.
With his background in architecture and his enthusiasm for technology, the young weaver was gaining a reputation as a modernist -- innovating in a field that was barely there: contemporary commercial fabric design. Modern architectural and interior design found themselves with an American audience in the 1940's and 50's, but there were few fabrics to fit the clean furniture or drape the picture windows. Mr. Larsen would create a strong market for them.
Invited to submit a design for a curtain for Lever House -- New York's first International style office building -- Mr. Larsen's entry, which was chosen, was a drapery of translucent lace woven with linen cord and gold metal, an exotic match of materials for which he would become well known.
By 1953, Jack Lenor Larsen was incorporated. "I had a Beverly Hills debutante as my weaving assistant," he said. "Neither of us had ever worked before." They hand-wove "shaggy" craft neckties, which found themselves noosed on New York's best-known necks, "the people I most admired," Mr. Larsen said, "like Sandy Calder and I. M. Pei and Leonard Bernstein." Florence Knoll, the modern design doyenne, who had turned down his portfolio in 1951 for being "too individualistic," commissioned furniture fabrics in a palette of olives and Spanish oranges that became the "avocado" and "harvest gold" of the 60's.
By 1954, he had a showroom on Park Avenue at 58th Street. Marilyn Monroe walked in with her decorator, shopping for the house in Connecticut she was setting up with Arthur Miller. Frank Lloyd Wright walked in, and walked out with 200 yards of a shimmering blue-green fabric for the music room at Taliesin. Wright was technically a rival. F. Schumacher & Company had introduced two lines of Wright's fabric design. It was understood among designers, Mr. Larsen recalled, that they had not been designed by Wright, but by stylists commissioned to produce Wrightian product. Mr. Larsen said: "Wright needed the money. He was such a spendthrift that he'd never paid his taxes."
As a weaver, Mr. Larsen had established a branch of architecture, the design of fabrics based as much on adventurous engineering -- pre-Columbian or postwar American -- as esthetics. "I like ancient techniques and the cutting edge," he said. "The extremes are always more interesting than the middle." On his loom, Mr. Larsen shuttled between the two.
By 1958, he had designed his first upholstery fabrics for airplanes -- Pan American's new 707 fleet. And he introduced the American public to their international neighbors, long before they became global consumers, through ikats and batiks that were previously familiar only to the privileged explorer. By 1974, Jack Lenor Larsen Inc. was producing fabrics in 30 countries.
Unlike world leaders, weavers understood each other -- by watching. Cloth was like an early map.
Today, Mr. Larsen's great love is home, which is largely Longhouse Reserve, completed in 1992 in collaboration -- their 30th -- with Charles Forberg, an architect. It is an imposing house on stilts, suggested by the Shinto shrine in Ise, Japan.
His collections of ancient and contemporary crafts, including textiles, ceramics and furniture, have followed him there and continue to grow, as does the garden with its art collection. Last year, he sold Larsen Inc. to Cowtan & Tout, a fabric and wallcoverings company; he remains a consultant.
"When I finished the house, I wanted to put an epitaph on it," he said. " 'To the Manor Died' -- I wasn't to the manner born." Mr. Larsen, leading a brisk tour through the garden (the briskest takes about 45 minutes) was debating the offer of a gift of Italian cypresses made to the foundation that morning. Past an allee of cedar trunks painted red, his parents' ashes under a fir leaf birch and a Buckminster Fuller open-air dome, lent this summer by his daughter, Mr. Larsen moved his small group toward Longhouse, a 180-foot-long building spread like a crane above man-made dunes.
Inside, Mr. Larsen did a quick walk-about in the living room, beneath its 65-foot skylight. Much of the foundation's loan collections are on display here. Then he strode the length of the house, past the center A-frame stairwell, with its two-story Dale Chihuly lizard-green glass pendant (it was Mr. Larsen who urged Mr. Chihuly, then a weaving student, to take glass-blowing lessons after he saw Mr. Chihuly's project of strips of woven glass) to the smaller, more intimate sitting room in Mr. Larsen's private quarters.
The peaked room is tented, in the style of Napoleon, in a Larsen fabric, "Canterbury," a Jacquard weave of Egyptian linen designed in the 70's.
"I'd hoped this tented ceiling and fabric walls would become a national trend," Mr. Larsen said. "It didn't."
The campaign-style room is neatly, snugly enfolded in Mr. Larsen's own personal collections. There is a Swedish ceramic stove, with two ebony Philippine armchairs before it. To the side is an 18th-century, painted-cloth Iranian camp table, which displays a box turtle shell found on the property and a 19th-century American patent ladder, which is used as bookshelves. There are five uncharacteristically delicate Edward Wormley tables and an important representation of pieces by Wharton Esherick, the dean of American craft furniture makers, including a side chair with a puzzle of miners' hammer handles fitted together to form the base. A pretty, varnished rolling table was his mother's. "Somebody made it in the Navy yard in Seattle, for cribbage," he said.
Many of the interior walls at Longhouse are sliding panels, stretched with fabric, a device based on a Japanese architectural element, the paper-panel fusama, which creates rooms and storage. An opaque, woven-leather cloth in the bedroom conceals clothes and bath towels; a sheer linen, threaded with hand-clipped Thai silk, showcases, in silhouette, shelves of ceramic collections. Other panels, rolled aside, reveal a short history of ceramics -- Yi-xing wine pots, Han Dynasty heads, a Dansk design of Mr. Larsen's and a vase by Dame Lucy Rie, the British studio potter, who was a friend.
Mr. Larsen picked the vase from the shelf, turning the milky ceramic in his hands as though it were a face he was trying to revolve into view.
"She became like an abbess, always in white," he said. "Frail, almost like blowing a dandelion down."
Mr. Larsen keeps his influences, experiences and memories on a shelf -- behind him, for others to admire. Weavers live for surprise -- that burst of firsts when paths intersect.
"I maintained the fantasy, until I was about 34, that I wasn't really working," Mr. Larsen said, composing a salad for lunch -- beets for color, walnuts for texture, string beans for structure and lettuce greens for form. "It occurred to me that I spent more hours doing what I did than anyone I knew. Other people would call it work. But I'm just playing very hard."

HEADLINE: Scholarships Provide Laptops Instead of Money

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
A NEW scholarship program at a California state college is one of the first in the nation to give students computers instead of financial aid.
By handing out $2,400 Fujitsu laptops to 40 incoming freshman, aid officials at California State University at San Marcos hope to narrow a technology gap among lower-income students that they think contributes to the low retention rate for first-year students. 
 "We have tremendous concerns with low-income students," said Paul E. Phillips, director of financial aid and scholarship at the campus, in north San Diego County, where, like elsewhere in the 22-campus system, about half of the students qualify for some financial aid. "We had students who had never turned a computer on."
Since faculty at the nine-year-old campus expect all of the 5,000 students to turn in assignments on computer disks or by E-mail, computer access is as much a requirement at San Marcos as textbooks and backpacks.
And while computers are available to students on campus, access may be impractical for those students who have family or work obligations.
Aid officials decided their resources would be most valuable buying PC's and software directly from a manufacturer and winning a volume discount. "We wanted to be sure they had every technological advantage they could to succeed," Mr. Phillips said.
Advocates for public access to digital services argue that the inability to harness technology's power will undercut economic and social advancement by the poor.
The San Marco laptop recipients are known as Evers computer scholars, named after their benefactor, the late Leonard Evers, a former resident of the region. He bequeathed $2 million for the college's needy students. The Evers scholars, selected from among 60 applicants with B average high school grades who also wrote essays, also are receiving $5,000 in monetary grants to cover tuition, books and some expenses. A full-time student's costs average $12,000 a year at a state college, which sets minimum entry requirements of grade-point average and test scores.
Besides the laptop, loaded with Microsoft's Windows 95 and Excel spreadsheet programs, the students also spent the first day of the semester learning how to click and close and dial up cyberspace under the tutelage of the campus computer-lab staff. While self-help with their own computer glitches is encouraged, the students also have been provided with a special call-in number for technical support. "They get V.I.P. treatment," Mr. Phillips said. They also get to keep the laptops if they graduate.
Mr. Phillips says it's too soon to look for results, although he is already hoping this year's laptop recipients become Evers scholars' mentors next year.
Financial aid experts say the unusual award at California State University at San Marcos is likely to be copied as a computer requirement becomes more prevalent at other campuses.
"Colleges that require computers, the cost is allowable as part of the expense budget," said John D. Joyce, a manager for the College Board scholarship service. He said the San Marcos program is the first he is aware of that defrays costs with equipment rather than cash.
Nationally, students borrowed 60 percent of $55.7 billion awarded in financial aid during the 1996-1997 year, the most recent figures available.

HEADLINE: Fed Chairman Renews Hopes For a Rate Cut

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, suggested today that the central bank would seriously consider cutting interest rates next week because of the deepening world financial crisis.
"We have to bring the existing instabilities to a level of stability reasonably shortly, to prevent the contagion from really spilling over and creating some very significant further difficulties for all of us," Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Budget Committee. 
 His comments sent the stock market up strongly, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed 257.21 points higher -- a gain of 3.26 percent -- at 8,154.41, its strongest advance since the 512.61-point plunge Aug. 31. Page C1.
Mr. Greenspan, who as usual left himself some wiggle room, hedged his comments by observing that the American economy remains strong and unemployment low, a combination that would normally lead the Fed to worry about inflation. And in a nod to members of the central bank's policy-making committee who might be reluctant to cut rates when they meet on Tuesday, he emphasized that the decision was not his alone. Excerpts, page C3.
But in his clearest warning yet that the global crisis is threatening the nation's long economic expansion, Mr. Greenspan enumerated developments over the last several months that could slow growth in the United States. They included the decline in the stock market, a reduction in lending by banks and a general rise in uncertainty that could make consumers more cautious.
"I can't comment at this particular stage on what particular actions will or will not be taken," Mr. Greenspan said when asked about the possibility of a rate cut on Tuesday. "But I really would suggest to you that I think we know where we have to go."
The Federal Reserve has not cut interest rates since January 1996, when it reduced its short-term Federal funds target rate to 5.25 percent from 5.5 percent. It raised the rate back to 5.5 percent in March 1997.
Economists said the central bank might still take only a half step when it meets Tuesday and adopt a formal "bias" toward an ease in policy, a signal that it expects it next move to be a rate cut.
But there was a feeling among analysts that Mr. Greenspan would make a strong case at the meeting for an immediate cut of a quarter of a percentage point and try to persuade the committee's more inflation-wary members.
"It means the odds now strongly favor him cutting rates on Sept. 29," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey Lanston & Company in New York. Economists said Mr. Greenspan previewed the argument he was likely to make to the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee in saying today that "deteriorating foreign economies and their spillover to domestic markets have increased the possibility that the slowdown in the growth of the American economy will be more than sufficient to hold inflation in check."
Mr. Greenspan has couched his increasingly explicit discussions of the rationale for a rate cut in terms of protecting the domestic economic expansion, which began in 1991 and has seen inflation almost erased even as unemployment has fallen to its lowest in more than 25 years.
But with much of Asia in recession, Russia in economic turmoil and Latin America increasingly at risk, industrialized and developing nations alike have been calling for a rate reduction in the United States.
A rate cut by the Fed could help the rest of the world by stimulating more growth in the United States, a major market for the goods and services produced in many struggling economies.
It could lead to a weaker dollar and help encourage lower interest rates in other nations. That could help ease some of the financial pressure felt by governments, banks and companies that are struggling with falling currency values and debts denominated in dollars. And it could provide a psychological boost to financial markets, which have been looking to Mr. Greenspan for signs of leadership at a time when governments and international institutions have provided few answers.
"It's a way of saying we're going to do our part to sustain growth in our own economy at a time when the world is fragile," said Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney in New York. "Cutting rates in America doesn't solve the banking and debt restructuring problems of these troubled places, but you start to form a base for rebuilding confidence in the global economy and then hope everybody does their part."
Mr. Greenspan first raised the possibility of rate cut in a speech in California early this month, saying the United States could not expect to remain an "island of prosperity" at a time when much of the rest of world was struggling. Last week he said there was no prospect of a coordinated rate cut by the world's biggest industrial countries -- Germany's powerful Bundesbank had already signaled that it would not go along -- but again hinted that slowing growth in the United States might justify a policy easing by the Fed.
His wording today, however, was far more forceful than in his previous statements about the risks facing the world and American economies and his signal of an eventual rate cut considerably less veiled.
There are few signs that the crisis that began last year in Asia is subsiding, he said, describing the last several months as "the most recent, more virulent phase of the crisis." The problems in the rest of the world have "also been accompanied by a rising concern for risk in the United States," he said.
Through much of this year, Mr. Greenspan held off pressure from a number of Fed policy makers for an interest rate increase to head off inflationary pressures. Two of the committee's 12 members -- Jerry L. Jordan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, and William Poole, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis -- voted last spring for an interest rate increase, and a number of others were leaning in that direction.
It is unclear how much opposition Mr. Greenspan might face to a rate cut now.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 25, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about remarks on Wednesday by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, referred incorrectly to the 257.21-point gain in the Dow Jones industrial average that day. It was not the strongest advance since Aug. 31; the strongest was 380.53 points on Sept. 8. Wednesday's close of 8,154.41 was the Dow's highest close since Aug. 31.

HEADLINE: PAKISTAN PLEDGES A-BOMB TEST BAN IF SANCTIONS END

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Pakistan's Prime Minister said today that he would sign a treaty banning nuclear testing within the next year, putting the onus on India to follow suit or be left with North Korea as the only nations refusing to curb their nuclear weapons.
But the Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, linked the decision to a lifting of the sanctions imposed on Pakistan after it tested nuclear weapons in May. 
 American officials said President Clinton told Mr. Sharif on Monday that there could be no general waiver of sanctions until Pakistan made a formal decision not to conduct any more tests of nuclear weapons.
Today Washington welcomed Mr. Sharif's announcement, made in a speech to the General Assembly, even though it was conditional.
Diplomats at the United Nations are watching to see if India makes the same gesture when its Prime Minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, addresses the Assembly on Thursday.
Mr. Sharif announced his decision only hours after a lunch meeting with Mr. Vajpayee, at which they agreed on steps to reduce tensions.
Pakistan's promise to sign the treaty is the first step toward ending the nuclear arms race in South Asia, which erupted in May when India set off a surprising series of explosions, embarrassing American intelligence officials and diplomats. Pakistan quickly followed with its own tests.
The United States and international lending agencies put sanctions on loans to both India and Pakistan after the tests, but the curbs have particularly pinched Pakistan.
For the past several months, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott has been shuttling from New Delhi to Islamabad, trying to persuade Indian and Pakistani officials to follow up pledges not to conduct more tests by putting their signatures on the test-ban treaty within a certain time limit.
"The within-a-year part is something that Strobe has been working overtime to try and nail down," said Michael Krepon, president of the Henry L. Stimson Center, a military research organization in Washington.
What Pakistan announced, he said, amounted to "a time-bound framework, a declaration of intent."
At their meeting today, the Prime Ministers agreed to resume high-level talks on the dispute over Kashmir, talks that have been suspended for more than a year. But Kashmir, divided between the two countries and not recognized by the United Nations as belonging to either, will be only one of a number of subjects on the agenda when negotiations open in mid-October.
The two leaders also decided to set up a "hot line" between them, improve transportation links and put an end to sporadic firing across the cease-fire line in Kashmir.
Mr. Vajpayee said the talks opened "a new chapter in Indo-Pakistani cooperation."
But neither leader showed any sign of budging from long-held positions on Kashmir's future, with Mr. Sharif renewing calls for the United Nations to get involved and Mr. Vajpayee refusing to condone any outside help.
India accuses Pakistan of arming and training rebels in the Kashmir Valley, a Muslim area that has been in revolt against Indian rule since 1989. Pakistan accuses India with repression and the deaths of thousands of Kashmiris under army rule.
"Disappearances, arbitrary arrests, summary executions continue to be daily occurrences," Mr. Sharif said today in his speech. "The nightmare of the Kashmiri people continues."
Before Mr. Sharif spoke, there had been reports in Pakistan that he would move closer to signing the 1996 Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, which Pakistan has always said it would not do until India signed.
Pakistan voted for the treaty at a United Nations conference in 1996; India did not. India tried to block approval but was overwhelmingly out-voted, and lost friends in the developing world.
Asked today if India is now ready to sign, Mr. Vajpayee told reporters they would have to wait until they heard his speech on Thursday morning.
Mr. Sharif's one-year time frame for signing the treaty was chosen because in September 1999, the nations that have adhered to the treaty -- 150 to date -- will meet to review it. The test ban will come into force then, but only if all 44 nations that are "nuclear capable" have signed and ratified.
The United States has signed the treaty but President Clinton has not yet sent it to the Senate for ratification.
Pakistan wants to be part of the 1999 conference to prevent the rules from changing if India holds out against the treaty.
Some nations have suggested that in order to avoid a slow death for the pact, it might be necessary to overlook India and North Korea and allow the treaty to go into effect with ratifications from only 42 nuclear-capable nations.
"Pakistan will oppose any attempt to change this fundamental requirement," Mr. Sharif said. "Such a change can only be made by consensus."
He also said that if India resumed nuclear testing, Pakistan would review its decision to join the treaty.
Despite all the possible pitfalls ahead, Pakistan's decision was welcomed today.
"Ever since the nuclear tests in South Asia in May 1998, I have consistently urged India and Pakistan to sign" the treaty, Secretary General Kofi Annan said in a statement. "The Government of Pakistan is to be commended for heeding the concern of the international community."
 

CORRECTION-DATE: September 25, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about Pakistan's offer to sign the treaty banning nuclear weapons tests referred incorrectly to the status of the treaty in the United States. President Clinton has indeed sent it to the Senate for ratification.

HEADLINE: Our Lost Best Chance

BYLINE: By James Traub; James Traub's books include "City on a Hill."

 BODY:
I spent the day The Videotape was released inside the bubble of New York University Law School's symposium on globalization. And a very pleasant bubble it was, with the First Lady and scholars and bankers and United Nations officials earnestly, even a bit piously, mapping a "third way" between laissez-faire capitalism and the welfare state.
Then, in the afternoon, President Clinton arrived, to talk about "Strengthening Democracy in the Global Economy" in a forum with three other heads of state and government. More genial blather, I expected. 
 But no; the President posed the hard questions the others had avoided. What kinds of problems are not amenable to "third way" solutions? How do you persuade a public, or a legislature, to deal today with a problem that won't surface for 10 years, like Social Security? The President even made Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, his trans-Atlantic soulmate, seem ever so slightly flashy.
On the way out, I asked a constitutional law scholar what he had thought. "That was the most intellectually serious President of my lifetime," he said. "And I can't believe we'll get another for a long time. What a waste."
That, I said, was exactly what I had been thinking. It must have been what many people at the symposium were thinking. What a pitiful waste.
At the reception afterward, the President stayed and stayed and talked and talked -- about the problem of the long term, about Kosovo, about anything. I had met him only once before, after a debate in New Hampshire in the fall of 1991, and then, too, he had stayed for hours, debating and delineating.
Some of the same forces of conventional opinion that ridicule Mr. Clinton now over his penchant for all-nighters and commons-room palaver fell hard for him then -- for his passionate engagement with the most serious issues, for his gift for posing complicated questions in the most lucid form. It seemed then that this man could break the ideological deadlock of left and right -- no one had yet coined the phrase "third way" -- and could instill in public life something of the intellectual vitality we associate with the Kennedy years.
And yet, the Clinton Administration has been haunted almost from the outset by the sense of wasted possibilities. President Clinton, unlike Prime Minister Blair, faced a hostile, highly conservative Congress. (At the reception, he said with a smile that at times he could see the merits of a parliamentary system.) Whatever might have been quickly disappeared with the failure of health care reform, the disastrous 1994 elections and the subsequent ascendancy of Dick Morris and "triangulation" -- a debased variation on the third way, in which the President reduced his ambitions almost to nothing.
Perhaps a different kind of man -- a man less intent on survival -- could have found a way to rally the nation to his side. Yet it is also true that the Republicans were determined to deny Mr. Clinton significant legislative victories.
But we didn't know then how profound the waste would turn out to be. After Monday's symposium, I came home, turned on the television and heard, "If the person being deposed kissed the breast of another person . . ." That's what it had come to. Democratization and the forces of global capitalism were inside the bubble, rarefied and faintly preposterous. The all-pervading reality was that the President was facing the prospect of impeachment for refusing to admit that he had touched Monica Lewinsky when she had touched him. And yes, of course, the President was very much to blame for the fix he was in. He shouldn't have done it, and he shouldn't have lied about it. But the world has not been kind to him. It has given him an avenging prosecutor, and a ravening media, and a Republican majority quietly sharpening its knives.
To Mr. Clinton's critics, it is obvious how history will apportion the blame for this colossal waste. But it isn't obvious to me.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (John Gruber)

HEADLINE: Money to Burn at the Pentagon

BYLINE: By Lawrence J. Korb; Lawrence J. Korb, the director of studies at the Council on Foreign Relations, was an Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Reagan Administration.

 BODY:
Ever since the Republicans took control of Congress in 1995, they have added money to the defense budget, over and above the Clinton Administration's requests. In 1995 and 1996, they raised the proposed level of defense spending by $20 billion. In 1997, as part of the balanced budget agreement, the Pentagon's five-year plan received an additional $17 billion boost. And because of lower than expected inflation, the Pentagon will have another $35 billion in purchasing power from 1999 to 2003.
As a result, defense spending is now only 12 percent below the average level from 1976 to 1990. Financing for training and operations is higher per capita than in the Reagan Administration. The United States spends more on defense than all of its declared or potential adversaries combined. 
 Yet this is apparently not enough for Republican leaders, now joined by the President.
During the summer, Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, wrote to Mr. Clinton and the Senate Armed Services and Appropriation Committees requesting an increase because "the military has begun a downward spiral." Defense Secretary William Cohen and Gen. Henry Shelton, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, warned that combat readiness was eroding quickly. The Under Secretary for Acquisitions said the Pentagon had become trapped in a "death spiral."
Until recently the President had responded to pleas for more money by saying that he did not want to renegotiate the hard-fought budget agreement. But this month, Mr. Clinton invited the Pentagon to provide him with a request for more money.
That would be a mistake. The problem is not lack of money or aging equipment. The problem is that those civilians who should be controlling the military are allowing the generals and admirals to unilaterally define the threat, develop the strategy and set criteria for measuring readiness.
Military leaders claim they need to be able to fight two major wars simultaneously without allied help. But the chance of two wars occurring at the same time defies history. Moreover, the military forces of Iraq and North Korea -- to cite examples of two countries we might be at war with at once -- are much less potent than they were in 1995. If anything, our advantage against them has grown.
Military leaders also claim that "peripheral" tasks, like peacekeeping in Bosnia, take money from their primary mission, fighting wars, and contribute to a decline in the troops' combat skills. Someone needs to tell the military that today peacekeeping is a primary mission.
True, the Pentagon's equipment is aging, but not for lack of money. It is aging because the Pentagon is buying the wrong weapons. The military behaves as if it is still in an arms race with the Soviet Union, buying $2 billion bombers, $3 billion submarines and $5 billion aircraft carriers.
One area where the Pentagon needs more money is for pay raises. Military pay is about 13.5 percent lower than comparable private sector wages, and with low unemployment, recruiting and retaining troops has not been easy. But that gap could easily be closed. Congress could switch the $5 billion it allocated for pork barrel Pentagon projects, which primarily benefit members' districts, to raise wages.
Both Congress and the President need to focus on the real threats to our security, including terrorism and the proliferation of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. That is the only way to find out how much the Pentagon really needs to do its job.

HEADLINE: ALBERT V. MANISCALCO, 90, a Staten Island Leader

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Albert V. Maniscalco, who was the Borough President of Staten Island during its dizzying shift from rural to urban borough, died on Sept. 2 at the Sisters of Charity Medical Center there. He was 90.
Mr. Maniscalco, a lifelong politician who joined a Democratic Party club at the age of 14, was Borough President from 1954 to 1965, a period in which the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge was planned, built and completed. The bridge, which opened in 1964, brought a flurry of development that caused the population of the city's least populous borough to multiply and new neighborhoods to sprout like mushrooms in what had been farmland. 
Ada Louise Huxtable, the architecture critic of The New York Times, wrote in 1965 that development was racing forward on Staten Island with "a haphazard abandon that could not be better calculated to destroy the countryside if it had been planned by enemy action."
But she praised Mr. Maniscalco for delaying an urban renewal project that would have accelerated the damage. In essence, it would have involved putting a Manhattan-style street grid on the island. He also opposed running a parkway through land that became parkland.
The Greenbelt Conservancy, a private parks group, honored him for his role in saving land that eventually became an emerald spine of natural areas on Staten Island. Indeed, the term "greenbelt" was first used by Mr. Maniscalco at a meeting of the Board of Estimate.
Everyone called Mr. Maniscalco Al, although he was always careful to use the proper title of any person to whom he spoke. He was revered for his politeness, and he spoke a version of English that some considered rarefied.
Mr. Maniscalco was born in Manhattan in 1908, a fact he never tired of repeating in his public speeches. His family moved to Staten Island when he was 9. Five years later, he joined the South Beach Democratic Club and a year later was the club's secretary. He was particularly interested in helping immigrants achieve citizenship.
"While most kids were playing games after school I was hanging around Democratic meetings," he said in an interview in 1960.
He left high school to work as an engine cleaner for the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad, but later earned a bachelor's degree and a law degree by attending night classes at St. John's University. In 1938, he was elected to the State Assembly, and served for two terms. He then served as Borough Secretary under two borough presidents and on the City Council for one year before becoming Borough President.
He is survived by his wife of 62 years, the former Grace Fiorelli; a son, Dr. Albert M. Maniscalco of Staten Island; a daughter, Linda J. Calarco of Woodbridge, Conn., and four grandsons.
