HEADLINE: I.M.F. Resists 'Blackmail' by Russia and U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
A senior official of the International Monetary Fund warned today that he would neither submit to "the blackmail" of Russian leaders who threatened national default if they are denied billions of dollars in aid, nor let Congress "impose conditions" on the fund in return for $18 billion in new contributions from the United States.
The comments came as the I.M.F. is facing the most intense criticism in its 53-year history, accused of mismanaging the spreading global financial crisis and misjudging the political effects of its prescriptions. But the senior official, who refused to allow his name to be used, conceded no mistakes on the part of the institution during his 90-minute breakfast with a large group of reporters this morning in the fund's executive dining rooms, three blocks from the White House. 
 While the official conceded that the world economy is "in a mess," he insisted that it would not "fall into a world recession" in coming months. He also made clear that a financial rescue package now being assembled for Latin America -- chiefly to support Brazil -- would require direct contributions from major economic powers around the globe, including the United States.
So far the Clinton Administration has refused to discuss publicly whether it would agree to commit American taxpayer dollars to stabilize one of America's largest trading partners. Any such move would have echoes of the 1995 bailout of Mexico -- a decision President Clinton made in defiance of Congress, which overwhelmingly opposed the loans. While Mexico paid back the full $12 billion in loans, Administration officials are clearly hesitant about repeating the experience, especially at a moment Mr. Clinton is conserving every vote he can in Congress to ward off impeachment threats.
But the official noted that the Government of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil, who faces a national election in 10 days, has made no "formal" request for aid. But he said that "we go on assessing the situation to be ready when the need arises," a considerable understatement of the frantic series of phone calls being exchange among the world's finance ministries in recent weeks to stop the economic contagion from spreading to Latin America.
In recent days the leadership of the fund -- particularly Michel Camdessus, its French-born managing director -- has begun a public-relations counteroffensive against its many critics. The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, and the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, have referred to Mr. Camdessus as a "French socialist" who has squandered the fund's resources, and the House recently rejected an $18 billion payment of the United States' commitment to the institution.
Meanwhile, the I.M.F. has been on the defensive about its $4.8 billion aid payment to Russia in late July. No one can account for what happened to the money, which was intended to stabilize the ruble. Instead, it was lost in currency transactions after the Russian Government allowed the ruble to be devalued. The I.M.F. aid did, by most accounts, provide some extra time for the country's oligarchs to get their cash out of the country before the devaluation.
At today's session with reporters, the senior fund official reversed course and was sharply critical of Russia, making clear that the fund would not go forward with the rest of the $17 billion bailout plan it cobbled together in July unless Russia met the conditions of the loan. The new Russian Government, meanwhile, appears to be going the other way -- announcing plans to print money to dictate to its lenders when and how much they will be paid back.
"For the Government to be credible with the international community they must behave in a civilized way with their creditors," the senior official said. "Any kind of imposed solution for debt restructuring would be a mistake."
 The official also derided Russia's statements in recent days that it would resort to "controlled inflation."
"Controlled inflation reminds me of what Anglo-Saxon people call being half pregnant," the official said. "The I.M.F. does not like countries to be half pregnant with inflation. People don't want to be paid for their arrears in fake money."
The senior official emphasized that "we are talking with Russia" and "trying to obtain from the authorities clarification of their intentions." But he said that the "I.M.F. does not accept" efforts to "blackmail" the institution into providing more funds by threatening further defaults on international loans, an event that could set off more global market turmoil. He seemed to be referring to comments made earlier today by Russia's deputy Prime Minister, Aleksandr Shokhin, who said that if the fund delays additional aid it would "drive Russia into a corner."
The comments on reluctance by Congress to provide $18 billion in new cash for the fund -- part of a far larger financial pool supported by other countries -- seemed intended to signal that the United States' should ask for changes but not dictate them.
"The U.S. must bring its contribution," he said, "and no country is entitled to impose conditions."
If every country tried to do so, he said, "at the end of the day we would have so many conditions -- contradictory -- that the job could not be done." The official held out a small olive branch, saying, "I hear many things on the Capitol Hill which are music to my ears and which are already in the cooking here," mostly reforms that would require the monetary fund to make more data public about internal operations and about the countries it helps.

HEADLINE: G.E. Agrees to Clean Part of Tainted River in Massachusetts

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The General Electric Company has agreed to spend $150 million to $200 million to clean up a contaminated stretch of river in western Massachusetts in a settlement that Federal regulators described today as a significant victory for the environment and a city.
In announcing the deal, the company and the Environmental Protection Agency said removing sediment laden with PCB's from an abandoned electric-transformer plant would rejuvenate a two-mile stretch of the Housatonic River and the city it flows through, Pittsfield, Mass. 
 The agreement apparently ends months of negotiations that began some two decades after industrialists and regulators alike recognized that PCB's, polychlorinated biphenyls, once widely used in manufacturing, were dangerous to human health and might cause cancer.
Carol M. Browner, who heads the environmental agency, said an economic redevelopment package that G.E. had agreed to as part of the deal would help return prosperity as well as environmental safety to Pittsfield, an economically ailing city of about 50,000 people in the Berkshires.
For its part, General Electric said in a statement by Stephen D. Ramsey, its vice president for corporate environmental programs, that it was "pleased to enter a new phase of investing in the future of Pittsfield and Berkshire County."
At first glance, the Pittsfield agreement seemed to invite comparisons with the environmental agency's continuing battle against G.E. over PCB contamination of the Hudson River from two abandoned plants in Fort Edward and Glens Falls, but people familiar with both cases cautioned that they were far from parallel.
They are vastly different in scale (2 miles of the Housatonic will be cleaned; some experts say about 40 miles of the Hudson should be dredged), and the Hudson River case is in a much earlier stage: the E.P.A. may not announce its long-range plan for cleaning up the river until December 2000.
The cost of the Hudson cleanup could be far higher if the most radical proposals, including dredging many miles of contaminated riverbed, are carried out. General Electric has insisted that leaving the tainted sediment alone might be safer than removing it.
The Housatonic was fouled around Pittsfield by a G.E. complex that opened more than a half-century ago, employed about 13,000 workers at its peak and closed in the early 1980's when the company quit making large electric transformers, company spokesmen said today. (General Electric has a separate plastics unit in Pittsfield that employs about 700.)
Company officials often point out that many companies used PCB's before their hazardous nature was recognized, and disposed of them in ways that were legal then, like letting waste flow into rivers. At Pittsfield, PCB's were used in liquid that seemed an ideal replacement for the flammable mineral oil, which was once used in transformers, said Bruce Bunch, a G.E. spokesman.
The Housatonic accord, which lawyers on both sides expect to be spelled out in a consent decree in Federal Court before winter, calls for G.E. to divert the worst stretch of river, a half-mile section that flows through the 250-acre plant complex, remove the tainted sediment and put the river back on its original course.
Tainted sediment will also be removed from a separate one-and-a-half-mile stretch downstream, though the environmental agency will bear some of that cost. G.E. has agreed to restore soil and vegetation to damaged riverbanks and to pay some $15 million to bolster the surrounding wildlife habitat. General Electric will tear down some buildings in the old complex and refurbish others before turning them over to Pittsfield for new development.
Mr. Bunch estimated the total cost to General Electric at $150 million, but an environmental agency official said it could top $200 million.
"If they can do it in less, God bless them," this official said.
The accord averted use of the Superfund law, under which the Government could have done the cleanup, then billed General Electric. John De Villars, the agency administrator for New England, said the agreement carried "a spiritual and psychic value" for all parties, one "that can't be quantified but is every bit as important as the substantial financial and economic factors."
But if this settlement produces good will, it seems likely to be tested. General Electric is liable for more than 70 cleanups under the Superfund law, including the mammoth Hudson River project.

HEADLINE: NEW DELHI PLEDGES TO SIGN WORLD BAN ON NUCLEAR TESTS

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 24

 BODY:
India joined Pakistan today in announcing that it is prepared to sign the international treaty banning nuclear testing within the next year, but said it is still discussing details with Washington.
Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, speaking to the United Nations General Assembly, said India had satisfied its security concerns with its nuclear tests in May and is ready to cooperate in bringing the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty into force. 
 "We are prepared to bring these discussions to a successful conclusion so that the entry into force of the treaty is not delayed beyond September 1999," Mr. Vajpayee said. The Prime Minister, whose party is backed by Hindu nationalist organizations, spoke in Hindi, breaking a long tradition of Indian leaders who spoke in English at the General Assembly.
The Clinton Administration reacted cautiously to Mr. Vajpayee's statement today and to a similar pledge by Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan on Wednesday.
"Obviously much remains to be done," Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright told reporters here: the actual signing and ratification of the treaty, the strengthening of export controls by both countries and other steps to bring India and Pakistan into full compliance with international arms control agreements.
If India and Pakistan carry out their pledges, North Korea will stand alone in refusing to sign the treaty, and its refusal could still prevent the accord from going into force a year from now, the deadline for ratification that was set by a United Nations conference two years ago.
At that time, India opposed the treaty and tried to block its passage. The Clinton Administration has been negotiating with India since then to change its approach.
Both Mr. Vajpayee and Mr. Sharif lead governments that are vulnerable to swings in public opinion fostered by their political enemies. Nuclear testing has been popular in both countries, and intentions stated here -- however qualified -- could unravel in the arena of South Asian politics.
India's scientific and nuclear establishment has a large stake in the weapons program there, as the Pakistani military does in Pakistan.
Forty-four countries with nuclear reactors must ratify the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty for it to take effect; 10 have done so. The United States has signed but the treaty is on hold in Congress.
Today opponents of the treaty accused President Clinton of bargaining away the sanctions on India for support for the test-ban treaty.
The sanctions suspended direct foreign aid, including Government loans and guarantees; canceled United States licenses to export arms to India; banned private American loans to the Indian Government, and require Congress to oppose aid channeled through the World Bank and similar groups.
Sanctions were also imposed on Pakistan, which followed India with tests of its own in May. On Wednesday Prime Minister Sharif of Pakistan tied the lifting of sanctions to his promise to sign the test-ban accord. Sanctions have hit Pakistan hard.
In a letter to President Clinton last week, three Republican Senators -- Jesse Helms of North Carolina, who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee; Trent Lott of Mississippi, who is the majority leader, and Jon Kyl of Arizona -- said they opposed lifting sanctions as a price for adhering to nuclear agreements.
"As the recent Indian nuclear tests demonstrated, the C.T.B.T. is not adequately verifiable," they wrote.
Talks between the United States and India and Pakistan have been going on almost continuously since their nuclear tests. The Indian tests surprised and embarrassed the American intelligence services, and made tests by Pakistan virtually inevitable because of the rivalry between the two countries. Indeed, subsequent questions about the scale of the tests have suggested that their political weight exceeded their strategic value.
Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott has been shuttling to various meetings with South Asian officials. As the talks progressed, arms control experts said, the bite of sanctions was beginning to be felt in India as well as in Pakistan, and both countries had reason to negotiate an end to their isolation.
Mr. Vajpayee said today that India had accepted the principles of the test ban treaty since its nuclear tests in May.
"After concluding this limited testing program, India announced a voluntary moratorium on further underground nuclear explosions," he said. "We conveyed our willingness to move toward a de jure formalization of this obligation. In announcing a moratorium, India has already accepted the basic obligation of the C.T.B.T."

HEADLINE: FALLEN STAR: THE MANAGERS -- An Alchemist Who Turned Gold Into Lead;
Financial Wizard Done In By His Smoke and Mirrors

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
When Salomon Brothers, the swashbuckling Wall Street firm of the 1980's, was raking in the money -- hundreds of millions, even billions, of dollars -- investors would grin at one another and say, "J. M.'s done it again."
"J. M." is John W. Meriwether, who, with a small and intensely loyal band of colleagues, turned vast profits by using complex trading strategies and huge amounts of capital to exploit price discrepancies in the world's bond markets. 
 Now, in perhaps the clearest sign to date of the current fragile state of global financial markets, Mr. Meriwether's latest bubble has burst. No longer at Salomon, he -- still pursuing his secretive strategies -- is at the center of a $90 billion storm, a storm that led to this week's $3.5 billion bailout of his hedge fund orchestrated by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Those who put up the cash for this bailout -- a roll-call of Wall Street names like Merrill Lynch, J. P. Morgan, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Goldman, Sachs and Chase Manhattan -- in return got 90 percent of Mr. Meriwether's company, Long-Term Capital Management of Greenwich, Conn.
Hardest hit are those at the eye of the storm: Mr. Meriwether, 51, and his colleagues. At the end of last year, the nearly 200 employees of Long-Term Capital held some 30 percent -- or $690 million -- of the hedge fund's $2.3 billion in capital, said Peter Rosenthal, a spokesman for the firm. And the bulk of that was held by Mr. Meriwether and his dozen or so partners.
With their stake slashed to about 3 percent of the newly capitalized company, the employees have seen their holdings shrivel to, at best, a little more than $100 million -- but even that could dwindle quickly unless the markets turn in their favor. According to some people familiar with the company, several junior employees had borrowed to finance their holdings.
It wasn't long ago that Mr. Meriwether and his colleagues were among the most fabled managers of hedge funds, those unregulated pools of capital that seek to offer rich investors rates of return undreamed of by small investors. The elite partners of Long-Term Capital include Myron S. Scholes, 57, and Robert C. Merton, 54, both Nobel laureates in economics; David W. Mullins Jr., 52, a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Eric R. Rosenfeld and Lawrence E. Hilibrand, former Salomon bond experts. Mr. Mullins, when he was a Harvard professor, even served on the panel that investigated the October 1987 stock market collapse with an eye to preventing such events in the future. Now regulators will spend the coming months debating how to protect the markets from hedge funds.
In early 1994, Mr. Meriwether -- who had left Salomon after one of his traders submitted false bids at Treasury auctions -- turned to raising capital for his new venture. Many of the world's richest and supposedly smartest investors flocked to his doors, giving him $1.25 billion, then a record sum for a new hedge fund. The list of investors -- minimum stake: $10 million -- included such well-known investors as Banque Julius Baer, the private Swiss bank, a Paine Webber management compensation plan and the Bank of China.
Several of Mr. Meriwether's investors complained vociferously when, at the end of 1997, he and his partners insisted on paying back about $2.7 billion of their capital, saying the markets had gotten trickier. They returned all the money that had been invested after Dec. 31, 1994, and all investment profits made before that date.
Those investors, of course, "are feeling extraordinarily lucky and happy" now, said Antoine Bernheim, president of Dome Capital Management, a New York company that compiles data on hedge funds. "Those who received preferential treatment by getting less of their investment returned last year must be feeling very unhappy."
So how did this meltdown happen? How could some of the world's best-known bond investors, and some of its most famous economists and mathematicians, get crushed, and so quickly? The partners themselves are not talking publicly, but, sifting through the wreckage, a familiar theme emerges. It is a story as old as the history of financial debacles: a gradual loss of confidence, eventually cascading into a full-scale rout.
As the summer wore on, the financial markets became increasingly concerned about risk, particularly in mid-August, after Russia defaulted on billions of dollars of its obligations. The financial institutions involved with Long-Term Capital -- whether lending it money, investing in it, or clearing its trades -- started getting nervous. They gradually came to believe that the ambitious financiers at Long-Term Capital might not have enough money to support their complex network of obligations in the world's markets, mainly in three areas: mortgage bonds, European government bonds and bonds issued by Russia and other developing countries. The hedge fund also bet that interest rates would rise in the Treasury market.
Events were playing havoc with Long-Term's strategies, causing the world's nervous investors to rush to buy the highest-quality securities, like Treasury bonds and German Government bonds.
But Long-Term Capital, according to those on Wall Street familiar with aspects of its business, had made heavy bets that interest rates throughout Europe would move closer together as many of its nations moved toward monetary union. And now, with investors suddenly more eager to buy Deutsche mark bonds, the "spread" between German and, say, Italian Government bonds widened rapidly -- precisely what the firm had bet against.
"There was a perception that there was not enough of an equity cushion underneath the positions," said a person familiar with the fund's business, who declined to be identified. "Very often in these markets perception becomes reality."
And the perception has gotten worse. Yesterday, one of Mr. Meriwether's oldest colleagues even asked whether the stories of personal bankruptcies at Long-Term Capital were true. Mr. Rosenthal, the spokesman, dismissed such questions.
Still, Mr. Meriwether and his colleagues have seen most of their wealth evaporate in a few frantic weeks, and this week they were forced to accept the terms imposed on them by their rescuers. Many on Wall Street also predicted that the fiasco at Long-Term Capital would probably mark the end of Mr. Meriwether's financial prominence, and that of many of his colleagues.
In the past, Mr. Meriwether has made some remarkable returns for his investors and for himself. In 1995, for example, the fund returned almost 43 percent after allowing for its 2 percent annual management fee and the fund managers' taking 25 percent of all profits under their agreement with investors. It is not clear how much Mr. Meriwether took out in profits over the years and how much of his wealth he kept in the fund.
Astonishingly, perhaps, some investors in Long-Term Capital may not have lost money even after this meltdown, Mr. Rosenthal, the fund's spokesman, said. Assuming an investor put in money only at the fund's birth, in early 1994, and took all the profits paid out through the end of last year, that investor would still have made a return of some 17 percent, he said, citing calculations by executives at the fund's offices.
Despite this record, many doubt whether Mr. Meriwether can bounce back for a second time after such a spectacular fall. In 1991, he lost his job as vice chairman -- and heir apparent -- at Salomon Brothers when it became clear that Paul Mozer, one of his subordinates, had submitted false bids at Treasury bond auctions. That scandal threatened to end his career, but Mr. Meriwether survived to bring his talent to Long-Term Capital.
The very scale of this latest fiasco is also likely to make it harder for Mr. Meriwether and other hedge fund managers to pursue such aggressive strategies again.
"Situations like this could have the adverse effect of regulators beginning to scrutinize hedge funds," said Holland West, a partner at Shearman & Sterling who specializes in derivatives and hedge funds. "Some of the financial institutions that are involved are going to be doing more and more scrutinizing and credit analysis."

HEADLINE: FALLEN STAR: THE REGULATORS;
Officials Assess Impact Of a Fed-Brokered Deal

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration played down today the potential risks to the financial system from Long-Term Capital Management L.P.'s brush with collapse, but the fund's fall raised questions in Congress about whether regulators can keep up with the increasing complexity and speed of the markets.
A day after helping big banks and investment firms work out a rescue package that will give Long-Term Capital some time to deal with its financial problems, the Federal Reserve emphasized that it had not put any taxpayer money into the deal. 
 Moreover, Fed officials said, the deal calls for Long-Term Capital's owners to suffer potentially substantial losses from their investment strategies gone wrong. As a result, they said, the deal was not a bailout and should not be seen by investors as a sign that the Government was willing to protect investors from their mistakes.
Still, at a time of instability in markets worldwide, the episode was seen by some members of Congress and economists as a new application of the "too big to fail" doctrine, under which regulators take steps to keep institutions afloat because allowing them to collapse would drag down other firms and endanger the entire financial system.
"It would appear that Long-Term Capital Management was deemed by the Federal Reserve to be too leveraged and too intertwined to fail," said Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the House Banking Committee. "The question that remains for the economy is what other risk exists in the hedge fund and derivatives industry."
Congressional aides said that discussions were under way about holding hearings into Long-Term Capital's problems, and the more general issue of the complex, risky investments made by hedge funds, but that no decisions had been made.
Among the issues certain to be debated is whether the Fed, by using its influence to help keep Long-Term Capital afloat, was sending big investors a signal that it will provide a safety net when they are at risk of suffering huge losses.
"Why should the weight of the Federal Government be brought to bear to help out a private investor?" Paul A. Volcker, a former Federal Reserve chairman, said in a speech in Boston today, Bloomberg News reported.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, was kept apprised of the talks on Wednesday but played no active role in the negotiations, which took place at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The New York Fed takes the role within the Federal Reserve system of monitoring financial markets and had been tracking Long-Term Capital's condition for several weeks, officials said.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said today that he had no concerns about any broader fallout. "The only issue that I have to worry about are issues that have systemic effects, that can affect the overall economy," Mr. Rubin told reporters. "I believe the system can handle everything I'm aware of" relating to Long-Term Capital's problems.
But there were indications that Fed officials were concerned that the incident would create a further perception of risk within the financial markets, exacerbating a developing credit squeeze and further slowing the economy.
Even as Long-Term Capital was hammering out a deal with its creditors, Mr. Greenspan was telling the Senate Budget Committee that the global crisis had become "more virulent" in recent weeks, with direct effects on the American markets.
Peter Bakstansky, a spokesman for the New York Fed, said it was wrong to characterize the situation as an application of the "too big to fail" doctrine, especially since no Government money was involved and the Fed's only role was to bring Long-Term Capital together with its creditors. But he said the Fed had to be aware of potential "disruptions" to the market.
"These situations are learning experiences, and we're looking at what we can do effectively in the context of our responsibilities," Mr. Bakstansky said. "We're not assigned to set margin requirements for the bond markets. We don't have regulatory authority over offshore hedge funds. But we do have responsibility for the safety and soundness of the banking system."
Robert E. Litan, the director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, said it was hard to evaluate the Fed's approach to Long-Term Capital without knowing more about the investment firm's positions -- always a problem with hedge funds, which are largely unregulated and operate in considerable secrecy.
"The whole premise of hedge funds -- the reason they're not subject to regulation -- is that they are limited to very large investors and that the creditors to them are big boys who are supposed to be able to take care of themselves," he said. "This may cause policy makers to revisit that assumption. Maybe one outcome of this will be more data collection."

HEADLINE: World Trade Center Goes Up for Lease

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
The Port Authority board voted unanimously yesterday to put the World Trade Center up for long-term lease, and several major real estate figures have already expressed interest in becoming the new landlord of one of the world's most prominent properties.
"I would be interested," Donald J. Trump said. "It depends on the numbers, but at the right numbers, anything is feasible." 
 LCOR Inc., a Pennsylvania-based developer involved in the privatization of another big Port Authority project, the new International Arrivals Building at Kennedy International Airport, said it would also take a serious look at the Trade Center.
The authority expects to request bids formally in the next 2 months for a 99-year lease on the 11-million-square-foot complex, which includes the skyline-defining twin towers and four other office buildings. The authority hopes to have a lease signed by next fall.
Authority commissioners have said they hope to get $1.5 billion for the complex, with $300 million up front, but officials shied away from any discussion of hard numbers yesterday. Charles A. Gargano, the vice chairman of the authority, would say only that he hoped to get "as much as possible."
Heading off a confrontation -- at least for the time being -- with the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Gargano, who is also chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said that whoever leased the Trade Center would have to pay full property taxes. The Giuliani administration says the complex should pay about $105 million in taxes, $80 million more than is now paid by the Port Authority, which is tax-exempt but pays a fee.
Gov. George E. Pataki had said Wednesday only that the lessee would have to pay "fair taxes." The Port Authority would presumably fetch a higher price for the property if it could get the city to agree to a tax break for the lessee.
But Mayor Giuliani insisted yesterday that, in private hands, the complex would be taxed like any other building. Real estate analysts said that at full taxation, the Trade Center was probably worth closer to $1.2 billion than $1.5 billion.
With Mr. Gargano's assurance on the tax question in hand, Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine called the authority's decision to lease the Trade Center "a great victory for the city and for the Mayor."
Authority officials were vague about their plans for any money the lease would bring in above the more than $100 million a year in net rental income the Trade Center generates now.
The authority's chairman, Lewis M. Eisenberg, said that if there was extra income, some of it could be used to pay off bonds. He added, "Whatever proceeds come will likely be spent on transportation infrastructure and the economic development of the region."
The authority has been under increasing pressure from the governors who control it, Mr. Pataki and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, to sell off its vast real estate holdings and concentrate on transportation projects like dredging New York Harbor and building a rail link to Kennedy Airport from Manhattan.
The biggest question now, however, is who will bid on the Trade Center.
Mr. Trump, who is already in the midst of building and seeking financing for the $3 billion Riverside South project on the Upper West Side, said his interest in the Trade Center would depend in part on "what the economy is like at the time they put it up." He declined to go into detail on how he might finance the project, but John Lyons, the executive managing director of Granite Partners, a national real estate investment banking firm, said that any developer who wanted to take on the Trade Center would have to hook up with "a deep-pocketed entity that is looking at this primarily as an investment."
Several real estate executives had said that Tishman Speyer Properties, which runs Rockefeller Center, might be a likely candidate to bid on the Trade Center, but the company said yesterday that it would not be interested.
For LCOR, the Trade Center is not an unfamiliar property: the company, based in Berwyn, Pa., bid on an earlier attempt to privatize the Trade Center's retail space, which was eventually folded into the current plan.
Company executives will give the proposal "a very close look," said Frank Marino, a spokesman for the company. In addition to holding a 40 percent interest in the Kennedy Airport terminal project, LCOR drew up the master plan for the upcoming relocation of Pennsylvania Station and developed the Federal office building at 290 Broadway.
Barry Gosin, the chief executive of Newmark & Company Real Estate, said that a big real estate investment trust might also be able to handle the project. But most REIT's have taken a beating in the stock market recently, which would make it harder for them to raise the money needed to acquire the Trade Center.

HEADLINE: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE PRESS;
Presenting News in a Time of Scandal Becomes a Delicate Balancing Act

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
It has been an unequal contest. Hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico versus the possibility of impeachment proceedings. International economic breakdowns versus an unprecedented video of President Clinton defending himself during questioning about intimate sex acts with Monica S. Lewinsky.
Sometimes it has seemed that the only newsmakers able to hold their own against the steamroller of the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal have been two baseball players, Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa. 
 What news coverage gets short shrift when a scandal like the present one takes grip of the news columns and airwaves? None, some newspaper editors and network news executives say. Lots, say others, citing the pre-election coverage of the primaries held around the country on Sept. 15, the instability in Russia, the economic troubles of Japan and Brazil and the issue of international terrorism.
"News coverage has been distorted to the most incredible degree I have seen in my lifetime," said Charles Peters, editor of The Washington Monthly, a political journal in the capital.
In interviews over the last two days, editors and news directors have defended their judgment calls, but most acknowledge concern about the sacrifices made to accommodate the heavy Clinton coverage that they believe is justified because the events could lead to impeachment hearings.
"You're talking about changing presidents," said Al Ortiz, the executive producer of the "Evening News with Dan Rather" on CBS. "It's hard to imagine anything more important as that. My intention has been to devote as much time to this story as possible, to explain what's going on behind the scenes."
Mr. Ortiz added, "Several important foreign stories -- Kosovo and Russia -- have had to take a little bit of a back seat."
Ben Bradlee Jr., a deputy managing editor of The Boston Globe, said: "The possibility of impeachment comes along once a generation. But you still have to be concerned about getting a good mix in the paper."
The release of the Clinton videotape demanded so much space that The Boston Globe delayed for a day the third part of a series on food safety. At The Chicago Tribune and The Baltimore Sun, investigative projects ready for publication were also temporarily shelved last weekend.
"What gets delayed might be a series on race or an investigative project in the works that's timely and topical but not urgent," said William K. Marimow, The Sun's managing editor.
The issue goes beyond where articles are placed. Diversion of resources comes at a price. One test of how excessive coverage is, said James P. Willse, editor of The Newark Star-Ledger, is "what do the papers look like three and four and five days away."
"If in covering the story you've exhausted yourself, and five days out there is nothing in the paper, that's a subtler statement of the kind of price you've paid," Mr. Willse said.
At The Sun, Mr. Marimow said, state political and government reporters were not called in to the crisis coverage. Instead, he said, "we took people we consider really talented working on ongoing projects that didn't have the same degree of urgency." For instance, a reporter working on a financial investigation, who has special legal expertise, was pulled off the day the Clinton videotape appeared to assess the President's effectiveness as a witness.
At The Washington Post, the managing editor, Steve Coll, said pre-primary coverage was not cut back.
"We certainly haven't produced any less journalism about the election this season than we would have otherwise," Mr. Coll said.
Even on days of peak coverage, the Clinton scandal has not driven all other news off front pages. The Dallas Morning News devoted three of seven front-page articles to the Washington crisis on Tuesday, the day after the videotape was broadcast. The front page also included an article about the Dallas Cowboy's Monday night victory over the Giants, a report on the death of the sprinter Florence Griffith Joyner and an in-depth article about Lithuania, part of a series on the Baltic states.
Reader complaints about excessive coverage of the Washington crisis have been heard, some editors say. But readers in unusually high numbers also bought the newspapers containing text from the Starr report. At The Tribune, that edition sold 75,000 copies more than usual; at The St. Petersburg Times, the excess demand for that edition reached 5,500 or more copies.
Rich Oppel, the editor of The Austin American-Statesman, said his paper containing text of the Starr report sold 9,300 extra copies. Nonetheless, he is troubled by the sacrifices in coverage.
"We delayed some Texas state election roundups," Mr. Oppel said, adding, "What got crowded off our page one has been the German election, the shaky economy, the Russian ruble, and reports of erratic economic developments in Tokyo and Hong Kong."
But Andrew Barnes, the editor of The St. Petersburg Times, argues that newspaper editorial judgments are "not a zero-sum game."
"We're in the position -- if there's more going on, we make more room for it," Mr. Barnes said, adding, "If the premise is that this scandal is a distraction, so is life."
Paul Friedman, the executive producer of ABC's "World News Tonight," strongly defends his network's mix of recent coverage, pointing to four reports on Russia since Sept. 7, an in-depth report on the world economy on Sept. 16 and a Sept. 9 broadcast from North Korea.
Still, in another office at ABC, the newscaster Ted Koppel said he and his colleagues at "Nightline" were assembling commentators to discuss, on the air periodically, "what it is they think is of gravest importance in the world that we're not paying proper attention to."
"We've made an institutional decision as a program," Mr. Koppel said, "that we need to do a night that says, 'While our attention was otherwise directed, these other stories were happening.' "

HEADLINE: Nigeria's New President Visits U.S. and Wins Support for Regime

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Gen. Abdulsalami Abubakar, who became President of Nigeria in June by an accident of fate, came to the United States this week determined to persuade skeptics that his Government will be short-lived, open and incorruptible, and that the country had finally turned the corner to democracy after years of military rule.
"Come next May, we will hand over to the elected Government," said General Abubakar, a low-key reformer who succeeded one of Africa's most destructive dictators, Gen. Sani Abacha, who died of a heart attack on June 8. The date with democracy, General Abubakar said today, is "sacrosanct." 
 General Abubakar, meeting with reporters at a breakfast in a glittering dining room at the Palace Hotel on Madison Avenue -- a reminder of the immense wealth that official Nigeria has at its disposal -- laid out the political steps ahead.
In December local elections will take place, followed by voting for state governors and legislators in January. In February an election for president and a national assembly will be held, with the formal handover of power three months later.
"Back home the political parties are busy forming," he said.
General Abubakar, 56, said that after his interim presidency ends, he plans to retire from any military and political roles.
The general, a measured speaker who seldom smiles, has won the confidence of American and European officials during his three months in power. Today the European Union's Development Commissioner, Joao de Deus Pinheiro, called for an easing of sanctions on Nigeria as a reward for General Abubakar's promise to restore democracy. Sanctions were imposed in 1995 after the Abacha Government executed Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight other advocates of the Ogoni people.
The United Nations is sending a team of political specialists to Nigeria this week to advise the Government on organizing elections. Secretary General Kofi Annan visited the country in the summer and aides say he was convinced that the new Government was making an earnest effort to listen to the Nigerian people.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who attended a Security Council meeting here today on Africa, praised General Abubakar for "taking steps to bring Nigeria back into the world community."
General Abubakar, who addressed the General Assembly today, met President Clinton in Washington on Wednesday. The Nigerian President, who described Mr. Clinton as one of the few world leaders really interested in his country, said he was told that if he stayed on his democratic course, the United States was prepared to help win some debt relief from international lending institutions and might also allow the resumption of direct flights to and from Nigeria.
Turning to the issue of corruption, for which Nigeria under a series of military rulers has made itself notorious worldwide, General Abubakar said that "Government transactions will now be transparent and open and whatever contracts are going to be given will be done by open bidding."
"On the issue of freedom of speech and association," he said, "we have done all we can to make these things as easy as it is all over the world. There is freedom of association, there is freedom of press. In Nigeria, licenses are being given now to private organizations to set up radio and television stations. We have well over 200, 300 newspapers and magazines circulating without any hindrance."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets Decline as Fears Of Additional Losses Grow
The $3.5 billion rescue of a large investment fund verging on collapse unnerved many markets around the world, raised a clamor for a Government investigation and created fear that other losses might surface.
Rather than contain the problem and bring stability, the cash infusion late Wednesday by a consortium of banks and brokerage firms to salvage Long-Term Capital Management only seemed to rattle investors. Page A1.
 
The Swiss bank UBS said it expected to report a third-quarter loss as high as one billion Swiss francs -- $721 million -- related to losses in emerging markets, equities and the near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management. Its charge for an equity stake in and derivatives transactions with Long-Term Capital Management was estimated at $685 million. C4. 

Russia Warns of a Further Default
Aleksandr Shokhin, Russia's Deputy Prime Minister of financial affairs, took a harsh line with the International Monetary Fund and other creditors, warning them of a potential default on its long-term debt if more Western aid is not delivered. A10.
 
Lehman Brothers won a court order freezing the British bank accounts of two big Russian banks. It contends the two banks defaulted on $110 million of obligations to it and its clients. Other foreign creditors are scrambling to recover whatever they can from their Russian holdings. C18.
 
Shares of an Internet I.P.O. Surge
Shares of Ebay, an Internet auction house, closed at $47.375 yesterday, after climbing $29.375 from its offering price. The first initial public offering in nearly a month was priced at $18, opened around 12:15 P.M. at $52, but fell later in the day. Market Place. C6.
 
Economic Data Show Strong Growth
Two Government reports indicated that the nation's economy remains strong. Gross domestic product grew at a 1.8 percent annual rate in the second quarter -- from the 1.6 percent estimated a month ago, but still well below the growth rate of 5.5 percent in the first quarter. In another report, orders for durable goods jumped 1.6 percent in August. C2.
 
Income Higher for Most Americans
The Census Bureau said the proportion of Americans living in poverty declined last year, mostly because of reductions in poverty among black and Hispanic families. The data reflected three consecutive years of growth in income, which have restored household incomes and poverty to the levels recorded in 1989, just before the last recession. A1.
 
Look Under 'H' for Hostile Bid
Day Runner, a manufacturer of personal organizers, made an unsolicited 47.9 million, or $80.5 million, bid for Filofax, maker of the leatherbound diary that became a 1980's accessory, but has since lost ground to electronic organizers. C3.
 
TV Networks Faulted on Labels
One year after the television networks revised their movie-style ratings code to add labels alerting parents to sexual or violent content, a study has found that the networks are not regularly adding those labels, like V for violence or S for sexual content, to the ratings in printed listings and on screen. A20.
 
Profits Off at Luxury Goods Makers
Falling profits were reported by LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the Gucci Group and Diageo, Europe's leading producers of luxury fashion goods. C5.

HEADLINE: In the Village, Halloween Parade Is Under Fire as Too Unruly

BYLINE: By KEVIN FLYNN 

 BODY:
Like the neighborhood in which it is set, the Greenwich Village Halloween Parade, a milelong train of 20,000 marchers outfitted in elaborate, often naughty costumes, has long celebrated creativity, eccentricity and the liberating power of bending the rules.
Now, as parade organizers prepare for the 25th-anniversary march, some neighborhood leaders are concerned that the event, which draws a boisterous crowd of more than a million to the Village each year, has traveled too far down the road from irreverent to unruly. 
 "There is a great deal of sentiment that the excesses of the parade have gone too far," said Alan Jay Gerson, chairman of Community Board 2 in the Village. "If it does not work out this year, this could be the last parade."
Mr. Gerson's board will hold a hearing next month on the future of the parade, at which time he hopes to hear ideas on how to alleviate the traffic snarls and rowdiness that have damaged the event's standing within the neighborhood.
But City Councilman Thomas K. Duane, who represents the Village, has gone even further, formally asking the Giuliani administration to cancel the parade now or move it to another neighborhood.
Mr. Duane is supported by some community board members and neighborhood leaders who contend that the event, which started as a local procession by a few dozen friends, has grown into an overcrowded nuisance, a magnet for drunken hooligans and a flash point for bias crimes against homosexuals.
"My own personal experience is that it is a sea of homophobia out there," said Mr. Duane, who is gay.
The parade organizers and their supporters, including the Greenwich Village Chamber of Commerce, say Mr. Duane is overreacting and threatening to kill a carnival, the "Mardi Gras of New York," that has become an economic engine for the Village and a vital thread in the cultural fabric of the city.
"I don't think the parade should just end because there are some potential problems with it," said Ralph Lee, 63, a mask designer who founded, but no longer runs, the event. "It seems like rather than chuck the whole thing, something should be done to work these problems out."
Jeanne Fleming, a theater director who runs the parade from her Dutchess County home, said: "This is a joyful night for the whole city. Very little goes wrong."
The parade debate comes at a time when many people in Greenwich Village are alarmed by a rash of crimes, including three recent murders and several reported assaults against homosexuals. The assaults were part of an 81 percent rise in reported anti-gay bias crimes citywide this year.
Last week, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said that in response to the crimes, he had added officers to the Sixth Precinct, which patrols the neighborhood.
In a Sept. 21 letter to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Duane, a Democrat who is running for the State Senate, said the city should withhold the parade permit until it held a public hearing on the parade.
"In light of the recent terrible and violent crime wave which our neighborhood has been experiencing, I believe that it is critical that we pay particular attention to this issue, and consider whether or not it is appropriate to continue to hold this event in Greenwich Village," he wrote Mr. Giuliani. The Mayor's office did not respond to calls for a comment.
Supporters of the event point out that, according to police statistics, no anti-gay bias crimes have been reported during either of the last two parades.
"I feel that the problems are slightly exaggerated and that the event goes very smoothly," said Officer Stephen O'Halloran, who handles community relations for the Sixth Precinct. He acknowledged that 400 summonses were issued for public drinking last year.
Parade critics said they were particularly concerned this year because Halloween falls on a Saturday and larger crowds are anticipated.
Few dispute that the parade, which steps off on Sixth Avenue at Spring Street and continues north to 23d Street, is a changed event from the homespun procession of years ago. It is now an established New York spectacle that is broadcast on television and partly financed through city and corporate grants.
Community leaders estimate that as many as two million people may line the police barricades this year to be entertained by the routinely unusual assortment of giant animated puppets, kazoo bands, stilt walkers and exotically costumed marchers, some of them acting in zany harmony, like the 40 public school teachers who showed up one year disguised as Imelda Marcos's shoes.
Though the parade is now shunned by some gay residents of Village, organizers said hundreds of gay men and lesbians continue to march each year.
"One of the reasons people come to the parade is to see the drag queens," said Ms. Fleming, the organizer. "This is a crowd that wants to have fun. They are yelling: 'O. K.! Way to go!' People are coming for the wacky and the creative. They are not there to hurt somebody. They are there to have fun."
Bobby Miller, a 46-year-old writer who is gay and has lived in the Village for 23 years, said the problem of violence against homosexuals pervades the culture and was not spawned simply by a parade.
"I don't feel threatened there anymore than I would be threatened at an Irish parade or a Puerto Rican parade or any other parade where there are large groups of people," said Mr. Miller, who has never missed the Village event.
But Arthur Strickler, who is also gay and the district manager for Community Board 2, said: "Many of these people who come out now are not there to laugh with us. They are there to laugh at us."

LENGTH: 546 words

HEADLINE: A Hedge Fund Crashes

 BODY:
The concept of "too big to fail" has now been extended to a huge hedge fund that was run by people thought to be financial wizards. The bailout of the fund by a consortium of the country's leading financial institutions is a reminder of how fragile the world's financial markets now are, and of the risks of making big bets that markets will act in predictable ways.
The hedge fund was run by John Meriwether, the former Salomon Brothers official widely viewed as a Wall Street genius. His forte was in trading bonds, buying those that were relatively cheap and selling those that were relatively expensive. The idea was to make a little money on each trade, and make a lot of money overall by using borrowed money to buy bonds in large quantities. For every dollar put up by investors in the fund, Mr. Meriwether seems to have borrowed more than $20. 
 In determining what investments to make, Mr. Meriwether and his colleagues, including two Nobel Prize-winning economists, had sophisticated computers that reviewed historical prices of bonds and other financial instruments and found relationships between them. Strategies were then calculated on the assumption that events that had never happened before could not happen at all. But they did. Bond prices almost always rise and fall together. But in the current financial crisis, the prices of United States Treasury bonds have soared as investors bought them in search of safety while the prices of most other bonds -- backed by corporations or by other governments -- have fallen, as investors grew nervous about the risks involved.
Unfortunately, Mr. Meriwether, who at the peak was managing more than $100 billion -- the vast majority of it borrowed money -- had bet against such an occurrence. After all, that is what happens almost all the time.
The odds were with Mr. Meriwether, whose fund returned profits of more than 40 percent a year in 1995 and 1996, and of 17 percent in 1997, even after hefty management fees. But betting the way he did turns out to be a little like Russian roulette: the odds of winning are very good, but you can't play again if you lose.
Effectively, Mr. Meriwether's fund has been taken over by the banks and brokerage houses that lent money to it. Investors in the fund -- who had to put up a minimum of $10 million each -- are likely to lose virtually all the money they invested. There is no public money in the $3.5 billion bailout, but it was organized by the Federal Reserve, which stepped in because of fears that shaky financial markets would suffer even more if Mr. Meriwether's fund was forced to liquidate its holdings.
At best, markets will return to normal and the banks that kept Mr. Meriwether's fund afloat will make some money, perhaps even enough to share with the original investors. At worst, markets will continue to sink and the bailout money will vanish.
The great bull market of the 1980's and 1990's has been built in significant ways on leverage, as big players found ways to borrow to the hilt. Now the banks that made the loans are getting nervous and demanding more collateral before lending to other hedge funds. That contraction in credit is prudent, but it will put more pressure on financial markets that are already feeling the strain.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
A Case Study In Instability Hurts Stocks

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stock prices tumbled yesterday on intensified fears about world financial instability, which has so badly infected a large American investment fund that the Federal Reserve helped organize a $3.5 billion emergency rescue.
Bank and brokerage shares were pummeled as the Dow Jones industrial average relinquished about two-thirds of Wednesday's big advance to decline 152.42 points, or 1.87 percent, at 8,001.99. Stocks also fell 6 percent in Brazil and by lesser amounts in Europe but advanced in Tokyo following a Japanese holiday. 
 Early today, at midday in Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 456.28 points, or 3.21 percent, to 13,749.50.
"It's clear the dimensions of these problems remain bigger than anticipated and will take a longer period to adequately deal with," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, referring to Japanese banks and other sources of persistent concern.
Long-Term Capital Management, the hedge fund based in Greenwich, Conn., is teetering on failure from bad speculative bets that could have resulted in a cascade of losses if not for the rescue. Mr. Galvin said that "the magnitude of the numbers shook the confidence of the market."
Analysts also expressed some second thoughts about Wednesday's enthusiasm for the possibility that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates next week. Some wondered whether it would accomplish much, while others reinterpreted the comments of Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, that prompted this optimism in light of what he undoubtedly knew was the dire condition of the hedge fund.
"We were reminded in the most eye-opening manner of what happens in a financial crisis," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer of the First Albany Corporation. "This is one of the ways financial crises can get transmitted around the globe."
Much of the fund's problem resulted from a rush by world investors into the safety of United States Treasury securities, which it had bet would decline, after Russia defaulted on debt.
Even though stocks had slumped in Europe -- 2.36 percent in Frankfurt, 1.25 percent in Paris and nine-tenths of 1 percent in London -- shares opened somewhat higher on Wall Street. But they quickly retreated as the implications of the near-failure of Long-Term Capital sank in. The Dow average was nearly 220 points lower before some late-session buying pared the loss and edged it back above the 8,000 mark.
J. P. Morgan, down 5 3/16 , to 87 5/8, and American Express, down 4 3/16 , to 79 1/4, had the biggest negative effect on the average, accounting for one-quarter of its decline.
Other decliners included Citicorp, down 6 3/4, to 98 3/4; Merrill Lynch, down 4 5/8, to 53 3/8; Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, down 5 11/16 , to 51 9/16 ; Lehman Brothers, down 4 3/16 , to 33 11/16 ; Chase Manhattan, down 3 3/4, to 46 3/8, and Charles Schwab down 3 1/16 , to 40 1/16 .
BankAmerica dropped 5 1/4, to 60, while Nationsbank, its merger partner, was down 4 3/8, to 54 3/8. Nationsbank stockholders today approved the deal, scheduled for completion next Wednesday. Travelers Group, which is to merge with Citicorp, skidded 3 5/16 , to 39 5/8.
Only five of the 30 Dow stocks ended with gains, all fractional except for International Paper's, up 1 9/16 , to 46 7/8.
Broader gauges fared worse, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index down 23.37 points, or 2.19 percent, to 1,042.72, and the Nasdaq down 39.93 points, or 2.27 percent, to 1,720.34.
Among high-technology fliers, Yahoo shed 2 5/8, to 115 1/4, and Amazon.com fell 3, to 102 1/8, following spectacular gains Wednesday, while Microsoft lost 3 1/2, to 110 1/8.
But nothing could keep investors away from Ebay Inc., bidding shares of the fledgling Internet company as high as 54 1/4 from an initial offering price of 18. The shares finished at 47 3/8, with more than 9 million shares changing hands.
Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advancing ones by 2,042 to 1,093, with 43 making new highs and 127 new lows. Volume was 805.9 million, down from 900.2 million on Wednesday.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Bond Prices Rally Again

(By Bloomberg News)
Treasury bond prices rose for a second day yesterday amid optimism the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates next week.
"What we're seeing in the market is an almost textbook reaction," with shorter-term securities, the most sensitive to Fed cuts, gaining the most, said Alan Koepplin, who helps manage $2 billion in fixed-income securities at SG Cowen Asset Management.
He expects the Fed to approve a quarter-point reduction, to 5.25 percent, in its rate for overnight lending between banks. The central bank has left its target for overnight lending between banks at 5.5 percent since March 1997.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 2/32 , to 105 6/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, remained at 5.16 percent.
The Ford Motor Company took advantage of a pronounced pause in market volatility yesterday to price a $1.5 billion global bond offering, adeal that was increased in size by 50 percent because of investor interest.
"The deal grew on itself," said Robin Luce, managing director in debt syndicate and debt capital markets at Merrill Lynch & Company, co-lead manager of the offering with Lehman Brothers Inc. "Ford wanted a well-received offering, a well-executed offering."

HEADLINE: FALLEN STAR: THE FALLOUT;
Swiss Bank Foresees a Loss Of $721 Million This Quarter

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ZURICH, Sept. 24

 BODY:
UBS A.G., Europe's biggest bank, announced today that it expected to report a third-quarter loss as high as one billion Swiss francs -- currently $721.6 million -- related to losses in emerging markets, equities and the near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management, the American hedge fund.
UBS, based here, said it was taking a charge equivalent to $685 million against an equity stake in, and derivatives transactions with, Long-Term Capital. Big institutional lenders, spurred by the Federal Reserve, agreed to extend $3.5 billion to the fund after huge 1998 losses. UBS had the biggest exposure of the 16 banks and brokerage firms in the rescue group. 
 "It's a tremendous blow to confidence," said Richard Kruse, an analyst with Oppenheim-Finanzanalyse in Frankfurt. "It really gives a bad impression of management."
UBS is the first institution to disclose damage stemming from Long-Term Capital's near-collapse. While the announcement could increase pressure on the other banks to disclose their potential exposure, the others are not expected to sustain similar losses because they are believed to have cash or Treasury bonds as collateral for loans or other obligations.
UBS's profit warning is the latest among dozens from European and American banks that have been stung by plunging stock markets stemming from economic turmoil in Russia, Asia and other markets.
While UBS had warned of losses in August stemming from Russia, the charge against its investment in Long-Term Capital came as a surprise, forcing the bank to call a news conference on short notice here after Swiss stock markets closed.
Shares of UBS plunged nearly 11 percent before the announcement, but after the company scheduled the news conference. The stock closed at 365 Swiss francs, down 44 francs. UBS shares have fallen 42 percent in the last two months,
The chief executive of UBS, Marcel Ospel, said the bank bought an equity stake of 10 to 15 percent of Long-Term Capital in 1997.
UBS and the other banks in in the consortium are not optimistic that they will get much of their rescue funds back. "The rescue plan does not leave much scope for recovery," Mr. Ospel said, adding that UBS never assisted Long-Term in its market investments and that the bank has no further investments in hedge funds of this type.
The bank's earnings potential, he added, "is not impaired in its foundation, provided the international economic situation does not decrease further."
The bank, which was created through the merger of the Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation, said it expected to report only a modest profit in the second half as a result of the third-quarter loss.
In equities trading, one-third of UBS's losses came from proprietary trading losses, with the remainder from what Mr. Ospel called "volatility" in worldwide stock markets.

HEADLINE: 2d-Quarter Growth Stronger Than Estimated,U.S. Says

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Solid consumer spending ignited stronger growth in the second quarter than previously estimated, the Government said today, while separate reports pointed to underlying strength in the nation's economy.
Analysts said that despite pockets of weakness, the American economy was weathering the turmoil in Asia, Russia and elsewhere quite well, with few signs that the expansion that began in the spring of 1991 was running out of steam. 
 The Commerce Department said gross domestic product, the broadest measure of the economy, grew at a 1.8 percent annual rate in the quarter, up from the 1.6 percent estimated a month ago, but still well below the growth rate of 5.5 percent in the first quarter. It was the weakest quarterly growth rate in three years.
In a separate report pointing to resilience in manufacturing, the department said orders for big-ticket manufactured goods jumped 1.6 percent in August, the third consecutive increase.
In another report, the Labor Department said new unemployment claims fell last week to the lowest level since April, a sign of continuing strength in the job market that could buoy consumer spending despite the unsteady stock market.
"The U.S. economy continues to have a tremendous amount of resilience," said Lynn Reaser, an economist at the Nationsbank Corporation.
"Going forward, the numbers are going to be somewhat better than the second quarter, which was hurt by the General Motors strike," she said, predicting a growth rate of 2.5 percent in the second half.
Part of the jump in orders for durable goods last month came as G.M. plants started production again after being idled in June and July. Aircraft orders were also strong. Excluding transportation, durable goods orders actually fell 2.1 percent last month, reflecting weak demand for electrical equipment and other products in Asia.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, speaking to reporters in Washington, said the farming and manufacturing sectors were vulnerable to global turmoil, though on balance odds remained strong for solid growth with low inflation.
"The risk to our economy is real and as the crisis has affected more countries, that risk has become greater," Mr. Rubin said.
In its report, the Labor Department said new claims for unemployment pay fell 8,000, to 292,000 last week, a fresh sign of a strong job market that is bolstering consumer spending, which fuels two-thirds of the economy.
"Consumers have been just irrepressible," said Cynthia Latta, an economist for DRI/McGraw Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass. "And no wonder since the job outlook is good, interest rates are low and pay increases have been substantial."

HEADLINE: FALLEN STAR: THE OVERVIEW;
Hedge Fund Bailout Rattles Investors and Markets

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
The $3.5 billion rescue of a big, risky investment fund verging on collapse unnerved markets around the world yesterday, raised a clamor for a Government investigation and created fear that other enormous hidden losses might become evident in the weeks and months ahead.
Rather than contain the problem and bring stability to Wall Street, the cash infusion late Wednesday by a consortium of banks and brokerage firms to salvage Long-Term Capital Management L.P. only seemed to rattle investors. Banks began to tighten lending requirements to other investment funds, raising fears of a credit shortage. 
 United States stocks fell broadly, with the Dow Jones industrial average losing more than half its 257.21-point gain on Wednesday. Shares of financial stocks were particularly hard-hit. Page C1.
Long-Term Capital, with a portfolio worth $90 billion, is one of the best-known hedge funds, financial investments that cater to the rich and make big and often risky investment bets with the hope of spectacular returns. The recent turmoil in financial markets, particularly the collapse in Russia, led to staggering losses for Long-Term Capital.
Investors tried to absorb not only what had happened to Long-Term Capital and its founder, the Wall Street bond trader John W. Meriwether, but what the deal to salvage the fund meant for markets now.
As details of Long-Term Capital's fall began to trickle out and the shock among traders, brokers and bankers began to fade, worry set in. Members of Congress called for an inquiry into what went wrong and resentment grew that an elite firm, populated by industry stars and two Nobel laureates, was saved from a disaster of its own making with an unusual dose of help from the Federal Reserve, which orchestrated the rescue effort.
By midday, it was clear that Long-Term Capital's problems were not going to be confined to the firm and a few high-roller investors. The ripple effect started with UBS A.G. of Switzerland, Europe's largest bank, which said it had lost as much as $721.6 million in the third quarter, partly because of its risky investments with Long-Term Capital. Its stock fell 10.8 percent.
Of deep concern to the financial world is what impact the fund's debacle will have on worldwide bond markets, which have already been badly shaken by events in emerging markets in the last two months. Fear of a pullback in lending by major financial institutions also grew yesterday as banks were awakened to the risks in their previous easy-money attitudes toward borrowers. If difficulty in borrowing money lasted more than a few weeks, it could cause a significant slowdown in the United States economy.
The implications of Mr. Meriwether's troubles are great for hedge funds, which operate relatively freely in world markets with little oversight from regulators. Many believe that Long-Term's near-collapse and effective takeover by big banks and brokers will translate into increased client nervousness and rising redemptions of shares at other firms. For funds operating in the already-damaged bond market, redemptions would cause a continued drop in the value of those portfolios. And if some of these areas sustain further damage, like high-yield bonds, heavy redemptions could damage plain-vanilla mutual funds.
Finally, there is worry on Wall Street that the debacle will bring increased scrutiny by regulators to hedge funds. Representative John J. LaFalce, Democrat of New York, the ranking minority member of the House Banking Committee, said yesterday that "the virtual collapse and bailout of Long-Term Capital Management makes clear that the banking committee must continue its inquiry into potential risks posed by any gaps in the regulation of hedge funds." He said he would call on Representative Jim Leach, the chairman, "to do precisely that."
The specter of Long-Term's near-failure is not going away any time soon. Indeed, it will dog the financial industry through at least the end of the year. Traders said the possibility that its $90 billion portfolio might be sold would keep much of the fixed-income markets frozen. If the Fed cuts interest rates next Tuesday, as many expect, that would hurt many of Long-Term Capital's trades, which were bets on higher rates.
An immediate reaction to Long-Term's woes was that major banks and brokerage firms began demanding increased margins, or partial payments from their hedge fund customers on new trades.
Yesterday, the details of the bailout were being firmed up. Late in the day, investors in the fund were waiting to hear where they stood. It is expected that existing investors will end up with 10 percent of their original stakes in the firm and that the consortium of banks and brokers will hold a combined 90 percent.
An oversight committee with representatives from the banks will direct overall strategy at Long-Term Capital. In one of the many paradoxes attending the crisis, Mr. Meriwether will be reporting to people who were, in some cases, very junior traders on his desk at Salomon Brothers in the 1980's.
In addition to the shock on Wall Street that Mr. Meriwether's best-and-brightest firm had almost closed, there was also anger that the Government intervened to avert the firm's collapse. Government regulators have in the past organized efforts to prevent panic-selling that could hurt the markets, but it was unusual to see the Federal Reserve help arrange a rescue of a private investment fund for the very rich.
"The public-policy implications of such a bailout are considerable and very negative," said Stephen Modzelewski, a hedge fund manager at the Watermark Group in Princeton, N.J., and a former Salomon trader. "To rescue a large, overly risky hedge fund can only encourage other hedge funds to increase their risk profiles to imprudent levels and to discourage global financial institutions from requiring prudent margins from their large hedge fund customers."
A former Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, also expressed doubt about the idea of the United States central bank moving to help save Long-Term Capital, a risk-taking securities-trading operation. Bloomberg News reported that in a speech in Boston, Mr. Volcker asked, "Why should the weight of the Federal Government be brought to bear to help out a private investor?"
A week before the Long-Term bailout was negotiated at the headquarters of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, testified to Congress that bankers knew exactly what they were doing in the policing of hedge funds, and their attendant risks. On Sept. 16, he assured Representative Richard Baker, Republican of Louisiana, that risk in hedge fund lending was well under control.
The most significant question is what impact the rescue of Long-Term Capital will have on world markets and the domestic economy.
While the deal between Long-Term Capital and its creditors put an end to rumors of impending crisis that had plagued the firm in recent weeks, it did nothing to inject badly needed money into the non-Treasury fixed-income markets. If anything, the fact that the portfolio of money-losing trades still exists added to a view that the market is paralyzed and will remain so for some time.
Even though Long-Term says the $3.5 billion infusion will allow it to keep its trades in place until they work, the widespread belief on Wall Street is that these things are for sale. For investors who want to sell their high-yield bonds, emerging-market debt, convertible securities, even some mortgage-backed issues, there is still no place to go.
Some of the higher-quality markets will likely recover, however, from current, beaten-down levels. This includes AA-rated corporate bonds, some United States agency issues and zero-coupon Treasuries. Riskier issues will stay in the doghouse.
But a great concern that has emerged from the Long-Term Capital debacle is that it may result in a protracted reduction in credit available to businesses. Even though they have been warned by regulators for months, banks tend to require a disaster of this magnitude to awaken to the risks involved in lax lending. Borrowing will be harder to obtain, and to the degree that the economy's growth has been fueled by credit, that growth may now be stunted.
Charles Peabody, an analyst with Mitchell Securities, said he feared a recession in such a credit squeeze. "Regulators are going to go into the examination process at banks and begin identifying specific risk areas and require more capital against them," he said.
Amid the gloom on Wall Street yesterday, there was gallows humor. One trader said he soon expected to see someone wearing a sandwich board that read, "Will Manage Market-Neutral Hedge Fund for Food."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "How a Hedge Fund Fell"
 
HOW SUCH AN INVESTMENT WORKS
1. The fund's managers find wealthy investors to invest in the fund. For example, each of Long-Term Capital's investors had to contribute at least $10 million.
2. The fund lines up credit from banks and brokerage firms to keep operations running smoothly. Some funds use these credit lines to increase the size of their investments, a process known as leveraging. At its high point earlier this year, Long-Term Capital was reportedly able to leverage the roughly $5 billion it had in capital into about $120 billion in investments.
3. Hedge funds are like other investment pools in that they can invest in virtually any type of security as well as complex derivatives in markets around the world. What distinguishes them is that they can take bigger risks and are subject to virtually no regulatory oversight.
 
HEDGING AN INVESTMENT
 
Despite their names, hedge funds do not necessarily hedge their investment decisions or protect themselves against market declines. They may speculate that some prices will rise at the same time that others fall.
 
A hedge fund buys a bond hoping that its price will go up. Betting that a bond's price will rise is going long in that bond.
 
At the same time, the fund borrows another bond and sells it, agreeing to return the borrowed bond sometime in the future. In this deal, the fund is hoping that the price of the borrowed bond will fall so that it will be less expensive to replace it. This is taking a short position in the borrowed bond.
 
Usually, the prices of many types of bonds move up and down in tandem. So if the price of the bond that was bought goes up, making money for the fund, the price of the bond that was borrowed is also likely to go up, meaning the fund will lose money in replacing the borrowed fund.
 
The hedge fund earns a profit if the profit on the bond that it bought is greater than the loss incurred on the bond sold short. Or if prices fall, the fund profits if the gain on the borrowed bond is greater than the loss on the bond that was bought. In either case, the process of going long and short at the same time is intended to minimize the risk to the fund, but it can also increase risk, as happened in the case of Long-Term Capital.
 
WHAT WENT WRONG
 
Long-Term Capital used sophisticated computer models to track and predict prices in the bond market. It got into trouble when those models failed.
 
Bond prices, particularly prices of bonds that are related, generally move in the same direction, but not always at the same rate. For example, one bond's price may temporarily rise faster than another's. Usually these price discrepancies eventually correct themselves. And usually the discrepancy in the relative price movements of two related bonds does not vary outside a certain range.
 
Long-Term Capital specialized in finding these price discrepancies and predicting which way prices would move. The fund got into trouble when it detected price discrepancies between U.S. Treasury securities and other bonds, including high-yield corporate bonds, mortgage-backed securities and European government bonds. Long-Term Capital decided to short U.S. Treasuries, a bet that their prices would go down, and go long on the other types of bonds, betting that their prices would go up.
 
The plunges in some many stock markets, though, caused investors to pour money into the U.S. Treasury market, a haven when there is economic turmoil, driving up the prices of Treasury securities. The falling yields on U.S. Treasuries, which move in the opposite direction to their prices, led to a decline in the interest rates for mortgages, pushing down the prices of some mortgage-backed securities. The flight to U.S. Treasuries also took its toll on the European and high-yield bond markets, where prices declined. With all of their bets going in the wrong direction, Long-Term Capital was squeezed.
