HEADLINE: Black and Hispanic Poverty Falls, Reducing Overall Rate for Nation

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The proportion of Americans living in poverty declined last year, mostly because of reductions in poverty among black and Hispanic families, the Census Bureau reported today.
The data reflected three consecutive years of growth in income, which have restored household incomes and poverty to the levels recorded in 1989, just before the last recession. 
 The poverty rate was 13.3 percent last year, down from 13.7 percent in 1996 and 15.1 percent in 1993. The number of people in poverty, 35.6 million last year, has dropped by 3.7 million since 1993.
The poverty rate for non-Hispanic whites was unchanged at 8.6 percent last year. But the rate for blacks declined to 26.5 percent, the lowest since the Government began collecting data on poverty among African Americans in 1959. The rate among blacks was 28.4 percent in 1996 and 33.1 percent in 1993.
And the poverty rate for Hispanic Americans declined to 27.1 percent, from 29.4 percent in 1996 -- the largest one-year drop in Hispanic poverty since 1977.
The data were a tonic for President Clinton, battered by months of embarrassing disclosures about his affair with a White House intern.
Mr. Clinton said the statistics vindicated his economic policies and showed that low-income people were finally sharing the fruits of a vibrant economy.
"Our growing economy is giving more and more families a chance to work their way out of poverty," he said in the Rose Garden of the White House. "After six years, it can't be an accident anymore."
Presidents generally get credit for economic growth and are blamed if the economy declines. Mr. Clinton fought successfully for increases in the minimum wage, which took effect in 1996 and 1997, and in the earned-income tax credit available to low-income workers. White House officials said those changes had helped reduce poverty.
Economists said that much of the decline in poverty was attributable to the overall strength of the economy, resulting from prudent management of Federal spending and interest rates.
Blacks have been among the President's most steadfast supporters in recent months, and today's data show that blacks have fared well in the Clinton years.
Over all, the number of families in poverty declined last year by 384,000, to 7.3 million from 7.7 million in 1996. Black families accounted for more than half of the decrease.
The welfare rolls are declining much faster than the number of people in poverty. But Rebecca M. Blank, of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said, "It's way too early to look at these numbers and conclude very much about the successes of welfare reform."
Many Democrats have predicted that cuts in welfare programs, like time limits on cash assistance, will tend to increase poverty. On the other hand, many Republicans say poverty will decline as mothers move from welfare to work and fathers pay more child support. In any event, it will be hard to separate the specific effects of the 1996 welfare law from changes in the economy.
The Census Bureau found surprisingly robust growth in income even among families headed by women, a group whose poverty has long seemed intractable. The incomes of households headed by women rose last year by 8 percent for blacks, 10.3 percent for Hispanic Americans and 3 percent for whites. Among non-Hispanic whites, hardly any change was seen.
The poverty rate for children was under 20 percent last year for the first time since 1989, and Mr. Clinton said child poverty had declined more since 1993 than in any other four-year period since the late 1960's.
But the poverty rate for people 18 to 64 years old was higher last year than in 1987-89. And for households headed by people 35 to 54, income has not kept pace with inflation, so real income was lower last year than in 1989, the bureau said.
Politicians have repeatedly denounced growing inequality in income distribution. But Census Bureau officials said their data suggested that inequality had stabilized.
"This is the fourth consecutive year in which there was no year-to-year change in overall income inequality," said Daniel H. Weinberg, chief of the Census Bureau office that collects income data.
Still, Robert D. Reischauer, former director of the Congressional Budget Office, said it was remarkable that "income inequality has not been reduced after two years in which we've enjoyed the healthiest economy in more than" 30 years.
Mr. Weinberg said the bureau's field interviewers probably missed many people with very high incomes, just as they missed homeless people. He said, anyone who reports income of more than $1 million a year is listed as having $1 million of income.
The data in the report are drawn from interviews with residents of 50,000 households chosen to be representative of the nation. A family of four was classified as poor if it had cash income of less than $16,400 in 1997. The threshold for a family of three was $12,802. Income, as officially defined, does not include capital gains, health insurance or Government benefits like food stamps, Medicaid and housing subsidies.
The Census Bureau data show that the income of black households, after adjusting for inflation, was higher in 1997 than at any other time in the last three decades.
The median income of black households rose 4.3 percent last year, to $25,050, and since 1993 it has increased by 15 percent, or $3,354, after adjusting for inflation. The number of households above the median is the same as the number below it.
For Hispanic households, the median income rose 4.5 percent last year, to $26,628, and has risen 4.8 percent since 1993. But Hispanic income appears to have stagnated and is about the same, after adjusting for inflation, as in 1972.
In its report, the Census Bureau also made these points:
* Median household income rose last year by 1.9 percent, to $37,005 from $36,306, after adjusting for inflation.
* State poverty rates, measured by three-year averages, ranged from an extraordinary low of 6.9 percent in New Hampshire to a high of 24 percent in New Mexico.
* The poverty rate for 1995 to 1997 averaged 8.8 percent in New Jersey, 10 percent in Connecticut and 16.6 percent in New York.
The report also said the number of blacks in poverty dropped last year to 9.1 million, from 9.7 million in 1996. The number of Hispanic people in poverty declined to 8.3 million, from 8.7 million. The number of poor non-Hispanic whites was about the same in 1997 as in 1996 -- 16.5 million.

HEADLINE: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: PUBLIC OPINION;
POLL FINDS CLINTON IN STRONG REBOUND SINCE VIDEO AIRING

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE with JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
President Clinton's standing with Americans has rebounded broadly in the days since the release of his videotaped testimony before a grand jury and, in fact, there are stirrings of a backlash against the Republican-controlled Congress and the House Judiciary Committee itself as it presses forward with an impeachment inquiry, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
By a clear majority, Americans said they disapproved of how the Judiciary Committee had handled the matter. While committee members said they released the video-tape for the public's benefit, 78 percent of Americans, and 65 percent of Republicans, said it should never have been released. 
 People said they objected to the committee's prying into what they regard as a private matter and that it was unnecessary to make public salacious details about sex. In addition, 65 percent of Americans said Republicans in Congress were unfairly trying to weaken the President and the Democrats; 39 percent of Republicans saw it that way as well.
But even in the face of a turnabout for Mr. Clinton, the first glimpse of how the Monica Lewinsky scandal could play out on Nov. 3 in the national elections helps explain why Republicans are sticking with a strategy of confrontation. The Republican approach is popular with the party's core voters, and those voters are most likely to turn out on Election Day. Appeals to a partisan core of Republicans may carry long-term risks, however, if they give the party an image as overly partisan and out to topple a President.
The apparent resurgence for Mr. Clinton has come swiftly -- and is surprisingly pronounced. Not only has the monthslong slide in his personal ratings halted but, in a marked shift from only a week ago, Americans also trust him more as a leader, like him more, are less inclined to think he committed perjury before the grand jury and increasingly believe that the scandal is a private matter that has little to do with his job as President.
Mr. Clinton is also helped by a growing sense among Americans that the investigation by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, has spiraled out of control.
In a telling display of the public's exasperation with the entire matter, people are now divided over whether Mr. Clinton should be censured by Congress. Forty-six percent of all Americans favor censure, as do 55 percent of Republicans; only a week ago 57 percent of all Americans wanted such a punishment, as did 70 percent of Republicans.
Despite the more promising news for Mr. Clinton -- his job approval rating has risen in the past week to a solid 67 percent and even to a respectable 40 percent among conservative Republicans -- his gains should be viewed in relative terms. Most Americans, for example, continue to say that the President does not share their moral code.
But the most striking finding in the telephone poll, which was conducted on Tuesday and Wednesday with 960 adults nationwide, was that on question after question Mr. Clinton recaptured support. The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Summing up the sentiment of many Americans who have grown impatient with the Judiciary Committee, Virginia Caperton, 68, a retired factory supervisor in Fennville, Mich., said, "I just feel the Judiciary Committee is too partisan."
Mrs. Caperton, a Democrat, explained in a follow-up interview: "I don't think they're going to give him enough time to go through all of the testimony. I don't think that the offense that he committed is worth all the time and the trouble and the expense of impeachment hearings."
Deborah Huisken, a poll respondent from Montague, Mass., said, "The members of Congress should look to themselves first and tidy up their own backyards."
Expressing weariness about the duration of the inquiry, Ms. Huisken, 42, a freelance writer who is an independent, said of Mr. Clinton, "It's appropriate for him to be censured, but it needs to be done as expeditiously as possible."
And Nancy Thirtyacre, 46, a Republican respondent from Wellsville, Ohio, who described herself as a housewife, put it this way: "This whole thing is a personal matter between him and his wife now, and we should let the guy do his job so we can get back on track."
Echoing the 53 percent of Americans who said they would be satisfied if no action was taken against the President and the matter was dropped, Ms. Thirtyacre added: "This whole thing has gone so far now that they're trying to dig up every little bit of dirt they can. But let's face it -- there's dirt on everybody."
She also was among the overwhelming proportion of 8 in 10 Americans who said the investigation has not been worth all it has taken from the public.
Seven in 10 Americans said they saw or heard some part of Mr. Clinton's appearance before the grand jury, although only 1 in 10 said they sat through the entire four hours. Yet the President's performance, and the subsequent drive by the White House to emphasize its side of the scandal and to frame the moves by Congress as needlessly partisan, gave Mr. Clinton the same sort of boost that has helped him out of difficult situations in the past.
Mr. Clinton's bounce back in the last few days was reminiscent of when his popularity shot up after his State of the Union Message in late January, which he delivered shortly after allegations about his relationship with Ms. Lewinsky, a former White House intern, were disclosed.
The President's gains seemed to have come at the expense of Congress and Mr. Starr. The overall rating of Congress is 48 percent, according to the latest poll, roughly where it has been all year. But last week it was unusually high, at 56 percent. The current rating is still impressive for Congress.
In November 1994, just before the last midterm elections, only 20 percent of Americans approved of the way Congress was doing its job. A year later there was a backlash against Republicans in Congress when the public thought lawmakers had gone too far and shut down the Government for partisan purposes. At that time, approval of Congress was at 26 percent.
Six out of 10 people who watched Mr. Clinton's testimony said he mostly tried to avoid answering the questions. But, by the same margin, Americans who watched said it was appropriate for him to refuse to answer questions about his sexual relationship with Ms. Lewinsky. Among Republicans, 4 out of 10 said his refusal to answer those questions was understandable.
That support for Mr. Clinton may come because a majority of Americans think Mr. Starr has conducted a mostly partisan investigation to damage Mr. Clinton. Sixty-four percent of Americans say the investigation is partisan; last week, 55 percent held that view. And 49 percent now say they believe the President committed perjury before the grand jury, down from 56 percent in a CBS News poll last weekend.
Americans also made clear that they do not expect any President to be a model of rectitude. Only 21 percent said that having a moral role model is most important; 65 percent said they would rather have Presidents who could do their job effectively.
While Mr. Clinton's personal ratings have improved since last week -- he is viewed favorably by 45 percent of Americans and unfavorably by 38 percent -- those of Speaker Newt Gingrich, who is leading the Republican Congressional strategy, have slipped further. The Speaker's favorable rating is 18 percent and his unfavorable rating is 34 percent; last week, the ratings were 24 percent and 31 percent, respectively.
Republicans warn that Democrats should not be too heartened by the poll findings. "It's like they're in the eye of the hurricane," said Rich Galen, an adviser to Mr. Gingrich. "I wouldn't take the plywood down from the windows just yet."
The survey underscored the gap that has confounded many politicians between the general mood of the public and that of the conservative Republican constituency. Throughout the poll, the views of conservative Republicans were dramatically different from those of liberal and moderate Republicans.
For example, when offered the options of censuring Mr. Clinton, beginning impeachment hearings or dropping the matter, 61 percent of conservative Republicans preferred to begin hearings, compared to only 35 percent of moderate and liberal Republicans. The more conservative Republicans are historically most likely to vote, and it is to those loyalists that Congressional Republicans are aiming their appeals.
While no national poll can measure the mood of voters in individual Congressional districts, it can provide clues to how the election could unfold. There are signs that Republicans at this point are in by far the stronger position. Asked whether they would vote for the Republican candidate or the Democratic candidate in their Congressional district, 39 percent of registered voters said the Republican and 44 percent said the Democrat. But as other conditions are applied, such as past voting behavior, attention to the ongoing campaign and certainty of voting in November, those numbers become more favorable to Republicans. The loosest definition of a likely voter produces a split of 44 percent Republican to 43 percent Democratic.
When conditions are applied that reflect typical turnout in a midterm election -- that is, with about 34 percent of eligible voters casting ballots -- the Republican advantage is 50 percent to 41 percent. If turnout is unusually low, the gap would widen to 53 percent to 41 percent.
Americans say the firestorm that has enveloped the White House is dominating the nation's political and policy agenda, and preventing necessary work from getting accomplished. Worries about the inquiry and related issues like declining values have eclipsed other concerns, including the economy, education and crime. Nearly two-thirds of the public said the inquiry has prevented the White House and Congress from doing any other work.
The public wants Mr. Clinton to finish his term even if it turns out that he committed perjury. Twenty-nine percent want him to apologize; 31 percent want him to resign; 26 percent want the matter dropped, and only 11 percent want Congress to move ahead with impeachment proceedings.
One poll respondent who is squarely against impeachment hearings is Martin Valle, 72, a retired military technician from Hanford, Calif. "If he did lie, he was just trying to protect himself -- any man would answer that question in the same way," said Mr. Valle, a Democrat. "I don't consider this an impeachable offense."
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Tuesday and Wednesday with 960 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number to permit access both to listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults. For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for Southerners, it is plus or minus six percentage points. For residents of the Northeast, or the Midwest or the West, it is seven percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
CITING GLOBAL SLOWDOWN, UCAR WILL CLOSE THREE PLANTS

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
UCAR International Inc., a maker of graphite and carbon electrodes for the steel industry, said yesterday that it was closing plants in Ontario, Germany and Russia, eliminating 950 jobs as part of a worldwide bid to cut costs. UCAR, which is based in Danbury, Conn., attributed the cuts to the continued slowdown in the global economy, which has eroded demand for steel and graphite electrodes. The cuts will save $24 million next year, and $33 million a year starting in 2000, the company said. Costs associated with the revamping will lower third-quarter earnings by $150 million before taxes.

HEADLINE: A Racial Gap at Southern Colleges

 BODY:

To the Editor:
For Brent Staples (Editorial Observer, Sept. 20) to note that the University of Alabama-Birmingham's 22 percent black enrollment is the highest among major research institutions in the region is faint praise indeed. Alabama's college-age population is 31.6 percent black. 
 Alabama's public universities awarded 18 doctoral degrees to blacks in 1994-95, up from 15 in 1976-77. These three additional degrees may be a 20 percent increase, but it is hardly progress.
The Southern Education Foundation report emphasizes that Alabama is not unique. Black representation among freshmen at flagship institutions in the 19 states studied was less than 10 percent. So, too, was the representation of blacks among faculty.
 
P. MICHAEL TIMPANE
Washington, Sept. 22, 1998
 
The writer is senior adviser for education policy, Rand Corporation.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Vital Lesson For Students Is Workaday

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
FEW eyebrows should have been raised, and most likely few were, when a recent survey showed that New York business leaders have meager faith in the city's public schools. Even so, it was hard to keep shoulders from sagging after the late-August release of the study, commissioned by the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce.
By 3 to 1, employers found public school graduates lacking in essential skills. They complained about young workers speaking poorly, writing poorly, performing basic arithmetic poorly and in general behaving poorly, because no one ever showed them the virtues of being polite, dressing appropriately and showing up on time. 
 True, nearly half those surveyed also said that the situation had improved a bit in the last few years. But over all, minuses outweighed pluses. A senior executive of an advertising agency filled out his questionnaire this way:
"It is almost impossible to hire competent clerical and/or entry help for administrative work from the New York City schools. Our recent successful hires were from Illinois, Toronto, Ireland etc."
Again, none of this will come as a shock to many New Yorkers. They have long grown inured to cashiers who have trouble giving correct change, to receptionists who need five minutes to take a simple message because they can barely spell, to file clerks who have to think hard about whether G comes before H or the other way around.
But even if not breathtakingly new, the business study hovered like a chilling specter over a symposium in Chelsea yesterday on how to make the city's young people more competitive in today's labor market. About 200 people representing various city offices, business groups and nonprofit providers of social services turned out for the conference, which was held at Covenant House, the youth shelter and counseling agency on West 17th Street.
If there was a recurring theme in the wide-ranging discussions, it was that programs are sorely needed to prepare young people for the real world. "You've got to connect people to the world of work," said John Rakis, who runs the South Forty Corporation, a nonprofit group that helps former prison inmates find jobs.
It isn't as though jobs are not there, everyone agreed. And it isn't, many also agreed, as though you can get away with glibly blaming racism for every problem facing the city's hundreds of thousands of job-seeking black and Hispanic youths. With unemployment lower than it has been in a long time, many employers are ready to gobble up anyone willing and able to work. Just stroll through Manhattan and try counting all the stores and restaurants with "help wanted" signs hanging in their front windows.
Steven Feldman, a senior official at the Board of Education, agreed that the schools must do more to make sure that their graduates can function in a modern service economy. The higher standards that Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has set for both students and teachers are part of the answer, Mr. Feldman said. But he added, "We've also got to motivate business to get involved in the public school system."
"In a sense, we've redefined education," he said. "We've redefined the school as a workplace."
WHAT they learn in the classroom will carry young people just so far, argued Edward DeJesus, an official of a Washington-based group called the National Youth Employment Coalition. "They don't just need a job," he said. "They need new rules for living."
In other words, it must be made obvious to them that nobody, whether a store customer or a bank officer, is going to turn over his money to someone who has three rings in his nose or who insists on talking and dressing as though he were a gangster -- even if he spells it gangsta. How, Mr. DeJesus asked, can someone expect to be trusted if he insists on "mean mugging," forever scowling in an attempt to intimidate the world?
"Young people are committing economic suicide when they're out there engaged in the street life," he said. "We can't be afraid to tell them that." If parents fail to shoulder that burden, he said, programs must be created to pick up the slack.
Things will improve, Mr. Feldman predicted, but it will take time. "The problem is that changing the schools is like knitting a sweater while you're wearing it," he said. But then, he added, no one thought the task would be easy. Just critical.

HEADLINE: View From Abroad: U.S. Policy Sapped by Scandal

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Ask in Foggy Bottom, ask in Whitehall, ask on the Quai d'Orsay, ask at the Kremlin, and you get the same deeply discreet answer: No, of course, Bill Clinton's personal and political troubles have not impaired the capacity of the United States to conduct foreign policy. But scratch a little deeper, push a little harder, and you discover that diplomats and politicians in most of the world's major nations are worried sick by the spectacle of a distracted President in Washington at a moment when, in their view at least, bold American leadership is all but indispensable.
"The world requires an end to this mawkish nonsense," said Christopher Patten, the last British Governor of Hong Kong, a top-level Tory politician and a newly minted author who is traveling in the United States to promote his book, "East and West." 
 "Most of the time Europeans like to poke sticks through the bars at the United States," he added. "It makes us feel important. We only realize how much we need you when things go wrong, like now."
Hubert Vedrine, the French Foreign Minister, spoke of "a world that isn't getting any stronger, with 25 regional conflicts involving 40 countries, states in the process of disintegration, a spreading financial crisis." He added: "What we need is strong leadership in all our countries, starting with the United States. For us, what is worrying is the guerrilla war between the Congress and the President, which has been going on for a long time."
The ambassador in Washington of one of the closest allies of the United States, speaking on condition of anonymity, used blunter language. He said, "You'd have to be deaf, dumb, blind and a mental defective not to see that Clinton has been weakened in his capacity to lead, at home and abroad."
So the United States can speak with one voice if serious crises need to be addressed this fall and winter, while impeachment proceedings may be taking place, the ambassador urged that the White House hold intensified foreign-policy briefings for Republican leaders in Congress, starting now.
"There are many complex problems in the world that were not able to be solved even before these events, and we shouldn't confuse the two," Mr. Vedrine cautioned a group of reporters at breakfast in Manhattan on Wednesday. "But that is my answer today. Will this affect America's capacity in the future? I hope not."
Some officials insist that Mr. Clinton has not been distracted at all. For example, Alistair Campbell, spokesman for Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, said after Mr. Blair and Mr. Clinton had talked at the United Nations in New York on Monday, the very day that Mr. Clinton's grand jury testimony was broadcast: "The Prime Minister found him totally focused and able to focus, and engaged on all the issues where he needs to be engaged."
But the calculus is a bit more complicated than that. It involves many questions, of which the President's ability to concentrate is only one. Can he spare the time, for instance, to rally international coalitions? Can he influence Congressional action on foreign policy? Will all his actions abroad be interpreted in unfriendly quarters at home, like the bombing raids on Afghanistan and Sudan, as mere ploys to divert attention from the Lewinsky case and impeachment hearings?
One thing is clear in almost every capital: A crippled President is good news for no one. Gratitude for past support was one element in the standing ovation Mr. Clinton got at the United Nations; it was led by Foreign Minister Rosario Green of Mexico, which the Clinton Administration bailed out of a financial crisis nearly three years ago. But the applause was also designed, some delegates said, to strengthen Mr. Clinton's hand at a time of trouble.
People in different countries fret about different issues.
A top-ranking State Department official said that proposals for fresh initiatives in two of the most difficult situations, those in Kosovo and in Iraq, have been on President Clinton's desk for some time. He would not say how long, but he commented: "We need action, and in normal times, we would have had it. But these are not normal times, as you may have noticed."
The United States has sat quietly by while Saddam Hussein expelled United Nations arms inspectors, having said previously that it would not accept such action, and it has failed so far to intervene to slow Serbian attacks upon ethnic Albanians in Kosovo. Some Europeans think Mr. Clinton's hands are tied.
"He cannot order retaliation against Islamic terrorism without raising the suspicion of it being a reckless political expedient," wrote Alberto Ronchey, the former head of the publisher Rizzoli RCS, in the Milan newspaper Corriere della Sera.
An Asian diplomat complained bitterly about what he called "intolerably late, intolerably inadequate" American action in the case of Anwar Ibrahim, the former Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister, who was dismissed this month from his positions in the Cabinet and the ruling political party, then arrested in Kuala Lumpur on Sunday on charges of sexual misconduct and treason.
Washington's first official comment came only today, in the form of a statement by the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, expressing concern over the detention of Mr. Ibrahim under Malaysia's Internal Security Act, which dates from the insurgency there decades ago. Asian representatives in Washington wanted a tougher American line, enunciated by Mr. Clinton.
The international financial crisis is another cause for anxiety, although some foreign officials continue to suggest that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin can manage American economic policy with minimal White House help.
Others suggest, though they offer no convincing proof, that if Mr. Clinton had not been preoccupied this summer when troubles broke out in Asia, Russia and then Brazil, he might have been able to react much more aggressively, whether that would have solved the problem or not. And his legal troubles are widely blamed abroad for the President's inability to persuade Congress to authorize an additional $18 billion for the International Monetary Fund.
Gianni De Michelis, the former Italian Foreign Minister who was convicted of corruption in the early 1990's, said that signs of Mr. Clinton's weakness on the international front were already evident in the I.M.F. setback.
No stranger to the political fallout of legal entanglements, Mr. De Michelis said: "If Japan blows up, we are facing an unthinkable disaster. It would obviously be useful to have at the head of the most powerful Government in the world someone who can deal with world crises with a free hand."
While Mr. Clinton's efforts to open a debate on the financial crisis have been welcomed in Brazil, the country's Finance Minister, Luiz Felipe Lampreia, said that the President's ability to lead that debate has been reduced.
Brazilian officials, the Finance Minister said, were "extremely concerned with the fact that President Clinton is weakened internationally."
Some on Capitol Hill believe that the Lewinsky affair has contributed to the looming failure of President Clinton's bid for wider powers to negotiate trade treaties. The House is scheduled to vote on Friday on so-called fast-track authorization legislation, with a defeat widely anticipated.
Representative Walter B. Jones Jr., a North Carolina Republican, said he had been leaning against widening Presidential powers last year but was now a sure "no" vote. His views had changed because of his constituents' views, he said, adding: "They don't want to see this President given any new authority."

HEADLINE: ART IN REVIEW;
Jason Martin

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:

Robert Miller Gallery
41 East 57th Street
Manhattan
Through Oct. 10
 Seen in their New York gallery debut, Jason Martin's smartly coiffed monochrome paintings have so many precedents, and so much intelligence, economy and all-round optical jazziness they are almost interesting. 
 A young British artist, Mr. Martin paints by covering largish surfaces of stainless steel, aluminum and plexiglass with (usually) a single color of oil paint; he then pulls a fine, sometimes specially made comblike tool across the wet paint, creating striations that move up and down according to various intervals and rhythms.
The electric-blue glide of "Patrol" wavers only slightly but nervously and consistently, like the results of lie-detector tests taken by the guiltless or dozens of flat-lining heart monitors. The marigold yellow surfaces of "Cha-Cha" and "Samba" have a lot of wave action; their wide undulations gleam, as if three or four spotlights were situated just above, or below, them. Elsewhere, as in the burgundy "Boudoir," the surface ripples, like a curtain. And occasionally the raking tool is lifted and the surface broken, creating dramatic fissures of fringed paint.
The artists brought to mind by Mr. Martin's no-hands technique and glistening effects include Jackson Pollock and Robert Ryman, Alan Charlton, Bridget Riley and David Budd, an American painter whose monochrome surfaces accrue in small palette-knifed, light-deflecting strokes, as well as contemporary painters like James Hyde.
But mostly one comes away with a sense of sensational, tacky retro-chic, as suggested by titles like "Stripsearch," "Harlot" and "Slapjack" and corroborated by the slickness of the paintings themselves. The problem seems to be one of taste. Mr. Martin needs to raise his sights higher so that his paintings can transcend the gimmicky mechanics of their own making. At this point they actually do seem to have been made by machines and have the brief dazzle of a Slinky toy making its way down the stairs. ROBERTA SMITH

CORRECTION-DATE: October 3, 1998, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A brief art review in Weekend on Sept. 25 about the English painter Jason Martin referred incorrectly to his show at the Robert Miller Gallery in Manhattan, through Oct. 10. It is not his New York gallery debut; the resume provided by his London gallery omitted a 1995 solo show at the Cristinerose Gallery, which was then in SoHo and is now in Chelsea.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Analysts See Positive Signs In Latin American Turmoil

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25

 BODY:
With increasing signs that world lenders are preparing to rescue Brazil from a potential financial meltdown, Wall Street analysts say that outflows of capital are slowing from stock markets from Mexico City to Buenos Aires.
They caution that the region's economies and markets may not have reached bottom yet. Corporate profits throughout Latin America are falling, a devaluation in Venezuela may be looming and a financial collapse in Brazil is less likely but still possible. 
 Latin American mutual funds have already lost $851 million, or 63 percent, of their asset value this year. Nevertheless, some say they believe they are beginning to see the bottom.
"The panic selling has subsided," said James A. Upton, Latin American equity strategist for Credit Suisse First Boston, who cautioned that he expected continued volatility.
"There's still a lot of risk out there," said Eduardo Cabrera, Merrill Lynch's chief Latin America equity strategist, noting the region's continued vulnerability. "The global situation is still turbulent but you have big brother finally stepping up."
The beginnings of cautious optimism are based partly on the view that the Governments of Mexico, Argentina and Peru have responded smartly to protect their currencies with timely rises in interest rates and that several of the region's largest countries are likely to have positive growth rates next year. They note that Chile, a traditional leader in regional economic policy-making, last week lifted a key capital control costly to foreign investors in another sign that Latin America would not veer from free-market policies adopted over the last decade.
But more than anything else, the more positive view tentatively emerging is based on expectations that the International Monetary Fund and other lenders will come to Brazil's rescue with an aid package that could exceed $50 billion and that the Federal Reserve will soon lower interest rates to help the United States and world economies. A loosening of United States monetary policy, the analysts hope, should indirectly raise the prices of several of Latin America's lagging exports such as oil, copper, paper and steel.
However all bets are off, Wall Street analysts say, if Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, does not win re-election as expected on Oct. 4. They also say he must fulfill his recent promises of an aggressive program to slash Government spending and to raise taxes to relieve the burden of a fiscal deficit that represents 7 percent of gross domestic product. With a population of 160 million and 30 percent of Latin America's total economy, anything that happens in Brazil reverberates through the region.
"Brazil was at the brink of a devaluation a few weeks ago, and that meant that all emerging markets were on the brink," said Jorge O. Mariscal, chief Latin American investment strategist at Goldman, Sachs. "But now, all the things the markets were clamoring for seem to be happening."
Capital is still leaving Latin American stock markets, but analysts say the flow is slowing. In the week ended Wednesday, Latin American mutual funds suffered an outflow of $15.6 million, slightly better than the average of $18.3 million a week over the last month. James Barrineau, Latin American equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, said the slight improvement came because "we've started getting hints of an aid package for Brazil."
Fears of financial collapse precipitated by Russia's devaluation and debt moratorium, followed by expectations that Brazil would avert that fate with an international bailout, have driven Brazil's stock market on a wild ride the last two months. Between late July and the first 11 days of this month, the market fell by better than 50 percent, only to recover most of its losses in recent days. Then it stumbled again Thursday and today for other reasons, mainly the prospects of the collapse of an American hedge fund. The Bovespa closed today at 6,711.52, down 132.83 for the day and more than 34 percent for the year. Mr. Mariscal and several other analysts said they expected a recession as a result of a recent doubling of interest rates that will depress corporate profits next year.
But while Wall Street analysts do not expect a sustained rally in Brazilian stocks, they say that as long as Brazil does not devalue, they like the economic prospects for much of the rest of the region, particularly Argentina, Mexico and Chile. Wall Street analysts say continued drops in the stock markets in all three countries should be buffered by the ready pools of cash available from their private pension fund systems.
A rise in Argentine interest rates in recent months to defend the peso has depressed auto production and construction, and is drying up consumer and mortgage credit. Jane Heap, Latin America strategist for Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, has lowered her estimates for Argentina's economic growth rate from 6 percent to 4 percent this year, and from 4.5 percent to 3 percent in 1999. But she expresses hopeful optimism.
"It certainly is not a recession," Ms. Heap said. "What is most important about Argentina is that there is no way the peso's peg to the dollar will break even in the worst case scenario."
With Argentine stocks beaten down by more than 40 percent this year, and several Argentine companies beginning to aggressively buy back their own shares, several analysts said they saw the potential for higher stock prices. They cautioned, though, that any investments in emerging markets were risky at this point. Analysts also said the Mexican economy should grow modestly next year, despite high interest rates, even if oil prices did not rise much.
Mr. Barrineau forecast a 10 percent drop in Mexican corporate profits this year compared with a 4 percent drop in corporate profits in Latin America as a whole. "However, next year, if Brazil does not devalue, 10 percent corporate earnings growth in Mexico is doable," he said.

HEADLINE: The Half-Life of Presidential Scandals

BYLINE: By Michael Kazin; Michael Kazin, a fellow at the Woodrow Wilson Center, is the author of "The Populist Persuasion: An American History."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Presidential scandals have always made for grand, or at least gaudy, public theater. For well over a century, Americans have been captivated by tales of the powerful brought low by their basest appetites -- for money, sex or absolute domination. But do these imbroglios help the opposing party win elections? Do they alter the course of our political life?
In the short run, the answer clearly is no. Between the end of the Civil War and the end of the cold war, four Republican administrations were rocked by scandal. But in each case, a Republican candidate won the next Presidential election and, more important, his party still set the tone of political debate. 
 In the early 1870's, several Cabinet officials in the Grant Administration were indicted for receiving kickbacks from contractors, and the Secretary of War was impeached. Grant made excuses for his subordinates' wrongdoing and helped them elude punishment. Still, Republicans, won the next two Presidential elections, albeit by exceedingly close votes. Moreover, they were able to impose high tariffs, which most Democrats loathed.
Half a century later, Warren Harding's Administration was gravely damaged by an Interior Secretary who sold oil leases to his friends and skimmed off hefty profits, and by an Attorney General who escaped a bribery conviction only by burning incriminating documents. The President suffered a heart attack midway through his term, and many said he died of despair.
But Harding's successor, Calvin Coolidge, won the next election in a landslide, and Herbert Hoover repeated the performance four years later.
Neither have more recent scandals -- Watergate and Iran-contra -- hurt Republicans in the long run. True, the Democrats gained 46 seats in the House in the election held four months after Richard Nixon's resignation, and Jimmy Carter eked out a victory over Nixon's successor, Gerald Ford, two years later.
But President Carter was unable to buck the continuing surge of conservative sentiment, and the Democrats surrendered both the White House and the Senate in 1980.
The Iran-contra scandal in the Reagan Administration had the slightest impact of all: it wasn't even an important issue in the next Presidential campaign, which took place only a year after top Reagan officials were indicted. George Bush lost the 1992 election because of the faltering economy, not because of his reputed role in the Iran-contra fiasco.
Why do such shocking scandals leave so limited an impression? Americans may get angry at the immorality of their leaders, but they usually vote based on self-interest -- as they perceive it. It takes a social upheaval -- a Civil War, a Great Depression, an implosion of liberalism -- to alter partisan habits and usher in a new political era.
Thus, few Republicans abandoned their party, whatever their misgivings about Grant, Harding, Nixon or Reagan, or the men surrounding them. In fact, loyalists often rally around an embattled President, if only to turn back the common enemy. That certainly has been the case in the present scandal, as Democrats condemned Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel, for obsessively reporting the details of the President's sex life.
But if White House scandals don't help the opposition party gain power, they do have an effect on the political system as a whole. The thievery of Grant's men galvanized a generation of muckraking reformers. Similarly, the Harding debacle emboldened future New Dealers to rein in big business. Watergate increased cynicism about government itself -- and led Congress to pass a hasty campaign reform law to which we owe the curse of political action committees.
It's too soon to divine what the larger political meaning of the Clinton scandal will be. But the polls suggest that, as in the past, most voters separate policies they like from the personal failings of the man behind them.
Perhaps Mr. Clinton's greatest legacy will be to complete the process of shrinking Presidents down to human size: future occupants of the White House may find that Americans view them not as role models, but merely as public servants. For the ferociously ambitious men and women who seek the job, that might be the biggest scandal of all.

HEADLINE: Coke Expects Flat Earnings This Quarter

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Painting a bleaker picture than many analysts had foreseen, the Coca-Cola Company disclosed yesterday that its short-term business results had been severely battered by global economic upheaval.
In a statement after an early-morning meeting with Wall Street analysts in New York, the company warned that earnings would be flat in the third quarter, compared with the corresponding period last year, and would fall in the fourth quarter compared with last year. About two-thirds of Coke's earnings come from markets outside the United States. 
 Coke said its worldwide case sales volume would grow only 3 percent to 4 percent in the third quarter, which ends next Wednesday, compared with annual growth forecasts of 7 percent to 8 percent. Many analysts had thought the third-quarter volume would come in around 5 percent to 6 percent. Last year, sales grew 11 percent in the corresponding period.
"While management is moving to adjust their business plans in some of the more chaotic markets, the impact will be severe in the third quarter and even more so in the fourth quarter," said Michael J. Branca, a beverage analyst for Lehman Brothers, who called Coke's presentation yesterday "somber but realistic." Following the meeting, Mr. Branca said he had lowered his earnings forecast for this year from $1.53 a share to $1.46, and ratcheted his 1999 projection lower as well.
Coke stock fell more than $3 a share as the stock market opened yesterday, but largely recovered to close at $56.1875, down 50 cents in heavy trading. The stock has fallen 36 percent since July 15, when it closed at $88.9375.
Pepsico, Coke's main rival, issued its own third-quarter volume results yesterday as well. The company normally does not release those numbers ahead of its earnings results, which are not due for several weeks. In Pepsi's case, global beverage volume rose 5 percent to 6 percent for the third quarter, though most of that reflects sales in the United States, since Pepsi's presence abroad is much smaller than Coke's.
"We had the data, so we thought it would be useful to put it out," said Richard M. Detwiler Jr., a Pepsico spokesman. At the same time, Pepsico also announced appointments for its bottling business, which many in the soft-drink business expect to be spun off as a publicly traded company before long.
Coke's news seemed to surprise many analysts, not in its general outlook but in the depth of the damage done in a relatively short time. But most analysts said the company's long-range prospects remained impressive, and those fundamentals were emphasized in the meeting by M. Douglas Ivester, Coke's chairman and chief executive, and James E. Chestnut, the company's chief financial officer.
"There's no doubt that the near term is worse than we thought," said Jennifer Solomon, a beverage analyst with Salomon Smith Barney. "And there's no doubt that it took them a little bit by surprise." She said Mr. Ivester seemed "taken aback by the degree of weakness in the global economy," but added, "I would hardly call him alarmed or worried."
Company executives gave no guidance about 1999 earnings, Ms. Solomon said. "They said they expect to get their volumes within 7 to 8 percent," she said. "But earnings are going to be tough."
Mr. Branca said the company indicated it would take unspecified steps to manage the economic difficulties.
Such steps could include cutting prices in some markets and increasing marketing outlays in others.
Another analyst, Bill Pecoriello of Sanford Bernstein, said he left the meeting feeling "still very confident in the long-term fundamentals, and knowing Coke will emerge stronger when these global economies turn around." Still, he said, "I remain cautious for the short run due to continued uncertainties."
Among the trouble spots for Coke is Japan, which is suffering one of its worst economic declines and which accounts for 17 percent of Coke's profits. "Management is hopeful that Government actions, such as a reduced consumption tax and more upbeat political P.R., could meaningfully improve that business," Mr. Branca said. Another worry is Germany, which accounts for 8 percent to 9 percent of profits. Sales by Coke's Greater Europe group are expected to increase just 1 percent to 2 percent in the third quarter.
"The near-term numbers are weaker than I thought, both in volume and earnings," said Marc Cohen, a beverage analyst for Goldman, Sachs. "That being said, I was somewhat encouraged by the enthusiasm they showed for being able to grow 7 to 8 percent from their 1998 levels." The company's discussion of the possibility that it would accelerate its stock repurchasing program was also encouraging, he said.
At Pepsi, the changes announced yesterday will make Craig Weatherup, now the global chairman and chief executive of Pepsi-Cola, the leader of the bottling company, to be called the Pepsi Bottling Group. It will comprise all of the bottling operations Pepsi owns, which handle 58 percent of the company's domestic volume. Mr. Weatherup, 53, will be chairman and chief executive of Pepsi Bottling.
Craig Jung, 45, president of Pepsi's bottling operations since last year, will become chief operating officer of Pepsi Bottling. In addition, John Cahill, 41, was named executive vice president and chief financial officer of the new bottling company.
Pepsi shares, which have been trading in the $29 to $31 range for most of the month, fell 56.25 cents, to $30.4375.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Ends WithSmall Gain on Expectation of a Rate Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks recovered from sharp morning losses yesterday to end the session and the week with gains.
Investors continued to be skittish about the potential fallout from the near-collapse of a large hedge fund, Long-Term Capital Management, and about financial crises in Asia and Russia. Expectations that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates next week, however, overcame such worries. 
 "Everyone is counting on Greenspan lowering interest rates," said Joe Joshi, chief investment officer at Systematic Financial Management in Fort Lee, N.J., which oversees $1 billion. "That will show he will not let a recession happen." Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and other Fed policy makers are scheduled meet on interest rate policy on Tuesday.
Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Budget Committee on Wednesday that deteriorating economies abroad "have increased the possibility that the slowdown in the growth of the U.S. economy will be more than sufficient to hold inflation in check." His comments were seen as a signal that short-term rates would be cut.
A rate cut "will stimulate the economy," allowing corporate profits to grow, said Martin Sass, president of M. D. Sass Investor Services, which manages $13 billion.
Stocks tumbled in early trading, following selloffs in Asian and European markets. Stocks fell 3.4 percent in Japan and 1.7 percent in Hong Kong. European markets, however, recovered some of their losses in late trading. London stocks closed down 2.06 percent, while in Paris, stocks ended down 2.09 percent.
After dropping as much as 112 points in early trading, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 26.78 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,028.77. I.B.M. led the Dow higher, but the average was dragged down in part by Coca-Cola, which warned yesterday that second-half earnings would be disappointing.
I.B.M. rose 2 15/16 , to 133 1/2 -- accounting for nearly half the Dow's gain -- while Coke fell 1/2, to 56 3/16 . For the week, the Dow was up 133.11 points, or 1.7 percent.
Broader market indexes were also higher yesterday. The Standard & Poor's 500 index gained 2.03, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,044.75. The Nasdaq composite index rose 23.35, or 1.4 percent, to 1,743.59.
But smaller stocks were weaker. The Russell 2000 smaller-stock index fell 1.23 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 369.02.
Dell Computer rose 2 3/4, to an all-time high of 66 1/16 , after executives said the economic slump in Asia would not impede sales growth.
Some American financial shares declined after Credit Suisse Group and Dresdner Bank joined UBS in disclosing that they would write off investments in Long-Term Capital Management. Chase Manhattan fell 7/8, to 45 1/2, and First Chicago NBD lost 1 15/16 , to 71 3/4.
J. P. Morgan rose 1 15/16 , to 88 15/16 , after diving 6 1/8 Thursday. The Wall Street Journal reported that J. P. Morgan had covered its exposure to Long-Term Capital through Treasury bills and cash.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Higher
(By Dow Jones)
Treasury prices ended higher yesterday despite gains in stocks, as uncertainty over the stability of global financial markets and expectations of a cut in interest rates continued to underpin the market.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 17/32 , to 105 24/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.12 percent from 5.16 percent.
Bonds started higher across the curve as stocks opened lower. Shorter maturities, however, fell during the session on profit taking.
But the short end of the market rallied late in the day, as traders and investors continued to be optimistic that Federal Reserve policy makers would cut short-term rates by as much as a half-point next week.

HEADLINE: Home Resales Down but Still Remain High

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Home resales declined last month but remained near a record level, while consumer spending rebounded, a sign of the economy's stamina.
"Americans are a bunch of happy campers," said Joel Naroff, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Philadelphia. "At least right now, we're not seeing much impact from Asia. There's no doubt that people are spending money. They've got it; they're spending it." 
 The National Association of Realtors said today that home resales fell 3.7 percent in August from July, to an annual rate of 4.73 million units, remaining near the record rate of 4.91 million units set in July, when sales grew 3.6 percent.
In another report, the Commerce Department said personal spending rose six-tenths of 1 percent last month after having declined one-tenth of 1 percent in July. Americans' incomes rose half a percent in August, faster than July's gain of four-tenths of 1 percent. The August figures were bolstered by a rebound in car sales after the end of two factory strikes against the General Motors Corporation.
Together, the reports suggested continued economic strength. Policy makers at the Federal Reserve, though, expect a slowdown as the American economy feels the effects of the economic crisis in Asia and some other parts of the world. Comments this week by the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, have led investors to expect a cut in interest rates when the central bank's policy committee meets on Tuesday.
"If the Fed does ease, it's not because of problems in the U.S. economy," said Kevin Flanagan, money market economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York. "Midway through the third quarter, the U.S. economy was still showing decent momentum."
That is likely to change, however. Just today, the New York Fed's president, William McDonough, said he expected economic growth to slow to an annual rate of 2 to 2.5 percent in the second half of this year and all of next year, well below the 3.7 percent rate in the first half of this year.
Housing has been strong in recent months because of low interest rates. The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage declined to 6.64 percent this week, the lowest level since 1967 and down from 6.66 percent a week earlier.
The home-resale data are regarded as an important gauge of the economy's direction. Sales of previously owned homes account for 85 percent of all home sales, and home buyers generally make significant purchases of furniture, appliances and other household goods, providing a further lift to the economy.
Consumer spending is key because it accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity. Spending rose at a 6.1 percent annual pace in the second quarter, unchanged from the first quarter. But that is not expected to continue in the second half.
Consumer spending on big-ticket durable goods rose 1.1 percent in August, in contrast to July's 4.6 percent decline. Analysts had expected a rebound as car sales recovered from the effects of the G.M. strike.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Gain in South Asia

 BODY:
Four months after shocking the world with their nuclear tests, India and Pakistan have declared their intention to sign a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. The announcement could reduce tensions in one of the most volatile parts of the world. But before the United States can lift economic sanctions imposed in response to the nuclear blasts last May, it should press India and Pakistan to reach additional curbs on the production of weapons-grade nuclear material and the development and deployment of missiles capable of delivering nuclear weapons.
The announcement was delivered in separate speeches Wednesday and Thursday at the United Nations by Prime Ministers Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan and A. B. Vajpayee of India. It was a major turnabout for India in particular, since Pakistan has long said it would sign the treaty if India would. India had denounced the treaty as unacceptable as long as the United States and other countries refused to eliminate their own nuclear weapons. 
 Since both Mr. Vajpayee and Mr. Sharif sit atop shaky governing coalitions, it took political courage for them to make their pledges. Mr. Vajpayee, as head of a Hindu nationalist coalition Government, is under pressure from his own camp to press India's claim to be seen an equal with China and other nuclear powers. The Clinton Administration also deserves praise for getting two countries that have fought three wars in the last 50 years to achieve a measure of progress. One key to the agreement was that India is not being challenged by the United States in its demand that the problem of Kashmir, India's only Muslim-dominated state, be settled in negotiations with Pakistan without intervention from the United Nations or other outside influences.
Tremendous obstacles remain in the way of a true rapprochement on the Asian subcontinent. Both Mr. Vajpayee and Mr. Sharif will no doubt try to link their signatures to promises of American sanctions being eased and other steps. President Clinton was supposed to visit India and Pakistan this fall, a trip this page urged him to reconsider after the nuclear blasts. Such a trip may still be premature, but the President should keep up the pressure for progress and schedule a trip, perhaps next year, as a spur to Indian and Pakistani agreements. With rising tensions in South Asia, including threats of a war between Afghanistan and Iran, the region looms as a more important security concern than ever.
Meanwhile, Mr. Clinton faces a tough battle in pressing ratification of the treaty in the Senate, where many Republicans are skeptical of its effectiveness. Politically distracted as it is, the Administration should redouble its efforts to win ratification of this important nuclear accord. Surely the Senate opponents will not want the United States to align itself with North Korea as the only holdouts on one of the most significant barriers against the spread of nuclear weapons.

HEADLINE: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Casts The Congress As Do-Nothing

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Cheered by polls that appear to show the beginnings of a backlash against Congressional Republicans for a seeming preoccupation with the Lewinsky scandal, President Clinton today criticized them for a lack of action on spending bills and other legislation.
In remarks before leaving the White House this morning for a three-day fund-raising swing on behalf of Democratic candidates, Mr. Clinton said, "By failing to meet its most basic governing responsibility, the Republican majority in Congress has its priorities wrong: partisanship over progress, politics over people." 
 Both in Washington and at a campaign fund-raiser here in Chicago, Mr. Clinton laced his comments with a sharp partisan edge, hoping to gain an advantage with the public as Republicans appear to be moving toward authorizing an impeachment inquiry against him. In his remarks today, as in others late this week, there were no apologies for his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky or for his seven months of misleading statements about it.
As he tries to turn attention away from the events that threaten his Presidency, Mr. Clinton has authorized his lawyers to negotiate a financial settlement of Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct suit, whose dismissal is now pending appeal. If successful in putting that matter behind him, Mr. Clinton could argue to Congress that he has resolved the accusations that ultimately exposed his affair with Ms. Lewinsky, although what effect a settlement would have on the impeachment inquiry remains unclear.
Today the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, resisted any notion of short-cutting the House deliberations on impeachment, saying the process should be allowed to go forward. And he returned fire on the President's criticism of Republicans, deriding Mr. Clinton as "fund-raiser in chief" and accusing him of neglecting his own responsibilities as he maneuvers to salvage his political future.
"The President comes out at a time when he needs cooperation with -- and we need cooperation from him -- with the Congress, and he takes a gratuitous slap, jumps on a plane and runs off for three days of fund-raising," Mr. Lott said. "Now, is he the fund-raiser in chief, or is he the Commander in Chief?"
"Now, we're doing our work," the Senator said. "Maybe he just hasn't noticed; he's been distracted. And what he's trying to do is distract attention from his problems by trying to, you know, push the blame off on somebody else."
Another Republican, Representative Anne M. Northup of Kentucky, said Mr. Clinton had failed to exert his influence to help win passage of fast-track trade legislation, which the President supports but a majority of Democrats oppose.
"Where is he?" Ms. Northup said. "He's out on a political junket."
Barry Toiv, the deputy White House press secretary, said it was the Republican leadership, not Mr. Clinton, that was responsible for gridlock in Washington.
"I don't know how he can say that," Mr. Toiv said of Mr. Lott's criticism. "It's not the President who has eked out a total of one appropriations bill in nine months, with only five days left to go in the fiscal year. It's not the President who is five months behind in enacting a budget. It's not the President who has failed to approve education spending."
"Look," Mr. Toiv added, "the Congress needs to get its work done. I think that's the point the President was trying to make today."
Mr. Clinton said there were still a few days left for Congress to act before breaking in early October for electioneering. But he held out little hope that Republican leaders would heed his call, and appeared delighted to have a slow-moving target at which to aim his fire.
He said he signed a stopgap spending bill this morning to keep the Government running after the fiscal year ends at midnight next Wednesday, but called the emergency measure "a regrettable sign" that Republicans were "moving in the wrong direction."
He was particularly critical of a House Republican plan to cut taxes by $80 billion over five years before the future solvency of the Social Security trust fund is assured.
The President appeared emboldened by recent polls that show approval of Congress slipping while his own popularity surges in the aftermath of the televising on Monday of his videotaped grand jury testimony. His most recent public comments reflect a calculation that he can gain politically by contrasting his focus on public business with Congress's heavy diet of impeachment talk.
On a separate tour with similar themes, Hillary Rodham Clinton campaigned for Democrats in Colorado, Oregon, Washington and California this week. At an elementary school in Sheridan, Colo., on Thursday, Mrs. Clinton complained that Congress did not seem to have time to devote to issues like education.
"And I wish that I could have every member of Congress who is too busy -- too busy to have a hearing about school modernization, too busy to consider adding teachers to lower classroom size -- to come with me to Fort Logan," she said, referring to the school where she spoke. "They could not do that, and the result is you won't see them."
The First Lady said Congress would "rather spend time dividing our country, diverting our resources, doing anything but focusing on the real problems of America."
The President sounded the same anti-Congress theme in an appearance at an elementary school in Chicago today, accusing Republicans of inaction on legislation concerning education, health care, the environment and the global economy.
And at a fund-raiser for the Democratic nominee for governor of Illinois -- an event at which the nominee, Representative Glenn Poshard, did not appear -- Mr. Clinton said that after eight months of inaction, the Republican Congressional leadership now wanted to use the first budget surplus in decades to pass a popular tax cut on the eve of the midterm elections.
"The majority party wants to make everybody happy close to the election with a tax cut," Mr. Clinton said. "But it's not the right thing to do. Before the red ink turns to black and it dries a little bit, people want to turn around and spend it again."
Mr. Poshard, who was in Washington, spoke by telephone to the $250,000 fund-raising luncheon, held at Chicago's Mercantile Club. He said that critics would accuse him of seeking to distance himself from a President in serious political trouble but that "nothing could be further from the truth."
"I'm very proud of your work," he told Mr. Clinton. "I'm very proud of your leadership."
Mr. Poshard said he had remained in Washington to vote on Social Security and tax legislation. But he was also preparing to vote to deny the President fast-track trade authority -- the power to negotiate trade agreements that Congress may then vote only up or down, without amending.
The Congressman's position on fast track is one he has held consistently, said his press secretary, David C. Gillies. Like many other Democrats, Mr. Poshard says the Administration's trade position does not insure adequate protection for workers and the environment in less-developed countries.
Mr. Clinton will appear at five more fund-raising events for Democratic candidates this weekend, three in California and two in Texas. He also plans to spend Saturday morning with Mrs. Clinton visiting their daughter, Chelsea, a sophomore at Stanford University.
He returns to Washington late Sunday night.

HEADLINE: House Rejects Expanded Trade Power for President

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
The House today rejected legislation to give expanded trade negotiating authority to President Clinton.
The outcome, 243 to 180, seemed assured in advance, since few lawmakers had switched sides from last November, when the same bill was pulled from the House floor before it could be voted down. If anything, the measure had lost support since then. 
 Mr. Clinton badly wants the authority, which would allow him to negotiate trade agreements that Congress could accept or reject but not amend. But he did not want the Congress to deal with it now.
That is because the vast majority of House Democrats oppose the legislation. Indeed, Democrats voted against the fast-track measure today, 171 to 29, and many accused Speaker Newt Gingrich of holding a vote on legislation he knew was doomed simply to expose Democratic divisions just weeks before the Nov. 3 elections.
"Why did the Speaker insist on bringing up this bill when he knew it was going to fail?" asked Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the Democratic whip.
Taking to the House floor at the end of today's four-hour debate, Mr. Gingrich angrily rejected the criticisms and accused Democrats of taking orders from labor unions who are Democrats' biggest donors and most loyal supporters, and who strongly oppose the measure.
"The real issue is that your unions won't let you vote for free trade," Mr. Gingrich said.
In a statement after the vote, Mr. Gingrich criticized Mr. Clinton for not rallying Democrats to his cause. "Instead of lobbying for fast track," he said, "the President neglected our nation's long-term economic health in favor of political fund-raising."
The House legislation would have extended the authority that all Presidents since Gerald R. Ford have had in negotiating trade accords that Congress can accept or reject but not amend. Mr. Clinton let those powers lapse four years ago rather than risk a vote that would split Democrats.
Mr. Gingrich and his lieutenants lobbied hard for the trade authority this week, but Democrats said it was all show to deflect complaints from business groups and farmers upset that Republicans have balked at providing $18 billion in new financing for the International Monetary Fund.
 The Speaker flipped the accusations around, warning that a vote against the enhanced trade authority would weaken the United States in the eyes of the world economic community and further unsettle jittery currencies from Asia to Brazil.
"If this goes down and this ends up in a step toward world recession, some of us will have the comfort to know we cast the right vote," Mr. Gingrich said.
Today's debate was a shadow of last November's confrontation that dealt Mr. Clinton one of his most stinging legislative setbacks. Supporters cast the debate as a choice between protectionism and free trade in an increasingly global marketplace.
"This is an argument between those who believe Americans can compete in the world market and those who believe they can't," said Representative Gil Gutknecht, Republican of Minnesota.
Representative Dave Camp, Republican of Michigan, said, "A vote for fast track is a vote for farm families. Trade is one of the most important tools to improve the farm economy."
Democrats retorted that the trade authority failed to insure that developing nations would uphold labor and environmental standards in their quest to profit in the global market.
"Are we going to let multinational companies bargain down environmental standards around the world in the name of economic competitiveness?" asked Representative Frank Pallone Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.
Democrats said granting Mr. Clinton enhanced trade negotiating authority would continue to undermine an American job market already suffering from the North American Free Trade Agreement of 1993, a conclusion that Republicans disputed.
Mr. Bonior, the Democratic whip, said, "Nafta is hurting hundreds of thousands of people on both sides of the border"

HEADLINE: AMERICANS LACKING HEALTH INSURANCE PUT AT 16 PERCENT

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Despite the booming economy, the number of people without health insurance rose sharply last year, to 43.4 million, and the proportion of Americans lacking coverage reached the highest level in a decade, 16.1 percent, the Census Bureau reported today.
After rising slightly more than 1 million a year, on the average, in the last decade, the number of uninsured people was up 1.7 million last year, the largest increase since 1992. 
 The data seem surprising at first. Robert L. Bennefield, a statistician at the Census Bureau, said, "In a healthy economy, you'd think you would have more people with jobs, and that would tend to increase coverage, so you'd see fewer people uninsured."
But he and other experts said there were several logical explanations for the rising number of uninsured. Medicaid rolls are down as stringent new laws prod people to move from welfare to work and the low-paying jobs they find often do not offer health benefits. Some employers have said they are cutting back health benefits, especially for dependents of employees, because of rising medical costs.
Even people with higher incomes are going without insurance. Households with annual incomes of $75,000 or more accounted for half the increase in the number of uninsured, the bureau said. The number of people in these upper-income households without insurance rose last year by 852,000, to 4.9 million.
The Census Bureau said that 8.1 percent of these higher-income households were uninsured last year, up from 7.6 percent in 1996. Economists said that many of these people were probably self-employed or worked for small businesses that did not provide coverage.
The number of poor people without insurance stayed about the same, 11.2 million. Nearly one-third of all poor people -- 31.6 percent -- were uninsured last year, about the same as in 1996.
The Government said that more than one of every five people was uninsured last year in six states: Texas, Arizona, Arkansas, New Mexico, California and Mississippi. By contrast, Hawaii, Wisconsin, Minnesota and Vermont had the highest rates of coverage, with fewer than 10 percent of their residents uninsured.
Expanding coverage has been a top priority for President Clinton since he took office in 1993. Since his proposal for universal health insurance died in September 1994, he has announced dozens of initiatives to achieve that goal. But he has been unable to stop the erosion in coverage, and Congress, which has passed several laws to provide health benefits in recent years, appears unlikely to do more in the near future.
Administration officials maintain that the situation would be even worse without their efforts to guarantee coverage for children and for workers who change or lose jobs.
Mr. Clinton has ordered Federal officials to redouble efforts to locate children who are eligible for Medicaid but who are not enrolled. Republicans and insurance companies, which helped to kill Mr. Clinton's plan in 1994, say they want to create new tax breaks to help people buy private insurance, but Congress has had difficulty finding the money to pay for such incentives.
The Census Bureau said that 10.7 million children were uninsured last year, about the same number as in 1996. Because of Medicare, nearly all people 65 and older have insurance coverage. So it was people 18 to 64 years old who accounted for the increase in the uninsured.
People 18 to 24 years old are least likely to have coverage, the bureau said. Thirty percent of these young adults were uninsured last year, up from 28.9 percent in 1996.
Hispanic Americans had the highest chance of being uninsured. Thirty-four percent of Hispanic people lacked insurance last year, compared with 21.5 percent of blacks and 12 percent of non-Hispanic whites.
The Census Bureau had been planning to issue a report on the data on Monday. But the raw data were posted on the Internet on Thursday. Physicians for a National Health Program, a small organization of doctors, tabulated and analyzed the data and issued its findings today.
"What's startling is the magnitude of the increase when the economy was booming," said Dr. Steffie Woolhandler, a co-founder of the organization. The group advocates universal access to health care.
Census officials and health policy experts suggested several reasons for the rising number of uninsured:
* Welfare rolls have been shrinking for several years. People on welfare automatically get Medicaid. But when they leave welfare, they often take low-paying jobs with no health benefits. These workers or their children may still be eligible for Medicaid, but they do not realize it.
* Small businesses are creating most of the nation's new jobs. But these businesses are far less likely than big companies to provide health insurance.
* Health care and insurance costs are on the rise. Cost is the reason most often cited, by individuals and employers, for not buying insurance.
Diane Rowland, executive director of the Kaiser Commission on Medicaid and the Uninsured, said: "We are in a time of transition and turmoil in welfare. While many states are trying to simplify Medicaid enrollment procedures, there are still many barriers. Caseworkers seem to be under greater pressure to find people jobs than to assure they have health insurance coverage."
New York City has begun inspecting the homes of some people who apply for Medicaid, to see if they misrepresented their income, assets or living arrangements. Some advocates for the poor say it is one more obstacle to getting health insurance.
Ms. Rowland said that changes in welfare and immigration law had deterred some people from applying for Medicaid. "Noncitizens often shy away from enrolling in Medicaid," she said. "And noncitizen parents may be reluctant to seek Medicaid even for children who were born in this country and are eligible for Medicaid as citizens."
The Census Bureau's report is based on interviews with 50,000 households chosen to be representative of the nation as a whole.
The Government said that 43.3 percent of the poor were covered by Medicaid at some time last year, down from 45.5 percent in 1996.
Many poor people do not qualify for Medicaid. Many states set income limits far below the poverty level. Childless adults are often ineligible even if they have very low incomes.
The Census Bureau found that the number of people with employer-sponsored health insurance rose last year, to 165.1 million, from 163.2 million in 1996. More people are working, and employers may be providing health benefits for some of those workers, even as they eliminate benefits for some dependents.
