Hedge Fund's Risks Studied
Long-Term Capital Management, the big hedge fund rescued with a $3.5 billion infusion by a consortium of Wall Street banks this week, made complex bets on international financial markets with a total value considerably higher than previously estimated, said financiers who studied its books. They said that at the end of August the firm had about $2.2 billion in capital. SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1212 words

HEADLINE: Fiscal Stones, Glass Houses: Bailout Points Finger at U.S.

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
If there has been a single refrain as economic shock waves rolled around the world for the last year, it is the importance of spotting and addressing financial risks before they get out of control.
But after a year of demands from the United States that Asia strengthen banking supervision and provide better information to investors, after unheeded warnings to Russia about the demanding discipline of the markets, the fall of a hedge fund suggests that the Treasury Department, the Federal Reserve and other regulators nearly missed a potentially big problem at home. 
 Right under the noses of the same people who were dispensing advice to the rest of the world, smack in the middle of the best-supervised, best-capitalized, most open financial markets in the world, a single firm, Long-Term Capital Management L.P., was making bets so big that when they went wrong they threatened to destabilize the whole system.
No one really knows what other problems might arise on Wall Street and ripple through the economy as the global crisis hits the United States with greater force.
"We are less vulnerable than any other nation in the world by a huge margin," said Roger C. Altman, a former Deputy Treasury Secretary. "But we are nonetheless vulnerable.
"None of us knows for sure whether there is another problem in this volatile environment which could rear its ugly head soon, and it might not be a hedge fund but something else," Mr. Altman said.
"Long-Term Capital Management happened to be a hedge fund. But the real point was that its failure was judged to be unacceptable, and that there's so much complexity and leverage in the global financial system that events like this can occur."
The chairman of the House Banking Committee, Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, said today that he would hold hearings in the next week or two to explore the economic and regulatory issues raised by Long-Term Capital Management's troubles.
"Questions exist as to whether appropriate national and international supervision exists and whether funds designed to hedge risk for individual participants create risk to the system as a whole," Mr. Leach said.
In some ways, the regulatory system worked just as it should. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in its role as monitor of the financial markets, caught signals several weeks ago that Long-Term Capital was in trouble. This week it brought together a group of Wall Street powerhouses to assemble a rescue that averted a marketwide problem without calling on taxpayer money.
"This is how the situation should have played out, given our current regime," said Bert Ely, a consultant to the financial services industry. "However, and this is where the average citizen should be concerned, it raises public policy questions about how this got out of control the way it did."
To some extent, the answer lies in the complex nature of the trading done by Long-Term Capital and other investment firms and banks. Not only are some of their trades so complex that they are truly understood by only a relative handful of people, but the strategies employed by Long-Term Capital and other firms are closely guarded secrets.
The hedge fund industry operates largely outside the scope of traditional bank and securities regulators, and relies on money borrowed from a variety of sources, including commercial banks, which to some degree are gambling with federally insured deposits.
George Soros, perhaps the best-known hedge fund operator, described the industry in Congressional testimony this month as "a daisy chain with many intermediaries, and each intermediary has an obligation to his counterparties without knowing who else is involved."
Mr. Soros's appearance before the House Banking Committee on Sept. 15 came more than a week before Long-Term Capital's problems became public.
But his firm was almost certainly aware of the developing difficulties at Long-Term Capital -- Mr. Soros was approached earlier this month about providing financial help -- and his description on Capitol Hill of the brewing problems in the market proved prescient.
After Russia's debt default rocked stock and bond markets around the world last month, "many hedge funds and other speculative accounts sustained large enough losses that they had to be liquidated," he said. "Normal spreads were disrupted, and professionals who arbitrage between various derivatives, that is to say, trade one derivative against another, also sustained large losses."
As a result, he said, banks were "frantically trying to limit their exposure, de-leverage and reduce risk," setting off a shortage of credit that was hurting developing nations and beginning to squeeze the United States.
With hindsight, the brewing problems at Long-Term Capital were no doubt a factor in the increasingly explicit hints from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and William J. McDonough, the president of the New York Fed, that the central bank might soon reduce interest rates. Mr. Greenspan mentioned during Congressional testimony on Wednesday that increasing disruptions to the financial system were one reason why easier monetary policy might soon be justified.
Indeed, having focused for the last year on Asia's problems, policy makers in the United States are well aware of how the bursting of Japan's financial bubble in the early 1990's and the subsequent credit shortage there have stunted the world's second-largest economy. For the last two years, Mr. Greenspan has been making the case that the Fed must be concerned with big swings in financial markets as well as prices as it sets interest rate policy, an approach that seems increasingly justified with each new tremor to hit Wall Street.
Still, Mr. Greenspan has always been reluctant to impose more heavy-handed regulation on complex securities known as derivatives, commonly used by hedge funds in trading strategies. He has argued that banks and other financial institutions are better positioned than auditors or regulators to determine the worth and risk of the securities they hold and finance.
But Mr. Greenspan and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin have been warning for months about the perils of lenders becoming too sanguine about risk. In the case of Long-Term Capital, it quickly became clear that some of the world's biggest and most sophisticated banks and investment houses had little if any idea what bets were made with the money they lent. And it raised anew the question of whether the regulatory approach to hedge funds is adequate today.
Many hedge funds operate under an exemption in the Investment Company Act of 1940. The exemption was intended to allow family businesses that invest in securities to avoid Federal regulation. The exemption covered pools of money that had fewer than 100 investors and that did not offer shares to the general public.
Funds can also be incorporated offshore and not allow Americans to invest, thus escaping Federal Government jurisdiction. Or hedge funds can operate under a 1996 amendment to the Federal securities laws that exempts from regulation funds limited to fewer than 500 "sophisticated" institutions or individuals -- those that invest more than $25 million or $5 million, respectively.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fallen Hedge Fund's Bets Are Put at $1.25 Trillion
Long-Term Capital Management made complex bets on international financial markets with a total value drastically higher than previously estimated, financiers who studied its books said yesterday. They said the fund used its $2.2 billion in capital from investors as collateral to buy $125 billion in securities, and then used those securities as collateral to enter into exotic transactions worth $1.25 trillion.
The portfolio had been previously estimated at $90 billion. The size of the fund's portfolio is extraordinary even in the world of hedge funds. How and why Long-Term Capital was able to make such astonishing bets remains unclear. Page A1.
 
The 16 partners of Long-Term Capital still appear to be sitting on gains in their original investments in the hedge fund they managed despite the fund's near-collapse. C3. 

Hopes of a Rate Cut Lift Stocks
Stocks reversed early losses to rally on optimism that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates next week, which offset concern that banks will report more losses on hedge fund investments. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 26.78, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,028.77, to end a roller-coaster week that left the average 1.7 percent higher. The Standard & Poor's 500 gained 2.05, or two-tenths of a percent, to 1,044.77. The Nasdaq composite index rose 23.33, or 1.4 percent, to 1,743.67. C3.
 
Treasury prices ended higher, pushing the yield on the benchmark 30-year issue to 5.12 percent from 5.16. C3.
 
F.D.A. Clears Breast Cancer Drug
The Food and Drug Administration approved Herceptin, a genetically engineered drug developed by Genentech, for the treatment of advanced breast cancer. A12.
 
Reports Show Economic Strength
Home resales declined last month but remained near a record level, while consumer spending rebounded. Economists said the latest data indicated the impact of Asia's financial crisis on the United States has remained muted so far. C14.
 
House Rejects 'Fast Track' Bill
A bill that would give President Clinton enhanced authority to negotiate trade agreements, or "fast track" powers, was defeated by the House of Representatives. A9.
 
Cautious Optimism In Latin America
Outflows of capital appear to be slowing from stock markets in Latin America, and Wall Street analysts attribute the change to signs that world lenders are preparing to rescue Brazil from a potential financial collapse. But the cautious optimism could evaporate if Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, loses the election an Oct. 4 or reneges on promises of fiscal austerity in Latin America's most important economy. C2.
 
NASA Contract for Lockheed
Lockheed Martin said it had won a $3.44 billion, 10-year contract to run NASA's space operations, beating out Boeing. Lockheed's initial contract is valued at $1.9 billion over five years, with options for another five years totaling $1.54 billion. C3.
 
Number of Uninsured Grows
Despite a strong economy, the number of Americans without health insurance rose 1.7 percent last year, to 43.4 million, the largest increase since 1992. A1.
 
Kremlin's Thirst for Vodka
Russia's new Prime Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, is preparing to reassert state control over key parts of the vodka industry, terminated when President Boris N. Yeltsin ended the Government's vodka monopoly in May 1992 and now rampant with corruption. The change, if it is successful, would re-establish something akin to the vodka industry of the old Soviet days and provide the state with a badly needed source of income. A4.

HEADLINE: In the Dominican Republic, Widespread Desolation After the Storm

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 25

 BODY:
The official death toll from Hurricane Georges in the Dominican Republic rose to more than 210 today. At least 800 other people were missing and feared dead, largely in hard-hit provinces east of the capital here, while rescue workers struggled to reach villages isolated by floods and mudslides.
With food and water stocks running perilously low, relief teams from the United States and France joined Dominican officials in trying to feed the hungry and thirsty survivors of the hurricane, which destroyed 90 percent of the nation's crops as it cut a deadly path through the island of Hispaniola on Tuesday. 
 At least half the houses in the eastern provinces were said to have been destroyed or severely damaged by the storm, with more than 300,000 people forced out of their homes and into public shelters.
A state of emergency already in place, President Leonel Fernandez appealed for international assistance and warned the more than eight million people in his country's that it might be six weeks before electrical power could be restored.
"In a word, the picture is one of desolation," Mr. Fernandez said after visiting devastated areas. The President calculated damage to the nation's electrical system alone at more than $100 million
Tourist resorts like Casa de Campo were also badly hit, Government officials said, as were the nation's three principal airports on the southern coast, including Las Americas International Airport, outside Santo Domingo.
"The problem there is not the tarmac, but the terminal" and control tower, both of which were heavily damaged, Bernardo Vega, the Dominican Ambassador to the United States, said this afternoon.
Villages north of of Santo Domingo became islands surrounded by miles of muddy water, and victims frantically waved as rescue aircraft flew overhead.
Eight hundred people swarmed around a Dominican Air Force helicopter when it tried to land today on an island in the town of Matamomon. Its three-man crew kicked off desperate people trying to climb aboard, and tossed food rations to those screaming on the ground below.
Food and water stocks ran perilously low after the hurricane struck here on Tuesday night with winds of 110 miles per hour.
"In the shelters people are hungry, thirsty and in bad conditions sanitary-wise," said Rodger Garner, a program officer for the United States Agency for International Development. "The food stocks will be used up pretty quickly."
A United States Air Force C-130 cargo plane landed in Santo Domingo with enough plastic tarpaulins to roof 2,000 houses. Sixty-three search-and-rescue firefighters from New York were being flown in, while a French C-130 also delivered disaster specialists, food and medical aid.
Paul Bell, regional disaster relief director for the Agency for International Development, said it was the first of an extensive airlift of food and other aid. Mr. Bell warned that people sick with water-borne diseases like dengue fever "will overload the hospital system, which was never very good anyway."
Hispaniola is an impoverished island of 15 million people shared by Haiti and the Dominican Republic, and its substandard housing could not stand up to the winds and flooding, the primary cause of most deaths.
In Santo Domingo, shelters opened only as the storm was about to hit. In Haiti, the Western Hemisphere's poorest nation, denuded mountains and unmaintained drainage systems were blamed for widespread floods.
At least 87 bodies have been recovered in Haiti, but the authorities there fear that the death toll could grow as they moved into poverty-stricken rural areas where the concept of civil defense does not exist and people live in flimsy shacks made of wood or cardboard.
Most of Haiti's hillsides have been deforested by people in need of fuel, which increases the possibility of mudslides and inundations. In the wake of the storm, there were also fears that epidemics of cholera and typhoid could break out and that swollen rivers could overflow their banks and deluge the fertile Artibonite Valley, which grows much of Haiti's food.
Twenty miles north of the Santo Domingo, treetops, stripped of foliage, poked above the brown, muddy water. At some points the flooding was miles wide.
Outside the capital, gun-toting guards and several hundred inmates stood on the roof of the pentagon-shaped La Victoria prison, most of which was underwater.
Throughout Santo Domingo, thousands of people stood in long lines for water, and many filled their jugs from the debris-filled Ozama River.
"There's no water, there's no power," said Domingo Osvaldo Fortuna, 51, as he filled a jug with river water. "There is nothing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Guards and inmates stood on the roof of the flooded La Victoria prison near Santo Domingo yesterday as the Dominican Republic's official death toll from Hurricane Georges topped 130. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Postings: Skyscraper Museum's New Exhibit, at 16 Wall Street;
'Building the Empire State'

 BODY:
With one exception (a certain tall structure at Fifth Avenue and 34th Street), there would seem to be no better place for the Skyscraper Museum to hold a show on the Empire State Building than in the former banking hall at 16 Wall Street, which was designed by the same architects, Shreve, Lamb & Harmon.
Opening Thursday, the show will use photos, schedules and a job diary to document the extraordinarily swift construction of the 1,252-foot Empire State Building, from April 7, 1930, to March 1, 1931 -- less time than it would take today to prepare an environmental impact statement on the project. 
 The world's tallest building was a tough act to follow. And Shreve, Lamb & Harmon did not exactly outdo themselves a year later with 16 Wall Street, a 25-story annex to the Bankers Trust Building.
But they did create a grandly modernist banking hall: a forest of squared-off, trunk-like columns clad in Oregon myrtle, as rich in color as roasted coffee beans. The T-shaped, 10,000-square-foot room extends to Pine Street. The woodwork resembles fine cabinetry and the columns soar 27 feet to a coved ceiling.
"I'm very pleased to be there and a bit intimidated," said Carol Willis, the founder, director and curator of the museum. The two-year-old organization has no permanent home and must borrow its exhibition space -- in this case, from the Chase Manhattan Bank, which moved out of 16 Wall Street in July.
Chase has donated the banking hall for use by the Skyscraper Museum through March 1999. The bank's lease runs through the end of 2004 and it is now looking for a subtenant. "Ideally, we would market it intact to a financial service-type user," said James Walker, an assistant vice president at Chase.
Both the pyramid-topped original Bankers Trust Building, 14 Wall Street, and its annex are landmarks. The designation does not cover the interior.
The show will be open Tuesdays through Saturdays, 12 to 6 P.M. Admission will be free in October, with a $2 suggested donation thereafter.
As a companion piece, W. W. Norton & Company has published "Building the Empire State," edited by Ms. Willis, which reproduces a fastidiously detailed 77-page scrapbook kept by the contractor, Starrett Brothers & Eken. The scrapbook came from the files of Starrett's corporate successor, H R H Construction.
The typewritten log is filled with marvelous arcana: the 250,000 square feet of terrazzo floors required 45 tons of brass for expansion joints and 15,000 bags of marble chips from Italy (Botticino), Belgium (Belgian black) and Maryland (Cardiff green).
But it also concerns itself with serious controversies, such as rumors and press reports implying that "adequate protection of human life was entirely disregarded in the feverish anxiety of all concerned in the project to establish a record for speed."
While denying the charge, the anonymous author noted that seven people lost their lives: three carpenters, two laborers, an ironworker and a pedestrian, Elizabeth Eagher, who died of blood poisoning after her ankle was fractured by a falling plank in July 1930.
The scrapbook ends wondering how long the tower will stand. "Perhaps it will live on to see old Empires crumble," it concludes. "Or, perhaps, the rapidly changing economic conditions of a new era will precipitate its destruction sooner than we care to anticipate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Empire State Building in late 1930. (The Skyscraper Museum)

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 10; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1161 words

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
One Lawmaker's Ideas on Peeling Away Layers of Redundant Services

BYLINE: By RICHARD TRENNER

 BODY:
In her quest for consolidation of municipal services, Governor Whitman may find an unexpected ally in a prominent Democrat who once sought his party's nomination for governor.
Alan J. Karcher, a former speaker of the New Jersey Assembly who is an ardent advocate of municipal consolidation, believes "the costs of maintaining New Jersey's multiple and redundant jurisdictions mount into the billions of dollars." 
 Mr. Karcher, a 55-year-old Princeton resident who represented Middlesex County in the Legislature for 17 years before retiring in 1990, has just completed a book, "New Jersey's Multiple Municipal Madness," (Rutgers University Press, 1998) in which he proposes that many of the state's 566 municipalities be shown the door.
Marc Mappen, a historian at Rutgers University and co-editor of the forthcoming Encyclopedia of New Jersey, summarizes Mr. Karcher's message this way: "We have a big problem in our state. It hits you in the wallet by producing high property taxes and bureaucratic inefficiency. It lurks behind the godawful suburban sprawl that destroys the environment and plagues your commute to work with traffic jams, and it is why our cities are dying. The problem is balkanization."
Clearing away the layers of fiefdoms, Mr. Karcher writes, would not only help Mrs. Whitman achieve her goal of lower property taxes, but also alleviate problems in several other important areas ranging from the state's public education system, which he calls "an abysmal failure," to post-1950 development characterized by "tawdry strip malls, ticky-tacky suburban subdivisions, and abandoned factories surrounded by battle-scarred ghettos."
Put another way -- or as Mr. Mappen observes, with "cynicism, sarcasm and humor," -- Mr. Karcher likens the state's jurisdictional outlines to "a web woven by a spider on LSD."
A key theme of Mr. Karcher is that the motives for creating so many municipalities, largely in the 19th century, were usually "petty, personal" and, by today's standards, politically incorrect.
To drive this home, Mr. Karcher does a good deal of storytelling about town origins. He recounts, for example, how the Borough of Florham Park, in Morris County, instantly became the richest town with the lowest tax rate in the United States when, in 1899, it was split off from Chatham Township for the benefit of two wealthy landowners. Their aim was to reduce the taxes on the roughly seven square miles that their estates jointly occupied.
About 85 years earlier, New Jersey's first borough -- Princeton Borough -- was created, Mr. Karcher writes, "for easier control of alcohol consumption and repression of African-Americans." Indeed, he sees the creation of local jurisdictions as having been, until the advent of zoning in the 1920's, a popular tool for segregating people along economic, class and racial lines.
A related theme is that whatever the original motives behind New Jersey's "multiple municipal madness," they are largely irrelevant today. "When are we going to acknowledge," he writes, "that we have too long tolerated a municipal framework that represents the opposite of everything this century has learned about effective management, efficient control, economy of scale?"
Although Mr. Karcher says that the basic purpose of his book is to diagnose problems rather than to prescribe remedies, he does make clear his belief that consolidation -- presumably the chief antidote to balkanization -- offers many benefits. He also presents various consolidation scenarios.
He recently estimated that $3 billion to $5 billion could be saved each year by eliminating many smaller municipal redundancies in the areas of education, public safety, and similar services. He also suggests that with consolidation, the "ratables chase," a leading cause of urban decay and suburban sprawl, would become much less seductive to many towns.
The urban-suburban tug-of-war and land use patterns have long concerned Mr. Karcher, according to Karen Jezierny, an assistant dean at Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs and an aide to Mr. Karcher in the Assembly. "He has been a visionary" in terms of regional planning and the need to counter the further division of New Jersey into prosperous suburbs and poor cities, Ms. Jezierny said.
In terms of consolidation scenarios, Mr. Karcher describes two basic types: voluntary and mandatory. The voluntary approach relies on incentives provided by the state to encourage consolidation of municipal services and boundaries.
While he recently commented that Mrs. Whitman has "probably spoken more and done more on this issue than any other governor since the Depression," he called her voluntary approach to consolidation "timid." The state "should create a whole spectrum of incentives" and in fact it "has the power to effectuate the greatest possible incentive of all: a uniform property tax rate."
Believing that the state's constitution renders home rule "a delusion," Mr. Karcher writes that the state "could begin to force consolidations, even without incentives for municipalities." Using a mandatory approach, consolidation could, he says, be phased in over several years, with the aim of halving the number of jurisdictions.
Mr. Karcher's book will not appear until November, but word of it has already begun to generate comment. Henry A. Coleman, the director of the Center for Government Services at Rutgers, and his predecessor, Ernest C. Reock Jr., said recently that they agreed with some of Mr. Karcher points but disagree with others.
Mr. Coleman said that while New Jersey has many more local jurisdictions than one would probably expect in such a small state, economists are still debating whether the number of jurisdictions is superfluous.
"People tend to believe that having a high number of jurisdictions leads to excessive local spending," Mr. Coleman said. "But we don't really know the optimal size for a local unit of government in order for it to be efficient or to generate the right degree of competition with other units."
While agreeing that some jurisdictions came about "for class and racial reasons," Mr. Coleman is skeptical about Mr. Karcher's emphasis on the "ratable chase" as a problem unique to having a large number of municipalities. If jurisdictions have access to only one main source of revenue, property taxes, the ratable chase will be a problem, Mr. Coleman said, "no matter how many jurisdictions there are."
Mr. Reock commented that data do not support Mr. Karcher's estimate of savings in the billions, even from massive consolidation. And both critics questioned the political feasibility of bringing about widespread consolidation.
Anticipating criticism, Mr. Karcher said he takes comfort in his sense that the main purpose of his book is to inspire debate about a problem with deep historical roots and serious ramifications yet is recognized by few New Jerseyans.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Former Assembly Speaker Alan J. Karcher says overlapping fiefdoms are responsible for "tawdry strip malls, ticky-tacky suburban subdivisions, and abandoned factories." (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Moody's Raises Ratings On Some State Bonds

BYLINE: By KIRSTY SUCATO

 BODY:
Moody's Investors Service has upgraded ratings for New Jersey's $7.45 billion appropriation debt, bonds that must be reauthorized by the Legislature each year, saying a strong economy and a reliance on the bonds for important capital projects make the state less likely to default, state officials announced last week.
The upgrades, on bonds issued by several state authorities, each came in one-notch increments. For example, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority's $456 million debt rose from an Aa to an Aa3 rating, while New Jersey Transit Corporation's $348 million bond issue moved from Aa3 to Aa2, three steps below the highest rating of Aaa. 
 Higher ratings mean the state will probably pay lower interest rates on future bond issues, said James M. Petrino, the assistant director of public finance in the State Department of the Treasury.
The rating for New Jersey's $3.57 general obligation debt, bonds authorized by voters, remained unchanged at Aa1, but Moody's revised its outlook from negative to stable. KIRSTY SUCATO

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Full-Time Mothers Meet Part-Time Jobs

BYLINE: By JULIA LAWLOR 

 BODY:
ON a typical school day in Mill Valley, Calif., Paula Reynolds rises at 5:30 A.M., gets her two oldest children out the door by 7:45 and hops into the car to follow her youngest as he navigates his bike down the hill to school. Then she commutes to work to San Francisco, 45 minutes away. Five hectic hours later, she heads back home in time to greet her children -- Peter, 12; Julia, 9, and Charlie, 6 -- at the door at 3 P.M.
"My kids are at an age where they want to be with me more than anybody else," said Ms. Reynolds, 43, the co-owner of a firm that supplies temporary executives to corporations. So she works a 26-hour week, guaranteeing that she will have some afternoon hours with her children. "I'll have plenty of time later to develop my career," she said. 
 Ms. Reynolds has resolved to her satisfaction the great quandary of the working Mom -- how to balance the demands of her job with the tugging at her heart. But the conundrum stymies millions of women, and not a few men, anew each fall as the school year begins.The job -- and the desire to advance -- beckon. But who will greet young children at the end of the day? Older children might be able to fend for themselves, but shouldn't somebody be there prodding them to do their homework or driving them to soccer practice?
For most women, quitting their jobs is not an option; they simply cannot afford the loss of income. Many of those part-time positions being advertised in the newspaper -- as bank tellers, school aides or store clerks -- pay pittances. And despite all the talk at corporations these days about family-friendly workplaces, asking the boss for a reduced work schedule often gets a frosty reception.
Ms. Reynolds found that out in 1986, when she asked her manager in the sales division of the AT&T Corporation if she could cut back on her hours to spend more time with her infant son. The answer was no. So she quit and founded her company, M Squared, with another mother.
But for the vast majority of working women, who don't own businesses, the task can be much trickier.
More people than ever want to escape the confines of the traditional workweek. In a survey of 2,877 employees last year by the Families and Work Institute, based in New York, 63 percent said they would like to reduce the number of hours they worked, up from 47 percent in 1992. Seventy percent of working parents say they did not have enough time to spend with their children.
But the study also showed that many workers felt that it would be difficult to move to shorter hours. Only 38 percent of full-timers said "yes" or "maybe" when asked if they could arrange a part-time schedule, while 58 percent of part-timers gave those answers when asked if they could switch to full-time.
 PART-TIME work is especially rare among managers. A survey of 2,000 managers and professionals in four companies last year by Catalyst, a New York firm that consults with businesses on women's issues, found that just 11 percent of the women and 4 percent of the men worked part-time, compared with 21 percent and 8 percent, respectively, for all working women and men.
Although more than 60 percent of large employers offer part-time work, according to Hewitt Associates, a benefits consulting firm, there are very few takers among the full-time staff, and for good reason. Part-time work, of course, generally comes with no health insurance, paid vacations, sick days or other benefits.
And many managers believe it is difficult to manage a staff that has varying part-time schedules. "People don't widely use these policies because there's a general sense that they don't work," said Marcia Brumit Kropf, a vice president at Catalyst.
Many corporate cultures continue to put more value on "face time," or the number of hours a worker stays in the office, than on the work product. And workers who switch to part-time schedules risk being viewed as less committed to their work.
There are also days when part-timers feel inadequate both at work and home and wonder if all the juggling is worth it. "Sometimes, I feel like I have the best of all worlds; sometimes I feel like I'm not doing anything well," Ms. Reynolds said. Her dual responsibilities have so crowded her life that her colleagues once bought her a "Where's Waldo?" book for Christmas, pasted a little picture of Ms. Reynolds over Waldo's face, and retitled it "Where's Paula?"
Linda Lindmeier, 42, a lab technician who has held a series of temporary jobs for nine years through Manpower, the temporary help company, thinks she would have been promoted to a management position by now had she stayed with one employer. But Ms. Lindmeier, of Wadsworth, Ill., has always wanted to work a 7 A.M.-to-3:30 P.M. shift and have summers off with her children, now 15 and 13.
"I grew up in a small town on a lake where we'd spend all summer hanging out," she said. "I wanted my kids to have summers off like I did, and not to be in day care 12 months a year."
True, she sometimes feels a pang of jealousy about her husband's paycheck, which equaled hers when the couple was childless but is now four times hers. Still, she cannot imagine giving up summers of swimming and bike-riding.
"I've gotten so darned used to this," she said, "I don't think I'll ever go back to full-time."

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM: JAMES SCHEMBARI;
Can a Generation Learn to Share?

BYLINE: By James Schembari; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years will appear the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to
jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
ON graduation day, during that walk to the auditorium to return our caps and gowns, giddy about the future, were we ever so confident as to imagine that we'd be where we are now? That we'd have lucrative jobs, full retirement accounts and nice homes soaring in value?
An American living in Geneva told me last summer, after I marveled about his city, that, yes, it was lovely, but that "I wish we had your economy." A few days later, a Paris businessman told me the same thing. 
 America's baby boomers are indeed fortunate. But what are we doing with our good fortune? What good have we done? There are moral issues involved in such plenty, and there is evidence that we are not responding as we could. How do we measure up, say, to our parents' generation when it comes to philanthropy?
"You Americans are very generous," my friend in Paris said, "but you are so . . . " He stopped, not knowing the English word. He spoke in French to another person at the table, who then turned to me and said, "clumsy."
Still probably not the right word, but the image of falling down was clear.
It is estimated that since the bull market began, stocks have created about $8 trillion of wealth. Money is now the national sport. We chat about our investments, show off our new kitchens, our Range Rovers. Even as the market sputters, there seems to be no limit to what we can have or do.
"It is the first time in history that the phrase 'we can't afford it,' cannot honestly be used to determine choices of consumption in a family," said Paul G. Schervish, director of the Social Welfare Research Institute at Boston College. "Affluence opens up the opportunity for charitable giving. But it also opens up the opportunity to buy a second home and then say, 'I don't have enough for charity.' "
So while no one says boomers lack hearts, there is concern that they are not approaching philanthropy with the same passion as consumption.
One measure of philanthropy is the percentage of personal income given to charity. In the mid-1960's, when many boomers' parents were in their 40's, it was 2.2 percent. Now it is 1.9 percent. And surveys show that giving by high-income people is not increasing as quickly as wealth.
But even if the boomers are close to their parents in giving, close somehow seems so inadequate in the midst of so much wealth.
"The baby boomers' parents were happy with a two-bedroom cottage and one-car garage," said Sara Melendez, president of Independent Sector, an association of nonprofit groups. "Now it's, 'How many TV sets do we have?'
"Baby boomers are at the peak of their earnings," she added, "and certainly when you are making more than you ever have before, that is the time to give more."
That sounds like our parents, prodding us to finish the food on our plates. "There are children starving in China," my mother would say. Of course, now there are schools that have been forced to hold classes in bathrooms. And that's in New York.
It's hard not to see the point. I've always warded off guilt with the feeling that I've been generous. I write checks to charity, and I volunteer at my church. But I took a harder look when I began researching this column. I do volunteer work for six hours a month, every other month. That's less than an hour a week. Those checks I write come out to 2.4 percent of my income, above the national average but still below what I know I can afford.
Why? I share the fears of many other people about the future: How will I ever have enough for my children's college education? My retirement?
But I've never asked the questions from the heart: Do I really need my three cars? Did I really need to renovate the bathroom? Should I have gone to the Poconos instead of to Paris this summer?
 VIRGINIA HODGKINSON, a research professor of public policy at Georgetown University, says that until the pressures of college and retirement are relieved, boomers probably will not increase their giving. But history suggests that they will change someday.
The most generous givers tend to be 65 to 74 years old, donating almost 4 percent of their incomes. So charities have their fingers crossed, hoping that the boomers, blessed with so much, will eventually arrive on the other side of their economic worries and do one great thing.
"The first wave of the baby boom has the capacity to engage in philanthropy like no previous generation," Dr. Hodgkinson said. That will happen, she said, when they realize how much has piled up in their 401(k)'s. "That's the moment when we need to ask this generation about their obligation to future generations."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
In Paris, a Wall Street Veteran Argues the Case for Laissez-Faire

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
FRANCE has been governed by the Socialists for the entire year that Felix G. Rohatyn has been the United States Ambassador in Paris. So Mr. Rohatyn, the former Lazard Freres partner who oversaw the rescue of New York City from the brink of bankruptcy in the 1970's, has spent a lot of time trying to explain American "popular capitalism" to the French.
"What I mean is a highly advanced market system in a democratic country, with large participation by the population in the ownership of capital assets, coupled with an active and intelligent Government that provides an advanced social safety net and sophisticated regulatory systems, in a law-abiding culture," Mr. Rohatyn said. 
 "The idea that we have casino capitalism in the States, and no social protection, is very widespread here. It has negative effects not only on us but in terms of policies that might help the French economy."
This is a man who spent most of his adult life on Wall Street, and who knows that up is not the only direction markets can move. Back in July, he told a French audience that "someday, markets are likely to turn down, and popular capitalism will encounter some difficult moments."
"Well, here we are," he laughed the other day in the Ambassador's residence, a palace with a back garden as big as President Jacques Chirac's just down the street.
Mr. Rohatyn and his wife, Elizabeth, prefer quiet dinners incognito at unpretentious bistros like Quincy, near the Gare de Lyon, or Chez Tante Louise, near the residence, to black-tie functions in official surroundings.
"I've never lost the feeling that somehow I don't belong, or that if I belong it's only because of the intervention of fate," he reflected, as if at 70 he could somehow still be blacklisted by French society.
His life has taught him respect for adversity. He acquired his perfect French as a boy at the Lycee Janson-de-Sailly in Paris from 1937 to 1940, after his family, all Polish Jews, came here from Vienna to get away from the Nazis. They fled again in May 1940, when the Germans invaded France.
"Our driver tried to take my mother, her mother-in-law, our old Polish cook and me across the border into Spain, but all the roads were closed," he recalled. "We decided we'd at least be better off in the part of France that wasn't occupied by the Germans. When we turned a corner in the woods we came to a German checkpoint, and it didn't take much imagination to see what was probably going to happen."
Fate did intervene. "The German turned and lit up a cigarette after waving through the car in front of us. My mother held her driver's license up at the window, and he let us through without checking our papers. I was 12 at the time. A year later they were deporting people, including children, to Auschwitz from occupied France."
The family eventually made its way to Casablanca and from there, by boat, to the United States, where Mr. Rohatyn would later go into finance and find success.
But it is only recently that Mr. Rohatyn has felt able to revisit the happier moments of his own past here and seek out a few former classmates from his old school.
Now, as he looks at the world, he sees Washington preoccupied with scandal and economies in grave trouble in Russia, Asia and elsewhere. "I believe President Clinton's call for a conference of foreign ministers to review the current state of the financial system is a welcome response to current concerns," he said, adding that it "will offset the eroding confidence which is beginning to paralyze the world."
Mr. Rohatyn now acknowledges that "popular capitalism" might not be the right answer for every country at every stage of development, and he thinks European countries will probably always prefer a wider social safety net than Americans do. But he tells visiting Americans to look at steps that the Socialist Prime Minister of France, Lionel Jospin, has taken toward privatization of state-owned aviation, military and banking companies.
The French and American business communities could learn a lot more from each other if they had a forum for exchanging ideas, he said, so he has started the French-American Business Council.
Over the years, Mr. Rohatyn's activities gave him hundreds of close contacts in French business and financial circles. "I first met a lot of these guys in the early 1980's, when France was nationalizing companies and imposing credit controls," he said. "There's been incredible change since.
"France is one of the major foreign investors in the United States, with almost 350,000 Americans working for French companies, and similar numbers for American investment in France," Mr. Rohatyn explained. "Companies like Compagnie de Saint-Gobain in glass and Danone in food products have a big presence in the States. Here, you have companies like I.B.M., Hewlett-Packard, Motorola, Procter & Gamble, Coca-Cola -- but there was no forum for them to dialogue with each other.
"I started talking last fall to a few people on both sides -- Dana Mead, chairman of Tenneco; George David at United Technologies, Jean-Louis Beffa at Saint-Gobain, Antoine Riboud at Danone, and others. And last June, when Mr. Jospin went to Washington on a working visit, he and President Clinton attended the first meeting of the council in the Executive Office Building, with about 50 C.E.O.'s in attendance."
On that occasion, Mr. Jospin said he and others in France had underestimated the ability of the low-tax, free-market American economy to produce hundreds of thousands of permanent, high-paying jobs -- instead of just the low-paying, fast-food jobs that so many intellectuals here had derided whenever anyone suggested that France should follow America's lead. Crushing welfare-state tax burdens and labor regulations are often blamed for France's failure to reduce unemployment, which is at 11.8 percent even after years of economic expansion.
Mr. Rohatyn, whose business background often makes him chafe at governmental inertia, looks for ways in which an ambassador can make a difference. His latest tilt at the bureaucratic windmills is an effort to increase the official American presence in the French regions outside the capital, where most American assets are today. His plan calls for setting up simple "American presence posts," a sort of miniature consulate with a staff of two or three people. The first is expected to open shortly in Lyons; Mr. Rohatyn hopes to add others in Lille, Toulouse, Bordeaux and Rennes.
That would be satisfying, but not quite like arranging a billion-dollar leveraged buyout. "I don't yearn to be back making deals, but what I used to do always had a beginning, a middle and an end," he said. "This is more like a continuum. It's never clear when you've actually accomplished something."

HEADLINE: The Tourist Trap;
With All Those Visitors Trampling the Welcome Mat, Can New York Be the Host With the Most for Everyone?

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY

 BODY:
WOULDN'T you know it? Now that New York's reputation is all bright and shiny, everyone wants to drop by. Last year, a record 33 million visitors did just that. But not everyone has the welcome mat out.
Tourism has been very, very good to New York. Visitors spent a whopping $13.7 billion last year, paid $710 million in taxes and generated thousands of jobs, as the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau is eager to point out. But many New Yorkers have grown weary of all the out-of-towners, who are showing up pretty much all year round. Some wonder if there are better ways to manage tourism that reap its benefits without sacrificing too much of the city's heart and soul. 
 Mayor Giuliani likes to trumpet quality-of-life improvements as one reason for the boost in tourism. But for many who live and work in New York, the camera-toting masses create quality-of-life problems of their own. It's not just the crowded sidewalks, the traffic jams, the tour buses belching smoke and the long lines for museums, movies and theater tickets. For some people, there's also the sense that they are living in a fishbowl.
Take SoHo. As City Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed sees it, the neighborhood has become "like a giant amusement park, except the people who live here aren't amused -- and the tourists don't even throw us peanuts."
Carol Friedman, an artist who lives in the neighborhood, endures double-decker buses regularly rumbling by the window of her second-floor studio, and guides with bullhorns who promise glimpses "of a real SoHo artist, if you look close!" She often keeps her blinds drawn. "When I don't," she says, "they photograph and videotape right into my space, often even pointing at me as if I'm an animal in a zoo; it's a continual disruption."
Some New Yorkers have gone so far as to stay home on weekends in an effort to avoid tourists, said Julian Vigo, a cultural studies theorist who is an adjunct faculty member at the Gallatin School of Individualized Studies at New York University. "That's sad," she said, "because we're in a city where we pay so much rent to live in such small spaces and the only thing we have is the streets, and now they belong to other people, at least in places like the Village. And what could be weirder than New Yorkers who don't want to go out?"
Gina Luria Walker, chairwoman of the social sciences department at the New School, agrees that the boom in tourism has changed the way many New Yorkers experience their city. "I think we see the city, despite the good economic reasons, transforming itself into a place that's not so different from other places," she said. "And that is for, and because of, tourism."
Though most New Yorkers would not consider themselves xenophobic, she said, "I think we mourn for the little stores that didn't have name recognition, and wandering through neighborhoods where you just happened on something that reflected yourself back at you in a way that the Gap and Disney and hordes of people who are clearly out-of-towners never could. They just dispel that magic."
"People are mourning the malling of Manhattan, and tourism has a lot to do with it," Dr. Walker added. "Some people say, 'We wish tourists would just send the money and not come.' On the other hand, this is a great, cosmopolitan city. And it's these very tensions that keep it so vibrant."
Even among ardent boosters of tourism, there's a growing consensus that tourism requires better planning. "We're beginning to see people saying, 'We want it done responsibly,' " said Lalia Rach, dean of the Center for Hospitality, Tourism and Travel Administration at New York University. "They want to address these things, because if tourism doesn't solve these problems, it will destroy itself."
 
'We're New York City, Not Charlotte, N.C.'
Fran Reiter, president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau and a former deputy mayor in the Giuliani administration, has heard just about every complaint in the book about tourists. "There are quality-of-life issues, balancing issues, waterfront issues, price pressures," she said. "And it is crowded. There are times when it's difficult to get down the street."
"If you stop a New Yorker on the street and you say, 'What do you think about these tourists?' they will immediately start complaining," Ms. Reiter said. "And I put myself in that category." So the tireless tourism promoter herself grumbles about the crowds? "Absolutely," she said. "I can complain with the best of them. But I keep it to myself and don't allow it to influence how we deal with these issues."
"We're New York City, not Charlotte, N.C., and there are certain things that come with living in New York," Ms. Reiter added. "There are fabulous things and not-so-fabulous things, and we need to protect the fabulous and deal with the problems."
While there have been no definitive studies to determine where tourism ranks in terms of its overall contribution to New York's economy, Ms. Reiter said, "tourism is one of the fastest-growing, most-important sectors." She says the Visitors Bureau expects to see an increase in tourism-related employment when it gets new figures soon. In 1995, 4.5 percent of the city's private-sector employment -- a total of 131,000 jobs -- was directly linked to tourism.
Still, finance, insurance and real estate provide the most jobs in the private sector, followed by the health care industry. "But our economy is too dependent" on the three big industries, Ms. Reiter said. "The stock market is out of whack, which disproportionately impacts the city, because it's so important. We need stabilizing industries that aren't as subject to those kinds of fluctuations. Tourism can provide that."
Ms. Reiter's enthusiasm is shared by many in New York, including Mayor Giuliani, who declined to be interviewed. They say mass tourism is far preferable to the days, not so long ago, when the city was widely viewed as unsafe.
"The impact is huge and beneficial in every way, direct and indirect," said H. Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association. "As for overcrowding, well, what a magnificent problem to have," he said. "Especially compared with when the city was down on itself. If the flip side is a hollowed out city, I'll take tourism."
But as Dr. Rach of N.Y.U. pointed out, tourism can become a victim of its own success. "You can lose your cachet," she said. "Maintaining status is a real problem for any destination. Just look at Cancun."
Travel is a fragile industry, subject to that perfect paradox from New York's own Yogi Berra: "It's so crowded there, nobody goes anymore." And overcrowding is epidemic in some areas of Manhattan, like Times Square, SoHo, Greenwich Village and parts of Fifth Avenue, where huge numbers of tourists wander, some seemingly oblivious to the living, breathing city around them. A recent study by the Times Square Business Improvement District found 7,083 pedestrians per hour on a corner of Seventh Avenue and 44th Street on a Wednesday, matinee day for Broadway theaters. "That's about double what it was a few years ago," said the district's director of community development, Suany Chough.
Denise Saunder, who works at a bank near Times Square, said the throngs of tourists sometimes kept her from going out during the day. "Some days I don't leave for lunch because it would take too long to get a sandwich," she said. "It's really not fair. We got to eat, too."
Ms. Vigo, who studies the relationships between private and public space, said she believed "the tourist crowds have become a serious quality-of-life issue." On Fifth Avenue and 10th Street on a recent Saturday, she said, "the tourists were stopping at street vendors, forming huge, impassable groups with no conception they were blocking foot traffic."
"I'm always amazed how they have no concept of the value of personal space in New York," Ms. Vigo said. "New Yorkers have this intuitive sense of space and boundaries, and tourism is all about being in someone else's space."
It's no wonder, she says, that residents become irritated when out-of-towners gawk at them as if they were exotic creatures, or, even worse, take their pictures without permission. Ms. Vigo recalled a scene in Greenwich Village when a tour bus passed through. When the guide "started talking about being in the 'gay area,' " she said, a man who was at a pay phone on the street "ran up to the bus waving and yelling: 'Yes! Hello! I'm gay, that's right, look at me!' "
 
Whose Neighborhood Is It? Troubles Over Turf
In some neighborhoods there is resentment when tourists come to look around but spend little or no money. Harlem, for example, has long attracted busloads of Europeans and Asians, who pack neighborhood churches for free gospel shows and often hurry back to their coaches before spending a dime uptown. "They pay up to $75 each to get bused up there," said Ester R. Fuchs, director of the Barnard-Columbia Center for Urban Policy. "Many tours have lunch in midtown before going to hear gospel music at a church, which they could do for free. And there's little spending in the neighborhood. Put in context, the local people are getting nothing."
The question for community leaders, she said, is how to "capture tourists' dollars without turning Harlem into a circus sideshow with nothing in it for the community."
Deborah Mitchell, director of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, said it's hard to get tourists to spend money there "when there's no organized effort to get people into local restaurants, or have goods to sell, like caps and T-shirts that say 'Harlem.' But, she added, "with some targeted investment we can turn that around."
In other neighborhoods, there is concern that tourism is pushing out longtime residents and businesses and leading to an increase in prices for basic commodities. In Clinton, for example, community leaders say delis and convenience stores along Eighth and Ninth Avenues have been charging more for food, a problem for residents in an area with only one big supermarket.
"People living near Times Square in Hell's Kitchen are not particularly wealthy, but food prices have become dramatically higher than what's charged in other areas," said City Councilman Thomas K. Duane, who represents the area. "The old mom and pop stores are being pushed out, and the new stores set prices at levels that tourists can pay. In some delis, especially near hotels, they charge $1.50 for a can of soda."
Bob Kalin, a tenant organizer for Housing Conservation Coordinators, a nonprofit group, said S.R.O.'s were increasingly converted into low-budget tourist hotels. At the Aladdin, at 317 West 45th Street, only 40 of the 110 permanent tenants remain, he said, with the rest of the rooms used for tourists. "We're depleting S.R.O.'s for genuinely poor people who've lived here a long time," he said. "Hundreds of units have been lost and hundreds more are threatened."
In SoHo, many residents worry about tourism driving out the artists who put the neighborhood on the map. "We're killing the goose that laid the golden egg," Ms. Freed said. "How are they supposed to work in this atmosphere? At night, people stagger down the block singing bad French songs. In the day, some idiot plays bagpipes. That's only for tourists."
Sean Sweeney, executive director of the SoHo Alliance, a community group, estimated that crowds and traffic doubled annually. "I don't shop on weekends, except maybe for milk and bread," he said. "I thought I was a kook. But apparently everybody does that." Mr. Sweeney said he knew 15 artists who had moved away in recent years.
While some New Yorkers see tourists as invading their home turf, to others the millions of visitors are competitors for urban amenities. What good are those world-class museums, theaters and shopping areas and all those taxis, many residents wonder, if the lines are around the block, the stores are mobbed and all the cabs are full?
Sixty-one percent of the tourists last year came for leisure, the Visitors Bureau said. And while 12.3 million people came on business, some of them find tourism has put a crimp in their plans. "In summer, we have to plan travel around the availability of rooms," said Bill Schneider, the CNN political analyst. "Sometimes there just aren't any. And believe me, CNN travel agents have connections. But New York has gotten so inconvenient. It's so hard to get a room that I don't go there as much as I would."
 
No Room at the Inn, No Room on the Bridge
Dr. Rach of N.Y.U. said that in the tourist gold rush climate, "providing services to traditional clients is not what it used to be." Some hotels, she said, are not nurturing long-term relationships with faithful customers. "Leisure travelers are beating down their doors," she said. "In the short term, there's lots and lots of money. But in the long term, how well are they taking care of their investment?"
"What goes around comes around," she said. And when there's a downturn, "all those rooms will become available, and those clients will have their revenge."
Ms. Reiter said: "It's a problem, of course. So how do we address it? Do we tell people, 'Don't come here on visits?' Hell, no. I'm not going to tell anybody not to come. We need more hotels; we need more conference space. We don't have the infrastructure in place to support the level of business we could have."
Is New York on its way to full capacity? Aside from hotel room occupancy, which Ms. Reiter said often approached 100 percent, though 5,000 more rooms were expected by the year 2000, no one seemed to know.
"I haven't seen any studies on capacities for cars and people," said Rae Zimmerman, director of the Institute for Civil Infrastructure Systems at the Urban Planning Program of New York University's Wagner Graduate School of Public Service. "But I know we don't provide enough public bathrooms for everyone."
Richard Barth, director of the Manhattan office of the city's Department of City Planning, said, "All growth factors are taken into account when planning services, and that absolutely includes visitors." He said his agency was working with the Department of Transportation to study pedestrian and traffic flow in heavily traveled areas and looking at ways to improve the situation.
Dr. Rach said: "When looking at any destination, whether it's quality of life, the number of beds or the public infrastructure, there's a carrying capacity that must be determined. But we have this megalopolis where it's not apparent that you even have a carrying capacity, and it's not till you build up the numbers that you feel the impact."
Whether the city's infrastructure -- including its roads, bridges and sewage systems -- is in shape depends in part on how many people use it. Bridges, for example, are designed not only with weight limits, but to accommodate a certain number of vehicles per hour. "We have one of the highest national ratings in terms of disrepair," Ms. Zimmerman said of New York's bridges. "I can't imagine that 33 million people coming into the city wouldn't stress bridges and tunnels." Calls to the Transportation Department were not returned.
As for the environmental impact of tourism, many New Yorkers point to the double-decker tour buses that spew exhaust fumes, but standing behind a city bus is no pleasure, either. Charles Sturcken, a spokesman for the Department of Environmental Protection, said many double-decker buses are old and exempt from Federal emissions standards, "which is a concern to this agency." He added, "We are working with other city agencies on some type of regulatory answer."
More tourism has brought more traffic. Of the 26.9 million Americans who visited last year, 56 percent came in vehicles, according to the Visitors Bureau. Only 20 percent arrived by bus or train, and 23 percent by plane.
"There are stresses from millions of visitors," said Eric A. Goldstein, senior attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council. "It does contribute to traffic congestion and turning up the noise level a notch or two. The sheer volume has an environmental impact. But that's mostly overwhelmed by the benefits."
Mr. Goldstein said that "despite the quality-of-life issues, tourism is a huge plus for the environment."
For one thing, tourism is easier on the environment than, say, manufacturing, he said. "Without it, the city would be in trouble," Mr. Goldstein said. "And healthy cities are central to protecting natural resources. Without them, you'd see more development of wetlands, shorelines and exurban areas."
But millions of visitors also means more garbage and millions of gallons of additional waste water. "Waste-water treatment plants at North River in Harlem and Newtown Creek in Queens have had lots of community problems with odor," Ms. Zimmerman said. "Has the tourist population been factored into the capacity of these plants?"
Mr. Sturcken of the Environmental Protection Department said it had been, adding that the city discharged some 1.5 billion gallons of water a day into the treatment system, whose capacity is 1.77 billion.
Altering bridges, tunnels and sewage treatment plants to accommodate more people is one thing. Changing the attitudes of New Yorkers is quite another.
"We are a very busy city, we like to move quickly, and there will be times when we may have to adjust," Ms. Reiter said. "But you have to explain to people why it's worth making the adjustment. They must understand the benefits first. That message is just starting to get out, but it's been very, very difficult."
As Dr. Rach put it: "It's going to be bumpy at times. But the city and society have to get involved to smooth those bumps out."
 
Striking a Balance
IF tourism is good, can it be better? Can New York get the most bang from the tourist buck without great cost to its physical and cultural environment? Can it strike a balance that spares certain neighborhoods from overload while allowing others to share the wealth?
Here are some ideas:
 
PLANNING FOR COMPANY -- "Every economic sector needs planning," says Lalia Rach, dean of the Center for Hospitality, Tourism and Travel Administration at New York University. "We need that with tourism: What are we offering and how? What's the infrastructure? How's it maintained?"
In Harlem, community, business and religious leaders are working with the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau to create a tourism council to both attract visitors and get them to stick around.
Maintaining neighborhood character is also a concern. "That's why local residents should be front and center in planning," says Deborah Mitchell, director of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone. "The council will allow people to talk about issues in real time, so small issues don't become big issues."
The idea came from Charleston, S.C., which created a tourism commission in 1978 to manage the industry and preserve neighborhoods. "What comes first is the livability of our communities," says Charleston's Mayor, Joseph P. Riley. "We can have a strong and growing tourism industry and improve the quietude and livability of our neighborhoods."
 
SPREAD IT OUT -- Most tourists visiting Manhattan spend their time below 96th Street. But Fran Reiter, president of the Visitors Bureau, points out that there are a number of cultural institutions outside Manhattan, like the Bronx Zoo and the Brooklyn Museum, "that in any other city would be No. 1 attractions."
To reduce congestion in major Manhattan tourist areas and "spread the wealth around," Ms. Reiter says, tour companies are being encouraged to promote sightseeing outside Manhattan. New York Apple Tours, she says, "made very major investments to take hop-on, hop-off buses to Brooklyn. And we've urged the entire industry to spread its wings into the other boroughs."
 
TAKE THE A TRAIN -- Getting tourists to use mass transit, even those who drive into the city, can help alleviate traffic congestion. And more promotion could familiarize visitors with the advantages of bus and subway travel before they arrive.
An unlimited-ride Metrocard could be "very attractive" for tourists, said the deputy executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Chris Boylan. "We'll be talking about one-day and three-day passes and maybe positioning them for tourists," Mr. Boylan said.
Yet some people "have an outdated impression of the system if they haven't been here for 20 years," he said. "It's much friendlier today."
Groups like the volunteer Big Apple Greeter Program can help visitors navigate the subway system. "They say they wouldn't be caught dead in the subway, until we take them there," said a spokeswoman, Carolyn Stone. "Then they feel like natives."
 
EDUCATING THE MASSES -- "We should make the effort to teach visitors their rights and responsibilities," says Gina Luria Walker, chairwoman of the social sciences department at the New School. She suggests a "clever" list of New York dos and don'ts.
"They could be handed out on airplanes and other points of entry," she says, adding that education campaigns could be conducted through consulates and Mayor Giuliani's office.
In Times Square, meanwhile, the Business Improvement District plans to teach people to use midblock passageways to alleviate sidewalk crowding on the avenues. The B.I.D. intends to put up signs directing foot traffic to the passageways.
 
CRACKDOWN TIME? -- The city regulated the helicopter tour industry after noise complaints from residents. Now some people want double-decker buses to be regulated. "They pollute the air, destroy trees, block side streets, invade privacy, blast loudspeakers, go where they're not allowed and idle beyond the limit," says Councilman Thomas K. Duane.
Earlier this month, Mr. Duane offered a bill banning tour buses from side streets in Greenwich Village, SoHo and Clinton. He and other Council members has also called for a multi-agency task force to deal with the problem, which he says is "spiraling out of control."
 
TO MARKET, TO MARKET -- Overnight business travelers on average spend $220 per day, while leisure travelers spend $123, the Visitors Bureau reports. Brazilians are the biggest spenders over all, at $225 per person per day, followed by Japanese, at $189. By contrast, the French part with just $87 a day and the British, $71. And while 70 percent of overseas visitors participated in a cultural activity while they were in New York, just 40 percent of domestic travelers did.
"Are we getting the consumer we want, one that spends a lot of money?" Dr. Rach asks. "Are we looking for the highest numbers or those tourists who return the most to the city?" She says New York should promote itself in places that cater to upscale, culturally aware travelers. Is there a magazine for overnight Brazilian business travelers? DAVID KIRBY

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Softer They Fall

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
What is the lesson from the rescue of Long-Term Capital Management, the hedge fund based in Greenwich, Conn., that's run by John W. Meriwether and a band of Wall Street's savviest traders? That it helps to be big, to be bold and to know the right people.
Wall Streeters not involved in the fund's $3.5 billion bailout by a consortium of large banks and brokerage firms are agog not only at the size of the losses but also at the idea that so speculative a firm would be saved from a demise of its own making. Cries of crony capitalism, Wall Street style, are growing louder. And with some justification. 
 For starters, the deal -- in which companies like J. P. Morgan, Chase Manhattan, Travelers Group and Goldman, Sachs agreed to put up roughly $300 million apiece to stabilize Long-Term Capital -- goes against the advice that American policy makers have been dispensing to tattered economies around the world. If a financial institution is bankrupt, Washington has scolded, it should be allowed to fail. The United States has been especially vocal on this score to officials in Japan.
Then there is the small matter of exactly why these institutions, under the Federal Reserve's sponsorship, came to Long-Term Capital's rescue. According to Sanford I. Weill, chairman of Travelers, the financial industry concluded that a bailout was "the best way to maintain orderly markets."
Mr. Weill is surely right. Forcing Long-Term Capital to liquidate its holdings under pressure would have unleashed a firestorm on already damaged worldwide bond markets. Because Mr. Meriwether had big holdings in junk bonds, for instance, a liquidation of those securities would have clipped their prices badly, hurting individual investors who own high-yield-bond mutual funds.
But the retail investor is only part of the story and hardly the heart of it. The bailout was in the bankers' self-interest, too. Most of the firms that executed Mr. Meriwether's trades piggybacked on them, putting on the same positions. So a mass liquidation of Mr. Meriwether's portfolio would have slashed the value of their holdings. Furthermore, some of the rescuers -- Merrill Lynch and UBS A.G., for example -- had stakes in the fund.
Is the bailout throwing good money after bad? An investment in Long-Term Capital may turn out to be a home run for Merrill Lynch and the other firms, which now have 90 percent ownership of the hedge fund. But the idea that many of these institutions extended so much credit to Long-Term Capital with little understanding of the risks doesn't say much about their management controls.
Some observers find it interesting to compare Mr. Meriwether's treatment with that of another failed investment manager -- Robert Citron, the disgraced former treasurer of Orange County, Calif. As with Mr. Meriwether, Mr. Citron's undoing was a series of wrongheaded interest-rate bets; his caused the county's 1994 bankruptcy.
There are big differences, of course. Mr. Citron was investing with public money, not the funds of high-rolling private investors. And he diverted money from one public account to another. He also was no denizen of Wall Street's corridors, given to wearing turquoise jewelry, not chalk-striped suits.
How many more hedge funds are about to need bailing out? Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, knows that the biggest hazard of one bailout is that it makes people expect another and another. He testified to Congress on the subject 10 days ago. And yet the New York Fed brokered the Long-Term Capital deal.
"That the Fed decided to send a helicopter to sprinkle money over Greenwich means Mr. Greenspan knows that the problem must be so big on the other side," said Stan Jonas, managing director at FIMAT/USA, a broker dealer in New York, referring to the banks. "It must be big, if he's willing to sacrifice principle just to get rid of it."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
A Crucial Week for a Frayed Global Safety Net

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
FOR the world's central bankers and finance ministers, this is the week to put up or shut up.
If they do what many analysts now expect, they could provide a much-needed breather for investors in a global economic crisis that began with the devaluation of the Thai currency 15 months ago, has engulfed Russia, is battering Latin America and threatening the United States. 
 But if they disappoint, watch out.
Federal Reserve policy makers meet on Tuesday, and Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has indicated -- but not guaranteed -- that a rate cut is in the offing. "We have to bring the existing instabilities to a level of stability reasonably shortly, to prevent the contagion from really spilling over and creating some very significant further difficulties for all of us," he told Congress last week.
While not a silver bullet, a quarter- or half-point cut in the Fed's short-term interest rate target could ease fears in emerging markets, lessening capital flight. It would also minimize the chances that the American economy would aggravate the crisis by slipping into its own recession.
Taking no action would be a jolt, sending stocks here and around the world lower.
The election for German Chancellor is set for today; Brazilians will select a president a week later. With the elections over, a new German leader (Gerhard Schroder) or the current one (Helmut Kohl) can pay more attention to global problems, a necessity if there is any chance for a global rate cut. President Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil, if he wins a new term, as expected, will have to make good on promises of deficit cuts and Social Security changes. Otherwise, it will be hard to lure back investors.
Then the world's financial leaders will be gathering in Washington at the end of the week, for the semiannual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The Group of Seven leading industrialized countries and the I.M.F. will be expected to do more to calm the waters. On top of the list is some kind of standby bailout package for key Latin American countries like Brazil. If no such deal is done soon, investors should worry about a steeper Latin American downside.
Even though many stock markets have settled into a volatile but contained trading range over the last two weeks, the Fed and the world's leaders still have plenty to worry about, especially in Latin America. Mexico, Brazil and Argentina are where global policy makers will have to make their last stand against a virulent financial crisis that, if left unchecked, could send the whole world into a recession.
Jose M. Barrionuevo, director of global market strategy at Lehman Brothers, has a risk barometer based on a country's level of dollar currency reserves. This level is compared with what would be needed, hypothetically, as a full defense against capital flight, without resorting to unsustainably high interest rates to defend the currency.
On this basis, Brazil and Mexico are still extremely vulnerable to a currency collapse and the economic crisis that would follow. In Brazil, the level of actual reserves is $47.5 billion and the defense level is $200.8 billion. In Mexico, reserves are $30.3 billion and the defense level is $100.6 billion.
"In the absence of additional external and domestic measures, these countries are likely to experience serious foreign exchange devaluation pressures," Mr. Barrionuevo said.
Argentina, which pegged its currency, the peso, to the dollar, is less vulnerable by this measure, with a reserve level of $25 billion and a defense level of $33.6 billion. But Mr. Barrionuevo is still concerned because Argentina's economic health is so dependent, through trade, on Brazil. The Czech Republic is also under threat.
"The support from the Group of Seven and the I.M.F. has to be materializing soon," Mr. Barrionuevo said. The Fed must ease, he added, because Latin America needs to see that the United States is not slowing too much, closing a key export market.
"The world," he warned, "is walking a very fine line."
Look how quickly the Greenspan-inspired, rate-cut euphoria evaporated on Wednesday. Just hours after the Dow finished the day 257 points higher, a $3.5 billion rescue was announced for one of the biggest casualties yet of the financial crisis: Long-Term Capital Management, the hedge fund founded by John W. Meriwether.
The Dow fell 152 points on Thursday, and for a day Mr. Meriwether's mistakes outweighed Mr. Greenspan's promises. That could make the chairman's search for stability tougher.
