HEADLINE: State Begins Complex Task Of Evaluating All Colleges

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
With its ratings of primary and secondary schools well established, the New York State Department of Education is embarking on an effort to assess the state's colleges and universities, both public and private.
As early as 2001, the state could issue its first report evaluating the performance of colleges. The format is yet to be worked out, and department officials are reluctant to speculate about specifics. But they say the wide range of institutions -- from research universities to community colleges and trade schools -- means that the report must be more complex than the school report cards, perhaps something more like the reports issued by U.S. News & World Report and the Princeton Review but somehow going beyond them. 
 "Certainly U.S. News & World Report has taken an opportunity, but my personal view is that the higher education community could do a better job," said Richard P. Mills, the State Education Commissioner. "The fact that their reports are so eagerly consumed by the public tells me there is a lot people do want to know."
The department is seeking an additional $400,000 in its budget to help pay for the evaluation efforts, which it plans to shape in the coming year with the help of educators in New York and nationally and with consultants.
In the next week or two, it will name a new higher education advisory council that will include about 20 college presidents, the chancellors of the state's two public university systems and other leaders from public and private institutions. The department hopes to use the council as a sounding board on higher education policy as well as on the new evaluation process.
And in February, the department plans to hold what it is calling a summit on higher education in New York City.
"Primary and secondary education are moving in the right direction now," said Carl Hayden, chancellor of the Board of Regents. "It is time to turn the focus to higher education and to really bring the discussion of higher education issues to the fore."
He said the board had already taken aggressive steps in higher education, including its removal of Adelphi University's trustees and the imposition of new teacher education standards, and now planned to move even more broadly.
Measuring the quality of New York's diverse higher education institutions -- 260 degree-granting colleges and universities and 260 other postsecondary institutions -- is something Mr. Mills and the Regents have wanted to do for some time.
Two years ago, Mr. Mills proposed a higher education report card that would have applied 41 performance indicators to colleges, measurements like graduate employment rates, changes in tuition and the proportion of students needing remedial education. But he was criticized for proposing a "one-size-fits-all" approach, and it was put on hold.
"My sense is that it wasn't yet ripe," Mr. Mills said last week.
This time, he is trying to remedy that problem by recognizing the differences and inviting college leaders to help him and the Regents devise ways that take them into account while judging the performance of institutions with widely differing missions -- from a community college like Hostos, for example, to a graduate research university like Rockefeller University.
Gerald W. Patton, the Deputy Commissioner for Higher Education and the official charged with leading the assessment effort, said he expected that some criteria, like graduation rates and graduates' scores on licensing exams, would be applied to all or most institutions. But he said he expected colleges to define their special goals and to figure out ways to measure whether they are meeting them. "It does require faculty to talk more about their goals and objectives," Mr. Patton said. "We aren't trying to tell them how to do it. We want them to develop the methodologies."
He said he hoped that a framework would be in place by next year and that assessments would begin by 2000. Any proposals will be subject to public discussion and approval by the Regents.
While many states are trying to make their universities more accountable, the New York effort is more ambitious than most.
For one thing, unlike most state boards, the Board of Regents has jurisdiction over all higher education in the state, including its two Ivy League universities (Columbia and Cornell), religious institutions like St. John's and Fordham, and commercial colleges like DeVry Institute of Technology.
For another, many performance measurement systems have gotten bogged down in counting what is easy to count, like numbers of students and scores on tests.
Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States, a nonprofit organization in Denver that advises state officials on education policy, called the effort a "complex undertaking" -- significantly more complicated than assessing high schools, which as a group have much more similar objectives.
"Most of the states that have struggled with this haven't done much once they have gotten past simpler measures to the more profound question of whether students are learning what they need to know to be effective citizens in the 21st century," he said.
Standards have become a mantra in education. Mr. Mills, who has an oversize set of alphabet blocks spelling "S-T-A-N-D-A-R-D-S" atop the tall bookcase behind his desk, has made an art of figuring out what they ought to be and then applying them.
He has laid out standards for his own performance as education commissioner. He has adopted the system of school report cards for rating primary and secondary schools in the state. And he is imposing strict new requirements for teacher education programs and teachers.
His plan to evaluate colleges, which has yet to be publicly announced, has drawn a mixed response. Some educators, like Mr. Newman of the Education Commission of the States, applauded it.
"For a long time in American higher education, we assumed quality, and that was a modestly reasonable assumption," he said. But those days are over, he added, because of the enormous change taking place in who is providing higher education, the new technologies being used, the broader range of students and the very different demands on graduates in the economy.
"All of a sudden, we can't make the simple assumptions we've all made that just because students have been through our educational process they are well educated," he said. "Seat time is not a good enough measure of quality any more."
But others question whether another layer of measurement will be worth the time and cost.
"I believe very strongly in accountability and in people's right to know," said Lois B. DeFleur, president of SUNY-Binghamton and chairwoman of the American Council on Education. "But we already devote unbelievable resources to the accrediting process and performance assessment and evaluation of our programs. They have to understand the cost in time and energy."
L. Jay Oliva, the president of New York University, offered a similar perspective. "There is no institution in the whole world that spends more time looking at itself than universities," he said.
Mr. Patton said he recognized the concerns, but added that he hoped colleges and universities would ultimately see the system as a benefit for them, too.
"It will be an avenue for them to do better," he said. "And it will send a message to the community at large about how higher education is improving."

HEADLINE: For Printers, an Eviction Notice;
Landlords Are Seeking Cleaner, High-Paying Tenants

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Harold Russell has to yell to be heard above the roar of the Miehle Roland presses churning out 25,000 brochures for an insurance company. The pungent smell of ink envelops the shop floor like a thick cloud.
Down the hallway, in Mr. Russell's office at 480 Canal Street, near the entrance to the Holland Tunnel, is the black skeleton of a 100-year-old Kelly letterpress and an oak time clock in which he punched his first timecard, at the age of 9. Earlier this month as he passed by the ancient clock, which runs 20 minutes slow, Mr. Russell, now 56, said he believed that time was finally running out for the printing industry in Manhattan. 
 Mr. Russell's landlord, Trinity Church, has put him and dozens of other printers on notice that the church will not renew their leases in its buildings in the 70-year-old printing district, near the Holland Tunnel. Other landlords are following suit, replacing printers who pay $10 a square foot with advertising agencies and other office tenants that will pay $25 to $30.
The current real estate boom, which has sent office tenants scurrying into industrial districts in search of cheaper rents, is threatening to wipe out what was once the second-largest manufacturing industry in the city. The printers say they will be forced to move to New Jersey, or even to close, if they cannot find industrial space close to their corporate clients, who want, in the words of Mr. Russell, to "sniff and touch" the sheets as they roll off the presses.
Even though commercial printing no longer accounts for one out of every seven factory jobs in the city, as it did during the 1920's, printers say the industry does provide skilled, relatively well-paid jobs and critical services for financial, advertising and entertainment companies.
"In the very short years to come, manufacturing will cease to exist in Manhattan," said Mr. Russell, president of the Skillcraft Group and a third-generation printer. "They want boutique shops. They say printers are dirty, so they don't want us. Between technological changes in the industry and real estate, we're really shoveling against the tide."
Trinity Church, at Broadway and Wall Street, is not the only landlord with printing tenants, but it is the largest in the printing district, which extends west from Avenue of the Americas to Hudson Street and north from Vestry Street to West Houston Street. Printers occupy about a sixth of the 15 buildings and 5.5 million square feet of space owned by the church. Trinity's decision to convert all but one of its remaining factory buildings to office space is forcing about 60 printers to hunt for new homes.
Stephen D. Heyman, director for leasing at Trinity Real Estate, said the church could no longer afford low rents and special deals for printers. These tenants, with their heavy presses and busy loading docks, will have to go, he said.
"The highest and best use for our portfolio is office space," Mr. Heyman said. "We decided to let the charitable work of the church be run by those who run charities. So we've been unwilling to renew or extend space to printers. You can't have a mixed-use building with printers. They're dirty. They make a lot of noise. The noise drives away a lot of people."
Other owners of buildings that house printers are also seeking quieter, more lucrative tenants.
In the garment district south of Times Square, office tenants are pushing their way in and pushing up rents, forcing out manufacturers. Some large printers like Tanagraphic own their buildings and are unaffected by the roiling real estate market. But most of the printers are family-owned businesses that lease space, and they say the expense of moving, which can run to several hundred thousand dollars or more, is a serious burden.
Roger P. Gimbel, president of Xerographic Reproduction Center, at 516 West 34th Street, said he wanted to expand his space to 50,000 square feet from 35,000, but his landlord, refused to even renew his lease. Mr. Gimbel's company is not an outmoded print shop; it is a computerized digital operation whose lifeblood is toner, rather than ink.
"The cost of picking up and moving is in excess of $1 million," Mr. Gimbel said. "We'd rather put that into equipment."
Downtown, Joseph Gitto, the president of Imtech, another digital printer whose clients are mainly investment banks, faces the same problem. He said his landlord at 130 Cedar Street, a longtime printers' building where he has rented 32,000 square feet for a decade, wanted him out, even before his lease expires in 2002.
New York has been hemorrhaging manufacturing jobs since the 1950's, and many of those jobs will probably never return. But urban planners and economic development specialists say the city needs to encourage manufacturers producing specialized, high-quality products with ties to local markets. These include computer software businesses, apparel makers that can produce goods quickly, and printers.
"In every major real estate cycle, there's somebody getting squeezed out of low-cost space in Manhattan," said Hugh O'Neil, president of Appleseed, an economic consulting company. "But the city's land use and development policies need to insure that some space remains available in Manhattan for blue-collar industries that support finance and business services, the media and the arts, or you could have the perverse effect of making Manhattan less attractive for those high-value activities."
Joseph P. Rose, chairman of the city's Planning Department, agreed, saying he had opposed efforts by landlords and speculators seeking zoning changes to convert industrial buildings to apartment houses in active manufacturing areas in Manhattan. But there is little he can do to stop the transformation of the printing district, he said.
"Clearly it's in the city's interest to retain manufacturing jobs," he said. "But there's no prohibition on the conversion of manufacturing space to office space."
About two dozen printers have banded together with the Association of Graphic Communications, a trade association representing 540 companies in and around New York City, to hire a real estate broker to find a building or buildings in Manhattan that could serve as a new center for printers, binders and engravers. William A. Dirzulaitis, president of the association, said the group had talked with city and state officials about getting help with moving expenses and electricity costs.
"The Mayor has been good when it comes to helping the commodity exchange, Conde Nast and the Yankees," Mr. Dirzulaitis said. "Here's a whole industry segment that could be lost if something isn't brought to the table."
Many printers are wary of alternative sites recommended by the city, like the Brooklyn Army Terminal or Long Island City in Queens, because they are hard to reach by truck or by public transportation. Trinity has set aside space for printers at 200 Hudson Street, but Michael Geoghegan, a broker at Insignia/Edward S. Gordon who is working for the printers, said there was little room left there.
Instead of celebrating the 75th anniversary of the company their grandfather started, Larry and Arthur Paladino, the owners of Palographia, one of the largest engravers in the city, at 175 Varick Street, are desperately looking for space in Brooklyn, Queens and Jersey City. Their landlord has refused to renew their lease.
"A lot of small printers like myself are going to get wiped out," Larry Paladino said.
Printers began moving to Hudson and Varick Streets in the 1920's to escape the congestion in lower Manhattan and to be closer to the Holland Tunnel, then under construction. At the time, nearly a quarter of all the commercial printing in the country was done in New York.
Trinity Church, which had owned a large piece of Manhattan under a 1705 land grant from Queen Anne of England, ended up with many of the factory buildings during the Depression. By the start of this century, the church had already disposed of much of its property, by either selling it or giving it to Columbia University. The church leased some of the land it kept to developers who built printing factories. And when the economy collapsed and the developers defaulted on their mortgages, the church bought the buildings.
Ever since, Trinity and the printing industry have been buffeted by technological change and the vagaries of the economy. In the 1980's, Mr. Heyman said, companies leasing 3 million of the church's 5.5 million square feet of real estate failed. Like many landlords, Mr. Heyman said, Trinity cut rents to help printers survive.
The church also has sought to gentrify the neighborhood, and named it Hudson Square. In the 1980's, Trinity leased land to Tishman Speyer, which built 375 Hudson Street, home to Saatchi & Saatchi DFS, an advertising agency. Later, Della Femina, McNamee WCRS moved into another Trinity property, 350 Hudson Street. Chic restaurants like the Buddha Bar, Hudson Grill and Triplets replaced printers' hangouts like Renato's on Vandam and the Printer's Pub at 480 Canal Street.
Now, Mr. Heyman said, Trinity is pouring money into transforming its largest building, 75 Varick Street, into 1 Hudson Square, enlarging the lobby, converting freight elevators to passenger use and installing a new air conditioning system. At 480 Canal Street, Trinity has already leased part of the building to a caterer.
Robert Mastellone, president of D & L Offset Lithography, is particularly incensed by the conversion at 75 Varick Street. Ten years ago, he spent about $1.5 million moving his company there from Trinity's building at 100 Avenue of the Americas. "We were told at the time that they had no plans to turn this building over to office space," Mr. Mastellone said. "We tried to get something in writing, but they said they could not do that."
Earlier this month, Alice Langon and her sons moved their engraving operation, I. Scheff, to West Babylon, N.Y., after 70 years at 480 Canal Street. George Linder, president of Linder & Company, another small printer at 480 Canal, has decided to go to Jersey City.
But most printers worry that they will lose many customers by leaving Manhattan. Given the boom-and-bust nature of real estate, they say Trinity is being short-sighted in ousting its longtime tenants.
"We're just getting clobbered," said William Abrams, vice president of AGW Lithographers at 225 Varick Street, a Trinity-owned building near Houston Street. "When this building was half empty, we still were paying our rent in a timely fashion. All of a sudden we're not good tenants. The market will face another downturn and we'll probably look like good tenants again."

HEADLINE: SPLINTERED HOUSE APPROVES TAX CUT WORTH $80 BILLION

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Brushing aside a veto threat from President Clinton, the House passed an $80 billion Republican tax cut today that would be paid for by projected Federal budget surpluses.
The vote put Republicans a step closer to a politically charged election-year showdown with the White House and Congressional Democrats over an issue that both sides believe will play to their advantage. 
 Republicans said a portion of the excess revenue expected to flow to the Government in coming years should be returned to taxpayers, in part to keep Washington from spending it.
Led by Mr. Clinton, Democrats have framed the issue as one of fiscal responsibility, saying that to spend any surpluses before they materialize would be reckless and endanger efforts to address the Social Security system's long-term financial problems. Since January, Mr. Clinton has been demanding that Congress set aside every penny of the surplus until it has agreed with the Administration on a plan to shore up Social Security.
The bill, which would save taxpayers $80 billion over five years, would provide a tax break for many middle-income married couples, exempt some interest and dividend payments from taxation, reduce inheritance taxes, accelerate a plan to allow the self-employed to deduct 100 percent of their health insurance premiums and extend a credit for research undertaken by corporations.
Today's House vote, 229 to 195, was largely along party lines. Eleven Republicans voted against the bill and 19 Democrats voted for it.
The legislation now goes to the Senate, where its prospects are uncertain. Because of the parliamentary rules that will apply to the bill in the Senate, it will require 60 votes for passage, a hurdle that Republicans, who hold 55 seats, said would be difficult to overcome.
Senate Republicans, who earlier this year voted to cut taxes $30 billion over five years, could scale back the House bill to try to win votes from wavering Democrats, although no decision has yet been made. Some Republicans have also weighed attaching the tax bill to a package of spending bills to make it more difficult for Democrats to vote against it and to raise the stakes should it come to a Presidential veto.
Battered and strained by Mr. Clinton's struggle for political survival, Democrats were clearly happy to turn their attention to an issue that could help unify the party and spur more Democrats to turn out at the polls in November.
Mr. Clinton, traveling in California, immediately put out a statement saying that the Republican plan "drains billions of dollars from the surplus before we have done the hard work of strengthening Social Security." The President reiterated that he would veto the bill if it reached his desk.
Republicans said the tax burden on citizens, measured as a percentage of total economic activity, was at its highest level since World War II. They said that cutting taxes would help move power out of Washington and back to states and communities while reining in Washington's predilection for ever-larger spending on social programs.
Mr. Clinton has already broken his own pledge to put Social Security first by proposing to use the surplus to pay for emergency spending next year for farm relief, increased security at American embassies and the peacekeeping mission in Bosnia, Republicans said. Moreover, they said, the projected Federal budget surpluses are so large that there is plenty of room for a tax cut without limiting the options for dealing with the looming crisis in Social Security, which will run short of money to pay benefits when the baby-boom generation retires over the next three decades.
They said their plan would leave most of the surplus free to help address Social Security's looming difficulties. The surplus is projected by the Congressional Budget Office to be $520 billion over the next five years and $1.55 trillion over the next 10 years.
"The time has come to admit tax-and-spend has failed," said Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who wrote the tax bill. "It's time to reduce the size of Government and to let people keep their tax dollars."
But most Democrats stuck closely to their party line that now is not the time for tax cuts. They said that all the projected surplus for the next five years, and nearly all for the next decade, will come from excess payroll tax payments that are earmarked for Social Security's trust funds.
Once the Social Security surplus is stripped out of the overall surplus calculations, the Democrats said, there is nothing left to pay for a tax cut, making the Republican plan a threat to the nation's long-term fiscal health.
"The passage of this bill will make solving the Social Security problem more difficult, plain and simple," said Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland. "We're raiding Social Security. Without Social Security we have no surplus."
The issue is already showing up in Congressional races around the country. The A.F.L.-C.I.O., a major source of support for Democrats as they struggle to keep Republicans from picking up more seats in the wake of Mr. Clinton's troubles, said it began running television commercials in 20 Congressional districts this week trying to rally support against the tax cuts.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader, said the message from Republicans was that the "election is more important to the Republican Party than saving Social Security for future generations."
Republicans said Democrats were relying on scare tactics. "Social Security will be protected," said Representative Sam Johnson, a Texas Republican.
Although the bill has provisions to benefit big business and the wealthy, its was written by Republicans to appeal to the middle class, and many Democrats said they would have supported it if it did not require dipping into the surplus. The cuts would be worth about $80 billion over five years and $177 billion over 10 years.
Republicans "have hijacked Democratic tax cut ideas and then made it impossible for us to vote for them because their bill drains the Social Security trust fund," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York.
The bill's centerpiece is a reduction in the so-called marriage penalty, the quirk in the tax code that causes many two-income couples to pay a bigger tax bill than they would if single.
The penalty primarily affects couples in which the two partners have roughly equal incomes. But the bill would provide a break to all couples who file jointly and claim the standard deduction by increasing the standard deduction for couples filing jointly so that it is double the deduction for single filers.
The second-biggest provision in the bill would be an acceleration of a planned reduction in the estate tax, a change that would benefit the heirs of individuals who have amassed considerable wealth. The provision would increase to $1 million from $600,000 the amount that can be exempted from Federal estate taxes, starting Jan. 1, 1999.
The bill would also exempt from taxation the first $400 in interest and dividend income for couples filing jointly, or the first $200 for single filers.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Still a Good Day for Sosa As Cubs Avoid Disaster

BYLINE: By BILL DEDMAN

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The moment was ready to be pasted into the Scrapbook of Frustration, the one kept on the shelf of memory by Chicago Cubs fans everywhere.
The day began with the Cubs in a three-way tie with the Mets and Giants for the last spot in the playoffs, and with the Cubs' Sammy Sosa tied with Mark McGwire in the home run chase. On the scoreboard, the Cubs could see that the Giants had beaten the Rockies, and the video screen showed that McGwire had hit two home runs, pulling two ahead of Sosa. And now the Cubs, who had rallied when Sosa scored the go-ahead run in the eighth, were blowing another lead. 
 Then, with two outs in the bottom of the ninth, in the next-to-last game of the regular season, with the Cubs leading by 3-2 and the tying run on third base, Dave Clark of the Astros rolled a little nubber up the first base line. Pitcher Rod Beck gloved the ball, swiped a tag at the batter and heard no one call "Out!" So he threw the ball toward first. It hit Clark squarely in the back and rolled away as a runner crossed home plate.
The 51,950 fans in the Astrodome knew the game was tied, and the groans of Cubs fans could be heard all the way from Chicago. The day that began with a three-way tie in the National League wild-card race would surely end, it seemed, with the Cubs and the Mets trailing the Giants by one game. And, as has happened as regularly as Halloween since 1945, the Cubs' October would not include a World Series.
But there was the mighty figure of Umpire Eric Gregg, pointing at Clark, calling him out for running outside the baseline to avoid the tag. The game was over. The jubilant Cubs had won, 3-2.
The day ended with the surging Giants and struggling Cubs a game ahead of the fading Mets, with only one game to play. The Mets lost in Atlanta, 4-0, and the Giants won in Denver, 8-4.
The Cubs were carried by heroes familiar and unlikely.
Sosa, who started the game-winning rally with a simple single to left field, finished the day 2 for 4, adding to his resume for most valuable player in the league.
Gary Gaetti, who was unemployed when the Cubs hired him in August on his 40th birthday, hit two doubles, one that helped the Cubs tie the game and the other to win it. He may be the Cubs' most valuable player for September, hitting .328 since he joined the team.
With their season reduced to two games, the Cubs won the first one with one arm tied behind their backs: Kerry Wood's.
The rookie phenomenon with the sore elbow sat on the bench, filing his nails, during this afternoon's game against the first-place Astros, 20 of whom he struck out in a single game back in May. Wood will sit out the Sunday afternoon game as well. He has thrown without pain in practice, but the Cubs say they will not risk a 20-year-old's career, even for a chance at the World Series. "We don't want him to hurt himself," Cubs Manager Jim Riggleman said.
Wood filed his nails harder as Sosa struck out in the sixth inning, leaving the Cubs behind, 1-0.
Wood started to chew on his nails in the seventh, when the Cubs tied the game on a double by Gaetti, a wild pitch, and a sacrifice fly by Orlando Merced. Neither player was a Cub until the past month.
Wood stopped chewing in the eighth, when the Cubs took the lead on a single to left by Sosa, a single to right by Mark Grace, and another double by Gaetti.
Then Wood nearly chewed up to his sore elbow in the ninth. The angst was induced by Beck, who has gained a reputation as a Houdini who throws himself overboard in chains, sometimes forgetting the key. Beck gave up a home run by Jeff Bagwell that gave the Cubs a 3-2 lead, then he allowed the tying run to reach third on a Moises Alou double and a groundout. Then came the slow roller to first.
"I know people don't think I know what I'm doing out there," Beck said in the loose and confident Cubs clubhouse after the game, "but I really do. Honest. I have 50 saves."
The Astros did not think much of Gregg's final call. "They blew it," Astros Manager Larry Dierker said.
The Cubs were saved today by their starting pitcher, Mark Clark, who hails from Bath, Ill., which is a Central Illinois border town. It's on two borders, actually, the one between Cardinals and Cubs fans and between McGwire and Sosa fans.
With a $5 million salary, Mark Clark is the highest-paid player on the Cubs after Sosa, who makes $8 million. Clark has been the least consistent member of the Cubs' starting rotation, with a 4-6 record since the All-Star Game break.
Clark was nearly removed after only five batters, when Houston took a 1-0 lead and loaded the bases. But he got out of the jam and allowed only five hits in eight innings. He was nearly matched by Shane Reynolds, who failed to win his 20th game, leaving with the game tied 1-1 in the eighth. Clark is now 9-14. Jay Powell was the loser, now 7-7.
A questionable left arm starts for the Cubs on Sunday. Terry Mulholland, the nonstarting starter, is scheduled to face Mike Hampton. The Cubs paid the veteran Mulholland $600,000 for the year, plus healthy contract incentives for successful starts, then kept him out of the rotation. Mulholland, a World Series veteran with the Phillies, gave the Cubs two terrific starts recently in Wood's place, made all the more remarkable because Mulholland's father is very ill. The 35-year-old won games on the road this month in San Diego and Milwaukee, giving up a combined three earned runs.
"Terry's pitched in the big dance a couple of times," Beck said. "He handles pressure better than anybody."
The starting pitcher for the Cubs in a playoff would be Steve Trachsel, who is 14-8 but has been pummeled in three starts since he gave up McGwire's record-breaking 62d home run in St. Louis on Sept. 8.
"We like our chances," Sosa said. "The home runs didn't come, but we got the win. That's what counts. I've always been saying that Mark is going to finish ahead of me."

HEADLINE: September 20-26;
Poverty Rates Fall

 BODY:
In a welcome bit of good news for the Clinton Administration, the Census Bureau reported that the proportion of Americans living in poverty declined last year, a drop largely attributed to progress made by black and Hispanic families. 
 The overall rate was 13.3 percent in 1997, down from 13.7 percent the year before. Mr. Clinton said the statistics vindicated his economic policies.

HEADLINE: September 20-26;
Reading Tea Leaves

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan and Keizo Obuchi have almost nothing in common. Except that the Federal Reserve chairman and the new Japanese Prime Minister both enjoy reputations for making public comments that leave investors puzzled.
What investors heard from Mr. Greenspan last week was a slippery statement that, "We have to bring the existing instabilities to a level of stability reasonably shortly" before the global economic turmoil really rocks America. The world immediately assumed that the Fed will cut interest rates on Tuesday. 
 Then there was Mr. Obuchi. Before meeting President Clinton in New York to discuss Japan's banking crisis, he said, "Instead of 'too little too late' we want to deal with this in ways that people say 'too big, too fast.' "
Even President Clinton's economic team had a hard time faking much optimism at those words. "You have to remember, we've been in office six years and we've already met six Japanese Prime Ministers," one noted.
 DAVID E. SANGER

HEADLINE: September 20-26;
NASA Seeks a Russian Bailout

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
The biggest science project of all time, a sprawling outpost for astronauts, is to start being hauled piecemeal into orbit in two months. But the plan is shaky because a key Russian player has been crippled by the nation's economic chaos.
So NASA plans to buy up to $660 million in goods and services over five years to help its partner complete a key station element. Congress hates the plan. But the alternatives -- including dropping the station, on which the Americans have already spent billions -- are unappealing.
 WILLIAM J. BROAD

HEADLINE: The I.M.F. Can Calm a Roiling Global Economy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While American officials were narrowly focused on the irrelevant question of whether to raise or lower interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point and how to get Congress to finance the International Monetary Fund with an additional inadequate $18 billion, Japan is making recommendations of world-class magnitude (front page, Sept. 21). 
 Instead of ignoring Japan's suggestions or putting it down for having the audacity to make them, United States officials should seize on them and put them together into one plan to tackle all the world's economic trouble spots at once: the $100 billion suggested by Japan for Asia should be increased to $200 billion for the world; the leaders of the industrialized countries should be combined with the other world leaders to discuss the instability of Asia, the Russian crisis and global economic risks.
 
JOHN R. BYERS
Scarsdale, N.Y., Sept. 21, 1998

LENGTH: 177 words

HEADLINE: For New York City, Garbage Is a Resource

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I applaud your call for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to expand weekly recycling pickups to the entire city (editorial, Sept. 21). However, you err when you refer to recyclable materials as "garbage." Old newspapers and rinsed-out tuna cans are not garbage but resources. 
 This distinction is important because the real savings from recycling come not from reducing the loads sent to landfills but from lower energy costs. It takes a lot less energy to prepare recycled glass, plastic, metal and paper for remanufacturing than it does to extract, transport and refine the raw materials.
For these lower energy costs to be realized, however, requires that a critical mass of recyclable materials be consistently available. New York City's sheer size gives us an unparalleled advantage in creating such a reliable market. A few much smaller, more spread-out municipalities have already begun to succeed in doing so, yielding lasting competitive advantage to their local and regional economies.
 
JOHN MC CRORY
New York, Sept. 21, 1998

HEADLINE: POLITICAL BRIEFING;
Forbes: Not Loved In Arizona Anymore?

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr.

 BODY:
Back during the 1996 Presidential campaign, Steve Forbes, the publishing magnate, spent the better part of $4 million, much of it from his personal fortune, to win a surprise victory in Arizona's Republican primary. Since then, his eye now fixed on the Election 2000 primary, he has returned often to the Grand Canyon State to meet and greet and to preach his special brand of conservative economics. 
 Just a few days ago he spoke at a fund-raiser for a fellow Republican, Representative J. D. Hayworth, who is running for a second term in Arizona's Sixth Congressional District. And in another week or so, he is scheduled to be the keynote speaker at the annual fund-raising dinner of the Arizona Christian Coalition, a major force in the state's politics.
Is he making any political progress? Maybe not, if a newly released Presidential preference poll is to be believed.
Taken late last month by Arizona Chamber Info, a subsidiary of the Arizona Chamber of Commerce, it asked 231 registered Republicans to pick a favorite from a list of party members who have indicated that they might run in 2000. Topping the list were Jack Kemp, the 1996 Vice Presidential candidate, with about 18 percent, and House Speaker Newt Gingrich, 14. Among bottom dwellers were Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, with 2, and Mr. Forbes and Lamar Alexander, the former Governor of Tennessee, each with 0.
How soon they forget . . .
Not so, Mr. Forbes counters. He slammed the survey as "preposterous fiction" and "random selection that just doesn't cut it."
In fact, a sampling of just 231 voters is on the thin side, as political polls go. Nevertheless, chamber officials defend the accuracy of their survey, calculating its margin of error to be plus or minus about 5 percentage points.
Since 52 percent of the respondents were undecided this early in the run-up to Election 2000, the chamber officials added, there is plenty of time and room for Mr. Forbes to improve and make another good showing.
On the other hand, maybe Mr. Forbes should forget about Arizona and concentrate more on another state he has also been working hard -- Iowa, quadrennial home of the first Presidential caucuses.
In a new Mason-Dixon poll of likely G.O.P. caucus-goers, Mr. Forbes and Governor Bush ended up in a dead heat, with the rest of the wannabe field lagging badly, most notably Mr. Alexander, who has spent more time trodding the Election 2000 trail that just about anybody. In Iowa a mere 2 percent of poll respondents picked him as their favorite.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
AFTER SILENCE: Rape and My Journey Back, by Nancy Venable Raine. (Crown, $23.) An uncommonly bold and intelligent analysis of the experiences of self-blame, rage, shame, pollution, panic, depression and helplessness that can follow the crime itself in a victim of rape.
 
THE BALTIMORE CASE: A Trial of Politics, Science, and Character, by Daniel J. Kevles. (Norton, $29.95.) A cautionary story of aggression by self-appointed science cops and of a scandal that ran for a decade before some high-powered scientists, accused of finagling experimental results, were finally exonerated.
 
BIRDS OF AMERICA: Stories, by Lorrie Moore. (Knopf, $23.) Moore's articulate, erotically frustrated protagonists reflect upon and worry about predicaments they can never resolve in this lighthearted, often hilarious, sublimely dark collection in which nothing is funnier than misery.
 
DEATH IN SUMMER, by William Trevor. (Viking, $23.95.) The child of a man who has never known love is abducted by a woman who longs for love with something like madness in this novel by an author expert in malformations of the heart.
 
EAST AND WEST: China, Power, and the Future of Asia, by Christopher Patten. (Times Books/ Random House, $25.) The last British Governor of Hong Kong defends the connections between democracy and prosperity and condemns the proposition that Asians need authoritarianism.
 
KING LEOPOLD'S GHOST: A Story of Greed, Terror, and Heroism in Colonial Africa, by Adam Hochschild. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) A history of European greed and atrocity in central Africa under the aegis of Leopold II, King of the Belgians.
 
LOST IN TRANSLATION, by Nicole Mones. (Delacorte, $23.95.) An American bigot's daughter becomes entranced with Chinese culture and Chinese men in a first novel that inspects two great cultures and their invincible convictions of superiority to each other.
 
MISTLER'S EXIT, by Louis Begley. (Knopf, $22.) Falsification of the self, a theme that runs through Begley's earlier novels, peaks out in a rich and powerful protagonist whose terminal cancer does not move him to separate his truth from his lies.
 
PLAIN AND NORMAL, by James Wilcox. (Little, Brown, $24.) The nebbishy, well-meaning hero of this gravely farcical novel is newly divorced, newly out of the closet and newly conscious that his every move is misconstrued by somebody.
 
THE VOYAGE OF THE NARWHAL, by Andrea Barrett. (Norton, $24.95.) A British naturalist turns a search for Franklin's disappeared Arctic expedition of 1845-47 into a voyage of self-discovery in an adventure novel that also serves to show the power of narration to make history.

HEADLINE: More Pie, Please!

BYLINE: By Steven Greenhouse; Steven Greenhouse covers labor and workplace issues for The New York Times.

 BODY:

From the Ashes of the Old
 American Labor and
 America's Future.
 By Stanley Aronowitz.
 246 pp. Boston:
 Houghton Mifflin Company. $25. 
 From the late 1970's to the mid-1990's, the American labor movement largely drifted into irrelevance, doing little to shape public policy and even less to reverse its decline in membership. Now, as it begins to throw its weight around once again, Stanley Aronowitz, in "From the Ashes of the Old," has catalogued the many mistakes labor made to become so marginalized. He also provides a prescription, part sound advice, part pie in the sky, for how it can once again become powerful.
In an era when big money dominates politics, when giant corporations control much of the economy and the national discourse, and when the divide between haves and have-nots grows ever wider, Aronowitz, a former factory worker and now a sociology professor at the City University of New York, sees a revived labor movement as the best antidote to all these developments. "That we have growing inequality in America -- income differences are greater than in any advanced industrial society -- may be ascribed mainly to the erosion of trade union power," he writes.
In analyzing labor's decline, Aronowitz describes how unions long devoted themselves more to catering to well-heeled workers in steel and automobiles than to helping those most in need, like farm workers and hotel housekeepers. He attacks the many union leaders who became petty, bureaucratic dictators, preoccupied with preserving their positions and perks. Most of all, he denounces "business unionism," in which union officials focused on negotiating contracts and processing members' grievances, while ignoring labor's traditional calling of organizing the unorganized.
The bulk of the book consists of recommendations on how to put more movement back into the union movement. Aronowitz calls on labor to organize those workers on the lowest rung. And he urges it to build a broad social coalition, tied to the civil rights and women's movements.
To swell its ranks, Aronowitz says, labor must organize millions of workers in the South, even though both employers and employees there have been especially resistant to unionization. He also calls for recruiting the many disgruntled white-collar workers and professionals who are being squeezed, downsized and pushed around by management.
Aronowitz acknowledges that John J. Sweeney has begun taking many of these steps since assuming the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s helm nearly three years ago. His message to Sweeney is simply: move farther faster.
Many times, Aronowitz cavalierly offers recommendations without addressing the huge obstacles to implementing them. Labor leaders, he writes, should refuse to grant major concessions in contract bargaining, as though corporations would suddenly roll over. He urges unions to demand a shorter workweek without addressing why, in an era of galloping globalization, this would not push up labor costs and perhaps push jobs overseas.
Written in a dry, sometimes academic tone, "From the Ashes of the Old" appears aimed not at rank-and-file workers but at politicians, union leaders and intellectuals. The book contains an impressive in-depth look at the workings and strategies of more than a dozen unions. Aronowitz might have made his arguments more persuasive by including some human voices and stories to personify the unhappy trends he describes -- workers struggling to survive on the minimum wage, for example.
In one of his few poignant passages, Aronowitz all too briefly tells how unions helped his father, a garment worker, and his mother, an office clerk. Proud that he has inherited their pro-union legacy, Aronowitz comes across as part of a dying breed: a member of the working class turned intellectual romantic. For him, labor's flame, though dimmed, can still someday burn brightly -- especially if union officialdom takes his advice to heart.

HEADLINE: Fallen Eagle

BYLINE: By Geoffrey C. Ward; Geoffrey C. Ward is a historian and writer of documentary films. He is currently at work on a book about Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Susan B. Anthony, as well as a history of jazz.

 BODY:

LINDBERGH
 By A. Scott Berg.
 Illustrated. 628 pp. New York:
 G. P. Putnam's Sons. $30.
 
 UNDER A WING
 A Memoir.
 By Reeve Lindbergh.
 Illustrated. 223 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $23. 
 Charles Lindbergh's one-man flight from New York to Paris in 1927 made him the most admired man on earth, and the kidnapping and death of his firstborn son won him the world's sympathy in 1932. But after Pearl Harbor, memories of his obdurate opposition to American intervention in the war against Hitler caused millions to see him as a Nazi sympathizer, a defeatist, perhaps even a traitor. "Imagine," his sister-in-law wrote, "in just 15 years he had gone from Jesus to Judas." The early war years proved to be the low point in his career's remarkable trajectory. He refused ever to recant his conviction that America had been wrong to go to war, but he demonstrated his patriotism by helping evaluate new aircraft and, although a civilian, volunteering to fly combat missions in the South Pacific; he then went on to write an account of his Paris flight that won him a Pulitzer Prize and to become one of history's most tireless -- and effective -- conservationists. Through it all, he remained taciturn, aloof, without apparent emotion -- a puzzle to the best of his biographers and something of a mystery even to his own children.
In "Lindbergh," A. Scott Berg brings us about as close as I suspect we will ever get to the man himself. The first biographer to be granted unfettered access to Lindbergh's private papers, Berg provides enough fresh detail to trace the roots of Lindbergh's personality, its strengths as well as its maddening flaws, all the way back to his turbulent boyhood, a period so painful to him that as an adult he once admitted, "I have no recollection whatever of my daily routine during the early years of my life."
Little wonder: He was an only child trapped between estranged, eccentric parents whose affection for him was more than matched by their loathing for each other. His father and namesake was a singularly independent-minded Swedish-born Congressman who destroyed his career by doggedly continuing to attack America's entry into World War I long after even his Minnesota constituents had mobilized to crush the Hun. He inculcated in his son both his stoicism -- the younger Lindbergh liked to boast that his father had once endured surgery to repair a hernia without anesthesia -- and his studied disregard for the opinions of others: "You and I can take hard knocks," the old man told his son. "We'll get along no matter what happens." It was his father's example, Berg writes, that convinced Lindbergh that "greatness came at the inevitable price of being misunderstood."
The boy was proud of his father but he spent most of his time in the bizarre company of a mother so noisy that members of her husband's family called her "the Anvil Chorus," and so hot-tempered and self-dramatizing that she once held a revolver to her husband's head and may have failed to pull the trigger only because her weary target told her to go ahead and shoot. Young Charles had little time to be a boy. He and his mother moved nearly every year -- he attended at least 10 schools by the age of 18, did poorly at all of them and made lasting friends at none. Instead, he was expected to act as his mother's confidant and caretaker, serving as her chauffeur from the age of 11, running the family farm for her while trying to finish high school and all the time struggling to stay at least one step ahead of her bewildering, perpetually shifting moods.
"Father . . . was ever on the alert for dangers, though the dangers were unspecified," Lindbergh's sixth and youngest child, Reeve, remembers in her wonderful family memoir, "Under a Wing." " 'It's the unforeseen . . .' he would warn us. 'It's always the unforeseen.' " All his life, Lindbergh would try to predict the unpredictable and to seek to impose his own absolute control over people and events. That compulsion served him superbly at 25 when planning his famous flight: he carried with him just five sandwiches, he explained, because "If I get to Paris I won't need any more, and if I don't get to Paris, I won't need any more, either."
But after that nothing would ever be the same. The larger world refused to bend to his will; time and again he would find himself undone by the unforeseen. Even after 45 difficult years of marriage, Anne Morrow Lindbergh could never read her husband's account of his landing at Paris without tears. "There is something," she confided to her diary, "in the directness -- simplicity -- innocence of that boy arriving after that terrific flight -- completely unaware of the world interest -- the wild crowds below. The rush of the crowds to the plane is symbolic of life rushing at him -- a new life -- new responsibilities -- he was completely unaware of and unprepared for."
Although she was the daughter of a wealthy diplomat, Anne Morrow was even more shy, more unprepared for fame, than the man whose life and responsibilities she shared from 1929 until his death. But when she surprised his latest biographer by opening her own papers to him as well as her late husband's, she sent him a remarkably clear-eyed note: "You can't write about Charles," she wrote Berg, "without writing about me." She was right: Her writings, filled with love for her husband but also with more knowledge of his faults than her previously published diaries would suggest, bring to this account of their lives together a remarkable intimacy and candor. "Lindbergh" is almost as much her biography as his.
The first crisis they faced together -- the death of their child, the appalling circus that surrounded his kidnapper's trial and execution -- also demonstrated the basic differences between man and wife. Anne Lindbergh was devastated. Her husband was never once seen to weep. Instead, he hurled himself again and again into the sky, to the West Coast, the Arctic Circle, Europe, seeking the escape he had always found in flight, the loss of "all conscious connection with the past" that had been precious to him ever since he'd first left the ground -- and his intrusive mother -- behind. Looking back, his wife would come to believe that his chronic restlessness resulted from a terror of facing his own emotions related to the unmourned loss of their son but reaching all the way back to childhood.
The kidnapping also drove the Lindberghs out of their country, first to England, then to a rocky private island off the northern coast of Brittany, in search of a place where they might be left alone. In 1936, the United States military attache in Berlin asked Lindbergh to come to Germany to assess Hitler's fast-growing air force. He was impressed by it -- and by what he called the "youth, hope and vigor in Germany today" as well. The democracies were "in decline," he believed, and of the "lies and insults of the press" in his own homeland, he wrote that "it takes the sweetness from the freedom of democracy and makes one wonder where freedom ends and disorder begins." In Nazi Germany, disorder was not a problem.
One of Anne Morrow's former teachers at Smith College privately dismissed Lindbergh early on as "really no more than a mechanic . . . had it not been for the lone eagle flight, he would now be in charge of a gasoline station on the outskirts of St. Louis." That was unfair. Lindbergh was a superb pilot, a skilled writer, an able laboratory researcher, whose work with Dr. Alexis Carrel helped produce an important precursor of the artificial heart, and an effective spokesman for whatever cause currently concerned him. But his mind was a muddle, a magpie's mix of science, eugenics, mysticism and apocalyptic visions. Race infused his thinking, too: aviation, he intoned in Reader's Digest in 1939, was "a gift from heaven . . . a tool specially shaped for Western hands . . . one of those priceless possessions which permit the White race to live at all in a pressing sea of Yellow, Black and Brown." Rather than go to war with Germany, America should join with her and England to form a mighty "Western Wall of race and arms which can hold back either a Genghis Khan or the infiltration of inferior blood."
Anne Lindbergh later confessed that she and her husband had both been "very blind, especially in the beginning, to the worst evils of the Nazi system." Her husband never retracted anything. But Berg discovered that when Lindbergh published his "Wartime Journals" in 1970 he did quietly try to tidy up the record. William Jovanovich claimed in the publisher's introduction that all the colonel's writings appeared precisely as written, save for references to persons still living and material that was either repetitious or "not important." Berg has found that much of the omitted material actually revealed Lindbergh's eerie attitudes toward Jews. Returning to America from Europe in 1939, for example, Lindbergh's ship passed through stormy seas. "The steward tells me that most of the Jewish passengers are sick," he wrote. "Imagine the United States taking these Jews in addition to those we already have. There are too many in places like New York already. A few Jews add strength and character to a country, but too many create chaos. And we are getting too many." Berg is admirably fair-minded -- he argues persuasively that his stubbornly misguided subject was never a Nazi, never a would-be dictator, as Franklin Roosevelt for one believed he was -- but when he writes that Lindbergh later, "not fully realizing" that comments like these were anti-Semitic, "intuitively deleted them," he is surely being too kind.
Reeve Lindbergh was born in 1945, and her memoir beautifully recaptures the determinedly ordered life her father insisted his family lead in their Connecticut home after the war. He was a loving, active father when he was home, she remembers, privately more demonstrative than her mother. But he was also severe: "Our lives," she writes, like the airplanes he flew, "were also monitored by checklists."His older daughter, Anne, remembered: "There were only two ways of doing things -- Father's way and the wrong way." He barred television and comic books and ice with 7-Up, and when his wife suggested she needed a new stove, he asked her to postpone the decision until they could talk over the purchase together "from personal, economic and military standpoints." No eventuality was too small -- or too unlikely -- to be overlooked when planning for the family's future: in case war broke out with the Soviets while he was away, his wife was to cancel the children's dental appointments since the enemy might poison the water supply. When his youngest son, Scott, rebelled against his strictures, Lindbergh neither spoke nor wrote to him for several years.
Anne Lindbergh's 1955 best seller, "Gift From the Sea," became a source of inspiration for a whole generation of wives and mothers -- "the great vacationless class," she called them -- who, like herself, were beginning to search for more fulfilling lives once their children had grown and moved away. As Berg shows for the first time, the book's poetic serenity came at a fearful price. Her husband's incessant comings and goings, his humorless efforts to direct her life and those of her children, his scorn for genuine emotion and impatience with her fragile sense of herself and her writing, all took their toll on her and on her marriage. She turned to psychiatry, sought solace in a brief affair and considered divorce before settling into a new kind of relationship, one in which she abandoned hope of slowing her husband down but also refused to conform to his every whim. Through it all, the Lindberghs somehow remained deeply in love with each other.
Nothing could stop Lindbergh's journeying -- but his mission changed with time. He led simulated bomber missions for the Strategic Air Command, promoted business for Pan American World Airways, championed the early space program. Then, in the mid-1960's, he abruptly changed course. Arguing that the aviation age he had helped usher in had done more harm than good, that the future of civilization now demanded the rescue of what little wilderness remained, he became a sort of one-man conservation commando corps, dropping from the skies wherever species were endangered or indigenous people found themselves threatened by change. In country after country, conservation laws were strengthened and wild places preserved because he had lent his name to their cause.
To the very end, Charles Lindbergh struggled against the unforeseen, fought to remain in full control. Dying from cancer in the summer of 1974, he insisted on being flown to Maui, the last and most remote of the several "perches" he had built for himself and which he expected his patient wife to oversee in his absence. There, surrounded by his family, he spent his last days meticulously planning his own burial. He picked the readings for his funeral, chose the inscription and the typeface for his tombstone, had his grave dug to precise specifications -- "Father was obsessed about drainage," his son Jon remembered -- and even saw to it that his death certificate was signed in advance. Every line was filled in except the date.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 78; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 2801 words

HEADLINE: Weld Thing

BYLINE: By Frank Bruni; Frank Bruni, a Times Metro reporter, wrote about Mary Bono for the magazine in March.

 BODY:
It starts the moment bill weld steps from the car and seems as if it will never stop: the craned necks, the raised thumbs, the exuberant hellos. As he makes his way into and then through Fenway Park, there is a new fan at every step, another outstretched hand at every turn. On this mid-July night in the heart of Boston, the approbation is as thick as the humidity. "Can I get a picture of you with my nephew?" asks one man, maneuvering the little boy into position.
Weld obliges with a hand around the boy's back, a well-practiced smile and a wry apology. "Sorry about the extra poundage," he quips, his free hand straying toward a belly that's only a tad larger than it used to be. There is another man who regales Weld with praise for his six and a half years as Governor of Massachusetts, another who vows eternal political allegiance to him, yet another who simply wants to chew the fat. 
 Finally, Weld reaches his destination: a swath of seats where more than a dozen colleagues from the blue-chip law firm where he now works are ensconced, frothy beers in hand, for a ties-off, wing-tips-unlaced outing. He takes his seat and looks toward home plate, a white speck, almost invisible from this remote section deep behind right field. Strangely, Weld has run a gantlet of adoration to end up far, far away from the action.
"Governor Weld," shouts a voice from three rows behind him, "what are you doing all the way back here?"
"These are the best seats I could get," Weld quips. "When you're out, you're out."
Just two years ago, Weld was very much in. He was a popular second-term Republican Governor in a heavily Democratic state. He had presided over, and certainly contributed to, the state's transition from economic bust to boom. Pundits touted his brand of fiscal conservatism and social liberalism as a New Age model, and Democratic peers emulated it. Journalists anointed him a Presidential possibility.
Then he made one of the most abrupt, astonishing U-turns in recent political history. Brashly tempting electoral fate, he challenged John Kerry, a popular Democratic incumbent, for one of Massachusetts' two seats in the U.S. Senate. It was a questionable decision, ending in defeat, that Weld followed with another, more quixotic quest: to become the U.S. Ambassador to Mexico, a post that Jesse Helms, the ultraconservative Republican chairman of the Senate's Foreign Relations Committee, almost immediately vowed to deny him. Weld left office to devote himself to the fight for confirmation. Once again, he lost.
Now comes another surprise, of an entirely different sort. This month, Simon & Schuster published Weld's first novel, "Mackerel by Moonlight," a political, picaresque tale seasoned generously with his trademark droll humor. Although Weld is not the first politician to try his hand at fiction, the book remains an unusual endeavor, the latest curve ball in a career that has recently been rife with them.
And it draws renewed attention to a question that has perplexed observers for some time now: How did William F. Weld, 53, a onetime golden boy, get from there to here? One of the most frequently offered answers has to do with Weld's status as a pro-choice, gay-friendly libertarian in a Republican Party that does not easily accommodate such thinking. Or, Weld's exile is chalked up to a few bad decisions.
But the truth is more complicated, and has at least as much to do with who Weld is on the inside as the world outside him. As reflected in both the substance and tone of "Mackerel by Moonlight," which is more "Primary Colors" than "Profiles in Courage," this is a man who has always favored irony over earnestness, who seems at least as interested in private amusement as in public service and whose itchy mind demands new adventures in rapid succession. This is a man, in other words, almost spectacularly ill suited to the stratagems, tedium and patience required for sustained political glory.
"Bill Weld is a guy who likes the bold stroke," says Ray Howell, who worked on Weld's gubernatorial campaigns. "He likes to throw the Hail Mary pass. Grinding it out is not something that appeals to him. Unfortunately, I think grinding it out is often the successful route for elective politics."
"Mackerel by Moonlight" introduces Terry Mullally, who is both like and unlike Weld. While Weld grew up on 600 acres on Long Island and followed his forebears' leather-soled footsteps to Harvard, Mullally comes of age in Brooklyn and gets his degree from a city university. Like Weld, Mullally first makes his name tackling corruption as a Federal prosecutor and ends up in Boston. Unlike Weld, he is a Democrat, and the elective office he seeks is district attorney.
As the novel tracks Mullally's meteoric rise and all the debris that falls to earth along the way, it eventually becomes a whodunit about two mysterious deaths. The title alludes to a pungent put-down of a successful politician, and of politics itself. Like a rotting mackerel in the moonlight, the saying goes, it shines and it stinks.
Jaunty and clever, the book nonetheless seems the byproduct less of Weld's literary talents than of his name recognition, a more respectable relative of "Embrace the Serpent," the bizarrely titled and quizzically received international thriller co-written by Marilyn Quayle, and "Murder at City Hall," a mystery co-written by Ed Koch that also left many critics scratching their heads, if not holding their noses. It underlines the way in which political celebrity seems to be a flexible currency that puts Susan Molinari in the anchor chair of a TV news program and Donna Shalala in milk advertisements.
But "Mackerel by Moonlight" is most interesting for what it says about Weld himself. He began writing it in January 1997, shortly after his failed Senate bid, when he was still Governor and, according to friends, beset less by disappointment than by disinterest in the familiar tasks at hand. His account of its genesis and rapid completion betrays not only his quicksilver mind but also his elite cultural bearings, intellectual vanity and "look, Ma, no hands" style.
He says the book was born one night as he sat in front of a blazing fire in his three-story, seven-bedroom house in Cambridge, reading a description of the way F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote "The Last Tycoon" from an outline. "I thought, Gosh, it must be easy to write a book from an outline," Weld recalls. So he tried one. "It took me 15 to 20 minutes."
He then dictated the narrative onto tapes for his secretary to transcribe, devoting one day every weekend to the task and finishing the first draft in eight weeks. His muses, he says, included Thomas Mann and Graham Greene. As he refined the novel over subsequent drafts, he kept a careful record of each version, "just in case some jaundiced observer should suggest there must have been a ghostwriter somewhere."
The result offers no life lessons and suggests no particular conviction, a charge that Weld's political critics have often levied against him. As the protagonist caroms through a weightless adventure that clocks in under 250 pages, his emotions remain inscrutable and his demeanor aloof, very much like his author's.
"I still have nothing to say," Weld explains one afternoon in his Boston office, referring to a remark he once made about being intrigued by the idea of writing a novel, but not being able to identify a message he wanted to get across. "I'm the guy who hates politicians who preach at you."
The next day, the subject recurs as he, his wife, Susan Roosevelt Weld, and one of his five children, Mary, sit on their vast, well-shaded lawn.
Susan says she did not actually crack the book but had Mary read it to her as they drove from Cambridge to New Haven, where Mary attends Yale. The two-hour drive proved ample time.
"It's a bagatelle," Weld confirms.
"Large print," his wife chimes in.
"Generous margins," Weld adds.
The exchange captures Weld's charm: his occasionally self-effacing humor, his banter. But it also suggests the lack of gravitas that made his political career so offbeat and unlikely, and arguably curtailed it.
Mary Weld, enjoying tiny spoonfuls of brownie batter interspersed with mincing sips from a quart of milk, weighs in with her own appraisal. "I'm glad it has no moral," she says. "A moral would be pompous."
Weld's tenure as governor from 1991 to 1997 was so successful that observers often forget how improbably he squeaked into office, and how much his personal wealth and fortunate circumstances mattered. Back in 1990, when he first ran, he was a leaden public speaker. He had never held any elective office, and while his experience as a high-ranking member of the U.S. Justice Department in the 1980's gave him law-enforcement credentials, he was untested on other issues. At their convention, state Republicans endorsed his rival in the primary, Steven Pierce. Howell remembers, "I couldn't get reporters to come to a campaign event if I promised that Bill Weld would be biting off the heads of chickens."
But Weld pumped about $1 million of his own money into his primary campaign, handily outspending Pierce. And primary voters gambled that Weld's liberal social views -- arising from his distaste for bigotry or any other limit to individual expression and potential -- gave him a better chance against the eventual Democratic nominee than Pierce had. Weld won the primary and then, in the general election, capitalized on voters' exasperation with the state's economic woes and their willingness to try a change from decades of Democratic leadership. He narrowly defeated a weak opponent, John R. Silber.
This was not the triumph of a man with a potent sense of calling or long history of political involvement. Although his years as a classics major and law student at Harvard coincided with the activism of the late 1960's, Weld was largely unmoved by it.
"He is the last person to get agitated about anything," says Mitchell Adams, a Harvard classmate who became the state's revenue commissioner under Weld and still holds that position. Adams and other classmates say that Weld stood out, instead, for his seemingly effortless mastery of his studies and zest for competitive games. "He played squash with a gentleman's relish," recalls Peter Lubin, another classmate. "He was very good at chess, and could beat people with his back to the board. It was a party trick he would do on occasion."
Weld approached the job of governing with a similar insouciance. He kept bankers' hours and seldom missed his thrice-weekly appointments on the squash court. After signing a bill to protect waterways, he dove, fully clothed, into the Charles River. Visitors to his office spotted a stuffed armadillo near his desk. "I like creatures who are slow and stupid," Weld explained.
For Massachusetts voters, Weld's levity and sublime confidence was a welcome relief after Gov. Michael Dukakis's severe prognostications. Moreover, he got the job done. Leading the national charge to trim welfare programs and generally rein in government spending, he reduced taxes while finding ample money for education and the environment. All the while, he had the cooperation of a Legislature still controlled by Democrats. In 1994, he was re-elected with a staggering 71 percent of the vote.
But aides said he was bored and had limited interest in serving out a second term. So he set his sights on the Senate, then the ambassadorship, which dovetailed with his curiosity about international affairs. Aides advised him that if he were looking toward the Presidency, such a job change and gambit were madness. Weld ignored them.
"He's not ambitious in the way most politicians are," explains Marty Linsky, his chief secretary from 1992 to 1995. "The stuff that most politicians care about it not important to him. He wants to have a good time. He wants to have fun. He wants to be engaged all the time, but his definition of engagement is different from most people's, like sitting at the end of a dock in the Adirondacks reading Greek."
Susan Weld emerges from the family's Cambridge house in a pink cotton dress, with a tall glass in her hand. She is the great-granddaughter of Theodore Roosevelt and a distinguished scholar of East Asian law, and it would seem fitting if she were carrying an iced tea or gin and tonic. But her cargo undulates. It lives. And without so much as arching an eyebrow, she asks: "Want to feed a maggot to the hedgehog?"
That would be Privet, who resembles a Lilliputian porcupine and divides his time between a glass aquarium in the kitchen and a makeshift outdoor pen. Crouching beside it, Susan Weld uses a stick to scoop grubs from the glass and leans close to Privet as he savors his snack.
"You have to put your head down so you can hear the crunching," she explains. "That's the best part of a hedgehog: the crunching."
The comment oddly echoes something Bill Weld said the previous day. He was talking about his regular business trips to Manhattan, where he has an apartment on Central Park South, and raving about a dinner at Balthazar, the cacophonous SoHo bistro. He, his wife, several of their children and a few friends began with "three deckers of chilled seafood, including snails and slugs, to which I'm particularly partial," he recounted. "These snails and slugs were so big you could see their ears, and hearing the ears crunch was too much for a couple of the ladies. So of course I made a show of it."
The Welds seem to have their own obscure sources of amusement. While others regarded the war of words between Weld and Helms last summer as a stomach-churning embarrassment for the Republican Party, the Welds pronounce it a grand diversion.
As Weld tells it, he ran into Helms months later and told the Senator that he wanted to buy him dinner, because Helms was the reason he was working as a high-priced lawyer and could afford to. When Helms responded that he usually ate at home, Weld turned to a companion and exulted, "Senator Helms has just invited me to his house for dinner!"
Weld guffaws at the memory. "Senator Helms was waving his arms, 'No, no, no,"' Weld says. So there was never a trip to Helms's house, for dinner or anything else. "No jammy party," Weld sighs.
Although he assumes that what he calls the "apostasy" of his liberal social views helped fuel Helms's opposition to him, he steadfastly refuses to bash either Helms or the religious right. That would imply that they rattled him, and it's not at all clear that that's possible. Besides, Weld says that he's happy now -- that there's more "intellectual content" in his current legal work advising venture capitalists and private equity firms than there was in his second term as Governor. And he has already finished the first draft of a sequel to "Mackerel by Moonlight." It took him seven days instead of eight.
Beyond that, he is maddeningly hazy about his future, quite possibly because he is waiting to feel the next tickle of his fancy. Friends say he once eyed the Presidency and probably, at some level, still does. When questioned directly, Weld gives answers that seem deliberately opaque. The year 2000, he says, is out, but if the Democrats win again and there is no plausible Republican challenger with moderate social views in 2004, "it's not so clear I'll be free to cultivate my own garden."
But by forcing a confrontation with his own party for a dubiously prominent position in a Democratic Administration, he came across as disloyal, to the point where a shot at the Presidency seems impossible, and a Republican President might be disinclined to consider him for the kinds of Cabinet posts he once discussed with President Clinton's advisers. "Politically," said Greg Mueller, a Republican political consultant, "he's in no man's land."
Even if he weren't, it's doubtful that Weld could ever muster the conventional sincerity for the ultimate political prize. "Bill Weld is the mirror opposite of Bill Clinton," says Stuart Stevens, a Republican media consultant. "Clinton tries to become you. He's like some sci-fi creature who wraps around you and sucks out your energy. Weld is a guy who knows who he is and is very comfortable with himself. He doesn't take himself that seriously."
At the end of the game in Fenway, which the Boston Red Sox win, Weld is briefly elated, then instantly intent on finding a route over the Charles, and into Cambridge, that circumvents traffic. His demeanor is rapt as he barks out directions -- left, right, faster, slower -- that brilliantly do the trick. He's home in a flash. It's not much of a journey, or much of an accomplishment, but it seems to give him great pleasure. He walks off into the night with a bounce in his step.

HEADLINE: Q. & A.;
A Tenant Overpays On a Sublet

 BODY:

Q. My daughter has been subletting a rent-satbilized apartment in New York City for the last two years. She pays the rent to the tenant that had the apartment previous to her and not to the landlord.She believes that the real rent is approximately $500, however she pays $600. She has just been told that the rent would be increased to $1,000 or she must move. What rights does she have, if any? Can she contact the landlord and deal directly with him? ... Eli- nor Geller, Kendall Park, N.J. 

A. Edward T. Braverman, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that under state law, tenants in buildings with four or more rental units (except municipal housing and co-ops) have a right to sublease their apartment. The right is subject to the consent of the landlord, which may not be unreasonably withheld.
In rent-stabilized settings, Mr. Braverman said, the sublet rent cannot exceed the rent set for that apartment under the Rent Stabilization Code. However, he said, if an apartment is being sublet on a furnished basis, the tenant may charge the subletting tenant an additional 10 percent. Moreover, he said, a rent-stabilized tenant may not sublet an apartment for more than two out of every four years.
"In applying the foregoing principles, the prime tenant may have already overcharged the subtenant," Mr. Braverman said, explaining that the most the tenant can charge the subtenant would be 10 percent more than the tenant himself is paying, and then only if the apartment was furnished.
"As with a regular landlord, the prime tenant would be responsible for the return of the overcharge to the subtenant," he said. And since the Division of Housing and Community Renewal usually takes the position that there is a presumption of an intent to overcharge, Mr. Braverman said, the damages that the subtenant would be entitled to under that presumption would be three times the actual overcharge, plus, perhaps, a lawyer's fees.
Accordingly, he said, since the subtenant has already been in the apartment for two years, neither the original tenant nor the subtenant have the right to extend the sublease further without the landlord's permission. "And there is certainly no authority for the prime tenant to increase the rent to $1,000," he said.
Additional information on subletting -- along with guidance about what to do in the event of a rent overcharge -- can be obtained from the Division of Housing and Community Renewal by calling (718) 739-6400.
 
Condo Owner Finds Sublet Fee Troubling
 
Q. I own a condominium in White Plains that I rent to a tenant. At a meeting of the board of managers, the board voted to charge a "change of occupancy" fee of $500 each time a new tenant moves in. The board did not give each owner the right to vote on this and, as you can imagine, the fee is a deterrent to those of us who choose to rent out their unit and it is also very costly. Please advise whether this fee is legal. . . . Jo Baker, Madison, N.J.
 
A. "It is absolutely a legal fee," said William Robbins, a White Plains real estate lawyer.
Mr. Robbins explained that by law co-op and condominium boards have the right to take actions for the benefit of the building as a whole. Accordingly, he said, it is not unusual for boards to impose sublet fees or even to restrict the amount of time or number of times an apartment can be sublet.
"The truth is," Mr. Robbins said, "restrictions against subletting are usually for the owners' benefit. Number one, there is the feeling that with more owners living in a building, there will be more pride of ownership. And number two, if the number of sublets in the building goes anywhere above 50 percent, most banks won't go anywhere near the building with financing."
The only way the letter-writer would be able to overturn the board's decision, he said, would be to find enough tenants with similar feelings about the change of occupancy fee to vote out the present board and vote in a board that would eliminate the fee.
