HEADLINE: Opposing Camps But Shared Opinions

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE

 BODY:
EVERY two years, since Naomi C. Matusow, a Democrat, did the unexpected in 1992 and beat a supposedly entrenched Republican for a seat in the State Assembly, the Republicans target Mrs. Matusow's seat as the one they will reclaim. In 1994 and 1996, the Republican candidate went down to defeat.
This year Republicans think that finally they have the recipe for success in the candidacy of Ursula G. LaMotte of Bedford, an articulate moderate Republican who serves on the County Board of Legislators. State Senator Nicholas A. Spano of Yonkers, chairman of the Westchester Republican Committee, said: "We have an outstanding candidate with a better message. I feel very good about the possibility of recapturing that seat." 
 But Democrats say that Mrs. LaMotte, a two-term County Legislator, should not start packing for Albany yet -- that Mrs. Matusow, also a resident of Bedford, is what her constituents in the 89th Assembly District want. "I think Naomi has won by increasing margins each time," said David A. Alpert, chairman of the County Democratic Committee. "She has a record people like."
The 89th Assembly District is made up of Bedford, Harrison, Mount Kisco, New Castle, North Castle, North Salem, Pound Ridge, Somers and part of White Plains. Republicans have a small edge over Democrats in enrollment, but there is also a large number of unenrolled independent voters. Mrs. LaMotte also has the Conservative Party line, while Mrs. Matusow has the Independence Party line.
The contest in the 89th District is one of seven Assembly races in the county, but the others are drawing less attention either because the entrenched incumbent has no opponent or the opponent is considered a long shot. In the 89th District both state Republicans and Democrats are expected to expend resources to help their respective candidates.
Separate interviews with Mrs. LaMotte and Mrs. Matusow suggest that the two share many of the same views and concerns. They are both pro-choice on abortion, and they express concern about economic development and taxes, children, crime, education and the environment.
And assuming the race stays in their gloved hands and is not turned over to outside party advisers (as sometimes happens in targeted races), it will be a positive campaign, with each emphasizing why she feels she has a record of achievement worthy of victory rather than trying to disparage her opponent's record. If this holds true, there will be no mudslinging in this race, no sloganism. "I don't want to get into a dirty campaign," Mrs. LaMotte said. "It's not necessary. My reading of the electorate is that they do not like it. I think we both have records that the people can judge."
Mrs. Matusow, a lawyer, said that would be a welcome change from two years ago when the campaign against her "was really negative and distorted my record beyond recognition." She added that she is not focusing on Mrs. LaMotte's record but on her own record. "I want to run a clean campaign; that is my intention," she said. Neither candidate has, each says, even spent much time scrutinizing the other's record.
What, then, distinguishes the two? Why is one a Republican and the other a Democrat when much of what they seem to stand for is similar? Mrs. LaMotte said she is a Republican because "I grew up in a very Republican household in the Eisenhower years, and those were good years for Republicans, I guess. Being a Republican seems to fit me." But she was quick to add: "I'm concerned about some of the trends in the Republican Party nationally, but I guess you'd call me a moderate. I think I'm a Westchester Republican as I understand them to be: pro-choice, pro-environment, in favor of keeping open space and being fiscally conservative."
Her role model is Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, and Mrs. LaMotte said she wants to go to Albany because "my concerns with the state government are very deep."
"I feel certainly our Governor has turned things around, and we are moving in the right direction," she said, "but we haven't gotten there yet." One of the obstacles to this, she said, is Sheldon Silver, the Speaker of the Democratic-controlled Assembly, whom Mrs. Matusow almost always supports, she said.
Mrs. Matusow said she is a Democrat because of the issues focused on by Democrats: "Being pro-choice, being concerned with the safety of children, being concerned with preserving the environment, providing quality public education, both at the secondary and college level, banning assault weapons." She added: "It's very fortunate for me that I can talk about these issues in a community where people want to know about the issues. Party labels don't carry any sway." She defeated Peter Sullivan of White Plains, a seemingly unstoppable Republican, in 1992 "because he didn't do things for people."
She continued, "I have been re-elected twice in spite of the fact that I have been the No. 1 target of the Republicans because the people in the district respect what I do."
The parts of her record Mrs. Matusow emphasizes include support for a ban on assault weapons (legislation that has died in the Republican-controlled Senate; the ban is supported by Mrs. LaMotte as well), a follow-through on campaign pledges to get more state school aid for her district, although she says it is still not enough, and her efforts as a member of the Assembly's Economic Development Committee to cut taxes in the state. "I have worked very hard to see that we cut taxes, sales tax, property taxes and the income tax," she said. "I have been instrumental in seeing tax cuts that total $10 billion." Her votes helped enact the state's School Tax Relief program, known as STAR, which lowers all property owners' school taxes, and the elimination starting next year of sales tax on some clothes and footwear. She knows, she said, the loss of sales tax will cut millions of dollars in revenue for Westchester governments, and she has vowed to push to get the state to reimburse the county, cities and other taxing districts.
She was endorsed this year by the League of Conservation Voters, an environmental organization. She also said she worked hard to pass Megan's Law, which requires that local officials be notified when sex offenders move into their community. A priority for the next term would be a law that allows schools, day-care centers and other agencies to fingerprint and do background checking on prospective employees who might work with children, the elderly or the infirm.
Mrs. LaMotte's civil associations are many and will, she said, help make her a good lawmaker. She is a former member of the County Planning Board and a former Deputy Supervisor in Bedford. She helped start recycling programs in the 1970's before they were mandated. And she is on the board of the Children's Aid Society of New York City, the Visiting Nurses of the Hudson Valley and the Boys and Girls Club of Northern Westchester. She was also a board member of the Westchester Children's Association. "My work with children's groups has given me great insight into social problems," she said. Housing issues, she said, is another top concern of hers.
Mrs. LaMotte serves on three committees on the Democratic-controlled Board of Legislators: the influential Budget and Appropriations Committee, as well as the Environment and Health Committees. As a County Legislator, she said, her accomplishments include increasing the dedicated parkland in the county, helping to defeat a proposed high occupancy vehicle lane for I-287 and encouraging long-term planning.
But there does seem to be a few issues on which they differ. Mrs. LaMotte supported a bill two years ago that would have set up the mechanism for the county government to reassess all property in the county. Mrs. Matusow voted against it. While it ultimately passed the Board of Legislators and then both the Senate and the Assembly, it was vetoed by Gov. George E. Pataki. Mrs. LaMotte is also in favor of the death penalty. Mrs. Matusow is not.
Neither candidate said she believes President Clinton's problems will affect the race. The voters in the district, they say, are too smart to let what is happening in Washington influence their votes for state office.

HEADLINE: In the Region / New Jersey;
Elizabeth Is Razing Its Time-Worn Public Housing

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WYNONA ANCRUM is looking forward to the day when she and her family will be able to move out of her time-worn public-housing complex in the Elizabethport section of Elizabeth into a new town-house-style apartment with a yard and front porch.
"The new housing will provide an uplift, a new outlook on life, especially for children who will be able to live in something better, live in a house," said the 43-year-old Ms. Ancrum, who has lived in her apartment in the 250-unit, eight-building Migliore Manor project for 20 years. She shares it with her mother, grown son and granddaughter. 
 Ms. Ancrum -- who is president of the Migliore Manor Resident Council, as well as a member of the Board of Commissioners of the Housing Authority of the City of Elizabeth -- is working with the authority on a five-year program to replace both Migliore Manor and the adjacent 405-unit, 12-building Pioneer Homes with new housing.
The complexes, which overlook the Arthur Kill, were built in 1940 and 1953 and are home to about 1,450 families, with an average annual income of $8,200. That compares with $24,487 a year for households in the rest of the struggling neighborhood of Elizabethport.
"This program," said Mayor J. Christian Bollwage, "is the start of a change that will provide a better quality of living than has existed for the last 30 years." It will also have a domino effect in the entire neighborhood, he added.
"As long as the high-density public housing remained untouched," Mayor Bollwage said, "there was no real incentive for private investment to come into the area."
A mix of at least 600 new and renovated residences, both rental and for-sale, are planned, including row houses, duplexes and detached homes. About 308 of them, including 60 units reserved for the elderly, will rise on the site of the two public housing complexes, which will be razed.
The designated developer for those units is a joint venture of the private Community Investment Strategies of New Brunswick and Liberty Group of Portland, Me.
The remaining units will take shape on scattered sites elsewhere in Elizabethport, which is in the far eastern corner of this Union County city. It is isolated from the rest of the municipality by the New Jersey Turnpike, which cut through the neighborhood in the 50's and contributed to its decline. Urban Strategies L.L.C. of Manhattan will develop most of these units along with other private and nonprofit developers.
The rebuilding program, expected to cost about $80 million, will start next month with the demolition of three now-vacant public housing buildings, with a total of 129 units within the two complexes. This will pave the way for construction of the first 72 on-site units, which is to start in January. At about the same time construction is to begin on eight two-family homes off-site on Front Street.
The rest of the units, both on and off site, are to be built in the next five years.
Financing for the program is coming in part from a $28.9 million grant from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, which the city received last October. The rest has and will come from other public as well as private sources.
The Federal grant requires that housing for people with higher incomes be part of the neighborhood mix. The new public housing units in Elizabethport will be targeted to families making up to 80 percent of the area's median income. For a family of four, 80 percent of the median would be $51,760.
The Federal grant also provides for job training and courses for residents in such matters as money management -- reflecting the theory of many housing advocates that new residences alone will not solve all the problems of public housing.
To help solve such problems, the city is turning the city's industrial waterfront into a recreational area, with a marina in place and recreational fields planned.
And to address the problem of jobs, said Mayor Bollwage, a retail-skills center will work in tandem with a $350 million mall with more than a million square feet now under construction northeast of Elizabethport. The complex, which is to be called the Jersey Gardens Mall, is scheduled to open November 1999.
Elizabeth is among the latest cities in New Jersey -- which has about 53,000 public housing units, according to the Newark office of H.U.D. -- to move forward with such a rebuilding program.
FOR the last six years, Newark has been involved in the state's largest program -- calling for the razing of 12 bleak public housing towers and replacing them with a total of 1,777 low-rise units. So far, eight towers have been razed and 949 of the new units have been built or are under construction. The rest are in various stages of planning or development, said Harry Robinson, a spokesman for the Newark Housing Authority.
Late last month New Brunswick received a $7.5 million Federal grant to initiate a $30 million program to replace the New Brunswick Homes public-housing complex with 246 units in four eight-story buildings alongside Route 18, not far from the city's downtown. The complex will be razed and replaced with 198 new units, both on the site and elsewhere in the city. Some 146 families now living in the complex have accepted Section 8 certificates for rental subsidies to move elsewhere, said Glenn Patterson, director of the city's Department of Policy, Planning and Economic Development. Demolition is at least a year or two away, he added.
High-density, and often high-rise, public housing projects started springing up in the 50's as a safe and economical way to house low-income families. But over time many of the projects -- beset by crime, neglect, overcrowding and mismanagement -- became the housing of last resort for the poorest of families.
The Federal Government no longer supports the building of high-density, high-rise public housing for families. About three years ago the Government also ended the one-to-one replacement program. Previously, a 1987 Federal law forbade razing public housing apartments unless they were replaced with an equal number of units.
In Elizabeth, the garden-style Pioneer Homes and Migliore Manor are the densest of the city's seven public-housing projects, totaling 1,678 units of which 600 are in four buildings reserved for elderly residents. The complexes, designed with their backs to the street facing interior courtyards, also became magnets for a tangle of urban ills, including crime and drug trafficking.
"The problem was one of having too many people of the same economic means living on too little land," said William D. Jones, executive director of the Elizabeth housing authority. The solution, he said, is to reduce the density and provide housing that "will mix the incomes better."
Under the plan, crafted over the last 20 months with input from tenants, the new housing will reduce the density on the eight-block site by 68 percent to 15 dwelling units per acre, which is close to the 11 dwelling units per acre found in the surrounding neighborhood. And by making units available to people of differing incomes the number of very-low-income families will be reduced to 53 percent from 89 percent.
All existing qualified public housing tenants will be guaranteed one of the new units built on or off site. But they also can accept Section 8 certificates for rent subsidies and move elsewhere if they choose.
As now planned the apartments will rent for $500 to $600 a month (the rent for public-housing tenants is capped at 30 percent of their income). Prices for the one- and two-family homes are expected to be $65,000 to $140,000, which is market-rate for the area, said Mr. Jones. Estimates are that 25 to 40 public-housing families will become homeowners, he added.
The first 72 on-site units that Community Investment Strategies will build will be rentals. They will rise along Front Street and nearby side streets, and 80 percent of them will be reserved for public-housing families, said Christiana Foglio, the company's president.
"This is not a program of gentrification," she added.
The apartments will have one to four bedrooms and 670 to 1,500 square feet. Monthly rents for public-housing tenants are capped at 30 percent of income. The rest will rent for $550 to $900 a month. Completion is expected by January 2000, said Ms. Foglio.
Mr. Jones, the housing authority director, said the one- and two-family homes under the rebuilding program would have two and three bedrooms and 1,000 to 1,400 square feet. The initial eight off-site two-family homes will also rise on Front Street. Sale prices are expected to be $65,000 to $140,000, which is market rate for the neighborhood, he said.

HEADLINE: In the Region / Connecticut;
Avalon Expected to Nearly Triple Stamford Rentals

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
WHEN Avalon Bay Communities completes two rental apartment projects under construction in Stamford -- and if it wins expected approvals on a third -- it will add 1,132 units to the total of 638 rental units it has already built in the city at Avalon Glen and Avalon Grove.
Since it was formed in 1993 as a real estate investment trust with headquarters in Alexandria, Va., Avalon has built in Connecticut alone a total of 1,106 units in Wilton, Trumbull and Hamden, and it has built or renovated more than 42,300 apartments in 29 markets across the country. The company focuses on building luxury rental apartments in or near major cities. 
 Over the next decade Avalon and other developers are expected to produce a combined total of 2,800 rental apartments in and around the downtown business district in Stamford, a city where almost half of the housing units are rentals.
According to Robin Stein, Stamford's land-use planner, "there is a tremendous need for housing people who work in the corporations and want to live downtown."
Samuel Fuller, regional vice president for Avalon Bay Communities in Wilton, noted the more than 98 percent occupancy rate of the existing Avalon rental complexes and reiterated his company's belief that Connecticut is grossly underbuilt in rental housing. But in the current climate of economic uncertainty, he added, "we are no longer moving into some of the more peripheral markets like Greater Hartford."
Stamford's increased need for housing results from its plummeting office vacancy rate, now 6 percent compared with 22 percent in 1992. Paul Bruenich, managing partner at William Pitt Real Estate, said:
"There is the potential for adding another 1.8 million square feet to the 15 million square feet of offices, and there is virtually no inventory in rental apartments. People moving up from Manhattan are accustomed to renting."
"We have over 40,000 units of housing in Stamford," said Mayor Dannel Malloy. "What's significant is that we are creating more housing downtown than any other city. Much of it is upper end, but we have older buildings that may no longer command high rents, and we intend to have an impact on all economic levels by redeveloping Southfield Village and rehabilitating Housing Authority property on Connecticut Avenue. We will see 2,000 units built without a single unit of lower-income housing being displaced."
Out of five major projects under way or planned in Stamford, four will offer 20 percent of the apartments at lower than market rates. Through a state formula, developers are given extra units in return for the reduced rents.
Avalon Corners, one of Avalon's projects now under way, is rising on three acres along Washington Boulevard, close to the business district and railroad station. The $32.5-million project, which will have a 24-hour concierge, will contain 195 one- and two-bedroom apartments.
In the courtyard there will be a heated swimming pool, a picnic area with barbecue grills, walking paths and landscaping. A clubhouse will feature a room for private parties, billiard room, a business center with computers and fax machines, a conference center and a fully equipped fitness center.
Each apartment will have a full-sized washer-dryer, designer kitchen and walk-in closets, and some will have gas fireplaces and lofts. Completion is targeted for the spring of 2000.
Rentals for one-bedroom units measuring 778 to 1,177 square feet will be at market rates of $1,500 to $1,800 a month. Two bedroom units of 1,077 to 1,547 square feet will rent for $1,800 to $2,200.
Another Avalon project, a joint venture with Landmark American of Portland, Me., will have the 20 percent component of lower cost units. It will replace the vacant city-owned Burdick Elementary School at Greyrock Place, currently being razed by Landmark American.
Landmark American acquired the 3.3-acre property for $6 million. "We outbid Avalon for the site," said Pam Gleichman, chief operating officer at Landmark American. Construction will begin next month on 306 apartments in a 15-story building, with completion scheduled for the spring of 2000.
LANDMARK AMERICAN will build the project with two tennis courts and underground parking for 460 cars, all subject to Avalon's approval. In an unusual arrangement for both companies, once the building is completed it will be turned over to Avalon under a presale agreement, the terms of which neither company wished to disclose.
A third Avalon project is to have 325 units and rise on a former industrial waterfront site for which it is currently negotiating. The company declined to make details of the project available.
"Still in the talking stage" is a fourth rental project that Stamford is promoting, said Mr. Stein, the land-use planner. A developer has not yet been chosen for the project, which will contain some 800 to 900 apartments with a 20 percent lower-income component. It will rise in the Mill River Corridor, a 20-acre downtown area anchored by an existing park and running south along the narrow river.
"The Mayor has asked city boards to begin processing zone changes and to declare an urban redevelopment area for new housing, improved parkland, a walkway extending from the University of Connecticut's new Stamford branch to the harbor, and a commercial development component," said Mr. Stein. The commercial sites, both on Washington Boulevard, are owned by the Hoffman family, local real estate operators, and the Dreyfus Corporation of New York City.
The fifth project, scheduled to begin construction next month, is the initial phase of Park Square West, a downtown complex of apartments, entertainment and shops that will fill the last undeveloped sector of Stamford's urban renewal district. Corcoran-Jennison of Dorchester, Mass., is the designated developer.
Demolition of an existing building has begun, and "we are working with a couple of investors before starting construction," said Marty Jones, Corcoran-Jennison's president. A $26-million Connecticut Housing Finance Authority mortgage is expected shortly and the sale of Federal tax credits for the 20 percent component of low-rent units will provide the developer with $2.5 million in cash, according to Julie Walpole, project director.
The first 143 units of an eventual 400 studio- to three-bedroom apartments will range in size from 600 to 1,000 square feet. Tentative rents are $1,130 to $2,500 and occupancy of the first phase is targeted for the spring of 2000.
Just east of Stamford in Darien, a proposal for yet another Avalon community called Avalon Hollow is facing some hurdles. Mr. Fuller and his associates presented their plan to a public hearing earlier this month, which will be continued Oct. 13. The proposal calls for 189 one- to three-bedroom units in 24 buildings on 32 acres.
The triangular site has been characterized by the developer as "unattractive, neglected and well-suited for a luxury apartment community." The site is typical of marginal locations that test the ingenuity of developers in land-scarce Lower Fairfield County.
Bounded by I-95, Metro-North's railroad tracks and the Noroton River -- the boundary between Darien and Stamford -- its sole apparent virtue is that it's vacant. A former gravel quarry, it is veined with streams, has pockets of wetlands, a manmade pond and an abandoned sanitary sewer pump station belonging to the Town of Darien.
To reach it Avalon had to obtain a 50-foot right-of-way from Hollow Tree Ridge Road through a three-acre parcel proposed for an apartment building by the Duhaime and Trukowski families. A decision on the families' application to build 148 units is due in October, according to Jeremy Ginsberg, senior town planner. Approval would not affect the right-of-way, but some apartments could be built as a bridge over it.
Avalon's plan contains 10 different apartment configurations, with 20 percent at reduced rental rates. There would be cathedral ceilings, crown moldings, large deep soaking tubs, and individual garages. Market rates would range from $1,650 to $3,000 a month and rent-restricted rates would be $1,000 to $1,200 a month, Mr. Fuller said.
Four speakers at the project's recent public hearing were concerned that traffic generated by the adjacent Noroton Heights railroad station would be worsened when Avalon residents mingle with local and commuter vehicles on Hollow Ridge Road.
Opposition to Avalon's communities in the many affluent Connecticut towns where it has built apartments is nothing new. Rental housing is frequently considered declasse, particularly when combined with below-market-rate units. However, a 1989 Connecticut Housing Appeals Law mandates that when legal action is taken by a developer or a town with regard to projects containing the 20 percent lower-rent units, the town must prove that it is detrimental to the welfare of the community in order to reject it.
"We expect to be turned down and go to court," said Mr. Fuller.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
A Middle-Income Housing Program Gathers Steam

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
RELAXED on a park bench a few days ago, Joseph Scarpinito looked across the street at the nearly complete apartment house he is building in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn and speculated on what might have happened on the site, but didn't.
"We were thinking it could have been a rehab, with 17 tax-credit or HOME units," he said. That's builder jargon for two forms of public subsidy used to build low-income housing. Until recently they were the primary mechanisms available for bringing public funds to bear in assisting multifamily rental construction anywhere in the city outside central Manhattan. 
 Usually the low-income programs are used to renovate existing buildings rather than build new ones. Any builder with a site that needs some public subsidy, however little, to be economically feasible, would have to tap into the low-income programs to build a multifamily rental.
The Scarpinito family, owners of JES Construction, a Brooklyn-based contractor-builder, would have been limited to rehabilitating an existing warehouse structure on the 22,000-square-foot site for low-income housing. It was large enough for only 17 apartments.
Instead, JES Construction has been able to demolish the old building and produce 52 apartments in a new eight-story building, called St. John's Apartments, at 287 Prospect Avenue. The site is off Sixth Avenue in the South Slope section of Park Slope, with St. John's Lutheran Church next door and the Prospect Expressway across the street.
The rents are $950 to $1,000 a month for the 30 one-bedroom apartments and $1,200 to $1,400 a month for the 22 two-bedroom two-bath apartments. Applicants, whose income must fall within certain ranges, are currently being interviewed at an on-site rental office. Occupancy will start in mid-October.
This outcome on the Scarpinito property is being replicated throughout middle-income neighborhoods of the city as a new program initiated by the city Housing Development Corporation moves into high gear. H.D.C. is a state-chartered public benefit corporation that provides bond financing for multifamily housing. Russell A. Harding became its president this year.
The first phase of the production program got under way last year with a $15 million subsidy from the corporation. Twelve construction projects have been initiated. Six of them are already being built and the rest are well advanced in the development pipeline. Seven of the 12 are from-the-ground-up new construction projects. Three are gut rehabilitations of existing but vacant residential buildings. And two are conversions of vacant nonresidential buildings in Brooklyn to housing use -- a former parochial school in Carroll Gardens and the former Clermont Armory in Fort Greene.
When completed the 12 projects will provide 930 new apartments at an estimated total development cost of $127 million.
The income guidelines under the program are so calculated that in principle a two-bedroom apartment with an allowable rent of $1,150 a month could be taken by a family of four earning as much as $105,600 a year. But in fact, because of the housing choices typically made by families of varying incomes, most tenants are likely to have earnings in the range of $35,000 to $70,000 a year.
The rent limits under the program are $800 a month for a studio apartment, $1,100 for a one-bedroom, $1,500 for a two-bedroom and $1,750 for a three-bedroom. The actual rents that builders charge, which reflect local housing markets, are normally lower than the allowable maximums by several hundred dollars a month. Occasionally they are a bit higher.
THE announcement of the program brought forth a number of developers who have previously done business with the Housing Development Corporation, had established a favorable track record and already had control of sites that were appropriate for multifamily development. They are in locations that do not require or justify the high public cost per housing unit that low-income subsidies provide.
In the middle-income program the Housing Development Corporation subsidy is a maximum of $20,000 an apartment, provided by way of a second mortgage at 1 percent interest. The average in Phase 1 has been about $17,000 an apartment.
Using this subsidy in conjunction with taxable bonds issued by the corporation has given the projects the assurance of longterm mortgage debt at an interest rate of about 6 or 7 percent, Mr. Harding said. New buildings also get a 25-year tax abatement under the city's Section 421a abatement program, instead of the 15 years that is standard for conventionally financed multifamily buildings outside central Manhattan. Rehabilitations are eligible for the city's J-51 tax abatement.
As one result of all this, Bell Realty of Great Neck, L.I., decided to put a 122-unit apartment tower above the store it is building for Staples between 58th and 59th Street on Queens Boulevard in Woodside. The 70,000-square-foot site was to have been developed in the 80's with a 19-story condominium and a school, but the property fell into foreclosure.
"We had the foundation in place for a future tower, but without the middle-income program it would not have been built at this time," said Charles J. Belanich, a partner in the project. Completion is expected in a year.
Another result is that Cheever Development Corporation of Brooklyn, owned by the Lonuzzi family, and Community Developers, headed by Getz Obstfeld, former director of the Banana Kelly nonprofit housing development organization in the Bronx, have been able to move forward with a long-delayed project, the rehabilitation of the former St. Agnes parochial school, long vacant, in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn.
"We had tried to develop the building for housing for the elderly, but that wasn't successful because of the cost and the difficulty of adapting the building," said Mr. Obstfeld. "The numbers worked perfectly for the H.D.C. program." It is a $10 million project that will create 90 apartments at 421 DeGraw Street, near Hoyt Street across the street from St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church. The construction loan closed in July and completion is scheduled for next summer.
In Queens, the Ciampa Organization is using the financing at the D. C. Colonnade, a new 60-unit building at 136-43 37th Avenue in downtown Flushing, a block from Main Street and Northern Boulevard. It is Ciampa's first new multifamily rental in 12 years, said Dominick Ciampa, a principal in the family-owned building company, which was founded in the 1920's. The project uses a subsidy of only $8,000 an apartment. Its rent schedule is accordingly a bit higher than most of the others.
IN the Rego Park section, the Bluestone Organization of Flushing will use the program for a 132-unit building at 65-90 Austin Street; Galaxy Construction of the Bronx will build a 110-unit project on West 238th Street, overlooking the Major Deegan Expressway in the Kingsbridge section; Leewood Development, based in Staten Island, will produce 74 apartments in a neighborhood of new homes known as Rainbow Hill, near the Staten Island Expressway.
And in the Baychester section of the Bronx, MacQuesten Development Corporation, based in Mount Vernon, N.Y., closed just a few days ago on the loan that will produce 67 garden-style apartments off Baychester Avenue. They are the first phase of what will be a 135-unit project in four contiguous four-story buildings. The two-acre site, now vacant, is bounded by Palmer Avenue, Tillotson Avenue and Given Avenue. The architect is DePasquale and Geremia Architects and Planners of Mount Vernon.
The rehabilitations of existing residential buildings involve the following properties: two vacant four-story buildings at 471 Vanderbilt Avenue and 12-18 Gates Avenue in Fort Greene, into 26 apartments; 39-07 208th Street in the Bayside section of Queens, also as 26 units; and seven buildings in Harlem -- on Frederick Douglass Boulevard and St. Nicholas Avenue between 118th and 120th Streets -- as 80 apartments.
Renting is done by the owner. The Housing Development Corporation provides callers with information on how to go about applying for an apartment. The phone number is (212) 344-8080.

(Steve Jung); St. John's Apartments, left, in Park Slope, and drawing of Carroll Gardens school rehabilitation, right. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times; Len Lizak)

HEADLINE: HOME REPAIR;
Techniques for Cutting Wood, Tile and Masonry

BYLINE: By EDWARD R. LIPINSKI

 BODY:
MOST household cutting jobs consist of slicing through paper, cloth or wood. Do-it-yourselfers can easily handle these cutting chores although sometimes cutting lumber to size can present problems.
Consider plywood, for example. It's easy to cut but often the saw splinters the wood and leaves an unsightly edge. One way to avoid this is by putting a strip of masking tape along the cut line and then sawing through the tape and board at the same time. Another way is by scoring the cut line with a sharp utility knife before cutting. 
 If you're using a hand saw, the good side of the panel should be up. The saw will splinter the bottom, i.e. the bad side, as you push down. The reverse is true if you cut plywood with a circular saw. The good side of the panel should be down because the sawblade cuts as it comes up. You will also get a smoother cut with a circular saw if you use an 80-tooth carbide blade in the saw.
Cutting down the center of a full 4 by 8-foot sheet of plywood can be awkward because you have to reach off balance to make the cut. The job can be made easier if you lay a few 2 by 4's on the work floor first, then position the plywood panel on these. The 2 by 4's should be parallel to the cut. Adjust the depth of the blade on your saw so it just goes through the plywood. Now you can push the saw as you kneel directly on the panel.
Cutting through masonry and ceramics is a difficult task that requires special tools or blades. You can cut into a concrete block, or paver, with your circular saw, provided you use a masonry blade. Do not try to cut completely through a thick concrete block; instead cut a groove about 1/2-inch deep on all four sides. Then use a heavy hammer to break the block in two. This will leave a rough surface at the break.
If you require a clean cut, you can rent a concrete saw fitted with a diamond cutting blade. It can cut to a depth of four inches. Sawing through concrete creates a lot of dust and noise. Try to work outdoors whenever possible and be sure to wear appropriate eye, hearing and dust protective gear.
You don't need a special saw or blade to cut bricks, but there is a knack to doing it. An experienced mason can cut a brick in half simply by whacking it with the edge of a heavy trowel. This technique takes a bit of practice to master. Most do-it-yourselfers will find it easier to break the brick by striking it with a hammer and wide masonry chisel.
There is another technique for cutting a brick. Score a groove about 1/8-inch deep in the top of the brick with a cold chisel. Place the brick on a 1/2-inch dowel or pipe, grooved-side up, so the dowel is directly under the groove. Press down on both ends of the brick to snap it in two.
Tile installations always require trimming a few full-sized tiles into narrower widths. Professional tilers use a wet saw for this. The tool has a circular diamond blade. A water jet directed at rotating blade cools it and washes away tile debris.
This tool is particularly effective for cutting thin pieces of tile. It also leaves smooth edges at the cut. This is important if those edges are to be left exposed. The wet saw is essential for cutting tiles made of marble and stone. A cutting saw can usually be rented at tile suppliers, but it can be expensive. Also the tile saw is big and requires two people to move it to the job site.
Do-it-yourselfers may find it easier and more economical to rent a snap cutter. Strictly speaking, the term "cutter" is a misnomer because the tool does not actually cut the tile. Instead, it breaks it along a scored line.
Snap cutters are available in various configurations, but they use the same cutting principle. The tile is placed on the bed, over a raised cutting bar.
A sharp cutting wheel is drawn across the tile face. The wheel does not cut the tile but only scores the surface. Pressing down on the cutting arm puts pressure on the edges of the tile. On either side of the cutting bar are soft rubber pads that "give" when pressure is applied. The pressure on the tile ends makes it snap at the cutting bar. If the break leaves a rough edge, you can smooth it with a rubbing stone.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Edward R. Lipinski)

HEADLINE: KOFI ANNAN'S Astonishing Facts!

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

 BODY:
Every year, the United Nations Human Development Report looks for a new way to measure the lives of people. Putting aside faceless statistics like per capita gross domestic product or export-import figures, the report burrows into the facts about what children eat, who goes to school, whether there is clean water to drink, how women share in the economy or who doesn't get vaccinations against diseases that go on killing even though they are preventable. This year, the report takes its first look at what people have -- from simple toilets to family cars -- and what proportion of the world's goods and services are consumed, comparatively, by the rich and by the poor. The pie is huge -- the world's consumption bill is $24 trillion a year -- but some servings are very small indeed. BARBARA CROSSETTE

GRAPHIC: Chart:
 
THE HAVES -- The richest fifth of the world's people consumes 86 percent of all goods and services while the poorest fifth consumes just 1.3 percent. Indeed, the richest fifth consumes 45 percent of all meat and fish, 58 percent of all energy used and 84 percent of all paper, has 74 percent of all telephone lines and owns 87 percent of
all vehicles.
 
NATURAL RESOURCES -- Since 1970, the world's forests have declined from 4.4 square miles per 1,000 people to 2.8 square miles per 1,000 people. In addition, a quarter of the world's fish stocks have been depleted or are in danger of being depleted and another 44 percent are being fished at their biological limit.
 
THE GANGES -- The Ganges River symbolizes purification to Hindus, who believe drinking or bathing in its waters will lead to salvation. But 29 cities, 70 towns and countless villages deposit about 345 million gallons of raw sewage a day directly into the river. Factories add 70 million gallons of industrial waste and farmers are responsible for another 6 million tons of chemical fertilizer and 9,000 tons of pesticides.
 
THE ULTRA RICH -- The three richest people in the world have assets that exceed the combined gross domestic product of the 48 least developed countries.
 
AFRICA -- The average African household today consumes 20 percent less than it did 25 years ago.
 
THE SUPER RICH -- The world's 225 richest individuals,
of whom 60 are Americans with total assets of $311 billion,
have a combined wealth of over $1 trillion --
equal to the annual income of the poorest 47 percent of
the entire world's population.
 
COSMETICS AND EDUCATION -- Americans spend $8 billion a year on cosmetics -- $2 billion more than the estimated annual total needed to provide basic education for everyone in the world.
 
THE HAVE NOTS -- Of the 4.4 billion people in developing countries, nearly three-fifths lack access to safe sewers, a third have no access to clean water, a quarter do not have adequate housing and a fifth have no access to modern health services of any kind.
 
MEAT -- Americans each consume
an average of 260 pounds
of meat a year. In Bangladesh, the average
is six and a half pounds.
 
THE FUTURE -- By 2050, 8 billion of the world's projected 9.5 billion people -- up from about 6 billion today -- will be living in developing countries.
 
SMOKE -- Of the estimated 2.7 million annual deaths from air pollution, 2.2 million are from indoor pollution -- including smoke from dung and wood burned as fuel which is more harmful than tobacco smoke. 80 percent of the victims are rural poor in developing countries.
 
WRISTWATCHES AND RADIOS -- Two thirds of India's 90 million lowest-income households live below the poverty line -- but more than 50 percent of these impoverished people own wristwatches, 41 percent own bicycles, 31 percent own radios and 13 percent own fans.
 
TELEPHONE LINES -- Sweden and the United States have 681 and 626 telephone lines per 1,000 people, respectively. Afghanistan, Cambodia, Chad and the Democratic Republic of the Congo have only one line per 1,000 people.
 
ICE CREAM AND WATER -- Europeans spend $11 billion a year on ice cream -- $2 billion more than the estimated annual total needed to provide clean water and safe sewers for the world's population.
 
AIDS -- At the end of 1997 nearly 31 million people were living with HIV, up from 22.3 million the year before. With 16,000 new infections a day -- 90 percent in developing countries -- it is now estimated that 40 million people will be living with HIV in 2000.
 
LANDMINES -- More than 110 million active landmines are scattered in 68 countries, with an equal number stockpiled around the world. Every month more than 2,000 people are killed or maimed by mine explosions.
 
PET FOOD AND HEALTH -- Americans and Europeans spend $17 billion a year on pet food -- $4 billion more than the estimated annual additional total needed to provide basic health and nutrition for everyone in the world.
 
$40 BILLION A YEAR -- It is estimated that the additional cost of achieving and maintaining universal access to basic education for all, basic health care for all, reproductive health care for all women, adequate food for all and clean water and safe sewers for all is roughly $40 billion a year -- or less than 4 percent of the combined wealth of the 225 richest people in the world.

HEADLINE: Kohl and His Story: New Chapter, or History?

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: BERLIN, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Change is not lightly accepted in a country where stability is paramount, and as Germany prepares to vote Sunday in national elections it appears gripped by last-minute doubts over whether the time has come to end the era of Chancellor Helmut Kohl.
For months, Mr. Kohl has trailed his Social Democratic challenger, Gerhard Schroder, and it long seemed that the burden of 16 years in office was too much for even the Chancellor who presided over Germany's unification to overcome. But with a relentless conviction, Mr. Kohl has closed the gap to the point where poll takers say any outcome is possible. 
 This in itself is extraordinary. A whole generation of young Germans has never known anything but Mr. Kohl's leadership, and Mr. Schroder's slick campaign, bent above all on avoiding mistakes and conveying an image of modernity, has struck a chord with the many who yearn for a more self-confident Germany less burdened by its past.
The thirst for a new face, one unmarked by the experience of World War II, which indelibly fashioned Mr. Kohl's outlook, may still carry Mr. Schroder, 54, to victory. He remains the favorite, with a lead most opinion polls put at about 2 percent. But Europe's most powerful nation appears agonizingly torn between an awareness that new blood may be needed and a visceral distaste for risk.
Mr. Kohl's achievement has done much to diminish that risk. The place of a unified Germany in NATO and at the heart of a European Union that has adopted a single currency, the euro, is now questioned only by small fringes of the left and neo-Nazi right. Whatever the result, America's critical alliance with Germany will not be rocked.
But with a new century beckoning, a new global economy posing challenges to Germany's long-cohesive social model and the return to the new capital in Berlin about to be completed, Germans sense that their vote is of decisive importance. What they see less clearly is who should oversee the symbol-laden return to the Reichstag in 1999, 44 years after the defeat of the Nazi regime.
"We can't look at the face of Kohl any more," said Joachim Jens Hesse, a political scientist. "It's a physical thing, a psychological thing, just as the British tired of Mrs. Thatcher. But at the same time, this is such an awkward choice. I do not know if I can trust the Social Democrats, especially in coalition with the Greens."
Coalitions have always governed under Germany's parliamentary system, but a "Red-Green" alliance is as yet untried. The idea alarms some of the centrist voters to whom Mr. Schroder has been trying to appeal because the Greens have in the past called for sharp increases in gasoline taxes and a review of Germany's NATO membership.
The alternative for Mr. Schroder, if his Social Democratic Party emerges victorious but does not have enough votes to govern with the Greens, would be a so-called Grand Coalition with Mr. Kohl's Christian Democrats -- a broad formula not tried for three decades.
Unwieldy, almost certainly condemned to be short-lived, such a coalition might at least provide the heft to push through the difficult reform of a welfare system that Germany is hard-pressed to afford. As in much of the rest of Europe, an aging population and high unemployment have strained public pension and social security payments.
The Christian Democrats have not closed the door to a Grand Coalition, but Mr. Kohl has said categorically that he would refuse to lead it. So, if the Christian Democrats emerge with more votes than the Social Democrats, but not enough to renew their current center-right coalition, the possibility exists that Mr. Kohl's acerbic deputy, Wolfgang Schauble, could emerge as the next Chancellor.
This outcome is not likely. But Mr. Schauble, 56, who has used a wheelchair since he was shot by a deranged man while campaigning eight years ago, has emerged in recent opinion polls as by far the most popular politician in Germany.
His suggestion that "16 weeks of Mr. Schroder will seem longer than 16 years of Mr. Kohl" has proved to be one of the more memorable phrases of a campaign in which oratory has scarcely soared. Mr. Schauble's popularity has in turn raised doubts about the wisdom of Mr. Kohl in insisting on seeking an unprecedented fifth term.
It is on Mr. Kohl's protracted rule that Mr. Schroder, the Premier of the state of Lower Saxony, has hammered, insisting in every speech that "Germany cannot afford four more years of Kohl."
As for the rest -- Germany's 4.1 million unemployed, Germany's role in Europe, the current world financial crisis, the replacement of Germany's beloved mark by the euro in 2002 -- Mr. Schroder has been much more vague, or simply silent, relying on images (like a meeting with Microsoft's Bill Gates), broad promises and rugged good looks to carry the day.
Four previous Social Democratic candidates have tried to take on Mr. Kohl by more confrontational means: Hans-Jochen Vogel in 1983, Johannes Rau in 1987, Oskar Lafontaine in 1990 and Rudolf Scharping in 1994. They all looked good for a while; they all failed. Not for nothing do Social Democratic posters insist, and insist again, that "Wir Sind Bereit" -- "We are ready."
Perhaps they are. In the end, it may be the unification of Germany, Mr. Kohl's crowning achievement, that proves his undoing.
Unification has proved extraordinarily costly. Germany has been transferring the equivalent of about 4.3 percent of its gross national product, or total output, to the east since 1990, straining public finances, transforming the area with new enterprises and urban projects, but failing to resolve the problems of the 16 million citizens of the former Communist state.
About one in five people of working age in the east is unemployed. The anger of these people, who once hailed Mr. Kohl for unifying the country, has been directed at the Christian Democratic Party, whose support in the area has plunged from close to 40 percent to under 30 percent.
These votes will not all go to the Social Democrats -- the Party of Democratic Socialism (former Communists) and various neo-Nazi groupings have both benefited -- but the damage to Mr. Kohl may prove insurmountable.
"There has been a free fall in Christian Democrat support in the east," said Lutz Erbring, a political analyst. "And I suspect it is in the east that the outcome of this election will be decided."
The other factor propelling Mr. Schroder is a vaguer but equally potent one. Germany has been in assertive mood of late -- its big corporations have been buying up the likes of Random House, Chrysler and Rolls-Royce -- and the Social Democratic challenger has contrived to symbolize this less cautious, less fettered spirit of a nation that feels it has labored under the weight of its past for long enough.
Mr. Schroder's call to rethink a planned Holocaust memorial in Berlin -- a monument strongly supported by Mr. Kohl -- has provided one of the few, clear policy conflicts between the two candidates and captured their differing priorities and preoccupations.
While Mr. Kohl dwells on the wounds of war, the glories of Germany's reconstruction, the building of a united Europe and the precious prize of peace, Mr. Schroder wants to shift the focus unflinchingly to the future.
He has by no means convinced everyone. The large number of undecided voters -- more than 20 percent, according to several polls -- appears to reflect in part the hesitations of many Germans in trusting a candidate who has shunned direct, declarative sentences throughout the campaign.
Analysts say that many of the so-called undecided are in fact people who will end up not voting, so their importance may be exaggerated. But if the hesitant opt in the end for Mr. Kohl's camp -- the reservoir of potential Christian Democratic voters is believed to be larger than that of the Social Democrats -- they could still swing the election.
"I am afraid that Kohl will still win it," said Andrea Zeller, a 25-year-old student, as she watched the Chancellor at a rally in Munich this week. "It's time for a change, but he always catches up." She added that she would vote for the Greens, but without the conviction that a "Red-Green" coalition could win.
In the last week of campaigning, Mr. Kohl has been playing on the fears of a conservative people, trying to portray Mr. Schroder as the gateway to a Communist presence in government. He has attacked Mr. Schroder's proposal to grant citizenship to some of Germany's seven million foreign residents, and warned of instability.
With unemployment falling -- it is expected to drop below four million this month after going as high as 4.8 million earlier this year -- and the German economy enjoying a recovery, Mr. Kohl's statements appear to have had an impact. His appearance as a rock of stability at a moment of world uncertainty, when the American President, Bill Clinton, is clearly distracted, has also helped his cause.
"A company that is doing well does not change its chief executive just because he has been there for 15 to 20 years," said Christoph Ahlhaus, 29, a banker. "Why should we?"
But the truth is that Germany has enough problems, and Mr. Kohl enough years in power, for Mr. Schroder to have a strong chance. Another truth is that, whoever wins, Germany is likely to flex its muscle more in the coming years.
"We do not want a European superstate," Mr. Kohl declared in Munich. "We want a strong Germany in Europe." That statement amounted to a shift: Germany long talked approvingly of a United States of Europe, with a truly federal system.
But the painful abandonment of the mark for the euro was Germany's pledge of good faith to the European idea. Now, whether under Mr. Schroder or under Mr. Kohl once again, or indeed under some other Chancellor, the country clearly feels it has the right and the might to make its voice heard, and to do so without any complexes.

PARTY VOTE
 Cast for a party. Need not be tied to district party vote.
 Half of the Parliament is elected through the party vote. Seats are distributed to parties based on the percentage of votes won.

HEADLINE: KOFI ANNAN'S Astonishing Facts!

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

 BODY:
Every year, the United Nations Human Development Report looks for a new way to measure the lives of people. Putting aside faceless statistics like per capita gross domestic product or export-import figures, the report burrows into the facts about what children eat, who goes to school, whether there is clean water to drink, how women share in the economy or who doesn't get vaccinations against diseases that go on killing even though they are preventable. This year, the report takes its first look at what people have -- from simple toilets to family cars -- and what proportion of the world's goods and services are consumed, comparatively, by the rich and by the poor. The pie is huge -- the world's consumption bill is $24 trillion a year -- but some servings are very small indeed. BARBARA CROSSETTE

GRAPHIC: Chart:
 
THE HAVES -- The richest fifth of the world's people consumes 86 percent of all goods and services while the poorest fifth consumes just 1.3 percent. Indeed, the richest fifth consumes 45 percent of all meat and fish, 58 percent of all energy used and 84 percent of all paper, has 74 percent of all telephone lines and owns 87 percent of
all vehicles.
 
NATURAL RESOURCES -- Since 1970, the world's forests have declined from 4.4 square miles per 1,000 people to 2.8 square miles per 1,000 people. In addition, a quarter of the world's fish stocks have been depleted or are in danger of being depleted and another 44 percent are being fished at their biological limit.
 
THE GANGES -- The Ganges River symbolizes purification to Hindus, who believe drinking or bathing in its waters will lead to salvation. But 29 cities, 70 towns and countless villages deposit about 345 million gallons of raw sewage a day directly into the river. Factories add 70 million gallons of industrial waste and farmers are responsible for another 6 million tons of chemical fertilizer and 9,000 tons of pesticides.
 
THE ULTRA RICH -- The three richest people in the world have assets that exceed the combined gross domestic product of the 48 least developed countries.
 
AFRICA -- The average African household today consumes 20 percent less than it did 25 years ago.
 
THE SUPER RICH -- The world's 225 richest individuals,
of whom 60 are Americans with total assets of $311 billion,
have a combined wealth of over $1 trillion --
equal to the annual income of the poorest 47 percent of
the entire world's population.
 
COSMETICS AND EDUCATION -- Americans spend $8 billion a year on cosmetics -- $2 billion more than the estimated annual total needed to provide basic education for everyone in the world.
 
THE HAVE NOTS -- Of the 4.4 billion people in developing countries, nearly three-fifths lack access to safe sewers, a third have no access to clean water, a quarter do not have adequate housing and a fifth have no access to modern health services of any kind.
 
MEAT -- Americans each consume
an average of 260 pounds
of meat a year. In Bangladesh, the average
is six and a half pounds.
 
THE FUTURE -- By 2050, 8 billion of the world's projected 9.5 billion people -- up from about 6 billion today -- will be living in developing countries.
 
SMOKE -- Of the estimated 2.7 million annual deaths from air pollution, 2.2 million are from indoor pollution -- including smoke from dung and wood burned as fuel which is more harmful than tobacco smoke. 80 percent of the victims are rural poor in developing countries.
 
WRISTWATCHES AND RADIOS -- Two thirds of India's 90 million lowest-income households live below the poverty line -- but more than 50 percent of these impoverished people own wristwatches, 41 percent own bicycles, 31 percent own radios and 13 percent own fans.
 
TELEPHONE LINES -- Sweden and the United States have 681 and 626 telephone lines per 1,000 people, respectively. Afghanistan, Cambodia, Chad and the Democratic Republic of the Congo have only one line per 1,000 people.
 
ICE CREAM AND WATER -- Europeans spend $11 billion a year on ice cream -- $2 billion more than the estimated annual total needed to provide clean water and safe sewers for the world's population.
 
AIDS -- At the end of 1997 nearly 31 million people were living with HIV, up from 22.3 million the year before. With 16,000 new infections a day -- 90 percent in developing countries -- it is now estimated that 40 million people will be living with HIV in 2000.
 
LANDMINES -- More than 110 million active landmines are scattered in 68 countries, with an equal number stockpiled around the world. Every month more than 2,000 people are killed or maimed by mine explosions.
 
PET FOOD AND HEALTH -- Americans and Europeans spend $17 billion a year on pet food -- $4 billion more than the estimated annual additional total needed to provide basic health and nutrition for everyone in the world.
 
$40 BILLION A YEAR -- It is estimated that the additional cost of achieving and maintaining universal access to basic education for all, basic health care for all, reproductive health care for all women, adequate food for all and clean water and safe sewers for all is roughly $40 billion a year -- or less than 4 percent of the combined wealth of the 225 richest people in the world.

SECTION: Section 14WC;Page 1;Column 2;Westchester Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: A Killing Refocuses War on Abuse

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
HILDA UGUNA has become yet another grim statistic. She is one of 1,300 women a year in the United States killed by abusive partners.
The 19-year-old woman, fearing for her life, sought a court order of protection last month against her husband, who, she said, slept with a knife and threatened to kill her. But because the application to Family Court in White Plains did not meet the precise legal criteria for an emergency order, her plea was rejected, and her case was postponed until October. 
 The delay cost the young mother of three her life: five days after the emergency order was denied, her husband made good on his threats.
According to police reports, Luis Uguna, 27, a landscaper, stabbed his wife, a factory worker, many times in her chest and neck on Aug. 21, before stabbing himself twice in the sternum and jumping to his death from their fourth-floor apartment in Sleepy Hollow, where the couple, legal immigrants from Ecuador, lived. Two of their young children, an 8-month-old son and a 2-year-old daughter, saw the slaying, the Sleepy Hollow police said.
In the weeks since Mrs. Uguna's death, judges, lawyers and law-enforcement officials have called for changes in the legal system to thwart abusive men like Mr. Uguna. In doing so, they claim that too many domestic violence cases occur despite heightened public awareness of how widespread they have become.
"It shouldn't take a murder to call attention to the problem," Alan D. Scheinkman, the County Attorney, said. He observed that while killings often make the headlines, there are "dozens of other cases that occur where women and children are scarred forever." Under a state grant, Mr. Scheinkman has assigned two county lawyers to work with the county's Probation Department to enforce orders of protection.
According to a 1996 report by the American Psychological Association, nearly one in every three adult women experience at least one physical assault by a partner during adulthood. But most of those women fail to report the crime to law-enforcement agencies, the report said.
Of those who do seek help, many -- like Mrs. Uguna -- are unsuccessful because they are unable to get through the legal maze presented by criminal and family courts, said Judge Adrienne Hofmann Scancarelli, who denied the application and has since come under criticism from several quarters.
Judge Scancarelli said, however, that a complainant must report violence or the threat of violence to the courts to establish grounds for an emergency order of protection. She said Mrs. Uguna's application did not include information suggesting that Mr. Uguna posed an immediate threat. The judge said that she was therefore bound by the law.
"I did not see an emergency in that case," said the judge, who issues hundreds of such orders a year and described herself as "a very vocal advocate against domestic violence."
Many who have questioned the judge's decision said it would have been wiser to abide by the spirit of the law -- which is to protect people like Mrs. Uguna -- than to obey its letter.
"What does it cost to issue an order of protection against someone with a proven history of abuse?" said the county's District Attorney, Jeanine Pirro, who was chairwoman of Gov. George E. Pataki's Commission on Domestic Violence Fatalities and presented the commission's report to him last year.
Mrs. Uguna sought protection from the courts for the last time on Aug. 19. In 1996 she obtained a court order of protection against her husband, but it had lapsed. The police said also that an earlier assault charge filed against Mr. Uguna was dropped when Mrs. Uguna failed to pursue the case. And two days before Mrs. Uguna sought help for the last time, her husband was jailed on drunken-driving charges in Tarrytown, Detective Frank Corona of the Sleepy Hollow Police Department said.
"The bottom line is that we have a court system that is supposed to help victims, and it turned away Hilda Uguna," Mrs. Pirro said.
For many, the Uguna case has stirred memories of another case in which the victim was also legally unable to keep her husband out of the house. Anne Scripps Douglas, the newspaper heiress, was beaten into a coma with a hammer allegedly by her estranged husband on Dec. 31, 1993, in her Bronxville home. She died six days later. The car of her husband, Scott Douglas, was discovered on the Tappan Zee Bridge that night, a bloody hammer inside. His body washed ashore along the Hudson River almost three months later.
In that case, too, criticism of the court system followed the crime. The New Rochelle Family Court and Judge Ingrid S. Braslow were faulted by social workers and lawyers for issuing an order of protection to the victim but not ordering Mr. Douglas to leave the house.
After that case and responding to a growing concern about domestic violence, the County Board of Legislators issued a report in 1995 stating that one in four women in Westchester are abused by their spouses or companions.
Last year, Governor Pataki signed legislation to protect victims of domestic violence by insuring that they are not arrested for defending themselves from attack. The Primary Aggressor legislation requires that the police arrest only the main attacker.
Despite efforts to thwart such crimes, domestic violence remains the leading cause of injury to women, according to the United States Surgeon General's office.
Recently in Westchester, there have been some dramatic cases of abuse that resulted in death, the ones -- as Mr. Scheinkman, the County Attorney, said -- that attract public attention. Early on Dec. 6, 1997, Patrick J. Biller, a 53-year-old Yonkers man described by neighbors as quick-tempered and troubled by health problems, finances and apparently a failing marriage, shot his wife, Maureen, and three children to death and then killed himself in the family's apartment.
In Tarrytown, Anthony Ambrosovitch, 65, a former police officer, has been charged in connection with the June 11 shooting deaths of his wife, Gloria, and a daughter, Melinda Podesta. Mr. Ambrosovitch, neighbors said, had a history of alcohol abuse and family difficulties. In a dramatic standoff, he held the police at bay for more than four hours after the killings.
In the county, law-enforcement officials and social workers are studying three main aspects of the domestic violence problem: obtaining orders of protection, enforcing those orders and helping abusers control their problems.
Judge Scancarelli said that too often women come to court unable to understand the application requirements. "If I had a wish to make," she said, "it would be that there was always an attorney present to help with petitions and court processes."
Lawyers from the domestic violence unit of Westchester Putnam Legal Services are working with law students at Pace University to help victims file applications for orders of protection, Amy Saltzman, a staff lawyer for Legal Services, said. "There are too many unrepresented litigants," she said. "We have to get them when they walk through the door and help them to follow through in the courts."
At the county's Department of Probation, Commissioner Rocco A. Pozzi said officers have been assigned to oversee orders of protection and arrest those who violate them so the documents do not become "just pieces of paper."
Batterers who do not obey the order issued against them are subject to arrest. "We're not talking about a slap on the wrist," the Commissioner said.
To help abusers control their behavior, both the Probation Department and the Mental Health Association of Westchester County run workshops.
"There are a lot of theories about why men batter," said Jennifer Brennan, director of outpatient mental health services at the Mental Health Association in Elmsford. "These are complicated issues."
Studies show that for the most part men are the abusers, but women sometimes batter their spouses or elderly parents.
Dr. Neil Jacobson and Dr. John Gottman, two professors of psychology at the University of Washington who have studied violent marriages, are the authors of "When Men Batter Women" (Simon and Schuster). In the book, they say that batterers fall into two categories: pit bulls or cobras. The former tend to be charmers until they enter into an intimate relationship. Then they act out of emotional dependence and a fear of abandonment, becoming stalkers and jealous partners. For example, the book puts O. J. Simpson in the category of a pit bull.
Cobras, on the other hand, are often sociopaths who are cold and calculating and demonstrate a high incidence of antisocial and criminal traits and sadistic behavior, the researchers found. A cobra's violence grows out of a pathological need to have one's way, to be the boss and make sure that everyone, particularly their wives and girlfriends, knows it and acts accordingly.
Ms. Brennan at the Mental Health Association observed that before 1977 it was not illegal for a man to assault a partner. She said her organization does not report more domestic violence in any particular socio-economic group. "Very poor and very wealthy women become victims," she said.
But results of studies distributed by the National Network to End Domestic Violence, a nonprofit advocacy organization in Washington, indicate some differences among ethnic groups. Black women, the Network reported, are more likely to feel protective of the batterer because he may have faced discrimination and other difficulties.
Also, battered Hispanic women in shelters are more likely to have experienced a longer duration of abuse, be married at a younger age, have larger families and have stayed in relationships longer, the studies revealed.
