HEADLINE: For Sale: Free Software;
Backers of Linux Say System Is Basis For Revolutionizing Computer Business

BYLINE: By AMY HARMON 

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.C.

 BODY:
In an experiment that is half business model and half populist movement, a small company called Red Hat Software is charging $50 for an operating system called Linux that anyone can get free on the Internet, and it is paying programmers decent wages to write code that it will give away.
While that might seem the most contrarian of business plans, Red Hat is attracting blue-chip investors to the notion that free can be profitable. 
 The movement, known alternately as free software and open source, is built around freely distributing source code, the basic commands that programmers write. Publishing these instructions before they are compiled into the binary language of computers offers other programmers the chance to examine the code and suggest or actually write improvements.
At its best, the movement's proponents say, open source could harness the collective wisdom of the world's best software designers for social good, undermine the Microsoft Corporation's Windows monopoly and propagate an operating system that does not crash.
A great deal of their passion is inspired by Linux, a version of the Unix operating system developed by Linus Torvalds of Finland and numerous collaborators worldwide. Linux (rhymes with "cynics") has attracted a cult-like following among programmers and systems developers who say it is a more secure, flexible and economic alternative to Microsoft's industrial-strength operating system, Windows NT.
Despite that kind of following, the business-model half of the Red Hat experiment strikes many people as counterintuitive.
Robert F. Young, the chief executive of the three-year-old company in Durham's Research Triangle Park, insists that open-source products can make money. And although he has nothing against contributing to a utopian vision of software development in the process, his pragmatic focus has lately attracted interest from venture capitalists and corporate backers.
"The software industry is built on intellectual property," said Mr. Young, a 44-year-old Canadian who used to run a computer leasing business. "You own your technology, and if you get it widely disseminated you can coerce your user base into buying new releases. We give up that control -- and those profits -- but that is exactly what is going to drive our success, because that is what's best for the user."
Among Red Hat's potential corporate backers are the Intel Corporation and the Netscape Communications Corporation. An announcement is expected as early as tomorrow, when Mr. Young is scheduled to appear with executives from both companies in San Jose, Calif.
Such support, particularly from Intel, whose close ties to Microsoft have recently shown signs of fraying, would lend considerable credibility both to Linux and to Red Hat's plans to build a business by providing customer service and technical support for the free operating system.
Recent support for Linux and other open-source projects seems to suggest a growing acceptance in the software industry of an alternative to the tradition of proprietary code.
I.B.M., for example, recently licensed Apache, a popular program for serving up World Wide Web sites. Like Linux, Apache is a free, open-source product.
And Netscape last February published the source code to its Navigator browser for navigating the World Wide Web. Forced to stop charging for Navigator by Microsoft's free distribution of its competing brower software, Explorer, Netscape gambled that going one step further and releasing its code would give Navigator a competitive advantage over Explorer in the long run by spurring innovation.
"Open source has already radically changed the computer industry," said Tim O'Reilly, whose publishing company, O'Reilly & Associates, makes money producing user manuals for free software. "In the first round, open-source software will not beat Microsoft at its own game. What it is doing is changing the nature of the game."
Mr. Torvalds, who wrote Linux in 1991 when he was a student at the University of Helsinki, licensed it in a way that allows anyone to submit improved code and redistribute it at will. Since then, thousands of programmers have volunteered elaborate improvements of their own design for no more reward than the respect of the geek subculture.
Submissions to Linux's core code, or kernel, are subjected to instantaneous electronic peer review, a technological meritocracy that has so far insulated Linux from the kind of fragmentation that has befallen other operating systems built around the international Unix standard.
Despite the operating system's reputation for power and reliability, corporations have been reluctant to use Linux because nobody owns it. That is why the emergence of companies like Red Hat and Caldera Systems Inc. -- a Linux distributor with a business plan based on corporate training, services and support -- is considered crucial to the success of the free operating system.
Now, bolstered by commitments from companies like Oracle, Netscape, Intel, Informix and Corel, all of whom have announced plans to support Linux in recent months, Red Hat and Caldera are getting more aggressive.
But their business plans are fragile. For instance, since Red Hat wants whatever code it writes to become part of the Linux kernel, it must be published under open-source rules. That means that www.cheapbytes.com can, and does, sell Red Hat's entire Linux package for $1.99 -- $48.01 less than Red Hat's customers pay.
Red Hat's Mr. Young estimates that as few as 1 in 10 of the people who use Red Hat have paid him for it. But that is one of the paradoxical pillars of charging only for support and services, not for intellectual property.
"My job is not to compete with Microsoft," Mr. Young stresses. "It's to lower the value of the operating system market. Microsoft makes $5 billion in operating system sales. If I get that market, I automatically make it a $500 million market."
Skeptics are quick to note that the technology companies lining up behind Linux, with its estimated seven million users, have their own competitive reasons to oppose Microsoft, which has 300 million users for its Windows operating systems.
What is more, the skeptics point out, no one knows how long Linux's labor-of-love development by programmers will last.
"An operating system is a living thing," said Carl Shapiro, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley and a co-author of "Information Rules," a book to be published this week by the Harvard Business School Press. "Ongoing investment and upgrades are essential to attract customers. Nice cooperative thoughts are not enough."
Still, use of Linux is growing by more than 40 percent a year, according to IDC, a research firm. And a 1997 survey by another research firm, Datapro, found that Linux scored higher with users than any other operating system. Dell Computer, which last year began offering Linux to customers who ordered at least 50 computers a quarter, said that more interest had been expressed in Linux in recent months.
James Love, director of Ralph Nader's Consumer Project on Technology, which has encouraged the Justice Department to investigate Microsoft's Windows licensing deals with computer manufacturers, said his office had found it impossible to buy Linux already installed on a PC from a major commercial vendor. But he managed to install it on his own computer, and he was impressed.
"This is the first time we've seen an industrial-strength product developed without a corporation behind it, and we think it's amazing" Mr. Love said. "If the operating system is in fact a natural monopoly, then what could be better than having an operating system that nobody owns?"
No one argues that Linux poses a threat to Microsoft right now. But at a time when the next version of Windows NT appears indefinitely delayed by a complexity that has grown unmanageable, Linux enthusiasts are beginning to find back-door ways to introduce the operating system into their corporations.
For example, when Randy Kessel, a manager for technical analysis for Southwestern Bell, part of SBC Communications, installed Red Hat's Linux on the 36 desktop personal computers that monitor network operations in Kansas and Missouri, it was done on something of a dare.
After poor results testing a memory-intensive application with Windows 95, Windows 98 and Windows NT, a colleague asked Mr. Kessel why, if he thought Linux was so great, he did not try it.
"So we took a mission-critical operation and we deployed a free operating system there," Mr. Kessel said. "And now we spend a tenth of the administration cost for those desktops that we do for the rest of the 315 we use."
Even so, he met resistance.
"The legal department says, 'When it fails, who do we sue?' " he said. "The I.T. department says, 'It's not a proved product.' Corporate security says, 'It's hackerware.' But it's the only thing that worked."
Other recent Linux converts include the movie director James Cameron's special-effects company, Digital Domain, which used the operating system to help create the illusions in "Titanic."
And when the city of Medina, Wash., was overwhelmed by documents -- including the four file cabinets filled with paperwork on the mansion built by Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates -- it installed an electronic document retrieval system that runs on Linux.
Ray A. Jones, president of Archive Retrieval, which installed the system for Medina, said he was aware of an irony in his choice of an operating system. But he recalled feeling vindicated when a bug arose in the scanning process.
"We asked a question on the Internet, and within a couple of hours we had an answer," Mr. Jones said. "I fixed it myself with three lines of code. With a commercial product I'd have had to wait for Microsoft to fix it -- if it ever did. This way, the whole Linux community benefited."
Marc Ewing, 29, who started Red Hat in 1995 because he found downloading the various pieces of Linux a major headache, said developing software in isolation -- without public contributions -- "would be like typing with one arm."
And yet for Linux to ever compete with Windows, it must be easier to use. Now users must control Linux with a complicated syntax of arcane commands. So Mr. Ewing oversees six programmers working on a project called Gnome, an effort to hide the nuts and bolts of the operating system behind the kind of graphical interface familiar to users of Macintosh or Windows machines.
While they sleep, other groups elsewhere in the world are getting up to work on Gnome. Often by the next morning, someone will have translated the code into Portuguese.
But Mr. Torvalds, who now works for a chip design company in Silicon Valley, insists that the true strength of an operating system is reliability.
"You use a Windows machine and the golden rule is: Save, and save often," Mr. Torvalds said. "It's scary how people have grown used to the idea that computers are unreliable when it is not the computer at all -- it's the operating system that just doesn't cut it."

HEADLINE: Senate May Vote on Financial Services Bill

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
For nearly two decades, efforts to lift Depression-era regulations on the nation's financial services industry have come to no avail. But that may end this week, as a measure to modernize the industry, one long written off as dead, is showing remarkable signs of life in the Senate.
The financial services businesses lobbied heavily late last week and over the weekend, as the Senate prepared to vote this week on the measure, which would make it easier for banks, brokers and insurance companies to merge into huge financial conglomerates. By last count, it appeared that the Senate leadership was close to corralling the 60 votes needed to cut off any filibuster and allow for a floor vote on the bill. 
 In the meantime, compromises carefully worked out between insurance agents, consumer groups, Wall Street executives and bankers appeared to be holding, though some outstanding issues remained to be resolved. "The odds are favoring getting the bill to the floor and it passing," said Kenneth Guenther, lobbyist for the Independent Bankers Association of America.
The bill would put into law what the marketplace, in large part, is already doing: It would provide for the creation of huge financial conglomerates able to underwrite securities, sell insurance and take bank deposits, all under one roof. It would do so by overturning the Glass-Steagall Act, written during the Depression, and the Bank Holding Company Act, written in the 1950's, that erected walls between commercial and investment banking.
The House passed this measure by a single vote in May, and its backers are racing to gain Senate approval before Congress adjourns in October. "Time is our main enemy right now," a Wall Street lobbyist said.
Senate leaders are trying to work out as many problems as possible so the bill can be considered on the floor with few disruptions. At the same time, the lobbying machine is cranking up: Merrill Lynch & Company is planning radio ads in Washington on the morning Don Imus program; insurance agents across the country plan to work on grass-roots telephone banks, and a letter has been sent by 50 top financial executives to all Senators warning of dire financial consquences if the bill is not passed.
"We simply must modernize our own financial system," the letter says, "if America is going to credibly advocate financial sector reform in Japan, Southeast Asia and other parts of the world."
Those signing it included Jon Corzine of Goldman, Sachs; Harvey Golub of American Express; Richard Grasso of the New York Stock Exchange and David H. Komansky of Merrill Lynch.
The main opposition appears to be led by Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, who opposes expansion of Government requirements that financial services companies provide low-cost banking services to low- and moderate-income consumers. He has threatened to "body block" the bill with a filibuster, several lobbyists say, if it is not modified.
Other issues still in play include a provision that would prevent savings and loans from being sold to commercial businesses; Washington Mutual, the largest savings and loan, is leading a battle against this. Efforts are also under way to smooth out a dispute between banks and insurance agents over the regulation of bank sales of insurance products.
A big obstacle to the bill's becoming law is a threatened veto by President Clinton over a provision that favors the Federal Reserve in the financial regulatory structure at the expense of the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, a branch of the Treasury Department.
But many say that Mr. Clinton will be hard pressed to make good on that threat because of current global economic turmoil. And amid impeachment talk, the President needs the support of Congressional Democrats who are behind the measure.
If the bill clears the Senate, it would land on the President's desk just about the time a meeting of international central bankers called by the Fed and the Treasury Department to address the global financial crisis convenes in Washington.
One of its main topics is a push by American officials for other countries to modernize their financial services industries -- making it difficult for Mr. Clinton to veto a bill to do just that in the United States. "How can the President veto the bill while asking others to modernize their financial systems," a banking lobbyist said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "It would undermine our ability to restore world financial confidence."

HEADLINE: For G.O.P., Rare Hope in Boulder

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: BOULDER, Colo., Sept. 27

 BODY:
Could Boulder, the liberal lighthouse of the Rockies, send to Congress -- a Republican?
For nearly a quarter-century, Colorado's Second District has been a safe seat for Democrats -- and an altar for Republican sacrificial lambs. The last Republican candidate to run from this district, Pat Miller, vowed to be the "voice" of paramilitary groups in Congress. 
 But now the Republicans have fielded Robert D. Greenlee, a moderate who favors abortion rights and enjoys a wide following as Boulder's first Republican Mayor since 1971. A self-made millionaire, Mr. Greenlee, 57, has deep pockets to finance his campaign.
For the Democrats, Mark Udall, who is in his first term as a State Representative, is mounting what appears to be an equally strong candidacy. An heir to the Udall Western political legacy forged by his father, Morris, a former Congressman, and uncle, Stewart, who was Interior Secretary as well as a Congressman, the 48-year-old candidate enjoys fervent support from local and national environmental groups. An avid mountain climber in a district where outdoor recreation is king, Mr. Udall directed the Colorado Outward Bound School for a decade.
Among Colorado's six House races this year, this is the only one seen as truly competitive.
"You have two of the most progressive people in state politics running against each other," said Timothy Wirth, a liberal Democrat who represented this district from 1974 to 1986. "It's now going to be an extremely interesting race."
Both national parties focused on the district immediately after David E. Skaggs, the Democratic Representative, announced last year that he would not run for re-election after completing this term, his sixth. A liberal stalwart of the House, Mr. Skaggs has received a near-perfect voting rating from liberal groups.
The Republicans took aim at the seat, noting it was 1 of only 16 nationwide where Democratic incumbents were not seeking re-election. The Democrat Party is determined to hold on to the seat.
"It's a race we are pretty excited about," said Thomas E. Eisenhauer, a political strategist from the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, who traveled from Washington to attend a debate between the two candidates on Wednesday. "Mark is a really strong candidate who proved in the primary he can raise money."
Mr. Udall was a long shot this year when he won a crowded primary, defeating better known candidates in Colorado.
"Udall's image is not of a strict Democratic partisan, but much more of a thinking environmentalist," said Floyd Ciruli, president of a polling and political consulting company in Denver. "Udall not only has the cachet of the name, but also the ability to raise money around the nation."
That ability is a special asset in this race, said Mr. Ciruli, who predicted that it would be the most expensive House campaign in Colorado history, costing about $2 million.
The district centered in Boulder is no longer a safe seat for Democrats for several reasons. The seven states sharing the Rocky Mountain time zone arguably now make up the nation's most consistently Republican region, with only three Democrats serving in the House -- Representatives Skaggs, Diana DeGette of Colorado's First District, which includes Denver, and Ed Pastor of Arizona's Second District. With the exception of New Mexico, all the states have legislatures controlled by Republicans.
Over the last decade in Colorado, Republicans have become the party with the largest number of registered voters, 35 percent to the Democrats' 30 percent. In that time, the Congressional delegation has shifted from an even balance to 6-2 favoring the Republicans. In the Second District, once firmly Democratic, voter registration gives the party only a small edge over the Republicans, 32 percent to 30 percent. The rest are independents.
Democratic control of the seat here dates to 1974, when the party's candidates were swept into office around the nation, riding a wave of anger over Watergate and President Richard M. Nixon, who had just resigned.
"There really is a parallel, but I don't think that Clinton's problems resonate in the same way that Nixon's problems resonated with the voting public," said Paul Talmey, president of a Boulder polling company. "Today, the world is at peace, the economy is doing well."
In the hourlong debate and question-and-answer session on Wednesday, the subject of President Clinton's affair with Monica S. Lewinsky never came up.
"That was a very good sign today," Mr. Udall said after the debate. "Last night, I was out knocking on doors, and it came up a few times. Mostly to say, 'We are sick of it.' "
Before the debate, Mr. Greenlee said: "I don't intend on using it in my campaign. But it's like a 350-pound gorilla. It's out there."
Addressing a business audience, Mr. Greenlee painted himself as an entrepreneur who had started 12 businesses and fought government regulations. He called for overhauling the Internal Revenue Service, paying down the national debt, instituting a system in which government vouchers could be used to pay for private schooling, and giving more opportunities to people in contrast to the government.
He stressed his success in building two of the Denver area's largest radio stations and a major restaurant chain. Apparently out of deference to the religious right, his campaign literature does not mention that he also is a major investor in Colorado's largest casino.
In a deliberate appeal to the lesser-known side of the Second District, Mr. Greenlee has placed his campaign headquarters not in Boulder but in Broomfield, a fast-growing suburb where high-technology companies are setting up shop.
Asked about initiatives to censor Internet content, Mr. Greenlee responded in almost a libertarian fashion, saying, "The freer the better."
In November, Coloradans are to vote on an initiative that would make Broomfield the state's first new county in 85 years.
Voting registration records in the Second District show that more newcomers are registering Republican than Democrat.
Mr. Udall, aware that the district is still dominated by the University of Colorado's largest campus, called for strengthening public education.
In the debate, Mr. Udall came off as a more polished campaigner than his opponent, who has served on the Boulder City Council for the last 15 years. While answering questions from the audience, Mr. Udall managed to tip his hat to two locally prominent Democrats attending the debate, a County Attorney and a State Senator, and to mention that his 74-year-old mother, Pat, is a Colorado native and a resident of Boulder.
No opinion polls have been taken in the race, and it is unclear who has the advantage.
"I am a lifelong Democrat, but for the first time in my life, I don't know who I will vote for," said Russell E. Shaw, a systems theory consultant who attended the debate. "They are offering different philosophies. Udall is trying to fix things. Greenlee is trying to empower citizens, instead of the government."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
In This Vote, You Can Take Manhattan

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

 BODY:
WOULD a "real mensch" trash Manhattan to curry favor in Munnsville?
Would a genuine champion of upstate interests embrace Ed (Rural Life Is a Joke) Koch? 
 The answer, New York State Democrats insist, is no on both counts. Hence their highly unorthodox step of promising to buy air time to rebroadcast Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's own advertisements.
Last week, Democrats announced plans to run an ad in upstate media markets that the Republican Senator himself has broadcast exclusively over New York City airwaves. In this ad, Mr. Koch and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani put aside their differences to praise the Senator, calling him a "real mensch."
Downstate, meanwhile, the Democrats say they plan to rebroadcast a commercial created by the state Republican Party for upstate viewing only. This ad depicts city Democrats, quite literally, as rapacious sharks gobbling up tax dollars.
"We are exposing downstaters to what Republicans have to say about them when they think they are not listening," said the state Democratic chairwoman, Judith Hope, who called the shark ad "very cynical and even offensive."
By running the two ads in media markets where they were most certainly not intended to be shown -- or at least by talking about doing so -- Democrats hope to dramatize internal contradictions in the Senator's campaign. In effect, they are betting that Mr. D'Amato has miscalculated, pushing too hard -- and too early -- on the old upstate-downstate rivalries.
But the last few elections also suggest that the risk Mr. D'Amato is taking in alienating city voters may well be worth it.
City residents tend to imagine that they live at the center of the world, to say nothing of the state. And while the city's influence, in cultural and economic terms, is disproportionately large, its influence in electoral politics is just the reverse.
A half-century ago, city voters made up half the state's electorate. Today, they make up just over a third. And even that figure overstates their significance, with a consistently low voter turnout rate.
Four years ago, for example, when George E. Pataki was a little-known State Senator running against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, two-thirds of all registered voters outside the city went to the polls. But within the city, fewer than half did. Had the city's turnout been comparable to the rest of the state's, Mr. Cuomo would almost certainly still be Governor, while Mr. Pataki would be a little-known former State Senator.
Four years before that, when Mr. Cuomo ran against the much-ridiculed Pierre Rinfret, only 37 percent of the city's registered voters went to the polls, while outside the city, 57 percent did. That year, Mr. Cuomo was pushing a $2 billion environmental bond act that was defeated largely because of voter apathy in the five boroughs.
EXPERTS cite many factors in the low city turnout, most significantly demography. "By and large," said Frances Fox Piven, a professor of political science at the City University's Graduate Center, "the pattern for fully a century now is that if you have less income, less education and are a member of a minority group, the less likely you are to turn out."
According to Ms. Piven, politicians could draw more city voters to the polls if they focused on the right issues, like income inequality, unemployment and health care access. The problem for Democrats, obviously, is that these are precisely the kind of issues associated with good old-fashioned New York City liberalism. Thus, they are precisely the kind of issues that can be used to galvanize opposition upstate.
If the last two gubernatorial elections are a guide, city residents will cast somewhere between 25 and 30 percent of the vote this November, a significant figure to be sure but hardly decisive.
So while it may be unseemly for Mr. D'Amato, himself Nassau County-bred, to attack his Democratic opponent, Representative Charles E. Schumer, for his New York City roots, it is quite logical for him to do.
In a D'Amato ad that the Democrats have decided not to rebroadcast, a large saw cuts the state in two while an announcer warns voters of Mr. Schumer's metro centrism. "Liberal Brooklyn Congressman Chuck Schumer doesn't think upstate New York matters," the narrator intones.
Perhaps the sharpest irony of the Republican strategy is that in statewide elections, it is increasingly New York City that doesn't matter.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 471 words

HEADLINE: Germany Turns the Page

 BODY:
A German politician once said of Chancellor Helmut Kohl that if he had been the Titanic, the iceberg would have sunk. So it seemed for 16 years as Mr. Kohl barreled over one opponent after another to lead Germany for longer than any man since Otto von Bismarck a century ago. But the Kohl winning streak was broken yesterday, and with it ended one of the most eventful and fateful periods in postwar German and European history.
Mr. Kohl deftly directed the peaceful reunification of Germany, helped fashion the political architecture for a united Europe and led the way to economic cooperation on the continent and the adoption of a common currency. In Germany itself he instilled a sense of confidence and accomplishment that helped overcome the burden of Germany's role in World War II and the Holocaust. 
 German unification was Mr. Kohl's singular achievement, even if it turned out to be one of the causes of his defeat. It is easy now to look back on the absorption of East Germany as a smooth, peaceful process. But as the Berlin wall fell and the cold war ended in the late 1980's, reunification seemed fraught with peril for Germany and for Europe. With the assistance of Mikhail Gorbachev in Moscow and George Bush in Washington, Mr. Kohl reunited the two Germanys democratically and made his country the anchor of peace and prosperity in Europe.
The financial cost of propping up eastern Germany was far greater than Mr. Kohl expected, and the sluggish growth and high unemployment it produced in recent years fanned dissatisfaction with Mr. Kohl. But after four terms, Mr. Kohl, who is 68, was defeated less by specific complaints than by a desire for new, younger leadership.
Mr. Kohl's departure portends no great change in Germany's relations with Europe, the United States and the rest of the world. It may not even mean much alteration in domestic policy, though power will now pass to a more left-leaning Government led by Gerhard Schroder and the Social Democratic Party. A radical student leader in the 1960's, Mr. Schroder, who is 54, long ago found his place in the German mainstream and campaigned as a pragmatic centrist.
His biggest challenge will be to deal with the economic drag produced by Germany's generous social welfare programs. Mr. Kohl tinkered with the system by curtailing a few benefits, but Mr. Schroder showed no inclination during the campaign to reform the long annual vacations, extended sick leave and other programs that Germans consider to be their birthright. Mr. Schroder also ought to make Germany's immigrants feel more welcome and make it easier for them to become citizens, an area in which Mr. Kohl often played to nationalist sentiments. Political and financial power in Germany is passing to a new generation. It will be measured against the Kohl legacy.

HEADLINE: Sharks in the Senate Race

 BODY:
Alfonse D'Amato, who represents New York in the United States Senate, appears to be planning a re-election campaign aimed at increasing the tensions and distrust between its residents. That is a remarkable conception of what it means to be a statewide elected official.
Mr. D'Amato's latest television ads against his Democratic opponent, Representative Charles Schumer, claim that because Mr. Schumer comes from Brooklyn, he "doesn't think upstate New York matters." Meanwhile, the state Republican Party is running similar commercials that depict New York City politicians as sharks, swimming up the Hudson to steal money from helpless upstate taxpayers. "They're back," says an announcer to music from the movie "Jaws." "New York City liberals have plans for higher taxes and higher spending, and you know what that means -- higher taxes for us, more spending for them." The Republicans are playing to a suspicion, long encouraged by upstate politicians, that the city is a drain on their economy, gobbling up far more than its share of resources. In truth, the city has been the economic engine for the state, and the real beneficiaries of an imbalance between taxes and spending are the small rural towns upstate, which are extremely dependent on state jobs and state aid paid for by all New York taxpayers. 
 No one should begrudge helping these needy towns, and if the political culture of New York were not so impaired, the state would have long since resolved some of the problems that have kept it lagging behind most of the rest of the country in job growth. But the mutual distrust between upstate New Yorkers and New York City is a political cancer that has laid waste to the state's government. The Legislature flounders perpetually because its members believe they were sent to Albany to champion their regions rather than work for the well-being of the entire state. Lawmakers have never been able to agree on sacrifice for the common good because in New York's warped political culture there is no common good, only a never-ending struggle to grab more for your own side.
The governor serves as the only real symbol of a unified New York, and it is incredible that Gov. George Pataki, the party's standard-bearer, would allow his party to run ads that aim at turning one part of the state against another. Mr. Pataki is well ahead in the polls and nurtures national ambitions, and his own ads are mainly feel-good paeans to his virtues. He cannot really believe he needs to run against New York City in order to be re-elected, but he cannot dodge responsibility for divisive commercials that are being paid for by his party on behalf of his ticket.
Playing the "liberal New York City politicians" card upstate is an easy dodge that transfers voter discontent away from local politicians and dumps it on a scapegoat far away. Mr. D'Amato did not invent the tactic, but he is perhaps the first official who actually represents New York City residents to use it against his own constituents.

HEADLINE: Making Do With Supplies, Dominican Republic Struggles to Rebuild

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER and RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: SAN PEDRO DE MACORIS, Dominican Republic, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Under a blazing Caribbean sun that made him squint as he worked, Rafael Dennis began trying to rebuild his mother's little wood-frame house this morning.
It was not going to be an easy job. 
 Like hundreds of thousands of people here in the Dominican Republic whose homes were blown down or damaged when Hurricane Georges struck last Tuesday, Mr. Dennis, in one of the hardest-hit areas, had almost nothing to work with. No lumber, no roofing materials. Not even nails.
Yet, with much of the wreckage of the storm cleared away, Mr. Dennis and many of the others were salvaging rusty nails, unbroken boards and anything else they could find to piece their homes back together. In every neighborhood, it seemed, men were up on ladders, balanced on roofs with hammers and saws flashing in the sun, as the country struggled to rebuild.
Mr. Dennis and some of the others said they hoped the Government would send trucks with corrugated tin for roofs. But they also knew that the authorities had been preoccupied with opening roads, restoring electricity and searching for missing people.
And although relief supplies have begun to arrive from abroad, many of the country's eight million people have yet to receive any help. Moreover, people who have tried to buy supplies say some merchants have doubled their prices.
For some Dominicans the worst of Hurricane Georges is still not over. Adriano Tejada, the chief spokesman for President Leonel Fernandez, said that at least a handful of towns and villages north and west of the capital were still cut off by flood waters. The Government shipped food to a staging point near some of those places, but it was not clear whether it reached the final destinations.
Government officials have reported 201 deaths, mainly from flooding and mudslides, but Hugh Parmer, a Texas lawyer who is now in charge of humanitarian aid for the United States Agency for International Development, said in an interview here that as many as 200 more might be dead.
While the Dominican Government has not yet issued an estimate of the cost of the destruction, Mr. Parmer said he expected it to run to about $3 billion, or about $500 million more than the nation's entire operating budget for this year. Officials have estimated the hurricane damage in Puerto Rico at $2 billion. One reason losses there were lower, Mr. Parmer said, was that Puerto Rico appeared to have been better prepared.
Four United States Representatives, led by Elton Gallegly, Republican of California, the chairman of the subcommittee on Western Hemisphere affairs, flew in from Puerto Rico this afternoon to talk with President Fernandez and other officials and visit a shelter for storm victims. As they were leaving a few hours later, Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat, said he would support an increase in aid for the Dominican Republic.
Mr. Parmer said the United States had spent about $500,000 in the relief effort here so far, and it expected to spend up to several million dollars altogether.
Dominican newspapers have reported that the hurricane caught many Dominicans by surprise and the newspapers have criticized the Government, saying that it failed to issue adequate warnings. This morning, one of the leading newspapers, Listin Diario, quoted Nicolas de Jesus Cardinal Lopez Rodriguez, the Roman Catholic Archbishop, as saying the Government's lack of preparation had contributed to the nation's losses. Responding earlier to the newspapers, Elpedio Baez, the Dominican Civil Defense director, said he believed that the criticism was politically motivated.
Mr. Parmer said Dominican officials had privately conceded to him that they "just underestimated the impact" of the hurricane.
"It's been 20 years since they've had a bad storm like this," he said. "It's human nature that when something happens that long ago, you forget."
San Pedro de Macoris, overlooking the Caribbean 32 miles west of the capital city of Santo Domingo, had the misfortune of being directly in the path of the hurricane as it steered a deadly course along the southern coast before veering inland and tearing across Haiti, the Dominican Republic's neighbor on the island of Hispaniola.
San Pedro is a city of more than 100,000 people, mostly poor and working class, dominated by sugar mills and dreams of big league baseball. It is the home of Sammy Sosa and scores of other baseball stars. Even in their misery, nearly everyone seemed to be thinking today of the Chicago Cubs slugger as he battled to become the home run king.
"It is great to see a fellow Dominican with such stature," said Efrain Vasquez, a 29-year-old factory worker, as he sat on a stone bench in the small plaza known as Central Park.
The hurricane jabbed and punched at this entire city. But the most crippling blows fell on the poorest people whose homes, like those of Mr. Dennis and his mother, had been fine shelters from the sun and the usual tropical downpours but were no match for the 110-mile-per-hour gusts of Hurricane Georges.
Juana Garcia lives in a neighborhood of small wood and concrete-block houses, Barrio Blanco, along the eastern bank of the Higamo River. She and her six children figured they would ride out the storm in their two-room concrete-block house. But as the winds began to shake the house, they ran to a neighbor's bigger house, higher up the bank. When the winds died down, all that was left of Ms. Garcia's house was the front wall and half of another.
At the white-washed, colonial-style Cathedral of San Pedro, homeless families have set up house in the pews. And they are pretty much on their own. Miguelina Contrera, a widow who ran to the church when the calm eye of the storm passed over, after the windows in her house had been blown out and the roof torn off, said that neither the Government nor the church had offered the refugees anything but shelter.
Besides the clothes she and her daughters, ages 2 and 9, were wearing, they had only a garbage bag with two thin blankets and a couple of shirts. Beside them was a plastic motor oil jug with water that Ms. Contrera said was not fit to drink.
In the city's industrial park, where row after row of low-rising factories produce things like clothing and simple medical equipment, tractor-trailers still lay on their sides today as workers patched roofs and tried to get drenched machinery working.
Working on his mother's home today, Mr. Dennis said he was not sure where or when he would get his hands on the lumber and roofing supplies he needed. But, he said, he thought he had salvaged enough to finish at least a single room so she could stop living with relatives.
"I have to do this," he said. "I feel bad because she's lost everything."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Franci Mercedes hung clothes to dry yesterday amid the remains of her house in San Pedro de Macoris in the Dominican Republic. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Calculated Risk: U.S. and I.M.F. Lead Push for Brazil Bailout Plan

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
With the Clinton Administration and the International Monetary Fund taking the lead, a package of loans for Brazil, likely to total more than $30 billion, is gradually being put together to limit the damage to Latin America's biggest economy from the Asian crisis. But the bailout plan is a calculated risk: rather than save Brazil, it could sink the country into deep recession.
The stakes for Americans are considerable. The huge Brazilian economy dominates Latin America, which purchases nearly 20 percent of America's exports and is host to thousands of American-owned factories, whose sales and profits contribute significantly to corporate America's bottom line. A sharp cutback in the flow of all this income, coming on top of a similar blow from the Asian crisis, might reduce economic growth in the United States to a crawl. 
 Now that Asia and Russia have been flattened, Brazil is suddenly the new front line in the struggle to halt the spreading financial crisis, with its power to pull down markets and plunge countries into recession. If Brazil goes down, then Europe or the United States would become the next battlegrounds.
"It is very clear from the statements being made by top officials in the Clinton Administration that Brazil is fundamental to the system," said Desmond Lachman, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney, a Wall Street firm with money at risk in Brazil. "There is just no way they can allow Brazil to fail."
The whole purpose of the proposed loan package is to preserve the present value of the Brazilian currency -- the real -- to avoid the steep devaluations that have been so ruinous in Asia.
Because Brazil spends much more on imports than it earns from exports, it must finance overseas purchases by continually borrowing money abroad.
That is not easy, given that foreign lenders are increasingly nervous about putting money into any country showing signs of difficulty. Since mid-summer, those lenders have gradually withdrawn money from Brazil.
The hope is that the huge loan package will reverse these withdrawals, particularly if it is combined with austerity measures already begun by Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso. Confidence in the Brazilian economy would revive and fresh foreign money would enter the country.
But obstacles are looming. The United States Government, for example, might take part in the proposed loan package. But rather than ask Congress for the money, the Administration might ask the Federal Reserve to make the loan from its resources, or it might tap the same emergency fund that it used in 1994 to help Mexico through its crisis.
Both possibilities are reported to have arisen in the preliminary discussions. And both are likely to draw the ire of Republicans, who challenged the Administration in 1994 for risking taxpayer money without Congressional approval.
Private lenders are also being asked to take part, and some are clearly reluctant. "Anything that boosts confidence in emerging markets we would regard as positive," said Andrew Tuck, a Chase Manhattan spokesman. "But as far as stepping up to the plate and putting up more money, we have $4.3 billion outstanding in Brazil already, and we cannot dig into our pockets every time someone asks for a handout."
The proposed package would be openly negotiated only after the presidential election in Brazil next Sunday, and only if -- as expected -- Mr. Cardoso is re-elected. Nevertheless, a senior Clinton Administration official acknowledged on Friday that active discussions are already in progress with the Brazilians, the I.M.F., other governments and private lenders.
He added, however, that "the speculation about the contents of a package are way ahead of reality."
The preliminary package, according to interviews with people involved in the talks, has taken this form: The I.M.F. would put up $10 billion or so, borrowing the money itself if its existing reserve is inadequate. The World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank would add roughly $5 billion apiece. The governments of the largest industrial countries, or some of them, would contribute sizable, but so far unspecified, amounts. And when these loans were in place, the private lenders, as a demonstration of their confidence in Brazil, would agree to roll over existing loans, and add roughly $10 billion.
Still, a giant loan package may not be sufficient to save the Brazilian economy, even if it is combined with the sort of cutbacks in spending that President Cardoso has already begun.
The Brazilian real must also be devalued, this argument goes, by 15 percent or more.
The reason is that the real is over-valued. An American-made toothbrush, for example, that sells in the United States for perhaps $1, sells in Brazil for the equivalent of 75 cents, while a Brazilian-made toothbrush sells in both Brazil and the United States for more than $1. No wonder foreign goods flood into Brazil, swamping Brazilian exports. No wonder there is so much demand for foreign loans to finance the resulting trade deficit.
No one is more outspoken on this issue than Jeffrey Sachs, director of the Harvard Institute for International Development and a persistent critic of I.M.F. practices. The proposed loan package is fine, he says. So are President Cardoso's austerity measures. But neither will work without a 25 percent devaluation of the real. Many economists agree in principle, but favor a smaller devaluation, say 15 percent.
"The Brazilians are suffering today from slow economic growth," Mr. Sachs said, "in part because they have been trying for months to defend an over-valued currency."
The issue is interest rates. In the midst of a worldwide financial crisis, foreign banks and other foreign lenders have grown increasingly reluctant to put money in a country that might soon have to devalue its currency. Brazil's hard currency reserves have dwindled to $50 billion from $75 billion in recent months as foreign money is withdrawn from the country. And part of the $50 billion could soon depart, as repayments are made for $49 billion in loans from foreign banks that have been coming due this year.
To keep the money in the country -- and also discourage Brazilians from converting their reals to dollars and depositing billions abroad -- President Cardoso has doubled interest rates since mid-summer, to more than 40 percent a year. At so high a level, Mr. Sachs argues, economic activity is discouraged and the already sluggish Brazilian economy will soon find itself in a severe recession. Devalue the currency, he says, and interest rates can be lowered.
The I.M.F. and the Administration are counting on the giant loan package, along with President Cardoso's spending cutbacks and the high Brazilian interest rates, to restore the confidence of foreign lenders before a recession can take hold. They resist devaluation on two other counts. It would end Brazil's fixed exchange rate, and that could frighten Argentina, and even Hong Kong -- two other countries still keeping to fixed rates.
And, they say, while the real may indeed be overvalued, any attempt at a limited devaluation could get out of hand in the current panicky environment. The real would then plunge in value, bringing the Asian crisis full-force to Latin America.

HEADLINE: THE GERMAN ELECTION: THE DEFEATED;
In Defeat, the Unifier of Germany Claims Yet Another Political First

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

 BODY:
It was characteristic that even when Helmut Kohl was finally ousted in Germany's national elections, he scored a first -- this time as the first postwar German Chancellor to be voted out of office.
It was not a first that Mr. Kohl relished, to be sure, nor one he likely worried about. For all his extraordinary records, both political and physical -- the first Chancellor of a reunited Germany, the longest-serving German Chancellor since Otto von Bismarck, and, at 6 foot 4 and somewhere around 300 pounds, indisputably the largest leader in modern Europe -- Mr. Kohl has not spent much of the past 16 years pondering his place in history. 
 "To hell with history," he once snapped at an aide who raised the subject. His medium was politics, and it was a medium in which he was a master, even if in the end he failed to recognize when to step aside.
Throughout his career, Mr. Kohl attracted an unending stream of unflattering jokes, and was often perceived by intellectuals as something of an embarrassing provincial politico. But nobody ever questioned his total control of his own party, the Christian Democratic Union, nor his skill in guiding his nation through the Byzantine politics of post-war and post-Communist Europe.
If he disdained talk of his "place in history," Mr. Kohl bridled when his opponents accused him of lacking vision. His was as concrete as it was consistent: to unify his people in the context of a unified Europe.
"Who has a better vision here in the Federal Republic?" he declared in 1990, on the eve of German unification. "I know no better concept than the one I represent -- European unification -- because in 10 years we will write 2000 and not 1900, and this country and this continent will have a chance in the year 2000, and beyond, only if they are united. O. K., there is the vision."
He spoke of unity as a "compass" in his politics. "My compass also says, to an almost emotional degree, friendship with France, friendship with the United States," he said.
If his formulation lacked the eloquence of a Helmut Schmidt or a Willy Brandt, Mr. Kohl never deviated from his compass, even when his decisions ran against the tide.
In the 1980's, his determination to maintain West Germany in an American-led NATO by allowing the deployment of Pershing II missiles prompted vast and brutal protests, yet he persevered.
And once the disintegration of the Communist world made reunification possible, he managed the Herculean task of gaining the acquiescence of the skeptical leaders of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France, and reuniting Germany within 11 months of the collapse of the Berlin Wall.
The achievement proved considerably more painful than Mr. Kohl had promised, and it was the enormous cost of reunification that eventually led to his political fall. But not many politicians or historians have argued that Mr. Kohl erred in his decision to press ahead with reunification as quickly as possible.
"I've been wrong about some things since 1990, but who hasn't been?" Mr. Kohl mused in the spring of 1994 -- one of the many times when the polls predicted prematurely that his era was coming to an end. Yet more than his vision or even his political skills, Mr. Kohl's longevity was probably due to the degree to which he represented his generation of western Germans.
What his adversaries often perceived as an uncanny political antenna was rooted in the degree to which he represented a generation struggling to reconcile the stigma of Germany's history with its remarkable economic and political revival.
Fifteen when the war ended, Mr. Kohl was old enough to know first-hand the horrors of Nazism and the war, but young enough to claim what he called "the absolution of late birth" -- a notion that irritated some listeners but was shared by many of his and younger generations.
Raised in in the hinterlands of the Roman Catholic Rhineland, he learned like many West Germans to balance a quiet patriotism against a constant awareness of how others perceived his people. Although his insistence on serving as host to President Ronald Reagan at a cemetery where some SS soldiers were buried created a furor in 1985, many of his trips abroad -- most notably to Poland and to Israel -- became milestones of reconciliation.
A man who relished quintessentially German food like stuffed sow's belly and plum pie, who never shed his provincial Rhineland accent and who commuted regularly to his home town of Ludwigshafen to mingle with its respectable, hard-working, heavy-eating, prosperous burghers, Mr. Kohl was the image of what his Christian Democratic Party represented.
Active in the party almost from the time of its founding after the war, Mr. Kohl rose rapidly, scoring "firsts" at every step -- at 30 the youngest member of his state legislature, at 33 the youngest floor leader, at 39 the youngest state premier, at 43 the youngest chairman of the Christian Democratic Union and finally, in 1982, at 52, the youngest Chancellor.
Yet at every step, critics spoke of his "luck," and predicted that he would go no further. His first speech as a legislator was so terrible that his colleagues wrote him off. In 1976, the legendary head of the Christian Social Union in Bavaria, Franz Josef Strauss, declared that Mr. Kohl was "totally incapable." And when Mr. Kohl did become Chancellor in 1982, his adversaries noted, it was not through an election, but because the small Free Democratic Party shifted support from the Social Democrats to Mr. Kohl.
In fact, Mr. Kohl personally never did well in polls, usually gaining office by being at the head of his party's list, and not through a direct victory. In today's voting, he was defeated in his home constituency of Ludwigshafen.
Yet so often did he defy challengers that stories of his revivals became cliches. When this election came along, it was a measure of Mr. Kohl's reputation that nobody predicted his loss with certainty, even when all the polls pointed to it.

HEADLINE: Schumer Tours Upstate to Counter Attacks by D'Amato

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 27

 BODY:
After a week of being assailed in television advertising as a "liberal Brooklyn Congressman" hostile to upstate interests, Charles E. Schumer campaigned across western and central New York today, ticking off the names of relatives who had lived there and blaming Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for the economic decline that has gripped this region.
From an airport terminal in Rochester to a union gathering in Syracuse to the front porch of the house where his father grew up in this central New York city, the Democratic candidate for Senate asserted that, his ZIP code and accent notwithstanding, he was sympathetic to the concerns of voters north of New York City. Mr. Schumer's visit here, which followed a series of television advertisements directed by Mr. Schumer at upstate audiences, signaled the extent to which both Mr. Schumer and Mr. D'Amato are viewing upstate as critical to the outcome of the November election. 
 Again and again, Mr. Schumer spoke about the anemic economy in the region, pledging to push legislation that he said would lower the cost of electricity and air fares, two major constraints on economic growth. But again and again, Mr. Schumer was reminded of the potency of Mr. D'Amato's saturation television campaign as he was repeatedly asked by reporters how a lawmaker who had spent his life representing New York City constituents could understand the concerns of upstate New Yorkers.
"Chuck Schumer is a tough-on-crime, tax-cutting, moderate Democrat, whose dad was raised in Utica, who shares the same values as upstate New Yorkers," Mr. Schumer said into a clutch of television cameras in Syracuse. He accused Mr. D'Amato of dividing the state for political gain, adding, "All his name-calling and negativity does nothing positive for the people of this state -- downstate or upstate."
In Brooklyn, Mr. D'Amato countered Mr. Schumer's move by venturing into the Congressman's district, appealing directly to Jewish voters and predicting that he would beat Mr. Schumer in his own backyard. "I'm going to carry this district," said Mr. D'Amato, who also campaigned today in Suffolk County.
Mr. D'Amato bristled at Mr. Schumer's assertion that the Republican Senator was running a divisive campaign and that he had failed to tend to the needs of New York's troubled upstate economy.
"That's total nonsense," he said after speaking at a Holocaust memorial service at the East Midwood Jewish Center in Brooklyn. "If you look at the record, you will see that repeatedly we have delivered over and over again for New York."
Mr. D'Amato declared that Mr. Schumer had been divisive in Congress by voting, for example, to raise the gasoline tax. "His votes are being divisive," said Mr. D'Amato, who has also supported a gas tax rise. "You've got to represent all the people. I have. I represented the interests of upstate, while at the same token, fighting for, championing and getting the largest increase for mass transportation because the people here in Brooklyn need it. And I've never played one against the other."
The exchanges captured a day in which Mr. D'Amato and Mr. Schumer battled over constituencies -- geographic and ethnic -- that both sides see as critical to victory in what has become one of the closest watched contests in the country.
Mr. D'Amato announced his intention to visit Brooklyn shortly after learning that Mr. Schumer had organized a trip upstate in an apparent attempt to confront him in a part of the state that the Senator has identified as his prime battleground. Mr. Schumer was trailed by a chartered plane filled with reporters.
Mr. Schumer, dodging thunderstorms that chased his single-propeller plane through a bumpy itinerary that included Rochester, Syracuse, Utica and Albany (Ithaca and Binghamton were rained out), signaled how he intended to compete with Mr. D'Amato upstate. He said the Senator had shown no concern about how this part of New York had lagged behind the economic recovery most of the nation had enjoyed.
"He hasn't done anything to create jobs in western New York," Mr. Schumer said. "Al D'Amato hasn't talked about jobs. He hasn't talked about ways to get businesses to come here and stay here. He has no plan. Rochester doesn't need a Senator who once every six years comes up to Rochester, calls somebody some names and then vanishes."
Democrats who accompanied Mr. Schumer accused Mr. D'Amato of running a divisive campaign. "They're going to try to pit one part of the state against the other for political advantage," said State Senator Richard A. Dollinger of Rochester. "I believe it's outrageous."
Mr. Schumer went to considerable lengths to try to dodge Mr. D'Amato's effort to characterize him as alien to upstate. At every opportunity, he took note of some relative who had made a home, no matter how briefly, in this part of the world. "I feel at home here," he said in Rochester. "I love this city. I have relatives here. In fact, my uncle is the head of surgery at Strong Memorial Hospital."
At Mr. Schumer's request, his parents drove up from Brooklyn to join him in Utica, so his father, Abe, who is 75, could pose with him at the home where the elder Mr. Schumer lived for three of the nine years he was here.
Yet even in front of his father's house, there were reminders of the difficulties Mr. Schumer faced here. John Cosgrove, a lawyer from the town of Clinton, who served in the Assembly in the 1960's, stopped by to praise Mr. Schumer's candidacy. When asked his party affiliation, Mr. Cosgrove responded loudly, "I was a Democrat," but then dropped his voice to a whisper. "And a liberal. But don't put that word in."
And one of the people who now lives in Abe Schumer's old home, Lisa Smith, said she had learned of the Democratic Senate candidate through Mr. D'Amato. "I hadn't even heard of Chuck Schumer until the last couple of weeks, until we heard the negative ads," she said. Ms. Smith added that she was offended by Mr. D'Amato's ads and was likely to vote for Mr. Schumer.
Mr. D'Amato's visit at a service in Brooklyn, organized by the Association of Holocaust Survivors From the Former Soviet Union, came as some analysts said his attacks on Mr. Schumer as a Brooklyn liberal could shake his standing among Jewish voters who are inclined to be sympathetic to Mr. Schumer.
At the service, Mr. D'Amato, wearing a yarmulke, discussed his fight against Swiss banks on behalf of Jewish depositors and their heirs who were refused the return of their money after World War II. "Our record is one that I'm proud of," he said. "For 40-plus years, the victims and their families of the Holocaust, no one paid attention to them, and I think when you come back and tell people, here I was and I did it and I was there, they understand that."

HEADLINE: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE FIRST LADY;
Hillary Clinton, Smile in Place, Hits Fund-Raisers

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Is she a national role model as First Lady? The President's top crisis manager determined to rescue his legacy? Or a traumatized victim deserving of America's embrace?
In a three-day, five-state fund-raising tour on behalf of Democratic candidates for Congress, Hillary Rodham Clinton was analyzed and lionized, criticized and beatified on each of these points. 
 Through it all, she stayed the course, smiling opaquely and assuring old friends and political allies that she was "Just fine!" as she thickly larded her speeches with praise of the President and criticism of Congress.
Her steadfast fans could not stop themselves from gushing.
"She's kind of like our American Princess Di," said Lawrence Johnson, 30, a clerk at Seattle's Westin Hotel who saw Mrs. Clinton as she swept in for an evening of fund-raising on Thursday. "They ought to leave her husband alone. And she should be our next President!"
With elections just a few weeks away and concerns that the President's sex scandal may inhibit Democrats from voting, Mrs. Clinton is getting many standing ovations as she asks audiences to empty their pockets and get out the vote.
And if there was any doubt that Mrs. Clinton was withholding support from her husband as she sorted out her own feelings, she dispelled it in her sweep through New York, Colorado, Washington, Oregon and California.
At times she seemed to be campaigning even more for Mr. Clinton than she was for the candidates, tirelessly promoting him as the President who turned around the economy, reduced crime, furthered educational change and balanced the budget for the first time since Neil Armstrong walked on the moon.
"By any objective measure, by any fair assessment, our country is so much better off because of my husband's leadership," she told a crowd of several hundred at a fund-raising dinner for four Congressional candidates in Seattle.
Most of the candidates said little about the President, and in some cases they appeared relieved that she, not he, was around.
Even so, Mrs. Clinton sits at the innermost circle of the President's crisis-management team, drafting hardball responses to the Lewinsky scandal and the Paula Jones sexual misconduct suit -- and to the Republicans who have attacked the President because of them. Mrs. Clinton's loyalists believe that she is a First Lady with a future, no matter how the Clinton Presidency weathers the impeachment debate, no matter whether the White House strategy, to which she has contributed so much, prevails.
"The attraction of Mrs. Clinton is that she focuses on the issues rather than the distractions swirling around Washington, D.C.," said Jay Inslee, who is running for Congress in Washington State. "The President is a distraction."
Despite the best efforts of Democratic candidates to change the subject from Mr. Clinton's woes to issues like child care, education, Social Security and the environment, the President's troubles kept intruding, often in unexpected ways.
At a re-election fund-raiser for Senator Barbara Boxer in the grand ballroom of the San Francisco Hilton Hotel on Friday night, the actress, Frances Fisher, of "Titanic" fame read excerpts from Mrs. Clinton's best seller, "It Takes a Village," telling the $250-a-plate audience of 1,100 supporters how children are "a moral touchstone amidst the complexity and contentiousness of modern life."
But on the sidewalk outside the hotel, 8-year-old Carolyn Ahr carried a poster that she had drawn with a sad face and the words, "The President lies and should be fired."
"Mrs. Clinton is a setback for American women," said Catherine Ahr, 37, a homemaker, and Carolyn's mother. "I've never protested in my life -- and I even went to Berkeley. But this time was different. What kind of moral message does this whole thing send to our children?"
In none of her child-related events did Mrs. Clinton answer that question. None of the candidates did either.
At Portland State University in Oregon, Mrs. Clinton appeared in front of a big poster that read, "Kids First" with David Wu, a Yale-educated lawyer and candidate for Congress whose main pitch is education and who praised his guest as "our nation's foremost children's advocate."
Asked whether there was a conflict between Mrs. Clinton's focus on children's needs and the difficulty parents are having in explaining her husband's behavior to their children, Mr. Wu said, "I will have to think about that."
So much was said in code and fraught with double meaning on Mrs. Clinton's campaign tour that it was often hard to sort out what the real message was supposed to be.
At the fund-raising dinner in Seattle, Mrs. Clinton mocked what she called "the other Washington."
"I think that's the way to look at it," she said. "It's like a parallel universe and sort of exists out there somewhere in outer space."
But she also said that the American people do not get enough political news, and throughout her trip described politics as a noble calling, exhorting her audiences to "persuade people that politics matters."
Unlike the First Lady, Mrs. Boxer, whose daughter is married to Mrs. Clinton's brother, said flat out in her speech at the fund-raiser in San Francisco, "The President has problems."
But she never said what they were. And she blamed the "extraordinary atmosphere we are living in" for making it impossible to get the media to focus on serious issues.
But it was not just the media that were focusing on sex. There was also Art Torres, the chairman of the California Democratic Party, introducing Mrs. Boxer and explaining how her Republican opponent in 1992, Bruce Herschensohn, was "the family values guy on every day except Friday nights."
"And then we found out," Mr. Torres continued, "he did other things in his spare time."
The audience groaned. Some people even cursed their chairman. (In 1992 the Democrats turned up evidence that Mr. Herschensohn had frequented a nude bar in Hollywood called The Seventh Veil and bought girlie magazines.)
"He didn't have to do that!" a woman said, referring to Mr. Torres's remarks. "This is not the time to bring this up."
As in San Francisco, there were competing demonstrators in Denver, where Mrs. Clinton campaigned on Thursday for Dottie Lamm, Colorado's former first lady who is running against Ben Nighthorse Campbell for the Senate, and Gail Schoettler, Lieutenant Governor and a candidate for governor.
As Mrs. Clinton shook hands with children in front of Fort Logan Elementary School outside Denver, Ilona Smith, 41, a mental health worker, shouted, "Hang in there, Hillary," as protesters down the block chanted, "Jail Slick Willy." A handmade sign read, "Lyin' King and the Queen of Denial." Another read, "It Takes a Village to Raise an Idiot."
"It's a really inappropriate forum for what these people are doing," Ms. Smith said. "It's rude, it's ill-mannered, it's embarrassing to Colorado. It's Hillary that's here, not Bill."
Mrs. Clinton spoke to safe, friendly audiences. She has avoided situations in which journalists could question her.
She was tireless in raising money and stingy with the chitchat.
In Seattle, a picture with her cost $2,500. She took a quick hello-and-thank-you approach. "I told her we support her and the Democratic agenda," said Arun Bhagat, a consulting engineer. "She thanked us for coming. Everyone was very tactful."
At a $200-a-head private reception for 200 in Denver, "a lot of people were doing the two-handed shake, saying thank you for what you're doing for Gail and Dottie," said Laurie Zeller, 38. "Nobody made reference to the current crisis."
Support is what Mrs. Clinton needs these days, said Brian Baird, a clinical psychologist who lost a Congressional race in Washington State in 1996 and is running again. "There was something different in the applause tonight," Mr. Baird said of the fund-raiser in Seattle. "There was a sort of effort to send some love Hillary's way. We want to help her during this trying time, in a healing way, to give her a respite from all this stuff."
Mr. Baird, who teaches psychology and treats cancer patients and other patients, said that he thought Mrs. Clinton was "doing well." But then, he added, " 'Well' is a relative word."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hillary Rodham Clinton campaigned for Senator Barbara Boxer of California on Friday in San Francisco. Mrs. Clinton was on a three-day, five-state fund-raising tour on behalf of Democratic candidates for Congress. (Peter DaSilva for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bronx Offers Stadium Plan for Keeping Team

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Hoping to place the Bronx back at the center of the debate over a home for the Yankees, the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, plans to offer a proposal today to renovate Yankee Stadium, install 120 luxury boxes, ease traffic congestion and redevelop the neighborhood with a waterfront park, a Yankee Hall of Fame and sports-related stores.
Mr. Ferrer's proposal, called Yankee Village, comes a month before George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the Yankees' principal owner, is expected to announce his decision on where the team will play after its lease with the city expires in 2002. Mr. Steinbrenner has long threatened to move his team to New Jersey or Manhattan, complaining that the Bronx stadium has too few luxury boxes and parking spaces, and that the neighborhood is unpleasant, unsafe and a traffic nightmare. 
 Mr. Ferrer's plan, which he commissioned himself and which combines elements of several previous stadium proposals, would cost an estimated $535 million, far less than any new stadium. But the chances of Mr. Ferrer's single-handedly settling the issue seem far-fetched, given his fierce and frequent criticism of the two people whose support for any stadium plan is essential: Mr. Steinbrenner and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Whatever its fate, the Ferrer plan is likely to add another layer of complexity to the speculation and debate caused by Mr. Steinbrenner's shaky commitment to the Bronx. Mayor Giuliani has praised the economic benefits of a billion-dollar stadium on the West Side of Manhattan. New Jersey beckons with its own plans. Even The Star-Ledger of Newark has weighed in, publishing its own plan yesterday for a stadium in northern New Jersey.
But even though a Yankee move has at times seemed a foregone conclusion, the focus of the debate has shifted in recent weeks back to the Bronx.
Just last week, Gov. George E. Pataki declared that the Yankees "belong in the Bronx, period." Mr. Pataki -- perhaps feeling pressure from the Democratic candidate for Governor, Peter F. Vallone, who strongly favors keeping the team in the Bronx -- now contends that traffic jams, widespread opposition and the high cost of construction in Manhattan "argue strongly against that site."
Mr. Steinbrenner himself suggested in July that the Yankees might stay in the Bronx if they drew three million fans this season. A spokesman later backed away from that statement, but the team set an attendance record anyway -- 2,949,734 by yesterday, the end of the regular season.
And now Mr. Ferrer has a plan that seems intended to blunt each of Mr. Steinbrenner's familiar arguments for moving away.
"Our proposal," Mr. Ferrer said, "will present to fans and visitors a year-round entertainment venue that will begin to return to the city the enormous investment the city will, and has already made, in the New York Yankees. It's fan-friendly, fiscally prudent and answers the legitimate concerns raised by the Yankees and by fans."
Under Mr. Ferrer's proposal, the 75-year-old stadium would regain its historic entrance porticos, perimeter wall at the upper deck and distinctive copper friezes, while a new, glass-enclosed concourse would be built on the outside wall. Babe Ruth Plaza would be moved to the west side of the 50,000-seat stadium, where restaurants, sports shops, batting cages and a museum would provide year-round attractions. Fans would arrive and depart from an expanded ferry terminal, a renovated subway station, a new Metro-North station and newly configured highway ramps.
Mr. Ferrer said that Yankee Village would cost less than half the price of a proposed stadium in Manhattan, with an estimated $360 million coming from state, Federal and private sources and only $175 million from the city.
The Ferrer proposal was prepared by the Manhattan architectural firm of Beyer Blinder Belle, which designed the Ford Center for the Performing Arts on 42d Street and the renovation of Grand Central Terminal. Richard Blinder, a partner at the firm, said he wove together his own ideas, features of the National Tennis Center in Flushing, Queens; Chelsea Piers in Manhattan, and previous design efforts to address complaints by the Yankees.
Mr. Blinder said he did the study for only $25,000 because he believed in the project and because an alternative -- the Yankees' relocating to Manhattan -- "is horrible."
Mr. Steinbrenner may gain some momentum for a move as his team heads toward the World Series. He has been discussing a possible sale of the Yankees to Cablevision, the Long Island company that owns Madison Square Garden. But some sports analysts and even Mr. Steinbrenner's associates say it now appears unlikely that the Yankees will leave the Bronx. As long as the possibility exists, however, Mr. Steinbrenner retains a strong bargaining position.
"The way the Yankees are playing, it makes it more than likely something good will happen for them on the stadium front," said Marc Ganis, president of Sportscorp Ltd., a sports business consulting firm based in Chicago. "The West Side has so much structural opposition that it is not likely to happen. But as long as that possibility is out there, it can be used as leverage to get a better deal in the Bronx."
Built in 1923, Yankee Stadium was the first three-tiered ball park and the first to be called a stadium. In the mid-1970's, Mayor John V. Lindsay renovated the stadium, but failed to make good on promises to rehabilitate the neighborhood as the cost ballooned to $120 million.
Mr. Ferrer's proposal seeks to restore many of the original elements obliterated by the earlier renovation, although some things may be gone forever. The original Yankee bat rack and bullpen steps are at the Smithsonian Institution, while the foul poles and some of the lights are in Osaka, Japan.
Under Mr. Ferrer's plan, luxury boxes would be built along the entire mezzanine level, while the stadium club, with a new dining terrace, would be moved to left field.
To answer the most persistent complaints from Mr. Steinbrenner and fans about traffic congestion and parking, Yankee Village calls for the creation of a total of 10,340 parking spaces (up from about 7,000) at six garages that are designed to feed traffic across either the Macombs Dam Bridge or the 145th Street Bridge, or onto local streets. The proposal also calls for building exits from Harlem River Drive, widening the exits from the Major Deegan Expressway and expanding the use of reversible lanes during games.
"The traffic problems at Yankee Stadium are solvable," said Samuel I. Schwartz, a transportation consultant and the former Deputy Commissioner and chief engineer of the city's Department of Transportation, who has seen parts of Mr. Ferrer's plan.
The plan tries to go beyond simply solving the team's problems by integrating the stadium into the economic life of the surrounding neighborhood. Restaurants and retail stores would be built alongside the Yankee Hall of Fame. Storefronts and street lighting would be improved along River Avenue and 161st Street.
The new garages would be limited to three stories to reduce the impact on the community and the exit time for automobiles. At the same time, sports centers with ball fields for local teams would be atop garages on the northeast and south sides of the stadium.
Most important, Mr. Ferrer said, he would have the city condemn the dilapidated Bronx Terminal Market, a 32-acre site on the south side of the stadium, to build a waterfront park along the Harlem River and 450,000 square feet of commercial space.
"We think this will revive the existing commercial areas and restore the neighborhood parks for Little League teams that play in the shadow of Yankee Stadium," Mr. Ferrer said. "It will ignite a whole system of active and passive parks with vibrant new commercial areas and make this as exciting as Camden Yards or the National Tennis Center."

GRAPHIC: Drawing: An artist's rendering of the revamped Yankee Stadium, as proposed by the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer. Restaurants and retail stores would be built alongside a Yankee Hall of Fame. (Beyer Blinder Belle)(pg. B3)
