INTERNATIONAL A3-10
 
Kohl Loses Election, Ending an Era in Germany
Gerhard Schroder won a decisive election victory in Germany, defeating Helmut Kohl, Germany's Chancellor for the last 16 years, who oversaw the peaceful unification of his country in 1990. The election marks the end of an era in Germany and the opening of a new one in Europe, where center-left governments now dominate the continent's politics. A1
 
European leaders congratulated both Mr. Schroder and Mr. Kohl. They hailed Mr. Kohl's role in consolidating Europe after German unification and expressed confidence that Mr. Schroder would continue in the same tradition. A10
 
Loan Package for Brazil
The Clinton Administration and the International Monetary Fund are taking the lead in putting together a package of loans for Brazil, likely to total more than $30 billion, to limit the damage from the Asian crisis to Latin America's biggest economy. A bailout plan is risky, but one that American leaders seem inclined to take for Brazil, which buys nearly 20 percent of America's exports and is home to thousands of American-owned factories. A1
 
U.S. Optimism Over Bosnia
Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen, visiting Bosnia, said that country's national elections created "some room for optimism" for the future of its shattered society, even though the Bosnian Serb leader endorsed by the United States, Biljana Plavsic, lost her bid for re-election. He warned that Bosnian leaders had to make more progress or risk losing international support. A3
 
Assault on Kosovo Continues
Serbian security forces continued their campaign of destroying ethnic Albanian villages in Kosovo province even though the Serbian Government announced on Saturday the end of the military offensive in the province whose people are mostly ethnic Albanians. In crippling the rebel movement, the Government has brought devastation to civilians. A3
 
Albright Holds Mideast Talks
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright pushed for agreement on crucial details of a long-stalled peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians, with American officials saying the White House hoped to announce progress when President Clinton meets with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel. A6
 
New Opposition in Japan
A credible political opposition is bubbling in Japan, a country that for half a century has been largely a one-party state. While the development has been obscured by the mountains of bad debts, battles in Parliament and growing international frustration with Japan's economic problems, a vigorous opposition leader -- Naoto Kan -- has been forcing the Government to alter its policies. A8
 
The Japan Leasing Corporation, with liabilities estimated at more than $18 billion, said that it had filed for bankruptcy, the largest such action in Japan since World War II. A6
 
NATIONAL A12-15
 
Hurricane Slams Gulf Coast With Winds of 105 M.P.H.
Hurricane Georges slammed into the seaside cities and resorts of the Gulf Coast with rain-packed winds of up to 110 miles per hour and a sea surge of 10 feet or more. A1
 
In Haiti, homes, livestock and crops were swept away and entire villages were destroyed by the flooding that followed the hurricane. Many people had ignored warning to evacuate. A12
 
While relief supplies have begun to arrive from abroad, many of the Dominican Republic's eight million people have yet to receive any help. A12
 
Attorney General Hospitalized
Attorney General Janet Reno fainted during a church service in suburban Maryland and was hospitalized at Georgetown University Medical Center, where she was to be held for observation. A13
 
First Lady Stays the Course
On a three-day, five-state fund-raising tour for Democratic Congressional candidates, Hillary Rodham Clinton stayed the course, smiling opaquely and assuring old friends and political allies that she was "just fine!" as she praised the President and criticized Congress. A14
 
President Clinton raised nearly $4 million in Silicon Valley, Hollywood and South Texas this weekend for Democratic candidates. Protesters carried signs outside the events, but inside, loyal Democrats offered moral support as they opened their wallets for the party. A15
 
An aide to the President sought to prepare the public for a possible settlement of Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct lawsuit, saying that it should not be taken as admission that her accusations are true. A15
 
Broadening its counterattack against possible impeachment proceedings, the White House is working with Congressional Democrats to turn the tables and investigate the investigators by examining how Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent prosecutor, came to look into the Lewinsky matter. A14
 
Three veteran politicians said that there would be no deal between the President and Congress until after the Nov. 3 elections. A14
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6
 
Republicans Sense Victory In State Assembly Races
Democrats are biting their nails and Republicans are smelling blood in Assembly races in the downstate suburbs, across upstate New York and in a few parts of New York City. Strategists on both sides predict that Republicans could gain 5 to 10 seats in the November elections, which would be the Democrats' worst setback in decades. B1

After a week of being assailed in television advertisements as a "liberal Brooklyn congressman" who was hostile to upstate interests, Charles E. Schumer campaigned across western and central New York, ticking off the names of relatives who had lived there and blaming Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for the economic decline that has gripped the region. B6
 
Bronx to Unveil Stadium Plan
Hoping to place the Bronx back at the center of the debate over a home for the Yankees, the Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, plans to unveil a $535 million proposal to restore Yankee Stadium's original monumental exterior, install 120 luxury boxes, ease traffic congestion and redevelop the surrounding neighborhood with a waterfront park, a Yankee Hall of Fame and sports-related stores. HEADLINE: Tokyo Politician Raises Hope for Real Opposition

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Obscured by the mountains of bad debts, by the battles in Parliament, by the growing international frustration at Japan's tardiness in confronting its economic problems, something remarkable is bubbling up in Japan.
It is a genuine, credible political opposition. In a country that for half a century has been largely a one-party state, it is striking to see a vigorous opposition leader -- Naoto Kan, a tempestuous baby-boomer nicknamed Kan the Irritable -- assailing the Government's policies and forcing it to accept his own instead. 
 It is unclear whether this is a step toward a two-party system in Japan or simply another political dead end. Japan has tried for years to nurture a genuine two-party system, in hopes of making government more honest and effective, but this has never happened except for brief periods.
Mr. Kan still faces enormous challenges in holding his fractious Democratic Party together, but so far he has managed better than most people expected in forging a broad anti-Government alliance. He has seized on the economic crisis to embarrass the Government, and he clearly hopes to replace Keizo Obuchi in the Prime Minister's residence.
"Of course we aim for the earliest possible dissolution of Parliament, because the Obuchi Government is not the choice of the people," said Mr. Kan, noting that Mr. Obuchi was not elected but was installed by the governing Liberal Democratic Party between elections. "Soon, the time will come when it will be apparent to people that the Obuchi administration is deadlocked and cannot achieve anything."
How soon will that be?
"In a few months," Mr. Kan said confidently.
Most experts do not see matters so clearly. For starters, general elections need not be held for two more years, and the Liberal Democrats are so unpopular right now that it is in their interest to try to delay elections as long as possible.
Moreover, while Mr. Kan has shaken up Japanese politics and is greatly admired as an individual, he is also untested as a national leader. His Democratic Party has a poor grass-roots organization and no clear identity, and while voters are fed up with the Liberal Democrats, it is not clear that they would prefer the Democrats.
While the United States and other countries have long hoped for the emergence of an effective multi-party structure in Japan, for now the spectacle in Tokyo has not so much inspired Washington as alarmed it. The wrangling in Parliament delayed any action on bailing out Japan's crippled banking system, although on Saturday the governing and opposition parties agreed -- for a second time -- on a joint plan for legislation to stabilize the country's financial system.
This joint plan is based largely on Mr. Kan's proposals, a rare case in which the political opposition in Japan actually contributed anything to the decision-making process. And so while the clash of political parties may slow the economic recovery, some see it as a milestone in Japan's political development.
"The whole process may be chaotic and a bit scary, but it's been very helpful for Japanese democracy," said John F. Neuffer, who writes a newsletter on Japanese politics. "This is the first time in memory that the opposition is looking like a credible opposition."
For most of the postwar period, the Liberal Democrats presided grandly over the political scene in Japan, with a token opposition provided by the Socialists. In 1993, a schism in the Liberal Democratic Party allowed the opposition to take power briefly, but opposing politicians never formed an effective party.
Then Mr. Kan suddenly appeared on the scene two years ago as a gust of fresh air, serving as Health Minister and uncovering a scandal in his own ministry. He won raves for seeming to be a take-charge politician who would lead the bureaucrats instead of the other way around.
Mr. Kan also has a sense, rare in Japan, of how to use television and public relations, while Mr. Obuchi rarely gives interviews and is ineffective when he does. Mr. Obuchi comes across a bit like the Russian Prime Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, for both rose in one-party systems in which the key to success was impressing superiors rather than charming television audiences.
Mr. Kan has been particularly adept at appealing to the resentments of urban voters ("tax-payers," he calls them) whom the Government has traditionally treated as a cash cow to subsidize rural citizens ("tax-eaters," in Mr. Kan's terminology).
Still, one of Mr. Kan's key tests will be whether he can maintain the opposition's unity when the subject is no longer the economic crisis. The opposition is a mosaic of different political hues, and it will be difficult to forge a common front on issues down the road like legislation defining the degree of military cooperation with the United States.
"We really need a balanced two-party system, but unfortunately, the opposition parties have lots of divisions and fights and personality differences," said Kazuyuki Hamada, a political expert and writer in Tokyo. "This opposition coalition is very fragile, with so many competing interests."

HEADLINE: THE GERMAN ELECTION: THE REACTION;
Europeans Congratulate Both Winner And Loser

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 27

 BODY:
European leaders congratulated both Gerhard Schroder and the man he defeated today in Germany's elections, Chancellor Helmut Kohl.
President Jacques Chirac of France, a conservative like Mr. Kohl, and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, whose fellow Socialists saw in the victory of Mr. Schroder's Social Democrats a continuation of a European trend that brought them and the Labor Party of Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to power last year, paid tribute to both German leaders in almost equal measure. 
 Mr. Chirac and Mr. Jospin hailed Mr. Kohl's role in consolidating European unity after German reunification in 1990, and expressed confidence that Mr. Schroder would carry on in the same tradition.
Mr. Blair, in Blackpool, England, for a Labor Party convention, telephoned Mr. Schroder to congratulate him and told reporters later, "It's a tremendous thing that we will now see center-left government in Britain, France and Germany. I pay tribute to Helmut Kohl for all of the things he has done for Europe."
There was a widespread sense that a turn by German voters to the left after a generation was a historic turning point that was not so much about ideology as about German self-confidence and assertiveness.
"The change has already taken place," Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine of France said recently. "It's a different Germany from the one we knew from 1949 to 1989."
What he meant was that more than half a century after the end of World War II, Germans no longer felt a need to buy respectability as partners in the building of Europe. They feel they have earned it, by their performance as the economic powerhouse of the continent, as good neighbors to all nine countries on their borders, as allies with the United States and Britain in NATO and as supportive partners of Russia.
Never before had Germany enjoyed good relations with all those countries at once, Mr. Kohl kept telling voters in his campaign, and Mr. Schroder did not contest the achievement. Germany, both clearly agreed, could now pursue its legitimate national interest in Europe freed of the complexes that had inhibited it.
Indeed, Mr. Kohl's Government surprised its European partners at a summit meeting in Amsterdam last year by announcing that Germany was no longer willing to be taken for granted as the rich uncle of the European Union.
Even with only 15 members, the European Union is strained to its financial limits. But if Poland and Hungary were admitted now, the common agricultural policy by which industrial Germany agreed to support French farmers in exchange for access to the Common Market in 1957 would bankrupt Europe as it currently operates.
And Germany has made clear it will not go on paying unless the rules are rewritten more equitably. "The Germans are still good Europeans, but they don't give anything away any more," Mr. Vedrine said. "We defend French interests with great energy, as the British defend theirs, and the Germans are becoming more like us."
A spokesman for the conservative Government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said the country was confident of continued close relations with Mr. Schroder as Chancellor.
With only Italy among major European states now governed by conservative parties, there are also those who see the chance for a new coordinated European approach to the problems of unemployment and instability in global financial markets.
Asked if Mr. Schroder's victory could be seen as a victory for European social democracy, Jack Lang, a French Socialist who campaigned for him in Germany, agreed, adding, "There's a great chance to give new dynamism to a Europe that has been a bit in the doldrums recently."
The Social Democratic Chancellor of Austria, Victor Klima, described the German election results as a "historic success" for Social Democrats but also "a success for a Europe of employment, a success for a Europe with more social justice and a success for a Europe of social democracy." He, too, expressed "respect and thanks to a truly great European, Helmut Kohl."
 
 

CORRECTION-DATE: September 30, 1998, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about European leaders' reaction to the German election misidentified the major European country governed by conservative parties. It is Spain, not Italy.

HEADLINE: Satellites Guiding Industries on the Move

BYLINE: By JIM CARRIER 

 BODY:
Moving millions of tons of earth around the Black Thunder coal mine in Wright, Wyo., has come to resemble playing a video game, except that the score is kept by military satellites high overhead.
Inside the cab of each behemoth D11 Caterpillar, a computer screen displays a little bulldozer plowing through virtual dirt -- red for what needs moving and blue for what needs covering. As a global positioning system, or G.P.S., receiver on the roof tracks the dozer's movement across the screen, the operator's job, explains Jim Long, the mine's chief surveyor, is to "push the red to the blue," creating the color green for the desired grade. 
 "It is really slick," Mr. Long said. "They don't even have to look out the window -- except to keep from running over somebody."
Black Thunder, a division of Arch Coal Inc. of St. Louis, will produce 47 millions tons of coal this year from this one mine, about 5 percent of United States production. And at a time when coal prices are at an historic low of less than $5 a ton, the G.P.S. gear, linked to a computer-designed mine plan, helps the company achieve crucial new levels of efficiency -- whether building roads across the nine-square-mile site, uncovering coal seams or reconstructing the original prairie contour once the coal is extracted.
"When the company first put G.P.S. units on its bulldozers in July 1997, we had some increases of 30 percent in productivity," Mr. Long said. "That's a pretty amazing number. It's not that the guy is moving any more dirt. He's getting it to the right place the first time."
Arch Coal is just one of thousands of American companies putting G.P.S. to work, appropriating a system originally intended for military navigation and using it for such commercial purposes as mapping delivery routes, tracking products all the way from factory floor to retail shelf, and monitoring the whereabouts of mobile workers.
Available for limited civilian use since 1984 but fully operational only since 1995, G.P.S. technology has become so important to industry that many businesses now consider it a utility like the Internet -- an element of information technology helping fuel America's economic engine.
A Commerce Department study (infoserv2.ita.doc.gov/ot) released this month estimates that worldwide G.P.S. equipment sales will reach $4 billion this year, and will double by 2000 and double again, to $16 billion, by 2003.
In contrast to Japan and Europe, where car-navigation systems are the main use of G.P.S. technology, the commercial market in the United States is dominated by mapping and geographic information systems like that employed by the Black Thunder mine. Even though G.P.S. gear is installed in virtually all United States military vehicles, and the satellite system is run by the Air Force Space Command in Colorado Springs, military purchases for G.P.S. now represent just a fraction of industry sales.
"Military uses are swamped by civilian use," said Joe Canny, deputy assistant Secretary of Transportation and the principal staff person on the Government's Interagency G.P.S. Executive Board, which sets the nation's G.P.S. policy.
No one has estimated the impact of G.P.S. on the nation's gross domestic product, but the figure is presumably "enormous," said Scott Pace, an analyst at the Rand Science and Technology Policy Institute and a co-author of the Commerce Department study.
"If you add up the critical industries -- oil and gas, financial networks, transportation -- you find that G.P.S. is an embedded assumption in the functioning in every one of those things," Mr. Pace said.
Take, for example, time.
Carrying atomic clocks that are corrected daily to Naval Observatory standards, the 24 G.P.S. satellites that orbit the Earth some 11,000 nautical miles above the Equator are the largest source of accurate time in the world. Much of the nation's power grid, and all of its long-distance telephone networks, as well as paging and mobile phone systems, are kept synchronized via software that periodically downloads G.P.S. time, said Dennis McCarthy, director of the Directorate of Time at the Naval Observatory in Washington.
The Naval Observatory's time data is available over the Internet (www.usno.navy.mil) and from computers around the country that periodically correct their clocks when an orbiting satellite passes overhead.
And G.P.S. time has become a crucial component of securities trading and many other forms of financial transactions. The Nasdaq trading system, for example, relies on a master clock kept in synch by a satellite dish in Trumball, Conn., which allows every Nasdaq trade to receive an official time stamp.
The first commercial receiver in 1984 cost $150,000, weighed 100 pounds and was accurate to within 100 meters.
Today a hand-held G.P.S. receiver costs as little as $100, and the semiconductor chip sets are small enough that the technology is finding its way into cell phones. And error-correction techniques have advanced so that specialized G.P.S. devices can be accurate to the width of a golf ball.
Such advances have brought all sorts of new G.P.S. commercial and industrial uses. Backpack G.P.S. units have revolutionized surveying of construction sites, power lines and boundaries. Creating accurate control points for such jobs in 1986, for example, required two workers, one to hold a marked rod and the other to site direction and elevation through a transit, at a cost of $10,000 a point. Backpack units worn by a single worker have reduced the cost to $250 a point, according to the Commerce Department study.
But in many cases, the business trend in G.P.S. has been away from the navigational question "Where am I on earth?" and toward the more managerial interrogation "Where on earth are you?"
Federal Express, for instance, has installed G.P.S. units on its 1,600 long-haul trucks, to track their movements and arrival times. The trucks' locations are beamed to satellites every 10 minutes, and computers route that data to destinations so that workers there can be ready.
Before the G.P.S. units were installed two years ago, Federal Express made "educated guesswork," according to Charlie Hicks, who is in charge of ground freight. "Because of our service commitment," he said, "it is very important to know when things are going to get in."
A similar system, sold by the Highway Master Corporation of Dallas for $2,000 a truck, has been installed on 100,000 trucks around the nation, including the fleet of Wal-Mart Stores; it can keep track of average speeds and miles per gallon. The Highway Master system also incorporates cellular telephones to let fleet operators stay in even closer touch with their drivers.
G.P.S. is by no means a commercial cure-all. In Denver, where Yellow Cab, a subsidiary of Stamford Capital, installed a $100,000 G.P.S.-based dispatching system in 1996, at an average cost of $350 a cab, the company has not yet seen any improvement in dispatching efficiency, said Michael Brown, the company's director of information systems. So far, the system mainly just lets dispatchers know how many cabs are stacked up at Denver International Airport, Mr. Brown said. He added that it probably would not have much impact on costs and revenues until a related "closest cab" dispatcher- software program is installed a few months from now.
The Denver system has had at least one tangible benefit, however. When a customer tried to steal a cab while the driver was in a store, the dispatcher radioed the police with the cab's location and the cab was stopped within two blocks.
In the Gulf of Mexico, many of the petroleum industry's floating oil rigs are kept in place over their wells with the aid of G.P.S. signals. John E. Chance & Associates Inc., a division of Fegro of the Netherlands, moves rigs into place using G.P.S. signals, and sets up on-board computers that keep watch over a rig's precise position and automatically fire underwater thrusters to move it back into position if it drifts away.
The labor required to position a rig has been cut in half, said Jim O'Neal, general manager of Chance's marine group.
Rising civilian and commercial demand for G.P.S. has prompted the Government's interagency board to approve tripling the number of civilian radio signals coming from the military satellites. The decision was announced earlier this year, but carrying it out has been at least temporarily delayed by technical questions, costs and competition for space on the radio-frequency spectrum. Mr. Canny said the additional signals were expected to be available on new satellites by 2004.
One of the largest users of the new signals will be airlines, employing the Federal Aviation Administration's new Wide Area Augmentation System. The system is supposed to allow pilots and air traffic controllers to determine an aircraft's location to an accuracy of within 25 feet -- enabling planes to save fuel and time by flying directly between airports rather than along strictly controlled corridors as they must do now to avoid risk of collisions. Using existing G.P.S. signals and ground-reference points, the first phase will be introduced next year.
Even Hollywood has embraced G.P.S.
In Sylvester Stallone's movie "Daylight," with its climatic escape from a flooded Holland Tunnel into the Hudson River, the main characters were shown bursting through the river's surface from the dark depths below.
But according to Ron Goodman, president of Spacecam, a special-effects film company in Los Angeles, the river was shot during the winter without the actors present. A helicopter camera panned down from the New York skyline as two G.P.S. units, one near the camera and one on the helicopter's tail, recorded the exact spatial orientation.
The camera angle and orientation were later duplicated over Lake Casitas near Los Angeles to film two stunt doubles emerging from the water. Only later did the actors bubble up in a nice warm studio tank -- leaving the rest to the special-effects magicians.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Hellzapoppin' With Dante And Friends

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
The burly performer, isolated by a hot spotlight, sits hunched over a watermelon. He lodges it between his legs and devours it ravenously. "I was Count Ugolino," he says, casting his eyes over his meal. "This was Archbishop Ruggieri."
The revelation is as funny as it is macabre, and is all the artifice the actor Jack Willis requires to conjure one particularly vivid precinct of hell. The Count is a cannibal, and as he relates his terrible autobiography between noisy helpings, one perceives both an act of abundant depravity and of imagination. He makes mouthwatering innards of the flesh of the melon, a skull of the outer shell. Alas, poor, tasty Ruggieri! 
 Mr. Willis, last seen in New York as the empathetic husband in David Mamet's "Old Neighborhood," does wonders with his share of the agonized vignettes of "Dante's Inferno," a highly condensed and remarkably theatrical staged version of the 14th-century epic that takes Dante, played here by Bill Camp and guided by the poet Virgil (Reg E. Cathey), on a fantastic voyage into Hades. Mr. Willis and Leslie Beatty complete the cast, portraying an assortment of damned souls in this economical, two-hour production. And these two -- how shall we put it? -- have all the fun.
Like more tormented versions of the sad sacks Dorothy collects on the yellow brick road, they confide their tales of woe to the visitor from another world. Mr. Willis and Ms. Beatty cringe and shudder, shrink and quake, affixing faces worthy of compassion to the teeming multitudes of the Underworld. As the acting opportunities pile up, the surprise of this "Inferno" becomes clear: even if it is not quite a fully realized verse play, it is much more than a staged reading.
There are certainly structural problems created in the compressing of the work, presented at Playhouse 91 by the 92d Street Y's Unterberg Poetry Center. And some of the more fanciful ideas need further refinement: a vaudeville sketch about lawyers in hell, for instance, would be a crowd-pleasing innovation if it were less clumsily executed.
But what makes this absorbing theater is the handiwork of a director, Robert Scanlan, who knows he must strike more than a few dark chords, and the poet Robert Pinsky, who steeps his translation in sensation and language that is both incisive and stageworthy.
Add to these elements a composer, Bruce Saylor, whose score, written for the violinist Gil Morgenstern, is an aural catalogue of dolors from the depths, and the ingredients are complete for an engrossing adaptation of a poem few would have imagined could work quite so well on a stage.
Mr. Scanlan and his designers, John Michael Deegan and Sarah G. Conly, transfer Dante's hell to the late 20th century. Dressed in business clothes, the actors traverse a mirrored multilevel set that vaguely resembles one of those nondescript office buildings along the interstate (which are some esthetes' idea of hell, anyway). As the story unfolds, so does the scenery, which is divided into compartments reached by ladders and stairs that denote the descending circles of hell.
To make a piece of theater, the work's creators knew they had to provide a sense that the characters were talking to one another, and not simply delivering beautiful oratory. The director shows the audience the differing effects of recital and performance by beginning the second act with Mr. Camp and Mr. Cathey taking turns at a microphone and reading from one of the poem's cantos. The scene is nicely instructive: there's a lot more music in the recitation -- both actors have resonant voices, full of color -- but less emotion. The minute Mr. Camp and Mr. Cathey stop talking in character, the very idea of a story in which they are participants seems to drop out of their voices.
This attenuated "Inferno" is constructed as a brief travelogue, a journey to selected points of interest in hell. Mr. Camp's Dante, hair askew, shirt collar open, begins the play in despair. In the words of the translation by Mr. Pinsky, the nation's poet laureate, Dante is "in dark woods, the right road lost." He embarks on a guided tour of Beelzebub's kingdom in the company of Virgil, played by Mr. Cathey as something of a Netherworld smoothie, a sophisticate showing a neophyte the existential lay of the land.
On the path to enlightenment, to a deeper understanding of mercy and justice, Dante is escorted by Virgil into lots of dark corners, for encounters with tortured beings whose plights could have been rendered by other artists and writers. Mr. Camp comes across a twisted Ms. Beatty, eternally encased in a thorn bush and wearing a countenance out of a painting by Munch. He later listens to the story of the lovers Francesca and Paolo, who wander as vaguely and dolefully as characters imagined by Pirandello. Christopher Walker contributes a sound score full of foreboding, suggested by the textual imagery: the lovers, for example, who enter "as doves whom desire has summoned," are preceded by the sound of birds in flight.
The scenes of Dante and the amazing variety of denizens of hell are some of the most evocative moments, and the production by no means exhausts one's curiosity about them. Dante's father, played by Mr. Willis, is drawn as an old man wrapped in towels at the Luciferian equivalent of a Turkish bath; a torsoless inhabitant is represented by a honeydew that meets an unfortunate end in Dante's arms. (Attention shoppers: Hell has a well-stocked produce department.)
"Dante's Inferno" reflects the poem's episodic nature. It's how skillfully Mr. Scanlan and his collaborators operate within the episodes that makes this an intriguing evening. Mr. Willis is especially rewarding in his myriad character roles, and on both the technical and interpretive level, all four actors speak with a grasp of the work's power and lyricism. This is a piece that gets better the lower it goes.
 
DANTE'S INFERNO
 
By Dante Alighieri; translated by Robert Pinsky; adapted and directed by Robert Scanlan; music by Bruce Saylor and Christopher Walker; design by John Michael Deegan and Sarah G. Conly; production stage manager, Abbie H. Katz; Italian voice recording, Claudio Saponi. Presented by the 92d Street Y Unterberg Poetry Center and the National Literary Audience Development Project, Jonathan Levi, producer. At Playhouse 91, 316 East 91st Street, Yorkville.
 
WITH: Leslie Beatty, Bill Camp, Reg E. Cathey and Jack Willis.

HEADLINE: Older People Enjoy Sex, Survey Says

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Many older Americans maintain an interest in sex, with nearly half of those over age 60 engaging in sexual activity at least once a month, according to a survey released today.
The survey, commissioned and released by the National Council on the Aging, found that 39 percent of respondents said they were satisfied with the amount of sex they were having, while another 39 percent said they wished they had sex more frequently. 
 "Our study debunks the prevailing myths about sexuality in older years," Dr. James Firman, president of the aging advocacy organization, said at a news conference. "We hope that it leads seniors to more open discussion of their sexuality and to more rewarding lives."
Dr. Neal E. Cutler, director of survey results for the council, said there have been few similar, broad-based surveys of elder sexuality and that the results should serve as a baseline from which to measure future changes in attitude and behavior related to sex among older Americans.
"Older people are sexually active," Dr. Cutler said, "Most older people are interested in sex, they find sex satisfying and they consider sex to be an important part of their lives."
Dr. Cutler said one of the biggest surprises of the survey was the emotional satisfaction from sex reported by active seniors. About 74 percent of sexually active men and 70 percent of active women said they were as satisfied, or even more satisfied, with their sex lives as they were in their 40's.
"This satisfaction could reflect a feeling of freedom about sex that comes with no more fear of pregnancy, having no pressures of children at home or just having more time to be alone with a partner and enjoying one another," Dr. Cutler said.
Active seniors were evenly divided on whether their sex was physically better now, with 43 percent saying it is just as good as or better than in their youth and 43 percent saying sex is less satisfying.
 The survey of 1,292 Americans age 60 or older was conducted this summer by Roper Starch Worldwide Inc. The mail survey of 534 men and 758 women was weighted to match the sex, age, race, income and marital status of the American population over age 60. The survey organization put the margin of error at plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.
The study was financed in part by an unrestricted grant from Pfizer Inc., which makes the popular anti-impotence drug Viagra. However, council officials said Pfizer had no role in the design, conduct or interpretation of the survey and was not informed of the results before the report was released today.
Dr. Firman said the survey did not delve into sex-enhancement drugs and treatments that are available now, or expected soon. But he said these treatments and increased discussion of sexuality among the elderly may result in even more sexual activity and reported satisfaction in the future.
Dr. Marian E. Dunn, director of the Center for Human Sexuality at the State University of New York at Brooklyn, said many older people are misinformed about sex and what to expect as they age. She noted that one-third of those surveyed felt it was natural to lose interest in sex as people got older, and that some felt it became physically impossible.
"This just isn't true for most people," she said, "While our bodies change and we respond more slowly or differently, sex is still possible and enjoyable as we get older."

HEADLINE: Struggling to Bolster Minorities in Medicine

BYLINE: By HOLCOMB B. NOBLE 

 BODY:
MEDICAL authorities, educators and civil-rights lawyers, concerned about a sudden drop in minority enrollment in the nation's medical schools, are striking back at moves to fight affirmative action that they believe threaten the future health of minority communities.
A coalition of 51 medical associations is mobilizing forces and raising money to help defeat a Nov. 3 voter initiative in the state of Washington that would ban any form of affirmative action. And minority groups as well as higher education leaders are conducting research and planning court strategies to challenge the movement against affirmative action. The coalition opposing the ballot measure, representing some two million medical professionals, includes the American Medical Association and the American Nurses Association. 
 The Washington vote, called Initiative 200, is one of several drives that have been undertaken against affirmative action in recent years. Since 1996, a Federal appeals court has ordered a rollback in affirmative-action programs in Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi. Lawsuits are also in progress to ban affirmative action in Michigan and Maryland. And California's Board of Regents has effectively banned affirmative action at state universities.
First-year minority entrants at medical schools declined by a total of 12 percent from 1994 to 1997. Applications continued to rise in 1994, 1995 and 1996, but then dropped in 1997 by 11 percent, studies by the American Association of Medical Colleges show. By the end of 1997, there were 1,770 new entrants from minorities representing African-Americans, Mexican-Americans, mainland Puerto Ricans, American Indians and Native Alaskans. These minorities accounted for 11 percent of the 16,165 matriculating medical students. In both 1996 and 1997, black medical schools had slight increases in enrollment.
Those minority groups represent about 21 percent of the nation's total population. Asian-Americans and some Hispanic-Americans were not underrepresented in medical schools and were not included in the study. The association had originally hoped to have 3,000 entering students by the year 2000.
Dr. Herbert N. Nickens, the association's vice president for community and minority affairs, said that in the past two years "the anti-affirmative-action drive has really started hitting us, and our progress is slipping."
Dr. David N. Sundwall, chairman of the Council on Graduate Medical Education, an advisory group for Congress and the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said in an interview: "The nation's health depends on access to doctors who reflect the nation's increasingly diverse population. Minority doctors are much more likely to set up practices in minority neighborhoods, and they are needed badly there."
For a variety of economic and societal reasons, many illnesses are more common and more deadly among minorities than in the general population. For example, black children have hospitalization rates for asthma about three times those of whites. A significant reason is that there are fewer doctors and health-care centers in inner-cities, where most of the sufferers live.
Moreover, annual death rates for blacks in general are about 50 percent higher than for whites, lowering life expectancy by about five years for women and eight years for men.
Dr. Sundwall said that despite gains in the 1970's and 1980's, minority representation appeared to be decreasing at all levels -- from medical school faculty members, to faculty members in key positions, to initial student applications to acceptances. Accordingly, in testifying in Washington last week before the Joint Commission on the Future of Medicare, which provides $7 billion to programs for teaching hospitals and graduate medical education, Dr. Sundwall urged the commissioners not to cut back on funds used to encourage minority medical school representation.
Jordan J. Cohen, president of the Association of American Medical Colleges, said: "Until we get to the point where we have an applicant pool that contains all sectors of our society with equivalent academic credentials, we will not get out from under the need to make special efforts to identify quality applicants across all those sectors." He added that the ultimate challenge is to repair educational disadvantages that exist so that the broad, diverse applicant pools will form.
The conflict over medical-school admissions policies and minority representation stems from a 1978 case involving Alan Bakke, a white premed student who applied to the medical school at the University of California at Davis. Though he had a slightly higher grade-point average and better scores on the Medical-College Admission Test (MCAT) than several black applicants, he was turned down on the basis of his race to enable the school to achieve a minimum racial quota of minority students.
The United States Supreme Court ruled for Mr. Bakke, saying a decision made solely on the basis of his race amounted to reverse discrimination. But in the second part of that ruling, the Court allowed race to be considered as one of many factors in admissions decisions.
But the 1996 and subsequent rulings by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, for Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi, effectively reversed the second part of the Bakke decision. Civil rights groups, including the Legal Defense Fund, challenged the appeals court's right to do so.
Wading into the fray, Derek Bok, former president of Harvard University, and William G. Bowen, former president of Princeton University, have completed a study of the grades, test scores, choice of major, graduation rates, careers and attitudes of 45,000 students at 28 selective universities over 20 years. They concluded that affirmative-action policies in general at the nation's elite colleges have created the backbone of the American black middle class and have taught white classmates the value of integration.
"The most drastic effects in eliminating affirmative action would be on medical and law schools," Dr. Bok said, "because the more selective the institution, the greater the impact, and nothing is more selective that medical schools and law schools."
The dean at the Harvard Medical School, Dr. Joseph B. Martin, who was chancellor at the University of California at San Francisco during the bitter controversy over the Board of Regents action two years ago, said: "I feel extremely strongly about the importance of diversity among medical school graduates. I am very troubled about the decline in applications and matriculations."
The Harvard Medical School has had an average 20 percent minority enrollment in the last five years and is now in its 30th year of pursuing affirmative-action policies. Dean Martin said it receives some 4,000 applications a year and makes a first cut to 800 applicants based on college grade-point averages and MCAT scores. The admissions officers then make decisions relying on a variety of considerations, including academic performance judged in ways other than from test scores, nonacademic accomplishments, backgrounds and leadership ability. "We have no intention of abandoning affirmative action," he said.
Theodore M. Shaw, a counsel for the Legal Defense Fund, called the attack on all forms of affirmative action "an attack by wolves in wolves' clothing."
Ryan N. Dockery, a premed student at Xavier University of Louisiana, a historically black college, said he personally was not being discouraged in his goal of becoming a doctor because of the anti-affirmative action efforts. "I know it's just one more hurdle," he said. "And you do have to look at the problem from all perspectives. It may seem unfair to white students if they have good grades but they are kept out because minority representation is considered. On the other hand, a whole range of disadvantages have worked against minorities and something has to be done for them to level the playing field."

HEADLINE: The Real Policy Makers

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich, a professor of economic and social policy at Brandeis University, was Secretary of Labor in the first Clinton Administration.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
American democracy is upside down. While Congress, the President, talk radio and yell television are obsessed with sex and scandal, the big decisions affecting our lives are hidden from view and made by people largely unaccountable to democratic processes.
Today the Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee will decide what to do next about short-term interest rates. If the Fed decides to reduce interest rates today, jobs will stay plentiful for a while longer, wages will continue to inch upward and homes and cars will become somewhat more affordable. 
 Some economists -- citing the current 4 percent annual growth in wages -- worry that lower interest rates would cause the economy to overheat and inflation to accelerate. That seems unlikely at a time when one-half the world's economies are stagnant or shrinking. And even if it proved true, a little inflation may be worth the extra jobs and higher wages that would come with it.
How do we decide whether the risk is worth it? We don't. It's all up to Alan Greenspan and his colleagues, and they will decide today in secret. (Summaries of their proceedings are eventually made public.)
In the old days, when America had a fiscal policy to speak of (that is, when Presidents and Congress were willing to spur the economy through public spending and tax cuts) and money didn't rush nearly as fast or as easily across national borders, decisions like this were important but not all-important. Elected officials could still fashion domestic policies affecting jobs, wages, the poverty rate and the availability of homes and cars. Now all of these depend on prevailing interest rates, which in turn depend largely on the Fed.
America used to have a real foreign policy as well, and an apparatus for setting it: a State Department run by people knowledgeable about the politics and societies of places around the globe, as well as a national security adviser and Congressional foreign affairs committees. But now our foreign policy depends largely on global flows of money, and our apparatus for influencing them is almost totally removed from democratic oversight.
Asian economies continue an implosion that began more than a year ago, when money began rushing out in search of safer havens. What had until recently been called the "big emerging markets" of the world are now big submerging markets. Capital flight is, by its very nature, a self-fulfilling prophecy: the last ones out are left holding a near-worthless bag. Much of the money has come to the United States, which is one reason the value of the dollar has soared and the stock market reached astronomical heights this summer. Of course, that was before the high dollar clobbered exports and squeezed corporate profits, causing Wall Street's bubble to burst.
Lower interest rates might help in this capacity; they would make the United States relatively less attractive to global capital, thus relieving some of the pressure on countries on the losing end. Lower rates would also reduce the value of the dollar, easing the plight of American exporters. Cutting rates would also send a signal to central banks abroad that they could lower their own interest rates.
Of course, much of this depends on the other new force in American foreign policy: the International Monetary Fund. For years, in part because of the influence of the Treasury Department, it sought to open other countries' borders to global capital. More recently, and again at the Treasury's urging, it has been trying to stanch capital flight. It has lent developing countries billions of dollars on the condition that they increase domestic interest rates, reduce public spending and deregulate state-run enterprises.
The avowed purpose is to convince global lenders and investors that they should not abandon ship. But the enforced austerity has had perilous social consequences -- driving up prices of food and fuel, increasing unemployment, smothering local businesses and shredding social safety nets.
It's a delicate balance. Without the I.M.F.-imposed austerity even more capital might flee. But those on whom the burden of austerity has fallen most heavily hardly benefited from the huge influx of speculative money to begin with.
The Fed, the I.M.F. and the Treasury are staffed by skilled economists, but can we be sure that the choices they make are the right ones in the eyes of most of the people whose lives are being altered by them? These experts, by and large, have no particular knowledge of politics or sociology and no special insights into what arrangements may be deemed just or unjust in places around the world. Nor are they accountable in ways that might provide them guidance.
Russia's defaulting on its short-term foreign debt last month spooked global creditors who worry about possible defaults elsewhere, especially Brazil. Japan is seemingly paralyzed. The United States remains in fairly good economic shape, but there are worrisome signs: exports continue to drop, consumer confidence has started to dip, and housing starts and commercial property prices are receding.
Officials at the Fed, the I.M.F. and the Treasury are scrambling to contain the problem. President Clinton has asked Congress for $18 billion to shore up the I.M.F., but any such prospect has dimmed in the last few months. He also has asked Mr. Greenspan and Robert Rubin, the Treasury Secretary, to convene a meeting of major central bankers and financial officials to figure out the next steps. But few Americans heard him do it -- we've been too busy parsing his definition of "sexual relations."
The global crisis is too important to be left entirely to central bankers and financial ministers. One reason governments exist is to insure that economies function for the benefit of people, and not the other way around.
In the short term, the Fed should lower interest rates -- by a full percentage point before year's end. There should be a coordinated large-scale reduction in global interest rates. Rather than demanding austerity, the West should allow troubled currencies to fall to some degree. We should slow the flow of hot money now racing across borders, possibly by having countries tax short-term capital flows. The important thing is that any such decisions involve subtle weighings of human needs and social justice.
The global economy is less sexy than what's on most Americans' minds these days. Yet there comes a point when a democracy must attend to what's important rather than to what's titillating.

HEADLINE: U.S. Hedge Fund Bailout Raises Asian Eyebrows

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Sept. 28

 BODY:
In Asia, which has been scolded and sermonized by the United States over its economic policies, there is a sense of grim satisfaction at the near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management L.P., and at its $3.65 billion rescue by a team of banks and brokerage firms.
Business leaders here noted that after prodding Asian governments from Japan to Indonesia to increase the openness of their financial institutions, the United States was bushwhacked by the calamitous losses at one of its own big hedge funds. And after urging Asia not to bail out its sinking banks, the United States did something suspiciously close to that with Long-Term Capital. 
 Although the money was put up by banks rather than taxpayers, the bailout was engineered by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
"It showed us that the Americans could easily ignore their own principles," said Tadashi Nakamae, a prominent economist and the president of Nakamae International Economic Research in Tokyo.
American policy makers and economists have regularly declared that Asian countries would rebound more quickly from the economic crisis if they allowed at least some of their troubled banks to fail. By pumping money into the financial sector, the American experts warn, the Asian countries are simply delaying the cleansing change that their economies must undergo.
Now, with Long-Term Capital, American regulators faced the same question of whether to allow a major financial player go belly up. Some experts here are unsympathetic to the argument that a bankrupt Long-Term Capital would have unhinged financial markets around the world.
"Of course, if L.T.C.M. fails, there would be a lot of negative chain reactions," Mr. Nakamae said. "But to me, that has nothing to do with systemic risk. It is simply a failure of the speculative chain."
Some people likened last week's rescue to a "convoy" -- a pejorative term that describes the Japanese practice of asking strong banks to bail out weaker ones, with the result that neither bank ends up healthy.
Nevertheless, few people here are gloating over a high-flying investment fund that crashed to earth -- even one based in Greenwich, Conn. It hits too close to home in Asia, which has seen many of its top investors wiped out in the financial crisis. As it happens, few Asian banks had invested heavily in Long-Term Capital. Among those that put up the minimum $10 million to join: Bank of China.
David Li, the chairman of Bank of East Asia in Hong Kong, said several wealthy individuals in Hong Kong had invested in Long-Term Capital, and had called him to ask nervously about the prospects of getting their investment back.
Even if the fund's near-collapse might not have crushed global markets, people here said it could have unnerved fragile investors.
"If this fund were allowed to fail, it would have affected the confidence of investors," said Paul R. Lowndes, the secretary of the Hong Kong Association of Banks. "If you get something too large, with too many dependencies, you may need to overcome your tendency not to intervene."
Mr. Lowndes said the hedge fund's near-death experience would have a beneficial effect if it woke up American policy makers to the risks of these largely unregulated investment pools, which typically use arcane calculations to place huge bets on the movements of interest rates and foreign currencies.
Hedge funds have become a local obsession in Hong Kong, where the government has blamed them for manipulating its currency and stock markets. Last month, the government intervened massively in the stock market in a campaign to punish what it described as a cabal of overseas hedge funds.
Sir Donald Tsang, Hong Kong's financial secretary, has set off on a three-week tour of Europe and the United States to urge policy makers to adopt stricter regulations and oversight of hedge funds. In remarks to reporters over the weekend, Sir Donald said Long-Term Capital would help his case.
"Sentiment has changed around the world on what we should do about monitoring the flow of major hedge funds," he said. "One thing is quite clear: Whether you are a skeptic or a supporter, we have a common problem and we need resolution because it is going to affect each one of us."
In addition to buying shares, Sir Donald curtailed short-selling -- or the selling of borrowed shares -- and trading of futures contracts. He has declined to identify which foreign hedge funds were active in the Hong Kong market.
Malaysia has also cited overseas hedge funds as one of the reasons it recently imposed sweeping capital controls on its markets. Government officials said the sudden huge flows of money into and out of Malaysia were making a mockery of its efforts to stabilize its currency and revive the economy.
"The financial world is dominated by those with big bucks, and those guys can invest a small sum to make sure we don't succeed," said Noordin Sopiee, the chairman of the Institute of Strategic and International Studies, a research group in Kuala Lumpur that advised the Government on its controls.
For all the ill will toward hedge funds, people here acknowledge that foreign investment funds are not the root cause of their economic distress. Most agree that Asian countries must overhaul their ailing commercial banks if they want to restore the confidence of investors. And few expect Asia's governments to use the rescue of Long-Term Capital as a justification for further bailouts.
Indeed, today, Japan's ruling and opposition parties reached an accord on banking reform that may set the stage for landmark legislation. Among the provisions: the ruling Liberal Democratic Party will not pour more Government money into Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, one of the country's largest and most troubled banks, to keep it afloat.
"Stemming the problems of one hedge fund is easy to do," said the head of research at a major foreign bank in Tokyo.
"But Mrs. Watanabe doesn't have her deposits in a hedge fund," he said, referring to a name for the ubiquitous Japanese housewife. "Mrs. Watanabe has her deposits in a bank."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
TradingIs on Hold Pending Rate News

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday, as traders and investors awaited an announcement, expected this afternoon, that the Federal Reserve policy makers have decided to lower short-term interest rates.
The gains recorded during the session were confined to blue-chip and large-capitalization stocks. Broader market measures were weaker. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 80.07, or 1 percent, to 8,108.84, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed at 1,048.69, up 3.94.
But the Nasdaq composite index fell 4.37, to 1,739.22. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies fell 1.01, to 368.01.
"The market is running into a level of resistance at between 8,100 and 8,300 on the Dow," said one trader, who asked not to be identified. "Even if the Fed cuts rates, there are still worries about Brazil, still worries about more fallout from Long-Term Capital" Management, the troubled hedge fund that is receiving a $3.65 billion bailout.
Anticipation of an interest rate cut has been building for weeks. But confidence that the Fed will move quickly to protect the economy from the effects of financial turmoil overseas reached a higher level late last week, following Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the central bank.
"The language Mr. Greenspan used was very forthright," Jeffrey Applegate, the chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers, said. "Right now people are marking time, debating if the Fed will cut rates by one-quarter of a percentage point, or by one-half a point."
The Federal funds rate, which is used by commercial banks as a benchmark to determine the interest charges paid by millions of consumers and businesses on short-term debt, has been 5.5 percent since March 1997.
Mr. Applegate and others said that a quarter-point cut in the Federal funds rate was already built into stock market prices. They agreed that failure by the Fed to cut rates by at least that much would get a harsh market reception.
"If the Fed doesn't move, it would be a material negative," said Michael Molnar, a managing director in retail sales and trading at Salomon Smith Barney.
But Mr. Molnar and others said a more dramatic move, such as a half-point cut, might be overly aggressive, and send the wrong signal.
Expectation of interest rate relief is not confined to the United States. Latin markets, which would benefit from a cut in American interest rates, posted gains yesterday. And price gains were widespread on European and Asian equity markets.
Concerns about the stability of the financial system were heightened last week after a group of the world's most powerful commercial and investment banks agreed to prevent Long-Term Capital Management L.P. from failing by pumping $3.65 billion into the hedge fund.
Rumors persisted yesterday that another hedge fund was on the brink of bankruptcy, and that talk hurt a number of brokerage stocks. Lehman Brothers fell 3 1/8, to 30 1/8, and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter dropped by 3 3/8, to 49 1/4.
Big consumer stocks, which have been pummeled over concerns about the effect slumping Asian economies will have on earnings, did better. Procter & Gamble rose 3 1/8, to 73 5/8. Gillette, which announced after the market closed that it would lay off 11 percent of its work force, rose 1 11/16, to 40. Colgate-Palmolive jumped 3 3/16, to 72 5/8. Coca-Cola, which told analysts last week that earnings were slowing, rose 1 1/16, to 57 1/4.

Treasury Prices Fall
By Bloomberg News
Treasury prices fell in sluggish trading yesterday, as investors awaited today's meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers.
If the Fed lowers short-term rates by at least a quarter-point, as widely expected, "it unwinds the flight to safety," said Eric Peterson, who helps manage $545 million at Talon Asset Management Inc. Treasury prices have risen sharply as investors seek a haven from tumbling stocks and uncertain global markets.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 11/32, to 105 17/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.14 percent, from 5.12 percent on Friday.
Trading tapered off as prices slipped. By 3 P.M., about $49.4 billion of Treasuries traded -- 18 percent below the average Monday of the last month, according to Govpx, a bond-pricing service.
The Treasury sold $16 billion of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills at its regular weekly auction. Following are the results of the auction:

HEADLINE: Worldwide Rebound Seen in Chip Sales

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 28

 BODY:
Worldwide sales of computer chips are expected to rise 12 percent in 1999, rebounding from a decline of 6 percent this year, according to a market research group.
The Dataquest research unit of the Gartner Group said today that weak demand in Asia and volatility in the market for memory chips would hamper results in the first half of 1999 but sales would probably pick up in the second half. Total revenue from computer chips is expected to increase to $155 billion in 1999. 
 Revenue from chips used in computers, consumer electronics and other devices has fallen as prices plummeted, demand waned and too much manufacturing capacity came on line. That, on top of the economic turmoil in Asia, which had been a key market, has resulted in weaker earnings for most chip makers.
"Despite the positive growth we anticipate for 1999, the industry still faces a stiff challenge," George Shiffler, an analyst at Dataquest, wrote in the report."

HEADLINE: Building a Bridge, a Theater Troupe From the U.S. Is Embraced by Havana

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Sept. 28

 BODY:
The veteran actors from Repertorio Espanol had performed the play "Broken Eggs" dozens of times before, in New York City, but on Sunday they took the stage here with the nervousness of beginners. One feared that she would become so emotional she would lose her concentration. Another said he was terrified that he would open his mouth and nothing would come out.
But when the lights finally came on, the actors managed to keep their composure as an audience of 300 people applauded each time a familiar face came on stage, shrieked with laughter at lines like "Do you remember when we used to think Fidel was sexy?" and sprung to their feet for a final standing ovation. 
 In a show that had the quality of a special, almost stolen moment, Cuba welcomed the first Cuban-Americans invited here since the two countries severed relations in 1961, some returning to the same stage where they worked before their exile.
Of the company's nine actors, seven are Cuban-Americans. Among them is a singer-actress returning to the island for the first time in 38 years, a gay actor who was among those labeled "undesirable" and sent to farm camps in the 1960's, a television actress who fled on the 1980 boatlift from Mariel and two young American-born actors discovering the homeland of their parents.
And in the audience were relatives and strangers, friends and old colleagues who knew some of the actors from work in Cuban theater and radio half a century ago. Some said they recognized as their own the idiosyncrasies in "Broken Eggs," a nostalgia-filled comedy about a three-generation Cuban family living in California.
"Cuba is their land and is always present in their lives," said Georgina Almanza, 65, an actress who walked out of the theater sniffling.
"Broken Eggs" ("Revoltillo" in Spanish) opened here in a cultural exchange that underscores how a rapprochement that has been elusive in the political arena is being accomplished through the arts.
The exchanges are allowed under the American economic embargo as "people to people" contacts, which American officials favor as a way of exposing Cubans to a democratic society, and the Cubans to foster goodwill in hostile territory. They have become increasingly common, although more Cubans have crossed over to the United States than American counterparts to Cuba. In the first seven months of this year 183 Cuban artists visited the United States but only 9 Americans visited Cuba, mostly to explore future exchanges.
While American theater groups have come here in the past, and a major New York City producer is expected soon for talks about bringing a hit Broadway musical to Havana next year, most recent contact has been through Repertorio Espanol, a 30-year-old nonprofit company in Manhattan. The company is led by Gilberto Zaldivar, its co-founder and producer, who returned to Cuba in 1995 after a 34-year absence and epitomizes the more conciliatory stance many exiles adopt toward Cuba after renewing old ties.
Although Mr. Zaldivar was drawn here by the illness of two uncles, that visit led to contacts in the theater community and the first cultural exchange -- Cubans working with Repertorio Espanol in New York in 1996. Others Cuban performances in New York followed before the group won permission from both Governments to bring here, by invitation from the Union of Writers and Artists, what Mr. Zaldivar and his associate producer, Robert Weber, consider the best play by the Cuban-born playwright Eduardo Machado.
Mr. Machado, who left Cuba when he was 8, has scheduled his own return on Tuesday, when the company is scheduled to play in Matanzas as part of a 10-day, three-city tour.
"It's only natural that this takes place," Mr. Zaldivar said. "It's logical, normal and human that these two Cuban communities communicate. We can significantly help create the climate for future relations."
The pioneering exchange came at a cost, however: one of Repertorio's Cuban-American board members resigned in protest, and there have even been death threats from those who favor isolating the island to cause its Government's downfall.
Much of the anger focused on Ana Margarita Martinez-Casado, a well-known actress from the 1970's American television sitcom "Que Pasa, U.S.A.?" who lost an advertising contract with a Miami hospital over the Cuba visit.
Ms. Martinez-Casado, who started her career here as a soprano on television, left in 1960 with her 2-year-old daughter, never returning from a job in Puerto Rico after the man who was then her husband warned her from Cuba that the political situation was getting worse. She lived in Mexico, Miami and now New York City, and saw her mother only when she visited Mexico once. Her father died in 1989, followed by her mother two years later, without ever seeing her again. "For many years we thought, things will change soon, and the years kept passing by," she said, citing political, economic and work-related reasons for not coming to Cuba before now. "There comes a point where one asks, 'Why not go?' "
Last week, at Havana's airport, she held the two brothers she had not seen in 38 years in a tight embrace.
"You look just like Papi did when I left," she told one brother, Luis, 64, a Cuban diplomat, through tears. "And you, who used to look like him, now look more like my mother," she told Manuel, 63, a beer company salesman whose own daughter and two sons have also left Cuba and live in Miami.
Manuel Martinez-Casado, calling her Chuchi, an endearing nickname she had not heard in a long time, told her, "I want to hear you sing."
As Ms. Martinez-Casado was driven through old haunts she barely recognized -- past revolutionary slogans on billboards and posters of Pope John Paul II on Old Havana's front doors, through the time warp of Chevrolets and Fords from the 1940's and 50's and with a cemetery stop to bid a belated goodbye to her parents -- troupe members like Ricardo Barber, 61, got reacquainted with once inseparable colleagues.
At a welcoming reception by the artists' union, Mr. Barber chatted with Ana Molinet, 56, an actress who once waged a three-month campaign, including slipping a note to Fidel Castro during a public appearance, to get Mr. Barber released from an agricultural camp for homosexuals and other victims of political persecution.
Mr. Barber spent a year cutting cane from dawn to dusk before he was released and went back to the theater, but he chose to leave Cuba for good in 1977. His first visit back was in 1995, with Mr. Zaldivar. "I wasn't the same" after the forced labor, Mr. Barber said. "I no longer believed in the revolution and I began to see the bad in everything."
While the arts have flourished under Communist rule, benefiting from Government sponsorship and a national system of specialized schools, the Cuban-Americans have found an artistic class hobbled by the economic problems of the country, despite the privileged status of a few. Television programming has been cut back to conserve energy. Films are limited to two or three a year, often co-productions with other countries.
And many theaters have closed, while those that remain are often shabby and inadequately equipped.
Still, tourism and travel have created new opportunities for artists, and officials consider those who tour abroad to be ambassadors who "foment understanding, make us known and favor dialogue," said Ismael Gonzalez, a deputy minister of culture. Artists who travel internationally are also an important source of revenue (although exchanges with the United States are governed by embargo restrictions on both earnings and spending), but individuals' allegiances to the Government vary.
"Most of them keep quiet and make art," a Western official here noted. Carlos Padron, a playwright who presides over the 1,600-member Association of Stage Artists, said the exchanges mostly answer to a yearning for knowing how the other side lives. "Six of 10 Cubans have family in the United States," he said. "People want to see what really happens to people over there, how they insert themselves in North American society, to what extent they maintain their identity."
Repertorio members have been the toast of the town here, enjoying favorable press coverage, welcoming receptions and a quick sellout of shows (tickets have sold for the equivalent of 25 cents). But a company member's cousin was arrested and briefly detained for staying overnight in the relative's hotel and another Repertorio member on a beach outing had to talk a traffic officer out of arresting a friend suspected of being an unauthorized chauffeur. Cubans are not allowed in hotels as guests, and vigilance appears heightened since last year's hotel bombings.
Reluctant to delve into politics or criticize their hosts, some Repertorio members instead talked about their hope to create bridges for eventual democratic change in Cuba, and at times seemed in awe of their compatriots.
"Their spirit of struggle fascinates me," said Rene Sanchez, 71, who had an acting career here before leaving in 1966. "How they invent things, how they try to figure out a better living, how they don't allow themselves to collapse even in the worst of times."
The last could also be said for Repertorio members. Hurricane Georges and immigration problems delayed the arrival of some of the actors and caused the cancellation of the two first Havana shows this weekend. Then, for the first of two scheduled performances on Sunday, the actress Tatiana Vecino got sick and a Cuban actress, Adria Santana, stepped in to read the role.
By evening, the Teatro Hubert de Blanck filled up again for the second show. Ms. Vecino recovered and returned to her role. But at intermission it was announced that the rest of the performance would be canceled. An electric transformer on the street had shorted out and the theater was forced to shut off its power.
The theatergoers were told more performances would be added next weekend, and many had already seen enough to come back for more.
"It was thrilling," said Osmara Velazquez, 54, a cousin of Mr. Zaldivar's. "Incredibly, culture has ended the separation."
